DOC.HEAD: Sharon Herbaugh to Head Islamabad Bureau
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Herbaugh, New Delhi news editor for The Associated Press, has been named chief of bureau for the AP in Islamabad, Pakistan. Ms. Herbaugh, 35, replaces Bryan Wilder, who has resigned. She has been assigned to New Delhi since 1988, and was appointed news editor in 1989. A native of Lamar, Colo., and a graduate of Baylor University, she joined the AP news staff in 1978 in Denver. She subsequently worked in Dallas, Houston and on the World Services Desk in New York before being assigned to New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: Norway's Rising Unemployment Inspires One-Way Telephones
DOC.TEXT: The phone company has introduced one-way telephones for people who can't pay their bills, in an apparent show of compassion for the country's record number of unemployed. Unemployment passed 100,000 people last week for the first time in more than 50 years. Due partly to unemployment, the state phone company Televerket on Wednesday introduced a service that allows slow payers to keep their phones for incoming calls but not to dial out, said the national news agency NTB. ``In the past, poor payers were exposed to their friends and family by the phone company's recorded message `this number has been temporarily disconnected,'' said NTB. The state employment directorate said Wednesday that 105,221 Norwegians, or 4.8 percent of the work force, were registered as unemployed last week. About 50,000 are employed in temporary government work programs.

DOC.HEAD: State-Funded Company Announces ``Streamlined'' Season
DOC.TEXT: The Royal Shakespeare Company has announced 21 productions for 1990, blaming a cash shortage for its most modest year since the 1970s. ``I regret the reduction in the work, but it will give all our actors a chance to do their work well,'' artistic director Terry Hands told a news conference Wednesday. He introduced four-theater repertoire ``as streamlined as we can make it.'' Hands, 49, is resigning later this year to go freelance. He said his successor is expected to be named next month and be in place by April 1. Hands attributed the reduced output to a cumulative deficit of $4.1 million dollars, despite the $1.65 million annually that the company receives from its internationally successful musical, ``Les Miserables.'' The company staged 27 productions last year, 32 in 1988, and a record 47 in 1987. He said the decision had nothing to do with critics' complaints that the company has been overextending itself, typically staging more productions per year than are seen on Broadway all season. ``I believe (quantity) is in the RSC's very nature,'' Hands said. It ``works at its best when going flat out, fizzing on all cylinders.'' The company's season opens March 28 with the transfer from Stratford-upon-Avon of Barry Kyle's staging of Shakespeare's ``All's Well That Ends Well.'' The production was poorly received in its Stratford opening last fall. Since then, Hands said, ``It's being refurbished and retreaded ... People are still working the show to try and improve it.'' Then come more transfers from Stratford: ``As You Like It,'' starring Sophie Thompson as Rosalind; ``Coriolanus'' with Charles Dance in the title role; ``Singer,'' Peter Flannery's controversial new play, staring Anthony Sher; and John Webster's ``The Duchess of Malfi,'' with Harriet Walter. Two musicals are planned _ a revival of Lionel Bart's 1961 ``Blitz,'' directed by Barry Kyle; and ``Children of Eden,'' an original show with music and lyrics by American composer Stephen Schwartz (``The Baker's Wife,'' ``Godspell''). John Caird, who co-directed ``Les Miserables,'' will direct. The Stratford season, starting April 10, will include six Shakespeare plays, beginning with ``Much Ado About Nothing.'' It will also feature Christopher Marlowe's ``Edward II,'' and a new play, ``Two Shakespearean Actors,'' by American dramatist Richard Nelson. His ``Some Americans Abroad'' was a London hit for the company last summer and opens off-Broadway next month. Eagerly awaited is a new ``King Lear,'' starring John Wood as Lear and directed by Nicholas Hytner, the admired young director of the musical ``Miss Saigon.'' It opens July 11. Hytner and Wood collaborated together last year on an acclaimed staging of ``The Tempest.'' Except for John Wood, the new season is noticeably lacking in stars, fewer of whom can be enticed to work for relatively low pay over a long period. Instead, the company is promoting rising young actors like Ralph Fiennes, who will play Troilus in ``Troilus and Cressida'' and the bastard Edmund in ``King Lear,'' among others, and Simon Russell Beale, the King of Navarre in ``Love's Labours Lost'' and Thersites in ``Troilus and Cressida.'' With an 11 percent increase in government funding over last year, Hands said the level of state subsidy should be 40 percent to 45 percent. Taking into account inflation at 7.7 percent, Hands said the increase gives the company $295,000 in ``new and extra money, about the cost of one major production on a major stage.''

DOC.HEAD: President, Governor, Conservationists Focus on Florida Woes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
Eds: Brien cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: The battle to keep Florida's environment off the terminal list gets a boost this week, as President Bush plans a visit to the Everglades and leading conservationists meet to set their agenda. Heavily populated South Florida is under mandatory water restrictions because of its worst drought in three decades, and state environmentalists say time is running out for ambitious, expensive efforts to reverse damage caused by runaway growth. ``The Everglades is on the critical list. It is the most threatened ecosystem in the United States,'' said Brien Culhane, a Wilderness Society official and chairman of the Everglades Coalition. ``The 1990s will be the decade of decision. The decisions we make _ and our success in carrying them out _ will determine whether the Everglades will be saved.'' The Everglades Coalition, an umbrella group of 25 organizations that includes the National Audubon Society, Sierra Club and Wilderness Society, begins its fifth annual meeting Thursday. After sessions with Florida's top politicians, seminars, and field trips, the conservationists will announce their agenda for the year. Meanwhile, Bush plans a tour and briefing Friday at Everglades National Park. The main purpose of Bush's six-hour Florida visit is to keynote a fund-raising dinner in Miami for Republican Gov. Bob Martinez's November re-election effort, but Martinez likely will lobby Bush for federal money to help Florida environmental projects. The governor is expected here Thursday to endorse an unprecedented, $276 million backfilling plan to restore the Kissimmee River to its original, meandering boundaries. The Army Corps of Engineers, because of state calls for flood control, built a 52-mile, 30-feet-deep channel to straighten the winding 98-mile-long river. But after the channelization was completed in 1971, pollution of Lake Okeechobee, the major reservoir of South Florida's freshwater, increased and tens of thousands of pollution-filtering wetlands were lost along with substantial numbers of fish and wildlife. Estus Whitfield, the governor's chief environmental adviser, said the state will ask for 80 percent federal funding of the restoration. Bush last month authorized expansion of the Everglades National Park by 107,600 acres, but state officials want him to push immediately for funding. Florida will donate 35,000 acres to the federal park, and has agreed to pay 20 percent of the estimated $40 million cost to acquire the other lands. ``When you're talking about getting sizable amounts of federal funds for any activity, that's tough these days,'' said U.S. Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla. Graham and other Florida leaders say the state's projects are more than environmental idealism. Adding wetlands and reversing development not only would protect the 13 endangered species and dozens of threatened species, but also could prevent the booming ``Gold Coast'' from Palm Beach to Miami from becoming a concrete desert. About half of South Florida's 4,000 square miles of wetlands were taken over by urban areas and agriculture after massive dredging and draining began around the turn of the century. Florida's population exploded after World War II, more than quadrupling to nearly 13 million people. Canals and channels were built for flood control, but changes in natural water flow have spurred pollution, destroyed wildlife habitats and disrupted evaporation-and-rainfall cycles. South Florida has had its lowest rainfall since 1962 in the past year, and the water level in Lake Okeechobee, which serves as a giant reservoir for South Florida, is three feet below normal and at its lowest on record. The dry conditions spur wildfires that push black smoke and ash over the southeast coast. Choking smoke last spring forced respiratory alerts and repeated closings of major highways. And the low water levels can allow ocean saltwater intrusion to underground aquifers.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Bills Passenger Who Forced Emergency Landing
DOC.TEXT: An airline passenger whose unruliness forced an emergency landing was sent a $2,300 bill for damages, the airline said. Britannia Airways did not identify the man but said Wednesday that unless he refunded the company's losses by the end of the month it would take legal action. Spokesman Alan Hyde said the man began striking at two women traveling with him and threatened other people on the charter flight from the Canary Islands to central England in November. The pilot diverted to Lisbon, Portugal, after the crew failed to calm the man, and police removed him, Hyde said. The bill included handling charges incurred at Lisbon and the extra fuel used to divert the plane, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Wonders Whether Type Size Cost him Election
DOC.TEXT: The former mayor of this western Pennsylvania town wonders whether he lost his re-election bid because voters didn't read the fine print. Richard Haddox's name on the November ballot appeared in a smaller type size than challenger Paul Spickerman's. Haddox lost by two votes. Haddox wrote to the Beaver County Board of Elections pointing out the type size difference. He decided not to challenge the outcome, but he suggested the board investigate the matter and release its findings. `` ... The variation in print size is suspicious and tends to raise questions about the integrity of the election and the process of printing the ballots,'' Haddox said. Elections board Chairman Chester Szurley said the company that printed the ballots admitted the varied type size was its decision because of space constraints. Szurley said each candidate must review a sample ballot prior to an election. He said Haddox apparently did not notice the type size difference then.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A commercial for submarine sandwiches ended with a kicker for 18-year-old Katie Ryan: Will you marry me? Chuck Schmitt, the 21-year-old assistant manager for the Submarine Sandwich Shop in Dubuque, wanted to be a little different in his proposal to Ms. Ryan, so he chose a radio spot broadcast Tuesday night. Fifty seconds of the spot on KDFX-FM contained all the glories about submarine sandwiches. In the final seconds, Schmitt said, ``By the way, Katie, I know you're listening, I love you really, will you marry me?'' Ms. Ryan had been told to listen, but the question was a complete surprise. KDFX news director Casey Flint said Ms. Ryan called the station about 30 seconds later, and was put on the air. She said yes, she was delighted to accept. The couple plans a Sept. 22 wedding.

Charles R. Pilotte's curiosity was piqued when he discovered a cache of pre-Prohibition era liquor stashed behind a wall in his cellar. He had to know how the whiskey would go down. ``It's smooth, but the aftertaste _ when it hit it knocked me up against a wall,'' he said. Pilotte found 19 bottles of liquor, including Haig & Haig Scotch, Gordon's gin, Old Crow bourbon, Chevalier brandy and Mount Vernon whiskey, as he tore down a basement wall Jan. 7 in his 80-year-old home. In the wall, between a coal bin and a coal storage room, he found a wooden fire break about 18 inches from the floor. He found the liquor bottles wrapped in copies of the Boston Sunday Herald and the Boston Evening Tribune, all dated from 1919, the year before Prohibition took effect. Pilotte believes the bottles were left there by either Selby Kidder or William B. Hunter, who lived in the house at that time. Pilotte is now trying to determine the value and age of his discovery. He believes the Haig & Haig might date back to the 1800s. Pilotte sampled the Mount Vernon whiskey because five bottles of that brand were in the wall, and one of the bottle's appeared to have leaked. The leak, Pilotte said, didn't effect the taste.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 49 In Magazine Bombing Case
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested 49 people in connection with the July bombing of the leftist magazine Globe, saying they have dealt a blow to right-wing extremists. Four policemen and several members of the small French and European National Party were among those arrested. Forty remained in custody late Wednesday afternoon. The four officers were identified as members of the Professional Federation of Police, close to right-wing elements. The Paris offices of Globe, a cultural-political magazine, were destroyed July 31 by a bomb described by police and ``homemade but sophisticated.'' No organization ever claimed responsibility for the attack and no one was injured.

DOC.HEAD: Thirty-Two Wounded Guerrillas Demand Evacuation
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-two wounded guerrillas who took refuge in a downtown church more than two months ago are demanding that the rightist government permit their evacuation abroad. The leftist rebels, who made their demand Wednesday, say the Geneva Accords oblige the government to permit evacuation. The U.S.-backed government says the accords do not apply in this case. Troops have maintained a cordon around the Calvario Roman Catholic Church since its occupation Nov. 9 by wounded rebels, most of them amputees. The church, where the rebels sleep on the floor and on pews, has been closed to worship. The International Red Cross has been allowed to deliver food to the war wounded. But the rebels issued a communique Wednesday saying they are suffering from lack of food and hygienic facilities. In October, the government permitted the evacuation to Cuba of 46 wounded rebels who had spent 43 days in Metropolitan Cathedral. The government of President Alfredo Cristiani is fighting a 10-year-old civil war with the rebels in which more than 70,000 people have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: `Wash Basins' Drain Cubans to Panama, But Not to America
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Hector Higueras paid $9,000 to come to the United States, but he ended up in Panama and now he can't leave. Higueras is one of thousands of Cubans who arrived in Panama the last four years as part of an underground ``human trafficking ring'' allegedly involving Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and members of Fidel Castro's government. ``Just as everyone knows there's drug trafficking in Colombia, everybody here knows Noriega was trafficking Cubans,'' said Higueras, 26, a computer programmer. ``Noriega profited financially, and Castro benefited by provoking illegal migration to the United States'' and getting rid of malcontents, he said. Since the U.S. invasion Dec. 20, Noriega's henchmen have either been captured or are hiding, and the Cubans who arrived here illegally are stuck. The refugees are asking for visas to the United States but don't qualify under U.S. ``immediate family'' quotas, which means they have to have parents or siblings living in the United States. Many of the Cubans are young, in their 20s, and have not known anything but a Communist system. By Cuban standards, they are a privileged lot, many having worked in the government bureaucracy as secretaries, accountants and engineers. ``We are not Marielitos,'' Higueres said, referring to the 1980 Cuban boatlift off the Miami coast. ``We are not prisoners. There's a lot of professionals.'' He said the Cubans left their homeland because of the economic situation there and events in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ``If you live in a cave but see a ray of light far away, you know there's something else there,'' said Higueras. ``But you don't know how dark it's been until you get to the light.'' Higueras, who helped form the new Cuban Refugees Commission, says the smuggling ring shipped about 40,000 Cubans to Panama. Although the exact number of Cubans in Panama now is not known, it is much lower than 40,000, he says. The U.S. invasion brought the issue to light because Cuban refugees say they did not feel free to speak up under Noriega's military regime. The Cubans describe an intricate network that spanned South America, including Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Brazil and the Mexican border. A lawyer familiar with the cases said relatives of the Cubans would have to give U.S. dollars, in cash, to an attorney in Panama. The Panamanian attorney would then contact officers in the Panamanian Defense Forces to get permission for the Cuban to enter the country. Sometimes Noriega himself would have to give his approval. Then the Panamanians would bribe contacts in the Cuban government, who would authorize an exit permit. The total cost could go as high as $20,000 in a difficult case, said the attorney, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Everybody got a cut,'' said the attorney. The final cost varied depending on the passport, papers and route provided by the ``palanganas,'' or wash basins, as the people who traffic Cubans are called in Panama. The Cuban ambassador in Panama said he didn't know anything about the smuggling ring. ``If it happened, it didn't have anything to do with the embassy or the consulate,'' Ambassador Lazaro Mora said Wednesday. As the Cubans arrived in Panama City, they were led through a ``tunnel'' at the airport where immigration officials would take their passports; for $20, they would get an identication card specifying, ``Can't work.'' ``I wanted to be a free person. But right away you felt like a slave,'' said Jorge Reyes Barcelo, 23, whose family in Miami paid $3,500 for him to leave Cuba. He said a ``palangana'' told him when arrived in Panama he had to come up with another $3,500 to get to the United States. ``I saw very quickly what price you had to pay for freedom,'' said Reyes. ``I saw we were being moved like animals for a lot of money. I thought until then everything was legal, because I didn't know what my family had paid.'' From the airport, the Cubans were driven to safe houses in apartments and houses where up to 20 other Cubans were staying. They said they were charged about $200 a month rent. Reyes said he was offered a trip to the Mexican border city of Ciudad Juarez, where he would swim across to the United States. Instead, he left the safe house and joined other disillusioned Cubans in Panama City. Higueras said he had received word he would be leaving for the United States on Dec. 20, the day of the invasion. ``I didn't know how I would be leaving, but I was told to be ready. I never heard from the man again. I lost all that money,'' said Higueras. ``But I felt happy. I knew it was a historic moment that was ending something bad.'' The new government of President Guillermo Endara is conducting a census and is filing charges against Belgica del Castillo, the director of immigration under Noriega, for allegedly running the smuggling operation. Ms. Del Castillo sought asylum with Noriega at the Vatican Embassy after the invasion. She surrendered last week. In Miami on Tuesday, a deputy U.S. attorney told a magistrate the government has evidence of a Noriega-led ring that smuggled illegal aliens into the United States. That raised the possibility he could face charges in the United States in addition to the drug trafficking charges. ``We believe we deserve refuge in the United States because of the conditions we've had to live with and because Panama is devastated and cannot absorb us,'' said Higueras.

DOC.HEAD: 300 Protest Persecution of Armenians in Soviet Union
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 300 people, waving Armenian flags and chanting ``Gorbachev must stop the killing,'' gathered near a Soviet embassy Wednesday to protest that country's failure to end fighting between Armenians and their Azerbaijani neighbors. ``We want the United States to put pressure on (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev to end this war,'' said Arby Coharian, a spokeswoman for the Armenian National Committee which organized the rally. ``This could be a thousand times worse than the earthquake,'' she said, referring to the 1988 disaster that killed thousands of Armenians. ``This could lead to the death of the nation.'' The crowd across the street from the Soviet Mission to the United Nations kept up a continuous roar of chants like ``No more genocide'' and ``Stop the killing in Azerbaijan.'' Some held American flags, others waved the blue, red and orange Armenian flag. About 15,000 people of Armenian heritage live in New York City. Coharian said her organization was raising money to provide arms so that Armenians can defend themselves. ``If no other country will do it, we will do it,'' she said. In Moscow, the Kremlin told the thousands of soldiers it sent to the Caucasus to shoot if need be to halt the fighting in the hills around the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. Thousands of Armenian refugees poured from the southern republic of Azerbaijan, many beaten or chased from their homes by angry mobs. Some blamed the attacks on Azerbaijanis who earlier fled ethnic violence in Armenia. The death toll rose to 58, mostly Armenians, and the number of injured to 169 in five days of civil warfare, said Interior Ministry spokesman Dmitri Seleznyov. A predominantly Armenian enclave ruled by Azerbaijan since 1923, Nagorno-Karabakh demanded in February 1988 to be annexed by Armenia, renewing a decades-old feud between the two ethnic groups. ``We have had massacres a lot. This time we are protesting before it happens,'' said demonstrator Lena Sarkissian. ``How much can we wait and see? Until we are gone and finished?'' Mrs. Sarkissian was born in 1918, three years after more than a million Armenians were killed in a wave of persecution in Turkey. She said what is happening in the Soviet Union reminds her of stories her parents told her about the 1915 massacres. ``It's very sad,'' she said, breaking into tears.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Chief Defends U.S. Stance on Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: The United States should ``dare not ignore'' signals that gas emissions may be heating up the Earth, but it's too early to set limits on carbon dioxide exhaust, the nation's environmental chief said. Environmental Protection Agency administrator William K. Reilly said Wednesday that although six of the 10 warmest years on record occurred in the last decade, more study was needed on global warming. Reilly said it would be three to five years before scientific research ``gets anything conclusive or definitive on greenhouse gases or climatic change. That should not, however, suggest it should paralyze policy.'' Environmentalists and some Senate Democrats have sharply criticized the United States for refusing to commit to stabilizing emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases by the year 2000. In November, at an international conference on ways to slow or halt dangerous climatic changes, many Europeans called for specific curbs on ``greenhouse'' gases by the century's end. The United States agreed to a compromise declaration at the conference that says global-warming pollutants should be stabilized ``as soon as possible.'' Reilly criticized the countries calling for limits on gas emissions. ``Most don't have a clue how they will achieve those cuts,'' he said in a speech, which was part of an environmental lecture series sponsored by The New York Botanical Garden. He said many countries haven't figured out the economic impact of improving the fuel efficiency of cars and industrial plants to meet a freeze in emissions. He said it would cost billions of dollars. Reilly said, however, it was time to step up research on the issue. ``Something important may be happening,'' he said. ``We dare not ignore it.'' He strongly supported the U.N.-sponsored Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which is to meet in Washington next month. Scientists say the greenhouse effect could eventually turn subtropical areas into deserts and coastal nations could face massive flooding. Researchers have theorized that certain gases are trapping heat within the atmosphere, causing temperatures to rise. They say that carbon dioxide emissions, along with chlorofluorocarbons, methane and nitrous oxides, may be the major causes. In his speech, Reilly encouraged conservation groups to make more debt-for-nature swaps, deals in which developing countries preserve ecologically sensitive areas for debt payments. He also said environmentalists now have a major opportunity to protect nature because of heightened awareness of the world's fragile environment. ``We need to seize the moment,'' he said. `` ... We need to do everything we can personally do to preserve our Earth while there is still time.'' Reilly told a story in which Mark Twain was walking with a friend in a hard rain. ``The friend asked, `Think it will stop?' ``Twain looked up and said, `Always has.''' He said nature, ``broadly defined, is a good deal tougher and resilient than we give it credit for. ... Nature, I have no doubt, will make it. It's human beings I'm worried about, whether we can make it.''

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Program Gets $600,000 In Bad Checks
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina's amnesty period for residents to repay back taxes brought in millions of dollars and $600,000 worth of bad checks. ``Can you believe that people will send in a bad check to pay off something like this?'' asked Revenue Secretary Helen Powers. ``That's just adding insult to injury.'' Ms. Powers told a legislative committee on Tuesday that those who bounced checks were ineligible for amnesty and will be chased down by the state. Not counting the bad checks, North Carolina received $38.6 million during the 90-day period during which tax evasion penalties were waived, Ms. Powers said. That total ranked North Carolina eighth among the 30 states that have conducted amnesty programs. There's more bad news ahead for the writers of bad checks: Tax evasion penalties have increased.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Student Guilty of Notebook Theft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `But Assistant ...,' to CORRECT second sentence that Hoyer was talking about Taborsky, sted reverse. Petr cq
DOC.TEXT: A former University of South Florida student has been convicted of stealing two notebooks of his research data from a laboratory at the school. Circuit Judge Richard Lazzara ordered Petr Taborsky to return the books no later than sentencing Feb. 9, after a jury found him guilty Tuesday of second-degree grand theft and theft of trade secrets. Taborsky, 27, also was ordered to turn over to prosecutors any copies made of the notebooks. He could face up to five years in prison, but state guidelines indicate he might get probation. Taborsky was hired to work in USF's engineering laboratory on research sponsored by Florida Progress Corp. in St. Petersburg. The company, parent of Florida Power Corp., paid the school $68,000 for the research it said Taborsky stole. Defense attorney Terrance Bostic argued that Taborsky was signed to work on a biological project that failed, then continued the work on his own. He said Taborsky maintains he owns the ideas. ``It's the story of a young, inquisitive student who returns to the lab and begins to think back on what went wrong with the biological portion and asks, What if?''' He shared his invention with his professor, Bostic argued, only to have the corporation steal it. But Assistant State Attorney Judy Hoyer read from a series of monthly Florida Progress reports that showed the company was working all along on the experiments Taborsky said he conceived on his own. She said if Taborsky were not convicted sponsored research would cease to exist at universities. Frank Lucarelli, director of sponsored research USF, said it would be a ``catastrophe'' if Taborsky was not found guilty because it would destroy the trust that private corporations, which sponsored $55 million of research last year, place in the school.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Cancels Reagan-Era Program Blamed for Billion-Dollar Loss
DOC.TEXT: Housing Secretary Jack Kemp is killing a mortgage insurance program that was part of the Reagan administration's effort to trim the bureaucracy but is now blamed for costing taxpayers nearly $1 billion. Kemp said Wednesday the Department of Housing and Urban Development will phase out the co-insurance program and all private lenders will have to get HUD approval before making new loans in the meantime. Kemp, in a statement, said another HUD insurance program will provide an alternative financing option. He said he would restructure it by year's end to allow private lenders to process and service those loans while making sure only HUD can approve the necessary mortgage insurance. The decision to kill the co-insurance program, among the programs investigated during last year's allegations of favoritism and mismanagement at HUD in the 1980s, came four months after HUD officials said it would be reformed and revived. Democrats in Congress have warned Kemp not to use agency problems as excuses to drop programs, but a congressional aide said he expected no battle over killing co-insurance. ``It was a seriously flawed program,'' said Donald Campbell, staff director of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs subcommittee on housing. Democrats, however, likely would question whether HUD has enough qualified staffers to oversee the program Kemp promoted as an alternative, Campbell said. The co-insurance program, created in 1983, allowed private lenders to issue mortgages for multifamily housing developments and commit HUD to insuring roughly 80 percent of the loans. Audits by HUD's inspector general have criticized co-insurance lenders for approving bloated mortgages. Those high mortgages led to excessive rents, which in turn were blamed for high vacancy rates that led to defaults _ leaving HUD holding most of the bill. The General Accounting Office estimates that defaults and other related HUD program losses have cost taxpayers at least $960 million. The most notorious case _ which Kemp cited in announcing the decision _ was the HUD-backed loan for Colonial House apartments in Houston. The development was co-insured for $47.2 million. HUD was forced to take over Colonial House after default and recovered just $8.9 million when it auctioned the property. In his statement Wednesday, Kemp said extensive reviews by HUD staff and outside auditors convinced him to kill the program. ``Our review of co-insurance, and its mounting losses, has shown that it cannot be managed or overseen in a way that will serve the interests of the public at large or the needs of families for affordable housing,'' Kemp said. ``It is clear that co-insurance has been a bad deal for the American taxpayer,'' he said. Kemp said HUD's full insurance program, under which the government itself issues the mortgage insurance and is 100 percent liable in the event of default, would help pick up the slack for homebuyers. Underwriting the mortgage insurance directly would give HUD greater oversight of loans. But Campbell, the Senate aide, said, ``The problem here is that they are going back to full insurance and there is no evidence that they have the staff to handle the demand.'' He said co-insurance was created because of HUD staff reductions and the Bush administration resisted attempts by Democrats to boost staffing levels this year. Documents released by HUD and testimony at congressional hearings showed that one company, DRG Funding Corp., had nearly $600 million of the loans of the $960 million in HUD losses. DRG was placed on probation during the Reagan administration by then-Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and required to submit all of its proposed co-insurance loans to HUD for approval. But Pierce lifted the restrictions after being lobbied by Carla Hills, a former HUD secretary who was then in private law practice and now serves as the Bush administration's trade representative.

DOC.HEAD: US Diplomats Worried About Impact of Panama Incidents
DOC.TEXT: Angry State Department officials say U.S. diplomats overseas could be the target of reprisals following a series of incidents between U.S. forces in Panama and foreign envoys there. ``We cannot conduct diplomacy on the basis of 25-watt thinking,'' said one administration official, accusing the U.S. military of failing to take into account the potential diplomatic consequences of its actions. The incidents ``put in jeopardy American diplomatic missions all over the world,'' said Perry Shankle, a former president of the American Foreign Service Association, the union of career diplomats. He was the only one of several officials interviewed who was willing to be quoted by name. Fearful of the diplomatic fallout as a result of incidents at the embassies in Panama of the Vatican, Cuba, Peru and Nicaragua, the association has expressed its concern in a private letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. The United States is considered particularly vulnerable to reprisals against its diplomats because it often pursues unpopular policies internationally and also has more envoys stationed overseas than any other country. The State Department insists the United States subscribes fully to rules governing treatment of diplomats spelled out in the Vienna Convention. On the other hand, it acknowledges that an ``unusual situation'' has prevailed in Panama. A U.S. official, worried about the precedent set in Panama, said, ``We diplomats have to rely on good faith of foreign governments to live up to their commitments to protect us.'' One foreign service officer expressed particular outrage over the statement by President Bush following the Dec. 29 penetration of the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama by U.S. forces searching for weapons. Bush acknowledged that a mistake had been made because the U.S. troops thought the envoy lived elsewhere, but the president sharply criticized the diplomat for ``having automatic weapons up to his eyeballs in his house.'' The U.S. official said Nicaragua is not alone in having weapons caches stored at its diplomatic sites. If a hostile group entered U.S. facilities in some foreign countries, ``don't you think they would find RPG's (rocket-propelled grenades)?'' the official asked. ``You don't think we have TOW (anti-tank) missiles in some compounds?'' Use of loud music outside the Vatican Embassy, where Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega sought refuge on Dec. 24, drew angry complaints of ``amateurism'' from some State Department officials and expressions of irritation from the Vatican. A few days after the invasion, Cuban officials charged the U.S. forces were preventing diplomats from entering or leaving their embassy as part of the effort to bar Noriega from seeking refuge there. U.S. officials denied the Cuban allegations. In an effort to track down Panamanians who served Noriega, American troops have been checking cars entering and leaving the Cuban mission even though some experts contend such vehicles apparently are exempt from such activity under international law. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler has said the Cuban ambassador's car ``has very dark, tinted windows which require troops guarding the mission to open the doors to identify the passengers.'' But a State Department official said the action by the troops ``exposes every American ambassador to the possibility of an armed blockade. He would have to agree to be searched. This is appalling. This is the most appalling thing I've ever seen.'' The official listed about seven adversary countries which he said may use the Panama precedents as an excuse to harass U.S. diplomats as a means of punishing the United States. At a time of embittered anti-American feelings in 1979, there were attacks on three U.S. embassies in the Middle East in less than a month, and each is believed to have had official encouragement or acquiescence. The attack on the U.S. embassy in Tehran produced the Iran hostage crisis, which dragged on for 444 days. Some Panamanians being sought by U.S. forces are wanted in the United States on drug trafficking charges, Ms. Tutwiler said. She added that the police functions being carried out by the U.S. troops at various embassies in Panama are being transferred quickly to Panamanian security forces.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Approval of Generics Fell Sharply After Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is approving far fewer generic drugs for sale to consumers as a result of the fraud and bribery scandal that enveloped the agency last year. The troubles at the FDA's generic drug division never shut off the pipeline entirely, but the agency said it approved fewer than half the generic drugs in 1989 than it had the year before. The slowdown, said Jay Molishever of the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association, has caused a ``clogging of the pipeline'' that is hurting consumers and generic drug companies alike. ``It hurts the consumer because the drugs aren't getting to them, and it hurts the innocent generic firms because the opportunity to market these drugs is delayed by the necessary diversion of manpower to correct the problem created by a few,'' Molishever said in an interview Wednesday. The FDA said it approved 265 generic drugs in 1989, compared with 684 the previous year. Hemant K. Shah of HKS & Co., a pharmaceutical analyst based in Warren, N.J., said there has been little impact from the approval slowdown because no patents for widely prescribed drugs expired last year and none will for the next six months. Only when a patent expires on a brand-name drug can a generic alternative be approved. Such approvals are sometimes granted within days of a patent expiration. ``Even if we had more generic approvals in 1989 there wouldn't have been an impact in terms of more generic use or less generic use because almost every important product that is off patent is facing generic competition,'' Shah said. ``In hindsight, this investigation came at the right time for the generic drug industry because ... it came at a time when more approvals wouldn't have meant anything to the industry,'' he said. Molishever said ``the low point has been reached'' in the approval process and ``the pipeline is starting to work again,'' but couldn't foresee when the regulatory process would be back to normal speed. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said the system won't be back to full steam until a permanent director and other top officials are chosen and ``the office is in place and running.'' Though he didn't know when that would be, he predicted generic drug approvals for this year will be off only slightly from 1988 figures. The scandal that became public last spring led to the bribery convictions of three generic drug company executives and bribe-taking convictions of three FDA employees, including Charles Chang, former branch chief in the generic drug division. The investigation also uncovered evidence that some drug companies cheated on FDA safety tests and prompted recalls of dozens of generic drugs, including the lower-priced clones of some popular drugs. One of the most widely prescribed drugs affected was Dyazide, a high blood pressure medication made by SmithKline Beecham. Last summer, Vitarine Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Springfield Gardens, N.Y., withdrew its version of Dyazide from the market after admitting company employees substituted samples of the brand-name drug for Vitarine's product in tests required for FDA approval. The only other generic version of the drug on the market is made by Bolar Pharmaceutical Co. Inc. of Copiague, N.Y. The FDA is trying to remove it because of allegations Bolar misrepresented data to the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Dominicans, Panamanian Stowaway Found on Ship
LaserPhoto AT6
DOC.TEXT: Nine stowaways from the Dominican Republic and another from Panama were being held aboard a freighter Wednesday following a failed attempt to enter the United States, officials said. Eight of the Dominicans were discovered Sunday after the Tramarco Trader docked in Gulfport, Miss., and two who got off the ship were caught later that day, said Dave Mandel, head agent of the Border Patrol's office there. The ship left that port on the central Gulf Coast, reaching Mobile on Wednesday. The Dominicans were scheduled to fly to their Caribbean island home Thursday, but the Panamanian was to remain aboard because of governmental problems in Panama, said Jeff Mynatt, operations manager for Strachan Shipping Co. The company must have permission from the Panamanian Consulate to remove him from the ship, Mynatt said. ``We don't really know why he got on board,'' he said. ``He said he was just trying to get out of Panama.'' The United States invaded Panama, ousting dictator Manuel Noriega, and installing a new government. Mandel said the stowaways were economic refugees ``looking for a good place to live and work.''

DOC.HEAD: New Technique Superior in Blocking Rejection of Transplants
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have prevented the rejection of transplanted organs by altering the immune system so that the organs don't appear to be foreign, according to a new study. The technique has been used only in laboratory animals so far, but it promises to be a vast improvement over current methods of preventing organ rejection in humans, says one of the study's participants, Dr. C. Garrison Fathman of Stanford University in California. The success of heart, kidney and liver transplants is limited by the ability of researchers to suppress the body's defenses _ so they don't reject the organ _ while leaving enough of those defenses intact to prevent infections and cancer. ``It's trading one disease for another,'' Fathman said Wednesday at the American Heart Association's annual science writers' forum. A heart transplant, for example, cures heart disease, but the immune system suppression leads to infections that often require hospitalization, Fathman said. Sometimes the organ is rejected despite efforts to suppress the immune system. In the new technique, treatment is given before the transplant, rather than after. A specially developed antibody is used to wipe out the white blood cells called helper T cells. These are the master control cells of the immune system. (They are also the cells attacked by the AIDS virus.) The organ transplant surgery is then performed. In the ensuing weeks and months, the helper T cells return, but in the course of their return they are ``educated'' not to destroy any of the body's own tissue. In the course of that ``education,'' the cells learn to recognize the newly transplanted organ as the body's own tissue, not as foreign tissue. Otherwise the immune system is perfectly normal and can protect against infections as well as it could before the transplant. The immune system is not suppressed. One of the technique's peculiar advantages is that even though the new cells are changed to recognize the transplanted organ as the body's own, they retain the ability to protect against infections that they have already fought off. The technique would not, for example, destroy the lifelong immunity to childhood diseases such as measles or chicken pox, Fathman said. He and his Stanford colleagues have done heart transplants on 25 rats and only two have rejected the transplants, he said. Research is under way to find human versions of the antibodies so that trials of the technique can begin in humans, Fathman said. So far, none of the antibodies tested has shown the same effects on human cells, but the researchers are confident that effective human antibodies will be found, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iowans Say Feds Throwing Paper Before Swine
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department is being roasted by Iowa members of Congress over its handling of a $3.7 million program that is supposed to curb outbreaks of pseudorabies in swine. Also called PRV, Ajuesky's disease and mad itch, the virus can be deadly to swine _ especially newborn pigs _ and can be transmitted to most other warmblooded animals, except humans and horses. Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said Wednesday that too much of the money meant for eradicating pseudorabies appears lost in ``a black hole'' of administrative costs. ``It's my intention to work with the inspector general and the GAO (General Accounting Office) to get some accounting breakouts,'' Harkin said at a hearing on where money for the 2-year-old program are going. ``Where's the black hole?'' he asked. More than 20 percent of Iowa swine herds are infected with pseudorabies and nearly 47 percent of the nation's infected herds are located in Iowa, said Harkin. Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, who says he represents the leading pork-producing district in the nation, also has blasted USDA for spending so much on paperwork instead of testing, vaccination and other efforts directly related to getting rid of the virus. ``This vital federal program dedicated to eradicating deadly swine disease has been rendered virtually useless by bureaucratic red tape,'' said Tauke in a press release Monday. Two USDA officials admitted at the hearing that a greater percentage of the appropriated funds was going to administration than Congress intended. But they defended the use as necessary and said there still was enough money to make progress in the eradication program. The 10-year federal effort to rid the nation's swine population of pseudorabies began last January with $3.1 million for 1989. The amount was increased for fiscal 1990. The program also calls for state and pork industry contributions. Harkin and Tauke are miffed because Iowa is getting only $6,000 more this year, despite the $600,000 overall increase in federal funds. Some states are actually being cut back. Lonnie King, deputy administrator at USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said that in 1989 other agency programs helped support the administrative costs of running the pseudorabies program. ``Because pseudorabies will pay its fair share of expenses and because of the consolidation of purchases to save money, some state allocations will be reduced,'' said King ``We are confident that the funds allocated to the states are adequate to further the progress of the national eradication program.'' But Harkin wasn't satisfied. ``This confirms everyone's worst fears about government,'' he said. Pseudorabies develops from a herpes virus that is completely different from rabies. However, its name was derived because of the mouth frothing, teeth grinding and other signs that also are characteristic of rabies. Even when swine recover from the disease, they continue to be carriers of the virus, according to USDA animal health authorities.

The Soviet Union is buying more U.S. wheat at subsidized prices under a long-term grain agreement, says the Agriculture Department. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Wednesday an additional 525,000 metric tons of wheat was sold by four private companies. The exporters will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Dickerson said 511,650 tons of wheat remain in the Soviet Union's current EEP allocation of 2 million tons announced on Dec. 19. Only wheat has been approved for sale to the Soviets under the price subsidy program. The seventh year of the U.S.-Soviet grain agreement began on Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought about 2.3 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery and more than 11 million tons of corn, plus some soybeans and soybean meal. All of the wheat was sold under EEP arrangements. Meanwhile, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced the next round of negotiations with the Soviets on a new agreement will be in Vienna on March 21-22. The current pact will expire on Dec. 31. In 1988-89, the sixth year of the agreement, the Soviet Union bought about 5.4 million tons of wheat and more than 16.3 million tons of corn, plus soybeans, soybean meal and grain sorghums. All but about 700,000 tons of the wheat was bought under EEP. A metric tons is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The 525,000 tons are equal to 19.3 million bushels worth around $73 million at recent U.S. farm prices. Dickerson reported the subsidies at an average of $18.73 per ton, or about 51 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices in order to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest wheat was sold by J. Aron & Co., 250,000 tons; Louis Dreyfus Corp., 150,000; Harvest States Cooperatives, 100,000; and Cargill Inc., 25,000.

Unseasonably high temperatures and dry soil conditions in much of nation are adding to worries about the 1990 winter wheat crop, says the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility. The facility, an operation of the Commerce and Agriculture departments, reported Wednesday on crop and weather conditions for the week of Jan. 8-14. ``Warmer-than-normal temperatures during the week in most winter wheat states created concerns of wheat breaking dormancy too early, making (the crop) vulnerable to a freeze,'' the report said. Winter wheat is planted in the fall and normally is dormant during midwinter cold before starting to grow again when warmer weather returns. The crop is harvested in the summer.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Denies Wrongdoing, Rakes Ex-Bank Chief As `Liar'
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Alan Cranston condemned his chief accuser in the Lincoln Savings & Loan scandal as a ``Hitlerian'' liar Wednesday, and declared he would seek and win re-election to the U.S. Senate in 1992. The Democratic whip, facing the worst political crisis of his 21 years in the U.S. Senate, refused again in a statewide series of news conferences to take any more than the most limited amount of responsibility for the billions lost by taxpayers and savers in the Lincoln collapse. He added that he is still not certain it was wise for the government to seize Lincoln,'' and refused to criticize Charles Keating, the Phoenix millionaire who was chief executive officer of Lincoln Savings, saying the courts will pass judgment on whether Keating did anything wrong. But Cranston lashed out angrily at Edwin Gray, the former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and Cranston's principal accuser. Cranston used the words ``lie'' or ``lies'' 20 times in prepared remarks to describe Gray's charges, and accused Gray of being a ``self-incriminating liar'' and practicioner of ``the `Hitlerian' technique of the big lie.'' Gray was vacationing in Europe and could not be reached for comment. Cranston said he was not aware that Gray would be unavailable to respond to his charges when he scheduled his series of news conferences in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Sacramento to attack him. ``I come before you bloodied but unbowed,'' Cranston told a crowd of reporters. ``I assure you I've only now begun to fight,'' he added, scoffing over ``ghouls'' he said want to succeed him in 1992. ``I have news for Mr. Gray and his right-wing friends. I shall run for re-election in 1992 and I will win,'' the Democrat said in the concluding line of a six-page statement attacking Gray. In his three-city media blitz, Cranston denied repeatedly that he did anything improper in the Lincoln scandal, which could end up costing $2 billion in a tax-funded bailout, plus losses of $200 million for 23,000 Lincoln investors. Cranston acknowledged that by taking $850,000 in contributions from Keating, then intervening with regulators on Keating's behalf that he created ``the appearance of impropriety and did myself political damage, but I repeat there was no impropriety.'' Three separate polls in recent weeks have reported Cranston's popularity falling to its lowest level in his long Senate tenure. The senator accused Gray of being the ``key source'' of accusations that Cranston and other senators met with Gray in April 1987 to delay action against Lincoln. Questioned by reporters, Cranston said it wasn't unusual that he, fellow senators Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John McCain of Arizona and John Glenn of Ohio, met with Gray. A second meeting, a few days later with San Francisco bank examiners, included Sen. Don Riegle of Michigan. The meetings are the subject of a Senate Ethics Committee inquiry. ``Each senator had his own reason for going to that meeting; I went solely to get a speedier decision on the audit, one way or the other.... I (have) said I made a political mistake.... I do not think it was a moral or ethical mistake.''

DOC.HEAD: 'Tis the Season to Save the Wetlands
DOC.TEXT: Mistletoe and holly no longer deck the halls, and everyone has stopped singing carols, but the interest in Christmas trees here is almost as high as it was a month ago. The trees are being hauled into the marshes and swamps in a battle to slow erosion of the region's wetlands, which are disappearing at the rate of about 50 square miles a year. ``Everybody wants to take part. It's great. Instead of just throwing out your Christmas tree, you can send it to save a marsh,'' said Bob Thomas of the Louisiana Nature and Science Center. Environmentalists hope the trees will collect sediment and form barriers to waves, protecting the shoreline. The project, in its third year, also has a side benefit: It saves space in dumps. The program was started by John Day of the Coastal Ecology Institute of Louisiana State University. Day and some graduate students built a line of fences across an eroded marsh and filled it with tree limbs and native bamboo. The project, which had to be done by hand, was impractical, Thomas said. ``It was not something that was going to catch on. It had to be done in January and February when the vegetation had died down. It was cold and you'd sink into the water and ooze up to your waist,'' he said. Day believed Christmas trees would do the job, but he didn't think he could get enough of them. The Nature and Science Center put out the word, however, and the trees came pouring in. There was so much interest, the project was expanded this year. Instead of making people haul their shedding trees to the Nature Center, curbside pickups were organized. ``We get more than we can use,'' Thomas said. ``We only have funding to put in 12,000 trees and a lot of people are disappointed when their tree just gets left for the trash.'' Contractors sank posts into the marsh, and the trees, some still twinkling with strands of tinsel, are laid between the posts. A fence is placed on top of the trees, said Gretchen Binet, the St. Charles Parish official who oversees the swamp work. ``It will affect 6,000 acres of marsh when it's done. We can see results already,'' Binet said. ``It's damping the wave action, protecting the shoreline. You can see the sediment around the fences already. Instead of washing away it's growing there.'' The state spent $35,800 to stack the trees into the fences that were set up last year. Other costs are minimal, said William Conner, an assistant at the Coastal Ecology Institute. Landfill owners have helped collect the trees, and duck hunters help place the trees in the swamps, Conner said. Preliminary studies are being compiled, he said. So far, they think the trees help, but they're still unsure how much. ``You can see the sediment around the fences. Mud flats are being created. It looks very hopeful. You can see the buildup, but we don't know how fast it will work,'' Conner said. He hopes that sediment will cover the trees completely before they decompose, making a long-term barrier. ``The areas we're working in were once marsh, but are now open water,'' Conner said. ``We hope to see grass take root and a marsh established again. It could be one of the best presents ever left by a Christmas tree if it works.''

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Selling Bonds for $5 Billion for Thrift Bailout
DOC.TEXT: Regulators are raising another $5 billion for President Bush's S&L bailout and putting another 43 institutions up for sale. The Resolution Funding Corp. (Refcorp) said Wednesday it will raise the $5 billion next Tuesday by selling 40-year bonds, a maturity 10 years longer than any current government issue. Meanwhile, the Resolution Trust Corp. (RTC) said the S&Ls for sale are located in 16 states and have assets totaling $5.2 billion. Some securities analysts have been skeptical about whether Refcorp bonds will appeal to investors. The Treasury last sold 40-year bonds in 1955. But the Treasury Department official in charge of debt sales said the government believes it can save money on the interest rate paid on the bonds, compared with 30-year debt. That's because of the lack of competition from comparable bond issues. ``Experts in the market are telling us we can sell 40-year paper cheaper than we can sell 30-year,'' said Michael Basham, deputy assistant secretary for federal finance. ``Obviously we'll find out pretty soon.'' The longer maturity also benefits the industry-owned Federal Home Loan Bank system, which through a complex mechanism is providing the money to pay off the principal of the bonds. The bank system must put up roughly $230 million to collateralize $5 billion borrowed for 40 years, versus $500 million to back that amount for 30 years. However, the bank system could end up paying a greater share of interest costs because the money is being borrowed for 10 years longer. Early on, the interest on the Refcorp bonds is being paid primarily by the Treasury, but later the industry will assume a greater share. All told, after the latest bond sale, the government will have borrowed $29.5 billion for S&L rescues, with $20.5 billion left to borrow through Sept. 30, 1991, bringing the total to $50 billion. Regulators, in a letter to the House Ways and Means Committee, also said they need to borrow another $40 billion to $100 billion in short term ``working capital,'' which will be repaid by selling assets from failed S&Ls. The letter, released Wednesday, said regulators hoped to come up with a plan for the additional borrowing by mid-February. The administration and Democrats in Congress have been struggling over whether the additional borrowing should be counted toward the budget deficit. The letter outlined three ways of raising the money, one on-budget and two outside the budget. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the Banking and Budget committees, said the two off-budget plans were ``unrealistic.'' He warned the on-budget plan could be structured to actually make it easier to meet Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction targets. ``It is designed to manipulate the crisis in the thrift industry to mask the size of the deficit and cover up a glaring inability to achieve real reduction,'' Schumer said in a statement. Meanwhile, the RTC said the latest batch of S&Ls offered for sale brings the total available to 70 institutions out of 293 in its portfolio. Each of the 43 has assets of less than $300 million. The RTC has already sold or closed 40 institutions. Institutions in the latest offering are located in Florida, Connecticut, Virginia, Mississippi, Georgia, Tennessee, Alabama, Arkansas, Kansas, Illinois, Michigan, Nebraska, Texas, New Mexico, California and Colorado. In another development, the Office of Thrift Supervision said Southmark Corp., the parent company of San Jacinto Savings Association, Bellaire, Texas, agreed to inject $210 million in capital into the S&L. San Jacinto is among a number of S&Ls, including Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, of Denver, that are under investigation for disguising losses by trading junk bonds to each other at inflated prices.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Congressional Liaison Resigns
DOC.TEXT: A senior Justice Department official, blamed by Democratic congressional aides for many of Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's troubles on Capitol Hill, is resigning. Assistant Attorney General Carol Crawford says she doesn't enjoy serving as the Justice Department's representative on Capitol Hill and considers herself ill-suited for the job. ``There is no eloquent way of saying this. This is not the right job for me,'' Ms. Crawford said Wednesday night. ``The functions of this position are not really funjoy or I am particularly well-suited for.'' Ms. Crawford, the wife of management consultant and Republican donor Ron Crawford, said she ictions that I ennformed Thornburgh last week of her decision to resign. Although she has been criticized within the department and on Capitol Hill for an antagonistic style, Ms. Crawford said her departure was her own idea. Ms. Crawford said she had no immediate plans, adding, ``Right now I am going to take some time off.'' She also expressed surprise at criticism of her performance. ``I can't think of anybody I've had unpleasant relations with,'' she said. Any adversave never been publicly disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Police Can't Make Random Drug Searches on Buses
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge says the war on drugs ``seems to have gone too far'' with random searches of young people riding interstate buses. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin ruled Wednesday that the searches, a key part of the District of Columbia police battle to stop drugs from coming into the city, violate basic constitutional rights to privacy. Sporkin threw out as evidence 20 grams of cocaine and 50 packets of heroin police said they seized from a suspect, Dennis S. Lewis, who was arrested in Washington last October on a bus from New York. ``The random, indiscriminate stopping and questioning of individuals on interstate buses seems to have gone too far,'' Sporkin wrote. ``In this `anything goes' war on drugs, random knocks on doors of our citizens' seeking `consent' to search for illegal drugs cannot be far away. This is not America.'' Sporkin said he was ``deeply troubled'' by ruling so that the case against Lewis might allow him to escape prosecution. But he wrote, ``We cannot become so obsessed with this drug scourge to permit it to dismember the Constitution.'' Lewis was on a bus at Washington's Union Station when he consented to a patdown search by a plainclothes detective, who found a packet of cocaine stuffed in one of Lewis' socks. Marijuana was found in Lewis' jacket pocket and heroin was found in a bag on the floor at Lewis' seat on the bus. The detective testified at a hearing that he had no particular reason for questioning Lewis and that ``sometimes I'll just walk up to anyone who may be on the bus and ask to talk to them.'' The judge said in his ruling, ``Even in our drug-infested society it is clear that our legal system demands the existence of some cause before a police officer will approach a citizen to determine whether that individual may be engaged in some illicit activity.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Convicted Killer Smith Executed in Missouri
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE Smith being executed, details. Edits to conform. Picks up 8th graf pvs, ``Earlier, Pleban ...' ^By R.B. FALLSTROM
DOC.TEXT: Convicted killer Gerald Smith was executed by lethal injection early Thursday, becoming the the 121st nationwide since the U.S. Supreme Court allowed states to restore the death penalty in 1976. Smith, 31, of St. Louis, who had asked that his death sentence be carried out, was pronounced dead at 12:09 by a physician, said Dick Moore, director of the state Department of Corrections. Smith had no last words and refused an opportunity to write a last statement, prison spokesman Dale Riley said. Among the witnesses in the death chamber: Smith's wife, Lynn; his court-appointed attorney, C. John Pleban; and an unidentified female acquaintance. Smith was given separate lethal doses of sodium pentathol, pavulon and potassium chloride. The process took about five minutes, and Smith was unconscious within minutes, Riley said. After the injection, Smith looked at his wife, who mouthed ``I love you.'' He appeared to respond, but then he closed his eyes. Smith had asked for a sedative about 8:30 p.m. and fell asleep about 10:30 p.m., Riley said. Prison officials awakened Smith at 11 p.m. to begin procedures for the execution. Death-penalty opponents made a last-ditch effort to save Smith's life by filing a motion Wednesday afternoon with the U.S. Supreme Court, but the court voted 7-2 to reject the appeal by the Missouri Capital Punishment Resource Center in Kansas City. Another group asked Gov. John Ashcroft for a reprieve to block the execution, but Ashcroft declined, his spokesman said. It was Missouri's second execution since 1965. Smith met Wednesday evening with his court-appointed attorney, C. John Pleban, said prison spokesman Dale Riley. ``Whether he had known that this appeal was going to be made, I don't know,'' Riley said of Pleban, who was unavailable for comment. Smith was told the appeal had been rejected. Smith, said as he ate breakfast in an isolation cell Wednesday that he was ready for the execution, Riley said. Earlier, Pleban conceded that few, if any, legal angles remained to spare his client, who has wavered in the past on his claim that he wanted to die. Smith's wife, Lynn, and an unidentified woman spent several hours visiting him in his cell, Riley said. Smith was sentenced to be executed for the beating death of Karen Roberts in St. Louis. Another death sentence was imposed for the slaying in 1985 of a fellow death-row inmate. The Missouri Coalition Against the Death Penalty petitioned Ashcroft to grant Smith a reprieve, but the governor's spokesman, Bob Ferguson, said his boss ``will not interfere with the judicial process.'' Smith had been sentenced to die a week ago, but Pleban got a stay from Associate Justice Harry Blackmun until the U.S. Supreme Court could review more arguments. The nation's highest court lifted the stay by a 6-3 vote Tuesday and the Missouri Supreme Court moved quickly to set the new execution date. Smith said in a letter to a newspaper that he chased and killed Miss Roberts because she gave him a venereal disease. ``I wanted her to feel some pain so I beat her little lousy head in. If she were living now I would do it all over to her again.'' He signed the letter: ``Gerald Smith, the cold blooded killer.''

DOC.HEAD: Eight Dead In Three-Day Crime Wave
DOC.TEXT: A man found dead Wednesday at a motel had been sought in the slayings of two fellow sailors at a submarine base and had a gun stolen from a pawnshop where a clerk was killed, the Navy said. The two sailors and the clerk were victims in a deadly three-day crime wave. Five other people died in three other apparently unrelated shootings. The rash of killings left investigators searching for motives and for an explanation to the sudden jump in Seattle-area homicides. ``I can't remember ever having this many in a three-day period,'' said Cecil Ray, a police spokesman for King County, which includes Seattle. The county had only one slaying this year before the latest spree. Navy officials said the sailors were found shot to death Tuesday in the bachelor enlisted quarters at Naval Submarine Base, Bangor, which is about 25 miles west of Seattle on the Hood Canal. The officials said little about the killings, which occurred at the base for the Navy's West Coast fleet of Trident submarines. The shooting at the Bremerton pawnshop about 10 miles from the naval base occurred about a half hour after the sailors' bodies were found. The Navy said in a statement late Wednesday that the sailor found dead in a motel room 180 miles south in Vancouver, Wash., apparently died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. The man had been sought in the slayings, and was found with the 9mm pistol stolen from the pawnshop, the Havy said. Except for those used by security guards, guns are banned on the base. The sailor's name was withheld pending notification of relatives, said Navy spokesman Gene Romano. The slain sailors were identified as David Allen Parker, 21, of San Diego, and Scott Anthony Seely, 18, of North Ridgeville, Ohio, west of Cleveland. Parker was a radioman and Seely a fireman on the submarine USS Michigan. Romano had earlier said the Navy killings were not connected to the pawnshop shooting in which clerk Julie Michaels, 32, was killed and her 35-year-old brother critically wounded. No money was taken and the only thing believed missing was a handgun, said Bremerton Police Capt. Dennis Plumb, who said police have few leads and no suspects. The pawnshop shootings brought to eight the number of deaths in shootings in the area during the past three days. On Monday, two Seattle lawyers were found shot to death in a house they were fixing up just south of the city. Capt. T. Michael Nault, King County police major crimes commander, said the lawyers were not killed at random and that at least one of the victims might have known the assailant or assailants. The county medical examiner's office said the two, Eric A. Hoyer, 34, and Steven M. Dorobis, about 36, were killed sometime Sunday. ``There's no obvious motive. We're trying to figure out why and who,'' said Ray, the King County police spokesman. A Seattle homeowner killed a man and wounded another in a shootout with intruders who broke into his home Sunday, police said. The homeowner was wounded in the hand. Two brothers were killed, a third brother was injured and a fourth man held for investigation of homicide and assault in a shooting spree Sunday outside an apartment complex in Des Moines, south of Seattle. Police said they believe the shootings may have been the work of a jealous boyfriend.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Average Down
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 36,729.46, down 91.68 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker's Final Weeks In Power Described
With PM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: As protests gathered strength last fall, East Germany's longtime orthodox leader Erich Honecker ``lost touch with reality,'' according to the man who succeeded him as Communist leader only to be ousted later. Egon Krenz, the successor, and former Politburo member Guenter Schabowski on Wednesday gave their versions of the bunker mentality that engulfed the hard-liners toward the end. ``There was the notion in the former party leadership that everything outside of planned events and demonstrations staged by the Communist youth group was an action organized by enemy forces,'' Krenz told an investigating commission in East Berlin. The testimony was broadcast on East German television. Schabowski said Honecker had personally ordered police attacks against demonstrators in early October, working closely with his then-secret police chief, Erich Mielke. ``Honecker took things into his own hands,'' Schabowski said. ``All decisions and orders that led to the police actions against demonstrators and to their arrrest went exclusively through Honecker and Mielke.'' Like Krenz, Schabowski denied any personal responsibility for the orders to attack the demonstrators in the capital. The attempts at suppression were engineered by Honecker and Mielke, bypassing the other 19 members of the ruling Politburo, Krenz insisted. ``Then-general secretary Erich Honecker and the internal security chief Erich Mielke immediately after each session of the Politburo consulted with each other on the security situation of the German Democratic Republic,'' Krenz said. Honecker and Mielke are now targeted for an indictment for high treason. The East Berlin city government commission is probing possible criminal charges stemming from police brutality during the October attacks in the capital. Club-swinging riot police brutally beat demonstrators on Oct. 7 and 8, when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in town to commemorate the country's 40th anniversary. The uprising was a turning point that speeded Honecker's downfall 10 days later. Krenz, who had responsibility for many internal security functions before Honecker's ouster, criticized the use of force during his testimony Wednesday. ``The excessive action of law enforcement authorities was neither politically nor morally justifiable,'' he told the panel, speaking confidently and wearing a gray suit. Krenz, who was thrown out six weeks after succeeding Honecker on Oct. 18, insisted he knew nothing about any orders to shoot demonstrators. Numerous news media accounts have said Honecker either planned or issued such orders. Krenz said he accepted ``joint responsibility for misjudging dissident citizens and dissident groups for years.'' ``From today's viewpoint it is incomprehensible that there was no general Politburo discussion about the negative developments then taking place in society,'' said Krenz, an influential Politburo member even before Honecker's fall. Krenz added that he and other then-members of the Politburo failed to realize that the Roman Catholic and Lutheran churches were ``not working against but rather for the German Democratic Republic.'' ``Honecker had lost touch with reality and had unrealistic perspectives,'' Krenz said of his one-time patron, who for years treated him like a son. Honecker has been in ill health following gallbladder surgery last summer. He was recently operated on for a malignant kidney tumor. Krenz's current occupation has not been publicized, following his fall as party chief on Dec. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Maybe Oat Bran Doesn't Lower Cholesterol After All
DOC.TEXT: The ballyhooed powers of oat bran are challenged by a study today concluding this faddish food fails to lower cholesterol after all. The idea that oat bran lowers the level of dangerous cholesterol in the blood has been widely accepted in recent years. Some health experts have recommended starting the day with a bowl of oatmeal, and oat bran has become a common ingredient in muffins, cookies, bagels, even doughnuts and potato chips. The new study found that people's cholesterol levels indeed go down when they eat lots of oat bran, but it's only because they also eat less saturated fat and cholesterol than usual. ``There really isn't any cholesterol-lowering property in oat bran,'' said Dr. Frank M. Sacks, a co-author of the study. Some researchers were skeptical of the findings. ``There is a clear cholesterol-lowering effect when you use oatmeal or oat bran,'' said Fred Shinnick, a research scientist at Quaker Oats Co., which stresses oat bran's benefits in its cereal ads. ``We don't think one small study disproves the weight of the evidence that has been published over the past 25 years.'' Oat bran is promoted as a health food largely because it is rich in soluble fiber. Several studies have suggested that this kind of fiber somehow removes cholesterol from the body. High amounts of saturated fat and cholesterol in the diet can raise blood cholesterol levels, leading to heart disease. But when people eat lots of grain products, they're too full to eat their usual amounts of fatty food, according to the new study. In the latest study, volunteers' cholesterol levels fell significantly both while eating lots of oat bran and while eating equivalent amounts of low-fiber white flour and Cream of Wheat. But they also cut their intake of saturated fat and cholesterol. ``They were meeting their caloric requirements, and they didn't feel hungry,'' said Sacks. ``If they were eating Cream of Wheat in the morning, they didn't have any room for bacon and eggs. If they had high-fiber dinners, they weren't out eating pepperoni pizzas. ``That's probably what happens in real life.'' The study, conducted on 20 volunteers, most of them hospital dietitians, was directed by dietitian Janis F. Swain at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. It was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. The volunteers ate seemingly identical muffins, meatloaf and casseroles for two six-week periods. During one period, the foods contained 100 grams, or 3{ ounces, of oat bran, while during the other it contained that much white flour or Cream of Wheat. The volunteers could eat whatever else they wanted. On both the oat and non-oat regimens, their cholesterol levels were about 7 percent lower than before they went on the diets. Before the diets, they were eating 12 percent of their daily calories in the form of saturated fat. This fell to 10 percent while on the high-fiber diet and 9 percent on the low-fiber diet. Consumption of cholesterol dropped by one-third. Among the reports most widely cited in favor of oat bran was a study conducted by dietitian Linda Van Horn at Northwestern University. It found that substituting oat bran for other carbohydrates in the diet lowered blood cholesterol levels by 3 percent. Her study attempted to keep fat consumption constant, and she said the latest work does not shake her conviction that oat bran and other forms of soluble fiber can lower cholesterol. ``With their small sample size and without the dietary control necessary to monitor the situation, I don't know what this means,'' she said of the latest study. Bonny Lieberman, director of nutrition at the Washington-based Center for Science in the Public Interest, said it may take five more years of research to be certain if Sack's assertion is true. In the meantime, she said, it's clear that ``oat bran is not the magic bullet that the food industry has led us to believe.''

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Mayor Shot in Nagasaki
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with mayor in surgery. Picks up 5th pvs, `Motoshima has ...' ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Nagasaki Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima, who has received death threats since he said the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot Thursday outside City Hall, a Nagasaki official said. City spokesman Megumi Nobeta said by telephone that the 67-year-old mayor was taken to Nagasaki Public Hospital immediately after being shot at the entrance to City Hall as he was about to get into a car. Nagasaki prefectural (state) police spokesman Hiroharu Naoe said a single gunman shot Motoshima, hitting the mayor in the left side of his chest, then fled in a white sedan. Police were searching for him, Naoe said. The Japan Broadcasting Corp. (NHK) said the mayor was conscious after being shot and it quoted ambulance and fire department officials as saying the bullet had not hit vital organs. The mayor was rushed into surgery within 45 minutes after he was shot, NHK said doctors had stopped the bleeding and had not found any bullets, indicating the bullet had passed through his body. Motoshima has been receiving threats from ultra-nationalists and others since December 1988, when he said at a city assembly session that he believed Hirohito, then on his deathbed, ``shares responsibility for the war, as well as all of us who lived in that period.'' Motoshima also said Hirohito could have ended World War II sooner and perhaps spared Nagasaki from the atomic bomb.
