Nagasaki was hit by an atomic bomb on Aug. 9, 1945, three days after Hiroshima became the first city to be hit by a nuclear weapon. The mayor's comments enraged fringe groups that reject any criticism of the imperial family, and Motoshima continued to receive threats even after Hirohito's death one year ago. In December, a right-wing doctor, 62-year-old Shigeru Kajiyama, was sentenced to two years in prison for threatening to kill the mayor. Testimony at his trial said he had sent three anonymous letters containing live bullets to the mayor. In January 1989, a rightist was arrested after breaking into City Hall with a knife intending to force Motoshima into retracting his statement. Early last year, rightists mobilized about 100 sound trucks to circle City Hall and blare slogans denouncing the mayor. Police at one time had about 1,200 officers deployed to prevent trouble in the city. Though the rightists made a great deal of noise, supporters of the mayor's position sent him a petition with some 286,000 signatures in April calling for more freedom to express opinions, even on taboo sugjects like the late emperor's war responsiblity.

DOC.HEAD: International Group of Lawyers Plans to Challenge Screening
DOC.TEXT: An international group of lawyers is planning a court challenge to the government screening process that determines which Vietnamese boat people are to be forcibly repatriated, a spokesman said today. ``We think that there are cases of persons who are genuine refugees who have fallen through the cracks in the process'' and were mistakenly classified as illegal immigrants, said David Clark, senior lecturer in political science at Hong Kong University. This British colony once considered all Vietnamese who arrived by boat to seek asylum as refugees eligible for resettlement overseas. But the government, facing a mounting influx of Vietnamese, decided in June 1988 to classify arriving boat people as illegal immigrants subject to repatriation unless they could prove they fled persecution in their Communist homeland. About 85 percent of the approximately 44,000 boat people who have arrived under the new policy are expected to face forced repatriation. The current screening process involves an interview with an immigration officer and gives the opportunity for one appeal. So far, 51 boat people have been forcibly repatriated and about 1,000 have gone back voluntarily. The London-based human rights organization Amnesty International earlier this week criticized the program, saying immigration officers often have scant knowledge of the situation in Vietnam and that translating services need improvement. The group of lawyers, which includes members from the United States and Britain, has selected nine boat people who were screened out by immigration officials and had their appeals denied. ``We have evidence in those cases that there were various defects'' in the process, said Clark. He added that the Vietnamese chosen for the case appear to have a good claim to being classified as refugees. The lawyers plan to go to the colony's High Court with their complaints in a few weeks to seek the overturn of the screening results, said Clark, who has taught administrative law in Hong Kong for 11 years. ``It will be a tough case to win,'' he said. ``The government will fight it tooth and nail.' If the High Court rules against the challenge, the lawyers' group can take the case to the Court of Appeal in Hong Kong and then the Privy Council in London. If that fails, the group may take action against the screening process through the European Commission of Human Rights. The impetus for the legal challenge came largely from Americans Arthur Helton, of the Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights; Janelle Diller, of the Indochina Resource Action Center, and Briton David Burgess.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deadlocks on 13 Charges; 52 Verdicts May Be Unsealed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Court session scheduled for 12:30 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: A judge prepared to unseal verdicts today on 52 counts in a molestation case at a once prestigious nursery school after jurors said they were deadlocked on the remaining 13 charges. Unless jurors indicate further deliberations might break their deadlock, Superior Court Judge William Pounders was planning to unseal the 52 verdicts that have already been returned by the panel in the nation's longest and costliest criminal trial. ``Most likely we'll take the verdicts,'' Jim Gilpin, the bailiff in Pounders' court, said Wednesday, after jurors sent the judge a note at day's end announcing the deadlock. Pounders called a hearing for today to discuss the deadlock and possibly opening the 52 sealed verdicts. No alternate jurors remain in the case and the judge has worried that losing one of the 12 remaining jurors would force a mistrial. Jurors have spent nine weeks deliberating on the molestation and conspiracy charges against Raymond Buckey, 31, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63. They are accused of molesting 11 children during a five-year period at their family-owned McMartin Preschool in Manhattan Beach. The trial has run nearly three years at a cost of $15 million. If the impasse cannot be broken, the judge would declare a mistrial on undecided counts and the prosecution would have the option to refile those charges at a later time. Buckey and his mother were required to stand trial after an 18-month preliminary hearing. Five female teachers who worked at the McMartin Preschool had charges against them dismissed. Among those were Buckey's sister, Peggy Ann, and his grandmother, Virginia McMartin, who founded the now defunct nursery school. Deliberations had been bogged down since Tuesday when one juror became ill. On Wednesday, the talks did not begin until 1 p.m. because another juror's child was ill. The judge, who will be the first to see the jury's verdict forms, said he's been rehearsing maintaining a deadpan expression _ by biting his tongue if necessary _ when he first sees the verdicts. ``You will try to read the verdicts on my face,'' he told lawyers. ``But I will wind up with a bloody tongue before I show you (what the verdicts are). If there's any reaction on my face, it will be, `Thank God it's over and we've got all the verdicts.' Then you will see me beaming.''

DOC.HEAD: Somalia Accused of Killing 50,000 Civilians
DOC.TEXT: A major human rights group says Somalia's government has in the past 19 months killed 50,000 to 60,000 civilians _ many shot in their homes _ whom it suspected of supporting or sympathizing with insurgents. Somalia also has driven about a half-million others into exile, said Africa Watch, a New York-based group. The group said Wednesday that most of the victims were members of the Isaak clan. The army suspects the clan of supporting or sympathizing with the Somali National Movement, a northern insurgent organization. The movement, which draws its membership mostly from the Isaak clan, is the largest in northern Somalia. It was formed in 1981 but did not begin waging all-out war against the government until May 1988, when it attacked two main cities, Burao and Hargeisa. There was no immediate reaction to the allegations from the socialist government of President Mohamed Siad Barre. Alleged rights abuses have prompted Western donors to severely cut aid to the Horn of Africa nation. Following the rebel attacks on the two provincial capitals, Africa Watch said, ``the army turned its firepower, including its air force and artillery, against the civilian population, causing predictably high casualties. ``On the claim of looking for SNM fighters and weapons, systematic house-to-house searches were carried out and thousands were shot in their homes,'' Africa Watch said. ``Residential areas were targets of artillery shelling.'' Africa Watch said it estimated the casualty toll on the basis of extensive interiews with refugees in neighboring Djibouti and the United Kingdom, where a large Somali community lives in Cardiff, Wales. Robert Gersony, a U.S. State Department consultant, conducted a similar study last year and ``conservatively estimated that at least 5,000 unarmed civilian Isaaks were purposefully murdered by the Somali armed forces between May 1988 and March 1989.'' The government has consistently denied that civilians have been killed deliberately, saying any civilians deaths were the result of ``exceptional episodes'' or the unavoidable consequences of war. Africa Watch said the government is taking similar harsh measures against civilians in central and southern Somali, where two new rebel groups, the Somali Patriotic Movement and the United Somali Congress, emerged in early 1989. But the organization acknowledged it had ``not been able to gather sufficient information based on its own research'' to detail alleged atrocities in those regions. Siad Barre, a major general said to be in his 80s, seized power in a bloodless coup in October 1968 to prevent the election to the presidency of a civilian opposed by the army. In recent years he has ruled a deteriorating nation beset by tribal rebellions in the north and south, clan warfare, and a bankrupt economy. Somalia became independent in 1960 after the unification of the north and south, colonized by Britain and Italy respectively.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Says Some Lens Solution Contains Dangerous Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration is advising contact lens wearers who use Wet Cote lens solution to check the numbers on their bottles to make sure they do not contain a bacteria that could cause serious eye infections. The contaminated batch carries the lot number W3028 and the expiration date 6-91 on the label, the FDA said Wednesday. It was distributed in Texas, Florida, Georgia, Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Ohio, North Carolina, Maryland, Tennessee and Illinois. Wet Cote, made by Occumed Inc. in Sarasota, Fla., is a wetting solution designed for use with hard contact lenses. Seven of 20 bottles of Wet Cote from the batch that were analyzed were found to be contaminated with a bacteria called Pseudomonas cepecia, which can cause serious eye infections that are difficult to treat and in rare cases lead to blindness, the FDA said. The manufacturer recalled the product, but only about a third of the 1,500 bottles produced were recovered, the agency said. The FDA advised consumers who have bottles of Wet Cote to check the label and if the lot number shows it was from the contaminated batch, not to use it but return the product to the place of purchase.
DOC.HEAD: Stronger Sanctions May Be Needed, Lawmakers Say
DOC.TEXT: The United States should consider tougher sanctions against South Africa, which continues to drag its feet on genuine reform of its racial policies, three members of Congress say. Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., leader of a delegation that visited South Africa this month, said Americans shouldn't be fooled by gestures such as the release of a few political prisoners. ``There's a tremendous yearning in this country to hope for the best,'' he said. ``There's a real danger that we will end up substituting the wish for the reality.'' Anti-apartheid leaders in South Africa are demanding concessions before endorsing President F.W. de Klerk's call for negotiations to bring blacks into the government. ``If those preconditions are not met, I don't doubt that there will be a growing movement in the Congress and internationally to intensify sanctions,'' said Rep. Alan Wheat, D-Mo. Wolpe, Wheat and Rep. Constance Morella, R-Md., said at a news conference Wednesday they were disappointed after their Jan. 4-9 trip that included meetings with de Klerk and other leaders in the government and the opposition. ``The government seems to be clinging to the fantasy that somehow conflict in South Africa can be reduced and the pressures from without will be eased while the white minority continues to hold to power and privilege,'' said Wolpe, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. The panel will begin hearings next month on proposals to further restrict U.S.-South African economic ties, Wolpe said.
DOC.HEAD: Gramm, Gingrich To Sponsor Tough New Anti-Crime Measures
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Phil Gramm is promising to get tough on drug thugs with a series of stiff anti-crime proposals that would require most inmates to work and could deprive them of such prison amenities as air-conditioning. But an official of the American Civil Liberties Union says the plan is an election-year ploy that fails to address the causes of drug abuse and drug dealing and ignores such issues as education, treatment and prevention. ``Every election year we see these new, get-tough approaches to the drug problem, and they're offered as though we haven't gotten tough on the drug problem,'' said Gene Guerrero, a legislative representative for the ACLU. Guerrero said drug use is actually down, prisoners are serving longer sentences and prison populations have tripled since 1970. The military is involved in the fight against drugs, yet more potent drugs are more readily available at cheaper prices than ever. Gramm, R-Texas, and House Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., are proposing legislation that would declare a five-year national drug and crime emergency act to ``deal with the problems of our bleeding nation.'' ``What I think we need to do is string some of these people (criminals) up,'' Gramm told a Capitol news conference Wednesday. Gramm's bill would require mandatory sentences, without parole, for federal drug and violent crime convictions. It also imposes stiff penalties for drug users; allows states, local governments and businesses to conduct random drug testing; and restricts the courts' right to limit prison overcrowding. Under Gramm's proposed state of emergency, prisoners could be housed in temporary space, including military bases or in tents, while costs for building new prisons could be cut by eliminating such non-essentials as air-conditioning.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Picks First Military Women As Astronaut Candidates
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA's new class of astronaut candidates includes the first military women and the first female Hispanic. Three of the 23 candidates are military women: Air Force Maj. Eileen M. Collins, of Elmira, N.Y., the first woman to be named a shuttle pilot candidate; Air Force Capt. Susan J. Helms of Charlotte, N.C.; and Army Capt. Nancy J. Sherlock of Wilmington, Del. Helms and Sherlock were chosen as mission specialist candidates. The list also includes Los Angeles native Ellen Ochoa, a Hispanic chosen as a mission specialist candidate. Seven pilot candidates and 16 mission specialists were selected from a list of 1,945 qualified applications. Last fall, 106 applicants were interviewed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The candidates will train for a year beginning in July before they are given technical jobs that lead to assignments on shuttle missions. The astronaut candidates include Ronald M. Sega, the husband of astronaut Bonnie Dunbar _ a mission specialist aboard the current Columbia flight. Sega, a Cleveland native who is now a professor at the University of Houston, was named a mission specialist. Shuttle pilot candidates and their hometowns: Kenneth D. Cockrell of Austin, Texas; Air Force Capt. William G. Gregory of Lockport, N.Y.; Air Force Maj. James D. Halsell Jr. of Monroe, La.; Air Force Maj. Charles J. Precourt of Waltham, Mass.; Air Force Maj. Richard A. Searfoss of Mount Clemens, Mich.; and Marine Corps Maj. Terrence W. Wilcutt of Russellville, Ky. Mission specialists and their hometowns are: Navy Lt. Cmdr. Daniel W. Bursch of Bristol, Pa.; Leroy Chiao of Milwaukee, Wis.; Army Maj. Michael R.U. Clifford of Norton Air Force Base, Calif.; Bernard A. Harris Jr. of Temple, Texas; Thomas D. Jones of Baltimore; Army Maj. William S. McArthur Jr. of Laurinburg, N.C.; James H. Newman of Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands; Donald A. Thomas of Cleveland; Janice E. Voss of South Bend, Ind.; Air Force Capt. Carl E. Walz of Cleveland; Peter J.K. Wisoff of Norfolk, Va.; and David A. Wolf of Indianapolis.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviets Order Partial Mobilization of Reserves to Cope With Caucasus Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov ordered a partial mobilization of reserve troops, including young men recently discharged, to cope with the bloody ethnic turmoil raging in the Caucasus, Radio Moscow reported Thursday. Interior Ministry, KGB and Soviet Army units trying to put down the Armenian-Azerbaijani violence that has left at least 66 people dead and more than 200 people wounded have been authorized to fire on gunmen who attack them or people who are trying to steal weapons. The Kremlin on Tuesday poured more than 11,000 additional troops into the troubled mountain region 1,250 miles southeast of Moscow in a bid to quell the deadliest round of violence in the most protracted ethnic conflict facing President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. To compensate for the depletion in the ranks caused by the airlifts, Radio Moscow, quoting Yazov, said a partial mobilization of reserves has been ordered in some areas of the Soviet Union to make it easier to send reinforcements to the Caucasus. ``Recently demobilized young men are being recalled,'' the state-run radio said. It did not give figures. It was unclear whether the mobilization would mean a freeze or reversal in Gorbachev's plan, announced in December 1988 at the United Nations, to slash the nation's armed forces by 500,000 men as part of a campaign to reduce East-West tensions.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Won't Give Traffickers Amnesty
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco's government has refused to give Colombian drug traffickers the amnesty they are now requesting, saying they will have to take their chances in the courts if they surrender. Traffickers from the Medellin cocaine cartel said in a communique Wednesday that the government has won its war against drugs traffickers, and offered to dismantle their empire in exchange for a pardon. They released two kidnap victims to back up the offer, which was similar to previous proposals rejected by the government except for its acceptance of defeat. Also Wednesday, a Colombian brother and sister were flown to the United States to face cocaine-trafficking charges, bringing to 13 the number of Colombians extradited to the United States since Barco launched the crackdown in August. In the 11-point communique, which was carried by one of the freed kidnap victims, the traffickers said: ``We accept the triumph of the state ... Thus we will lay down our arms and abandon our objectives for the benefit of the highest interests of the fatherland.'' The communique, like others from the traffickers, was signed by The Extraditables, the name of the Medellin cartel's armed wing. The drug cartel's communique followed Barco's comment, in response to reporters' questions Tuesday night, that his government is not ``inflexible'' regarding a negotiated settlement with drug lords. Previously, Barco ruled out talks. But Wednesday night, Minister of Government Carlos Lemos Simmonds said in a television interview that the government's position of not negotiating with the traffickers stands. ``I don't see why we have to change our position when our own enemies have declared that that position has won out,'' Lemos Simmonds told Channel 7 News, a nationwide program. Barco, President Bush and the leaders of the cocaine-producing countries of Peru and Bolivia have joined forces to fight drug traffickers. They are expected to sign an accord to that effect at a drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia, on Feb. 15. Patricia Echavarria, who was kidnapped Dec. 16 in Medellin along with her daughter, carried the communique when the two were freed Wednesday in Medellin. ``We submit to the existing legal establishment in the hope of obtaining from the government and from society respect for our rights and our return to our families and communities,'' the communique said. That has been the traffickers' way in the past of saying they want pardons and to not be extradited to the United States. ``We have decided to suspend the shipment of drugs and surrender the weapons, explosives, laboratories, hostages, the clandestine landing strips and other effects related to our activities at such a time as we are granted constitutional and legal guarantees,'' it continued, reiterating previous offers. Presumably, government pardons would mean none of the traffickers would be prosecuted for the murders of scores of people in Colombia, including governmment officials, judges, journalists, and members of security forces. The communique said Mrs. Echavarria and her daughter, Dina, had been freed as proof of the cartels' desire to make peace. Barco began his crackdown on drug dealers five months ago after drug lords assassinated leading presidential candidate Sen. Carlos Galan, who demanded more action against drug trafficking. By law, Barco can't run for re-election. As part of the crackdown, Barco revived Colombia's extradition treaty with the United States, something feared by Colombian traffickers. In the latest extradition, Diana Maria Caballero Rangel Gamber, 29, and Roberto Caballero Rangel, 32, were turned over to U.S. marshals by Colombian authorities, the Marshals Service said. The two were arrested Oct. 20 by Colombian authorities in Bucaramanga on trafficking charges stemming from a 1988 indictment in the United States. Drug traffickers have responded to the government crackdown with a terror campaign that has killed 209 people, including 107 who died when a bombed jet crashed outside Bogota in November. More than 1,200 people have been injured in the attacks. In the last 45 days, 85 people have been kidnapped, and police believe most of them were abducted by the traffickers. In the communique, the traffickers offered to act as intermediaries to end violence by groups fighting for control of Colombia's emerald mines and to stop activities of right-wing death squads. In the last four years, death squads have killed more than 1,000 people suspected of being sympathizers with Marxist guerrilla groups.

DOC.HEAD: Refugees of Soviet Unrest Share Pain in Moscow
With Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Among the refugees milling around the Armenian republic's office in Moscow was a 49-year-old music teacher, her face swollen and blackened from a fractured jaw, her broken left wrist and two fingers encased in plaster. ``They are killing us,'' said Alisa Arakelova. Along with dozens of other Armenian refugees from the ethnic strife in the southern Caucasus, she had gravitated to the Armenian mission Wednesday in search of help. Armenian media say some 1,500 refugees from Azerbaijan are arriving daily in Yerevan, capital of the bordering republic of Armenia. In all, more than 7,000 Armenians have been evacuated from the Azerbaijani capital of Baku, the reports say. No matter what, Arakelova said, she will never go back to Baku. Authorities say dozens of people have been killed since anti-Armenian riots in the city Saturday night touched off Armenian-Azerbaijani battles in the hills around the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. Most of the victims have been Armenians, attacked by mobs in Baku. Arakelova fled for Moscow days before the outbreak, but not before falling victim to an ethnically motivated attack. She said some Azerbaijani men broke into her apartment a week ago and ``they began beating me with everything they could find,'' including a brick and a heavy wooden pole. She fled that night, and, along with her two children and mother, left her hometown a few days later, not even stopping to find the identity papers she must produce to check into a Soviet hotel. ``They took all my property, and there is somebody living in my apartment already,'' she said. She said the police had lost control of the city and advised them to leave. Armenian refugees gathered at the Armenian mission traded horrendous stories of atrocities, but none claimed to be direct witnesses. The official Tass news agency reported that people were set on fire in Baku and a Russian resident said she saw women dangled and dropped from balconies. Many of the Armenians vilified Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, blaming him for failing to halt the violence that has torn the two southern republics for nearly two years. They yelled that Gorbachev was an oppressor, and a poor learner who had yet to understand the blooy history of the Caucasus. The refugees at the mission and government newspaper Izvestia said much of the violence in Baku involves Azerbaijani refugees from Armenia forcing Armenians from their apartments so they will have a place to live. Izvestia said tens of thousands of Azerbaijanis who fled ethnic violence in Armenia in late 1988 remain without homes or jobs in Baku. There have been no reports of new waves of Azerbaijani refugees. The Armenians in the Moscow mission did not seem to be getting any help. There were no officials in sight, and many simply left after doing no more than exchanging their bitterness with others in the same plight.

DOC.HEAD: Swaggart: Tax Ruling Breaches Constitutional Protections
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Supreme Court ruling that California can tax religious items sold by Jimmy Swaggart Ministries could lead to selective taxation of unpopular religious groups, the evangelist said. ``Now it is clear that all taxes, including income taxes, put on business can now be put on churches,'' Swaggart said. ``Now we have the real threat of intrusion of government into the religious ministry of churches and synagogues.'' Wednesday's unanimous ruling upheld lower court rulings that California could collect $183,000 in back taxes on books, records, tapes and other items produced and sold by the Baton Rouge-based ministry between 1974 and 1981. Mail-order sales from Swaggart's Louisiana base to California consumers during those years totaled $1.7 million. Sales of merchandise at California crusades totaled $240,000. The evangelist did not challenge California's taxing of T-shirts, mugs, bowls and crown-of-thorns replicas sold by his ministry during the period. His challenge of the California tax had been supported by an array of religious groups _ including Hare Krishnas and mainline Protestants. Lawyers for the National Council of Churches, representing most Protestant denominations, called the California tax ``a serious threat ... a tax on the dissemination of religious messages, and thus a forbidden tax on the exercise of religion.'' Swaggart, whose ministry was damaged by a 1987 scandal arising from his alleged dalliances with a New Orleans prostitute, said the court's decision could have ominous consequences. ``Unpopular religions, small religions that don't please one particular state government could conceivably be taxed out of business because many churches derive a great part of their incomes from the sale of tapes, records, Bibles, et cetera,'' he said. Most states tax the proceeds of at least some mail order sales to their residents, but California and Virginia appear to be the only states that do not exempt religious organizations. Other states searching for additional tax revenues now could follow California's lead. The Supreme Court said the California taxes do not violate religious freedom. ``California's non-discriminatory sales and use tax law ... imposes no constitutionally significant burden on (Swaggart's) religious practices or beliefs,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote for the court. Swaggart's lawyers had relied on a 1943 high court ruling that overturned the convictions of Jehovah's Witnesses who violated a city ordinance requiring all people engaged in door-to-door canvassing to get licenses and pay fees. But Wednesday's decision drew a distinction between those fees and the California tax. ``Our concern (in the 1943 ruling) that a flat license tax would act as a precondition to the free exercise of religious beliefs is simply not present where a tax applies to all sales and uses of tangible personal property in the state,'' O'Connor wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Rivera Says The 1990 `Geraldo' Is a Return To His Roots
DOC.TEXT: A kinder, gentler ``Geraldo''? Perish the thought, say producers of the troubled, daytime television talk show who nonetheless are trying to veer away from such topics as battered lesbian lovers and topless doughnut shops. ``This is a return to my roots,'' Geraldo Rivera said Wednesday at the National Association of Television Program Executives convention, where he and his producers are gamely making the best of the worst thing to hit Geraldo since a skinhead's chair in 1988. The show, straining for more viewers during the November 1989 ratings period when it went up against ``The Oprah Winfrey Show'' in 125 markets, ``went a little wild,'' said executive producer Martin M. Berman. They also irritated a number of big, important sponsors, which irritated a number of big, important TV stations, eliciting what Berman called ``station concerns, advertiser concerns.'' The producers reacted quickly to the criticism and commissioned surveys of stations, advertisers and viewers. ``They did not want to see a less provocative show. They did not want to see a `kinder, gentler' Geraldo,'' Berman said. ``But at the same they didn't want to see Geraldo doing the kind of subjects that they believed were not subjects that Geraldo was comfortable with. ``And Geraldo said, `Well, they're right, I'm not comfortable with this. It's not what I want to do. It's not the legacy I want to leave.''' The fine-tuning began around Thanksgiving, Berman said, and for the past seven weeks there has been no decrease in the ratings. ``The fact is that for the last seven weeks we've done no shows that would fit into that exploitive, sensational category,'' he said. Next week, the show will announce the formation of an investigative unit to ``do some serious investigative stuff as part of the mix.'' ``We're not changing, we're just shifting the profile of our repertoire away from the bottom end of it,'' he said. Berman said ``Geraldo'' would leave the convention with virtually its full lineup of stations, and has struck deals with some stations to use the show through September 1993. Ads for the show promise that in 1990, ``you'll experience a better balance of personal and public topics and information, a wider range of important issues in the social, moral and political arenas, more responsiveness to local stations and a more sensitive, more concerned, more humanitarian Geraldo.'' The show has its work cut out for it, said John Rohr, a senior marketing executive for Blair Television, which is the sales representative for about 145 TV stations. ```Geraldo' probably will be renewed for next fall, but the preponderance of time periods he will get will be morning time periods,'' Rohr said. Morning is a lot less expensive in terms of the licensing fees that TV stations pay for their programs. Conversely, it's a lot less lucrative for the program than, say, ``early fringe time,'' 4 to 6 p.m. EST, when there are many more viewers at the tube and advertisers pay more to run their commercials. ``Even if he doesn't change, he is less of a liability than he is in the afternoon,'' Rohr said. Rivera says he's enjoying the fine-tuning of his show. ``For better or worse, I've been singing the same words for 20 years,'' Rivera said. ``This is a return to my roots. I want to go back to busting crooked doctors.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo, Dollar Edges Up
DOC.TEXT: Yet another rumor, this time about interest rates, stopped an upturn by the Tokyo Stock Exchange's main index today, and a rumor about oil helped the dollar edge up against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 91.68 points, or 0.25 percent, closing at 36,729.46. It had gained more than 170 points in early trading, but market players were selling in the afternoon on a rumor that the Bank of Japan soon would raise the nation's official discount rate. The central bank had raised the key rate for lending to commercial banks three times last year to the current 4.25 percent. Although monetary officials have ruled out another increase soon, economists say there is inflationary pressure in Japan. The market is speculating that another rate increase would be considered the most effective monetary policy to stem inflation. After falls of more than 650 points in the Nikkei for two consecutive trading days, the market started turning up on Wednesday, only to start down again on a rumor that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would resign. ``The market has been very sensitive to rumors lately, partly because it is pessimistic and lacking energy,'' said Tadahiro Makita, a dealer with Yamaichi Securities Co. Rumors about Gorbachev affect shares in companies thought likely to profit from increased trade with reforming East bloc countries. Declining Japanese goverment bond prices also have been discouraging the stock market, and the price of bond futures was down 0.87 today to 96.42, bringing the yield as high as 6.85 percent, the highest level in five years. The discount rate rumor contributed to sell-offs in the bond market, dealers said. Stock trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 530 million shares, down from Wednesday's 550 million. The dollar closed at 145.66 yen, up 0.14 yen from Wednesday's 145.52-yen close. It opened at 145.48 yen, its low for the day, and went as high as 145.75 yen. Investors were selling yen in the afternoon when some market players spread a rumor that petroleum supplies from Saudi Arabia would decline, said Naozumi Tsusumi, a trader with Daiwa Bank. ``Somebody spread the rumor to move the market because it was inactive due to a lack of fresh market-affecting news,'' he said. A larger-than-expected U.S. trade deficit in November, announced Wednesday in Washington, did not help the yen recover, he said. The U.S. Commerce Department reported the nation's trade deficit in November rose to $10.50 billion from a revised $10.25 billion in October. Some economists had predicted a deficit of around $9.4 billion. The Bank of Japan sold an estimated $200 million to check the dollar's rise. The central bank does not comment on its exchange market activity.

DOC.HEAD: Government Camp Indicates Forming New Conservative Party
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to reshape South Korea's faction-ridden politics took a new turn today when President Roh Tae-woo's governing party indicated it would dissolve itself to form a new ``grand'' conservative party. The move by the governing Democratic Justice Party, coupled with strenuous efforts by the two centrist opposition parties to merge, made the country's political picture complex. ``We will actively respond to moves by the two opposition parties to merge,'' said the governing party's secretary general, Park Jun-byung. Another Democratic Justice official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``It is possible that we would consider forming a new pan-national, centrist party representing all democratic groups.'' If the new conservative party is formed, the governing party could be folded and its leader, Roh, would give up party membership and stay neutral, the same official said. Kim Young-sam, head of the No. 2 opposition group, said today that he would firm up plans next month to merge his Reunification Democratic Party with the No. 3 opposition group, the New Democratic Republican Party, led by former premier Kim Jong-pil. The two opposition leaders earlier agreed in principle to merge their parties possibly before local elections, scheduled in the first half of this year. ``It would not be a simple merger of two parties. The new party to be born would be a central force comprising all conservative groups,'' Kim Young-sam told reporters. Kim said his ultimate goal is to make the present four-party system into a bipartisan setup. If the two parties merge, it would become the largest opposition group, replacing Kim Dae-jung's Party for Peace and Democracy. The emergence of a centrist opposition party would be welcome news for the governing party, which has been trying to isolate and discredit Kim Dae-jung's liberal, pro-reform party. Kim Dae-jung, holding a news conference today, vehemently opposed the planned merger by his opposition rivals, contending an artificial restructuring of the present four-party system would only benefit Roh's governing party. He said the government camp would try to use the planned opposition merger to seek a conservative alliance, through which it would try to remain in power beyond 1993, when Roh steps down at the end of a single five-year term. Many politicians believe the government camp also favors a political realignment that would enable it to hold onto power as Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party does. If its plan to merge or seek alliance with opposition moderates is successful, the government camp, assured of enough votes in the Assembly, would propose a constitutional amendemnt to change the present presidential system into a Cabinet setup headed by a prime minister, they said. The governing party, with 127 seats in the Assembly, is currently far short of a two-third majority required for a constitutional amendment. South Korea's politics are currently controlled by four main parties, neither of which has a controling majority in the 299-member National Assembly. The three main opposition parties have a combined majority in the single house but intense rivalry makes it difficult for them to cooperate. At his news conference, Kim Dae-jung said he would try to rally support from ``centrist democratic forces'' to counter moves by his rivals to merge or seek alliance. However, his proposal lacked details. He also reiterated that his party would, if the government endorses the plan, send delegates to communist North Korea in the first half of this year to discuss national unification. If the dispatch of the party delegation is proven successful, Kim said he would visit Pyongyang with government approval to meet with North Korean leader Kim Il Sung He said President Roh responded favorably when he raised the issue last week. But presidential and government officials said the opposition plan to send delegates to the north was premature.

DOC.HEAD: Group Finds Anti-Semitic Incidents Rose in 1989
DOC.TEXT: The number of anti-Semitic incidents attributed to neo-Nazi skinheads jumped nearly 200 percent last year, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith reported. The total number of incidents rose almost 12 percent to 1,432 _ the highest number recorded in the 11 years the ADL has conducted an audit on the subject. The ADL said incidents of anti-Jewish vandalism and desecrations rose 3 percent, to 845, in 1989. They included cases of arson, bombings, cemetery desecrations and swastika-daubings against Jewish institutions, Jewish-owned property and public property. There were five bombings, four in California, and eight arson attacks, according to Wednesday's audit. Last year also saw 587 episodes of harassment, assault or threats against Jews or Jewish institutions, a 28 percent jump over 1988, the study found. The total includes the June killing of Max Kowalski, a 72-year-old Holocaust survivor who police said was beaten and stabbed after confronting a man he accused of scrawling a swastika on his door in a Brooklyn boarding house. Abraham H. Foxman, ADL national director, said in a statement that the record numbers were disturbing, but not surprising considering ``the rise in hate-inspired violence generally around the country.'' The audit reflects incidents in 44 states and the District of Columbia, as reported to the ADL's regional offices and law enforcement officials. Among 1989's findings: _ A record 116 incidents of anti-Semitism in 24 states were attributed to neo-Nazi skinheads, 180 percent more than in 1988. Of the 144 people arrested in connection with anti-Semitic incidents in 14 states last year, 21 were identified as skinheads; 125 were under 21 years old. _ Anti-Semitic incidents on college campuses rose 30 percent in 1989, to 69 reported on 51 campuses; among the most serious was the October beating of two Jewish students at Brooklyn College on the eve of Yom Kippur. The ADL called for increased efforts by law-enforcement authorities to apprehend perpetrators; strict enforcement of anti-bias crime statutes; and community information and action programs.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Texan Sure to Kick up Dust in Governor's Race
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Boston University President John Silber's entry into the Massachusetts governor's race is only the latest in a lifetime of audacious acts. The 63-year-old transplanted Texan, who voted for presidents Reagan and Bush and has described himself as elitist and populist, announced Wednesday that he will seek the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. He said he can turn the crumbling Massachusetts economy around with a little old-fashioned grit and conservatism. ``In recent years, I have become increasingly dissatisfied with the direction of the Democratic Party,'' he said. ``It has become increasingly a party of very narrow special interests and single-issue politics.'' The governorship became a wide-open race a year ago when Michael S. Dukakis announced he would not seek another term when his third term expires at the end of 1990. Silber joins three others seeking the Democratic nomination: Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, former state Attorney General Francis Bellotti and state House Taxation Committee Chairman John Flood. Former federal prosecutor William Weld, state House Minority Leader Steven Pierce, former U.S. Rep. Paul Cronin and former Metropolitan District Commissioner Guy Carbone are among those seeking the Republican nomination. Silber, a man with no previous political experience, relishes change _ but his way. He can count among his admirers Henry Kissinger, who served with him on the National Bipartisan Commission on Central America. Kissinger said of Silber last year: ``When he first started, my only question was if I killed him, would it be considered murder or justifiable homicide? He is very fierce in his convictions. He takes no prisoners. I swore I'd kill him and then, as the weeks went by, I grew extremely fond of him.'' Silber has long defied the pigeonholers. He said that at the age of 10 he defended FDR to his father. But he also is fiercely anti-communist and favors U.S. intervention abroad. ``His views have been consistently arch-conservative on almost every single issue,'' Arnold Offner, a BU historian said recently of Silber, with whom he has had differences. ``His views are much more congenial with the Reagan part of the world than the Democratic Party on foreign policy.'' Silber's 95-year-old mother, who joined him at Wednesday's announcement, was a schoolteacher; his father, an architect who had emmigrated from Germany. They raised their son as a Christian; when Silber went to the University of Bonn on a Fulbright scholarship and after his father had died, he discovered his father was Jewish and a sister of his father's had died at Auschwitz. Silber, the father of seven children, was 44 when he took over Boston University 19 years ago after being fired as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at the University of Texas at Austin. He steadily transformed an academically uneven school burdened by a projected deficit of $8.8 million into one of the country's more respected private institutions. Last year, the 26,000-student school across the Charles River from MIT and Harvard boasted revenues of $464.8 million, an endowment of $183 million and a budget approaching $500 million. Silber did much of it through hard work. His office is open from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., with a staff that works in shifts to keep up with his 80-hour to 100-hour workweek. Silber has appointed nearly 90 percent of the current faculty, he has been faithful to those he has supported. He is disdainful of professors he believes are incompetent or lazy, and openly refers to them as ``third-raters.'' He was 5 years old before realizing his right arm was withered, he has said. Soon enough he also discovered the hard bone of the stub was useful in boyhood fights. He is an active Kant scholar, a frequent public speaker, and the author of a book published last year that is characteristically bold. Its title: ``Straight Shooting: What's Wrong With America and How to Fix It.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS BURBANK, Calif.-dated third item to UPDATE throughout with judge's decision.
DOC.TEXT: Adam West, the Caped Crusader in the ``Batman'' TV show, lost his dynamic duel against advertising agencies that produced a commercial using an actor who had his Bat moves down well. West, who still dresses up as Batman for public appearances, sought $900,000 in damages for invasion of privacy, unfair competition and unauthorized use of an endorsement. But Burbank Superior Court Judge Stephen O'Neil ruled Wednesday that the central issue was a contractual one that had nothing to do with West's portrayal of Batman. ``Adam West is a talented actor, but he was an actor, not the creator of Batman,'' O'Neil said. West, 59, said the actor in the commercial ``whirled as Adam West would whirl to go to the bat poles.'' The 30-second commercial was produced for Zayre, a Massachusetts-based discount store chain. Defendants were North Hollywood producers Ian Leech and Associates; Ingalls, Quinn and Johnson of Boston and the advertising agency BBDO New York. The defendants have said West holds no rights to his portrayal of Batman; DC Comics owns the rights. O'Neil said the advertising agencies involved in the commercial had paid DC Comics for the right to use the likeness of the Batman character. West had insisted the imposter trampled on his artistic expression. ``When you look at the Mona Lisa, you don't think of identifying the copy with the original,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Videotape Recounts Chilling Details in Murder for Hire Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A videotape showing a young man writhing in pain after being shot three times in the chest is a key piece of evidence against a man charged with two murders and the attempted slaying of his wife. Konstantinos Fotopoulos, 30, is charged with hiring two men to kill his wife, Lisa, 29, the daughter of a wealthy Greek immigrant. Court records show six mostly bungled attempts to kill her over five days. Mrs. Fotopoulos suffered a gunshot wound to the head in the final attempt on Nov. 4, but says she has recovered. Bryan Chase, the man allegedly hired to kill Mrs. Fotopoulos for $5,000, is dead, shot by Fotopoulos, who told police Chase was burglarizing his home and had shot his wife. Fotopoulos now is charged with the murder of Chase, of plotting his wife's killing and in the killing of 19-year-old Mark Kevin Ramsey, whose death was captured on videotape. Also charged is Deidre Michelle Hunt, who told authorities that she killed Ramsey while Fotopoulos videotaped the slaying. All involved in the case are barred from discussing it because of a gag order imposed by a judge who became incensed when he learned of re-enactments of parts of the case on the syndicated television shows, ``A Current Affair'' and ``Inside Edition.'' But search warrants, police affidavits and arrest reports unsealed Tuesday help complete a portrait of Fotopoulos. Daytona Beach police Lt. Charles Evens described the 57-second videotape of Ramsey's grisly killing in one of the court documents. ``The camera then pans to the face of Kevin Ramsey and then back to Deidre. She says, `Ready?' The male voice says, `OK.' With that, Deidre draws the gun from her right side, aims at the chest of Kevin Ramsey and fires three times into the chest. Kevin grunts with pain and says, `God.' He then says, `Ahhhh' and lifts his left leg in pain. With that, Deidre walks to him, grabs his hair, raises his head up and puts the gun to his left temple area and fires once more. Kevin falls forward and is silent. His hands can be seen tied behind him with rope. Video ends.'' The male voice was identified as Fotopoulos, who Evens said shot Ramsey in the head with a rifle. Ramsey was an employee of Fotopoulos, but the unsealed court documents give no motive for his killing. An indictment alleges that Fotopoulos hired Chase, 18, to break into his house and kill his wife. Then, thinking his wife had been shot to death, Fotopoulos allegedly killed Chase to silence him. Police initially thought Fotopoulos was a husband protecting his home and wife. But detectives noticed that Chase had entered the house through one of the few windows not hooked to an alarm system, had walked past bedrooms occupied by Mrs. Fotopoulos' mother and brother, ignored expensive stereo equipment and other property, and had gone straight to the couple's bedroom where he shot Mrs. Fotopoulos. The indictment says Ms. Hunt, 20, worked for Fotopoulos at Top Shots, a billiard hall he owned on Daytona Beach's boardwalk, arranged for the hiring of Chase and served as the contact between Fotopoulos and the hit men. She and Fotopoulos are charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of Ramsey and Chase; conspiracy to commit murder in planning the death of Mrs. Fotopoulos, Ramsey, and Chase; attempted first-degree murder, and solicitation to commit murder. Also arrested were Teja Mzimmia James, 22, and Yvonne Lori Henderson. They are charged with conspiracy to commit first-degree murder in the shooting of Ms. Fotopoulos; attempted first-degree murder, and solicitation to commit murder. All four are being held without bail.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Trial Date Set; Another Co-defendant Extradited
DOC.TEXT: A judge set an early March date for ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega's drug trafficking trial to open, but he expressed doubt that the timetable would be met. U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler set a March 5 date only when pressed Wednesday for a speedy trial by attorneys for one of Noriega's co-defendants, Luis del Cid. But Hoeveler, indicating the case's complexity, made it clear postponements were likely. ``We will set the date for that week,'' he said, ``but of course, there will be further motions and we will just have to see what will happen.'' On Tuesday, Noriega attorney Steven Kollin said that he and co-counsel Frank Rubino might need up to two years to prepare Noriega's defense. Rubino and Kollin refused to comment on the judge's ruling. ``Sam wants to try his case,'' was Rubino's only comment, referring to del Cid's attorney, Samuel Burstyn. Noriega, del Cid, and 14 others were named in a February 1988 federal grand jury indictment returned in Miami on drug, racketeering and money-laundering charges. Burstyn reminded Hoeveler that the judge still hadn't ruled on motions calling for separate trials for del Cid and several other co-defendants. Also Wednesday, Noriega's sole co-defendant in a separate Tampa marijuana trafficking indictment was extradited to the United States after surrendering to FBI agents in Panama. Enrique Pretelt, 47, a Panamanian businessman, was scheduled to appear today in a Tampa courtroom, according to Justice Department spokesman Michael W. Robinson in Washington. Pretelt is charged with trying to smuggle more than 1 million pounds of marijuana into the United States. In a separate development Wednesday, convicted Colombian cocaine kingpin Carlos Lehder said in an interview broadcast by NBC-TV that he and his associates paid Noriega millions of dollars for protection for about 10 years. In the interview, videotaped in November at the federal prison in Marion, Ill., for the West German magazine Stern, Lehder said Noriega took all drugs and drug paraphernalia seized in Panama and sold them to drug dealers in Colombia, Panama and the United States. Rubino refused to comment later Wednesday on Lehder's statements, saying he hadn't seen the broadcast. Hoeveler continued del Cid's bond hearing, giving Burstyn and co-counsel Kenneth Swartz, an assistant federal public defender, 10 days to respond to new evidence presented at the hearing by Assistant U.S. Attorney Myles Malman. The judge set no date for the bond hearing to be reconvened, and del Cid, 46, remained in custody without bond. Del Cid has pleaded innocent to charges he collected bribes and acted as a liaison between Noriega and drug traffickers. If convicted on all counts, del Cid faces up to 70 years in prison and fines of up to $550,000.

DOC.HEAD: Southwest Winter Weather Creeps Eastward
DOC.TEXT: The southern Rockies braced today for the storm system that dumped up to 2 feet of snow on Southern California's mountains earlier this week. Rain was expected along a front extending from Texas to Maine. Arctic air and flurries were forecast near Lake Superior, while cooler air crept into the Northeast. High pressure over the northern Rockies should move east and south, bringing variable clouds and cooler temperatures to the nation's midsection through Friday. More showers and thundershowers were expected to soak northeastern Texas across Arkansas to the Tennessee Valley. Wednesday thunderstorms left hail almost an inch in diameter near Waco, Texas. Northwestern Texas, western Oklahoma and southern Kansas looked for snow by tonight. Parts of western Texas and Oklahoma expected ice storms. Winter storm watches for tonight and Friday were called for in the Oklahoman and Texan panhandles and in northwestern Texas. Rain and flurries were predicted for Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. But NASA said the storm would leave later in the day, and conditions were expected to improve for Friday's planned space shuttle landing. Advisories for frost were posted over parts of southwestern California. A high wind watch was posted today in Utah's Cache Valley and Wasatch Front. Snowfall from Wednesday's western winter storm included 5 inches at Julian, Calif., and Panguitch, Utah. Record highs for Jan. 17 were set in the Pennsylvania cities of Allentown, Wilkes-Barre@Scranton and Williamsport with 61 degrees. DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds That Philadelphia Police Department Discriminated Against Woman
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury has awarded $2.44 million to the city's first female homicide detective and the four officers who supported her sex-discrimination complaint. Carol Keenan, 38, alleged she was the victim of a pattern of discrimination, and her colleagues argued they were transferred out of the homicide unit merely because they supported her. After two months of testimony, the U.S. District Court jury Wednesday awarded the five officers $640,000 in compensatory damages and $1.8 million in punitive damages. The largest part went to Keenan, now a detective in South Philadelphia. The jury awarded her $220,000 in compensatory damages and $600,000 in punitive damages. Keenan, who joined the police force in 1976, predicted the verdict will help other women in the department. ``The next woman who makes this kind of complaint won't be ignored _ they'll listen,'' she said. Keenan contended throughout the trial that she repeatedly tried to resolve the problem informally, but officials refused to take her complaints seriously. She filed the lawsuit in 1988, saying she was subjected to unusual scrutiny by Robert Grasso after he became commander of homicide. She also alleged discrimination led to her transfer from the unit in 1987. She was joined in the lawsuit by Lawrence Gerrard, Walter Smith, Ernest Gilbert and Daniel Rosenstein. The city planned to appeal. ``The verdict is totally out of proportion to justice, law and reality and will be appealed from now to infinity,'' said Deputy City Solicitor Richard G. Freeman. Jurors said they hoped their decision sends a message to the city. ``I would say there was simply little, if any, defense,'' said jury foreman Thomas Gilbert. Juror Harry Wilson Jr. said he hoped the verdict showed city police officials ``that they have to be fair in their treatment of all their employees, flat and simple.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The problems which have been accumulating for tens, no, for hundreds of years have erupted.'' _ Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in his first public comments on the worst strife in the southern USSR between the mostly Christian Armenians and mainly Moslem Azerbaijanis since the groups' decades-old feud over Nagorno-Karabakh erupted in violence two years ago.

``Oat bran is not the magic bullet that the food industry has led us to believe.'' _ Bonny Lieberman, director of nutrition at the Washington-based Center for Science in the Public Interest, after a study challenged oat bran's ballyhooed powers to lower cholesterol levels.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was stronger against key currencies in European trading this morning, and gold prices rose. Despite worse-than-expected U.S. trade figures announced Wednesday, analysts said traders were nervous over unrest in the Soviet Union and thus retreated to the traditional safe haven of buying dollars. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 145.66 yen, up 0.14 yen from Wednesday's 145.52-yen close. Later in London, the dollar traded at 145.72 yen. London's gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $413.60 bid per ounce this morning, compared to $409.75 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold traded at $413.80 per ounce, compared to $409.75 per ounce late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose the equivalent of $3.12 an ounce today, to close at $412.15. DOC.HEAD: Killer Executed As Last-Minute Appeal Fails
DOC.TEXT: Convicted killer Gerald Smith, who had said he wanted to die, was executed by lethal injection early today, becoming the second Missouri prisoner put to death in a quarter-century. Smith, 31, of St. Louis, was pronounced dead at 12:09 a.m., said Dick Moore, director of the Missouri Department of Corrections. Smith was executed for the 1980 beating death of Karen Roberts, his former girlfriend in St. Louis. In a letter to a newspaper, Smith said he murdered Ms. Roberts because he believed she gave him a venereal disease. Smith's wife, Lynn, watched the execution along with court-appointed defense attorney C. John Pleban. As the first lethal drug was administerred, Mrs. Smith raised her left hand and made a ``V'' sign. She mouthed, ``I love you.'' Smith became the 121st prisoner executed since the U.S. Supreme Court allowed states to resume carryuing out the death penalty in 1976. Death-penalty opponents made a last-ditch effort to save Smith's life by filing a motion Wednesday afternoon with the U.S. Supreme Court, but the court voted 7-2 to reject the appeal by the Missouri Capital Punishment Resource Center in Kansas City. Smith came close to execution several times before, but stays were issued as he changed his mind about whether he wanted to die. Last week, Associate Justice Harry Blackmun stayed an execution for Smith that was scheduled last Thursday to allow the court to consider motions by Pleban. But the full court lifted that stay on Tuesday, and the Missouri Supreme Court acted swiftly to schedule the execution. Smith also was under a death sentence for the 1985 slaying of fellow death-row inmate Robert Baker. Opponents of capital punishment gathered for prayer services at churches in St. Louis and Jefferson City. Gov. John Ashcroft was asked to reprieve Smith on Wednesday by the Missouri Coalition Against The Death Penalty. The governor's spokesman, Bob Ferguson, said Ashcroft would not interfere with the judicial process.

DOC.HEAD: SOFIA: reported today.
DOC.TEXT: Zhivkov was ousted Nov. 10 after 35 years in power and as this Balkan country was swept up by a peaceful popular revolt. He was replaced by more moderate Communists who are promising a transition to democracy. According to the announcement, a warrant was isued to ``remand in custody'' the ousted dictator and that a team of prosecutors has been assigned to conduct the investigation. The ousted leader is reportedly under government protection at a house near the capital of Sofia. While BTA said the prosecutor general had initiated preliminary investigative proceedings against Zhivkov, it also reported that he was charged with ``incitement of ethnic hostility and hatred, with unwarranted receiving of excessive amounts of public property and with gross malfeasance.'' BTA said the investigation was launched on the basis of materials supplied by a parliamentary commission of inquiry into the ``abuses and breaches of the law committed in the state, public and economic life by the previous regime.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: SOFIA: previous regime.''
DOC.TEXT: Zhivkov has been accused of abusing power by enriching himself at the people's expense, damaging the economy through cumbersome central planning and enforced discrimination against the country's ethnic Turkish minority. Under his forced assimilation policy, the ethnic Turks were forced to adopted ethnic Slavic names and their language and religious rites were banned. The new government overturned that policy on Dec. 29. Petar Mladenov, who took over from Zhivkov as Communist Party leader, has promised reforms and free elections this year. On Monday Parliament repealed the Communist's guaranteed monopoly on power, making Bulgaria the last Warsaw Pact country to formally do so. The party is still powerful, however, and opposition groups complain that it is not moving swiftly enough on reform.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Rock Hall of Fame, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0497,0714
DOC.HEAD: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inducts Newest Members
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Brothers Brian...', with one graf to DELETE reference to songwriters' influence on Motown in the '70s; they left label before then, and to DELETE reference to `Please Mr. Postman,' not by all three songwriters cited. ADDS final graf with background on how inductees are chosen. Rock and Roll, sted 'n', is cq in name of hall. Changes category code.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY15,NY17
DOC.TEXT: Paul Simon said he and Art Garfunkel would feel at home in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, noting that their relationship was rocky. ``We can join those other happy couples,'' he said at Wednesday night's induction ceremony. ``Ike and Tina Turner, the Everly Brothers, Mick (Jagger) and Keith (Richards), Paul (McCartney) and all of the other Beatles. ``Maybe they'll have a separate wing for all of us, probably completed in time for the Eagles to be in.'' Despite their breakups, Simon called Garfunkel ``my oldest and best friend'' more than once during his speech at the annual black-tie dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. While Simon and others celebrated, one inductee cried. Hank Ballard, who wrote ``The Twist,'' said he felt alone in accepting his award. He said his wife, who also served as his manager, was killed in a hit-and-run accident in New York three months ago. ``When she took me on four years ago, she swore she was going to take me back to the stars where I used to be,'' he said. ``It's tragic she's not here tonight with me.'' Besides Ballard, and Simon and Garfunkel, the acts inducted were the Four Tops; the Who; Bobby Darin, who died in 1973, best known for ``Splish Splash'' and ``Mack the Knife''; the Four Seasons; the Kinks; and the Platters. One of the songwriting teams honored, Gerry Goffin and Carole King, created their first hit ``Will You Love Me Tomorrow?'' for the Shirelles, and followed it with ``Up on the Roof,'' ``Loco-motion'' and ``Go Away Little Girl.'' Brothers Brian and Eddie Holland and Lamont Dozier, a creative cornerstone of the Motown sound of the 1960s, were honored for writing more than 70 Top 10 hits. Three of their 20 No. 1 hits were ``(Reach Out) I'll Be There,'' ``You Keep Me Hangin' on'' and ``Stop in the Name of Love.'' Three performers inducted for their early influences on rock 'n' roll were Louis Armstrong, Charlie Christian and Ma Rainey. Armstrong, who died in 1971, was a trumpeter and singer, and considered by some the greatest jazz musician of all time. Christian, who died in 1942, was a jazz guitarist, the first to play hornlike, single-string solos on electric guitar. Rainey, who died in 1939, recorded nearly 100 blues songs after 1923 and toured, popularizing the music. Stevie Wonder, inducting the Four Tops, said: ``If we could imagine ourselves as being the Four Tops and be able to come together with a sense of harmony and unity and make our own hits by doing the right thing for 36 years, this country would truly be written in the sands of time forever. ``Obie, Lawrence, Duke, Levi _ you truly are the sunshine of my life.'' The irreverent Kinks wore tuxedos to be inducted. ``Seeing everybody makes me realize rock 'n' roll has become respectable,'' Ray Davies said. ``What a bummer.'' Dodd Darin, only child of the late Bobby Darin, accepted the induction of his father from Paul Anka. ``He was very much into rock 'n' roll,'' Anka said of Bobby Darin. ``Because of him that form of music became much more acceptable to the listening public.'' Groundbreaking for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland is planned for this year with a projected 1992 opening. After the ceremony, about 60 musicians, including Bruce Springsteen, Roger Daltry and Peter Townshend of the Who, hopped up on stage for a jam session. Those considered for induction had recordings released by the end of 1964. Some 200 performers, producers, writers, record executives and broadcasters selected by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Foundation made the choices.

DOC.HEAD: Killing of Star Athlete Heads Soaring List of Washington Murders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead and 4th graf, Unger was, to update with overnight killing
DOC.TEXT: The murder of a star high school athlete, one of 18 killings since Friday in the nation's capital, is prompting President Bush to dub January ``the month of murder'' in the District of Columbia. As Bush was decrying the carnage in the district, students, coaches and faculty at McKinley High School on Wednesday mourned the killing of 18-year-old Samuel Unger, a basketball and football captain who was shot to death on Saturday. ``It's a very empty feeling, a horrible sensation,'' said Steve Milam, Unger's basketball coach. ``He was a well-rounded student and had the world ahead of him ... I hope that my son can grow up to be like him.'' Unger was one of 29 people killed in the nation's capital so far in 1990, including a woman whose body, bearing multiple stab wounds, was found in a parking lot early today. That rate is ahead of the pace that led to a record 438 murders in 1989. In 1988, 369 were killed in the district. ``We have seen great progress where it counts, in the streets, where record amounts of cocaine have been seized ... yet we have yet to turn the corner,'' Bush told a luncheon with the heads of federal law enforcement agencies. ``In this very city, January has been the month of murder, the deadliest month in the history of the District of Columbia,'' the president said. Last January, 52 people were killed in the nation's capital, including 18 in the first two and one-half weeks. Police blame more than 60 percent of the killings on drug-related violence. Police believe that Unger, who died after being shot in the head Saturday night, was the victim of a robbery attempt. He was killed less than a block from his home and one of the city's open-air drug markets. Police said he was not selling drugs. However, WRC-TV, citing law enforcement sources, reported that Unger had been arrested in December and charged with possessing cocaine with the intent to distribute. Unger was charged as a juvenile, the station noted in explaining why court records on the case remained under seal. Mayor Marion Barry said he and Police Chief Isaac Fulwood were working to come up with ways to help cut the surging homicide rate. ``We're going to do something different, I don't know what, but we're going to do it,'' Barry said Wednesday. ``We cannot continue to have people be killed on the streets of Washington, D.C.''

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Test Systems After Bad Signal Sends Ship in Spin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Bush; snow at landing area; new adjusted landing time.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1
DOC.TEXT: President Bush hailed the ``superb job'' of Columbia's astronauts today as they headed for Friday's homecoming after taking control of their ship when a bad navigation signal from the ground sent it into a slow spin. In a radio-phone call from the White House, the president termed their rescue of a huge science satellite ``a very exciting grab,'' and he invited the five crew members to meet with him at the White House after the mission. Commander Dan Brandenstein said the retrieval of the satellite was a highlight among several important accomplishments of the space journey. ``Well done _ we're proud of you,''' Bush said. The president also mentioned the erratic spin imparted to Columbia by the faulty signal when he said, ``I'm calling to congratulate you and the crew _ after all those somersaults _ for doing this superb job up there.'' Brandenstein had been roused from sleep during the night to manually override the shuttle's navigation system. He stabilized the craft until Mission Control transmitted correct guidance signals. There was no danger to the five astronauts, but ``we had a little excitement tonight,'' said flight director Bob Castle. After analyzing data, controllers reported that Columbia had made four rotations in yaw (side-to-side), one rotation in pitch (up-and-down of the nose and tail) and three-fourths of a rotation in roll. At times, they said, all movements were taking place simultaneously. Each rotation took two minutes, too slow for the astronauts to sense while asleep. Another flight director, Lee Briscoe, said it appeared that ``a couple of words got dropped'' in the navigation program, ``so the vehicle thought it was around the center of the Earth'' instead of repeatedly passing back and forth across the equator at a 28-degree angle. The incident happened Wednesday night, about 2{ hours before their scheduled wakeup. A false fire alarm also got them out of their beds Wednesday. A third wakeup, at the planned time, was music to their ears: a rendition of Washington and Lee University's fight song. One of the astronauts, David Low, is a graduate of the school. ``Good morning, Columbia, after what must have been a restful, or restless, night,'' the control center radioed. Brandenstein and pilot Jim Wetherbee successfully tested Columbia's flight control systems to make sure they were in good shape for returning home. During the 10-day mission the astronauts have deployed a Navy communications satellite and retrieved an 11-ton science laboratory that had orbited for six years. Snow was falling this morning at the landing site at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., and about an inch had covered the desert before dawn. Briscoe said forecasters were watching the weather closely, but ``it still looks good for tomorrow.'' The pre-dawn landing is scheduled at 2:54 a.m. PST. Recent heavy rains have closed the public viewing area, and the space agency discouraged citizens from driving to the base to watch the touchdown. While Brandenstein and Wetherbee checked the shuttle's systems, mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Marsha Ivins and Low completed a series of medical and science experiments and began stowing them away. Castle said Columbia began its slow spin after an errant navigation signal from the ground caused six small steering jets in the shuttle's nose to fire on and off, the longest for two minutes. That sent the shuttle into an unwanted spin of about 3 degrees a second, or about one rotation every two minutes, Castle said. He said the navigation data had suffered radio interference during the transmission, but that an operator on the ground failed to catch it. Castle said that if nothing had been done, Columbia would have continued to rotate at that rate, but there would be no threat to the astronauts. ``I'm concerned about what happened because we have to find out what happened and correct it,'' Castle said. ``But I'm not real concerned. It was an error on the ground. Columbia did exactly what Columbia should have done.'' NASA spokesman Jack Kroehnke said the astronauts would not have felt the spin imparted by the six thrusters, part of a system of 44 steering jets on the shuttle. ``If we had not awakened the crew, they'd eventually have awakened themselves, I'm sure, and looked out to see the Earth view changing in the windows,'' Kroehnke said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Suggests Coffee Drinkers Love Longer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to ADD that participants were not asked whether they drink regular or decaffeinated coffee and that the researcher says more study is needed. PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `Oh, Lord ...'
DOC.TEXT: Older couples who drink coffee appear to be more sexually active than elderly non-coffee drinkers, according to a new study. In response to a survey, 62 percent of married women 60 and older who drank coffee said they were sexually active. Forty percent of women older than 60 who do not drink coffee said they were active. Among married men the same ages, 36 percent of coffee drinkers said they sometimes were impotent, compared with 59 percent of those who don't drink coffee. The study in the January issue of the Archives of Internal Medicine did not give a margin of error or date for the survey of 744 Michigan residents done by Dr. Ananias Diokno of William Beaumont Hospital in the Detroit suburb of Royal Oak. Diokno, attempting to explain the results, said coffee stimulates the central nervous system and relaxes certain muscles. But he said it also was possible that people who drink coffee also happen to be ``more liberal in their sexual behavior.'' ``We want to pursue this and find out why there is this connection between sex and coffee,'' he said. The study team did not ask participants whether they drank regular or decaffeinated coffee or how much they drank, Diokno said. Some researchers were skeptical of the findings. ``Oh, Lord help us, now they've linked coffee and sex,'' said Gail Kershner Riggs, associate director of restorative medicine at the University of Arizona's College of Medicine, who has done her own research on sex among elderly women. ``Dr. Diokno is a respected researcher,'' said Dr. Tom Stanisic, a professor of surgery and urology at the University of Arizona College of Medicine in Tucson. ``But before anyone starts drinking coffee to boost their sex life, it would be wise if other people looked into this a little more. ``It's not something I would act on immediately.'' Coffee and caffeine are popular research topics; more than 500 studies on their effects have been published in medical journals since 1983. Some studies have linked coffee to heart disease, high cholesterol levels and pancreatic cancer, while others found no such relationship. Diokno's survey also found that about 75 percent of married elderly men and 56 percent of married elderly women remain sexually active, compared with 31 percent of unmarried elderly men and 5 percent of unmarried elderly women.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Seeks to Force Father of Bone Disease Victim to Donate Marrow
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose 4-month-old son has a rare bone disease is suing the child's father to force him to donate bone marrow to save the boy's life. The boy has osteopetrosis, which affects bone growth. The lawsuit filed Wednesday in Roanoke Circuit Court says the boy is expected to live six to 12 months if he does not receive a bone marrow transplant. Sue Argabright asked the court to force Sanford Andrew Moore to undergo tests to determine if can donate bone marrow to the couple's son, Andy. The lawsuit argues that Andy's biological father has ``a duty and obligation'' to undergo ``minimally intrusive tests'' and, if eligible, to donate bone marrow to his son. John Fletcher, director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Virginia, said forcing the father to donate bone marrow would set a bad precedent. ``Once you start to compromise donation by using force, then you have opened the door for a lot of other things, including selling organs,'' said Fletcher. ``The tradition in the United States for organ donation _ including donation between relatives _ is that it is a gift of life,'' said Fletcher. University of Virginia officials said they are searching bone marrow registries to find potential donors. The lawsuit says a biological parent is much more likely to be a suitable bone marrow donor than a stranger. However, Ms. Argabright was tested and was found to be an unsuitable donor, the lawsuit said. Ms. Argabright issued a public appeal for donations earlier this week, saying she could not afford to pay for the transplant, which doctors have told her could cost as much as $180,000. She said she gets no support money from Moore and has no private health insurance. It was not clear if Ms. Argabright and Moore have ever been married. Moore could not be located for comment. Someone answering his phone Wednesday said he would be out of town until Friday. Most of Andy's medical expenses so far have been covered by Medicaid, Ms. Argabright said, but the Virginia Medicaid program does not pay for transplants for children. Osteopetrosis prevents the body from breaking down and reforming bone. Bones become increasingly brittle and deposits build up, putting pressure on the optic and auditory nerves. Doctors say Andy probably will be blind and deaf by his first birthday.

DOC.HEAD: The People Still Wait For Signs of Promised Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 13-14 pvs, `According to...' to UPDATE with order to arrest Zhivkov. Pickup 15th pvs, `Parliament on...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: More than two months after hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov was ousted, signs of change are few in his hometown, a sleepy lakeside resort nestled among mountains northeast of Sofia. Like many Bulgarians, people in Pravec still harbor serious doubts that after more than 40 years of authoritarian rule the sweeping democratic reforms promised by Zhivkov's Communist successors will materialize in the near future. Skepticism appears to run deeper in the countryside than in the capital, Sofia. On a narrow, fir tree-lined lane, Zhivkov's family house _ one of over 30 luxurious residences he kept nationwide _ is shuttered up, the white-walled garden decked in snow untrodden for weeks. Hefty stone street signs that until recently bore the name of Zhivkov's mother, Marutsa Zhivkova, have been replaced by new plaques dubbing the road Vassil Levsky _ after Bulgaria's most revered national hero. In Sofia, tens of thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators have taken to the streets regularly since the former leader's overthrow Nov. 10, demanding quicker steps toward democracy from former foreign minister-turned-reformist leader Petar Mladenov. But Pravec, only 19 miles away, is another world. ``In principle there has been no change whatsoever,'' said Velin Ogledalov, chief cook at the pagoda-roofed Shatra restaurant, where Zhivkov often held state dinners for visitors that included former Romanian dictator _ and honorary Pravec citizen _ Nicolae Ceausescu. ``The Bulgarians are thinking: `We have taken a load off our shoulders,' but there is still fear,'' said Ogledalov. ``Department Six (secret police) used to be everywhere. And they're still there, only now they're smiling,'' he added. In early January, the burly 34-year-old set up Pravec's first independent trade union, which is campaigning for multiparty democracy, private enterprise and free-market economics. He claims he is not afraid, but often checks the restaurant dining room around him for eavesdroppers. ``The old leaders are all still there.
