Only the moment they start falling, can we begin making real changes,'' he said. The state news agency BTA reported today that Zhivkov was arrested and charged with malfeasance in office, among other charges. According to leading opposition figure Petar Beron, Zhivkov's family and cronies also will likely be tried. But he said a parliament-led commission investigating abuses of power during the clique's 35-year rule would probably stop short of unearthing evidence of corruption by other leading Communists who are ``very much still at large.'' Beron said Zhivkov was at his Boyana residence near Sofia, being ``protected from the wrath of the people.'' Parliament on Monday struck the Communists' guaranteed leading role in society from the constitution. East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary already have done so. But for the time being, the Balkan country still remains, at least constitutionally, ``a socialist state ... headed by the working class.'' Major steps toward democracy look far away in Bulgaria. ``All our neighbor countries are ahead of us now,'' said Emil Angelov, 21, a medical student fom Pravec. But he said he was optimistic that ``time will take its course _ if we really have free elections, (the Communists) will lose.'' Opposition leaders are not so sure. Zhelio Zhelev, president of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, says his group might not be prepared in time for the general elections Mladenov has pledged for May. Claiming the state-controlled media is still biased toward the Communists, Zhelev has called for two-stage elections, with a vote in May to eject close Zhivkov associates from Parliament followed by a full election in November. ``People feel freer, and we're trying for change, but all we've had up to now is the nationalities problem,'' said Angelov. Tensions flared between Bulgarian nationalists and the country's estimated 1.5 million ethnic Turks and Moslems after the country's new leaders on Dec. 29 reversed Zhivkov's harsh ethnic assimilation policy, which banned the use of Turkish names and language and Moslem religious rites. The decision sparked protests and strikes and brought about a national debate that distracted attention from calls for swifter political reform. Some opposition figures even have accused veteran local party officials of inciting hatred among the nationalists in an attempt to cling to power. ``It basically put our struggle for more democracy on ice and I can't see the process speeding up that much in the near future,'' said Zhelev. Both Ogledalov and Angelov said the tensions have been used to postpone painful decisions on Bulgaria's real problems _ its one-party system and its tattered, centrally-planned economy. In Pravec, a few inhabitants laugh and joke about Zhivkov now. But most are reluctant to talk about the man known familiarly as ``Toshko,'' whom Ogledalov remembers as ``jovial and hearty with a good sense of humor and a good network of bodyguards.'' Zhivkov made Pravec a Socialist showpiece, and its inhabitants were often resented for their pretty homes, clean air and well-stocked stores _ rarities in many Bulgarian towns. ``But we weren't privileged,'' said Ogledalov, ``Every month we had to scrub every inch of the town with our own hands before (Zhivkov) arrived.''

DOC.BYLINE: Mazowiecki Urges Early Democratic Local Goverment Elections ^By DRUSILLA MENAKER
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki asked parliament today to move up this year's democratic elections for local governments, the last bastion of Communist power in Poland. The radical economic and political reforms of the East bloc's first government led by a non-Communist are being slowed by resistance on the provincial and municipal level, and Mazowiecki said the voting should be held in April. The elections had been expected in June or November, but Solidarity leader Lech Walesa on Monday urged earlier balloting, saying reforms were not being carried out quickly enough. ``The government's most important task next to leading the nation out of economic collapse is the building of a strong and stable democratic foundation for a democratic system,'' Mazowiecki told the Sejm, the lower house of parliament. ``Until we create a real `self-government,' we will not defeat the resistance that we meet while introducing reforms,'' he said. The lawmakers showed their approval of Mazowiecki's views with a standing ovation. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist president, looked on from a gallery during Mazowiecki's 40-minute speech. Jaruzelski agrees with the new election timetable, the pro-Solidrity Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper reported Wednesday. Non-Communist candidates are expected to do well in the local and provincial elections. Solidarity candidates won an overwhelming victory in the partially free parliament elections in June, 1989 leading to creation of the Solidarity-dominated government that ended four decades of Communist control of Poland. On Jan. 1, the government began implementing reforms to create a market-oriented economy and curb inflation. Mazowiecki praised Poland as a leader of East bloc reform and ``a stabile point on the European map.'' ``Our society accepting with dignity and calmness the difficulties connected with the repairing of the economy arouses respect in many countries,'' he said. ``The course of our reform is giving stimulation to the changes in other countries of the region. The failure of our efforts could make more difficult the evolution occurring in Central and Eastern Europe,'' he said. East Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovkia, Bulgaria and Romania also are carrying out political reforms following popular uprisings of their own. Mazowiecki is to visit Czechoslovakia next week, and he urged closer alliance with the new Prague government. ``In close cooperation, our significance in Europe could be greater,'' he said. Polands' economic reforms include a tight wage policy as part of the attack on inflation. Prices are soaring, however, because they are no longer controlled by the government or kept artificially low by budget subsidies. Finance Ministry officials say it will take at least six months for prices to stabilize, and that the interim period will be difficult for workers. More than 6,000 miners demanding higher pay struck for a third day today at five mines in southern Poland, the official PAP news agency reported. The strikes are the first significant labor protest since the government began implementing the reforms. None of the mines currently on strike participated in the August 1988 protests that pushed then former Communist government to begin talks on political reform with the Solidarity-led opposition. The Solidarity trade union will open a six-day national congress on April 19, its first since before the 1981 martial law crackdown. Debate over the government's economic policy and possibly even Walesa's leadership can be expected during the congress, to be held in Gdansk where the union was born during an August 1980 Lenin shipyard strike. The Communist Party, which is struggling to maintain a role in Poland, will open a congress Jan. 27 and is expected to vote to form a new party based on the social democratic model, with a new name and a redefined program.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Says E. German Revolution Must Remain Peaceful
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with call for all secret police weapons to be turned in, demands for removal of former Communist chief's oath of secrecy. Pickup 14th pvs, `The protests...
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's top opposition group met with government officials today for the first time since demonstrators stormed secret police headquarters and said the nation's revolution must remain peaceful. The negotiators backed a resolution calling for all guns, grenades and other weapons belonging to the secret police to be turned over to the Interior Ministry by Jan. 31. They also proposed that the government nullify former Communist Party chief Egon Krenz's oath of secrecy, thus requiring him to give a complete account of secret police functions when he appears before the next session of talks Monday. Krenz cited the oath during earlier testimony before a commission investigating police brutality during demonstrations in October in East Berlin. At the start of today's session, the eighth between opposition groups and the government, New Forum issued a statement repeating the organization's ``insistence on a peaceful revolution.'' The government blamed New Forum, the largest opposition organization, for the rampage Monday of secret police headquarters in East Berlin. New Forum organized the protest outside the building but said it was to be peaceful, and it denied responsibility for the rampage. ``Even one hour of property damage is too much,'' it said. New Forum demanded to know who had opened the door to the complex to allow protesters inside. Many East Germans have said they suspect government infiltrators instigated the rampage to weaken the opposition before elections May 6. The 16 opposition groups, political parties and the Communists represented at the negotiations joined in a call for protesters to reject any violence in future protests. The demonstration Monday was to oppose the ``Stasi,'' or secret police, who under former hard-line leaders used strong-arm methods to suppress dissent. Premier Hans Modrow has promised the secret police agency will be completely dismantled by June. Krenz, who resigned in early December, on Wednesday faced a commission of the East Berlin city government that is investigating police violence during massive street protests Oct. 6 and 7. The protests coincided with the visit of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and were a turning point that led to the ouster of hard-line leader Erich Honecker 10 days later. Krenz said he accepted ``joint responsibility for falsely estimating dissident citizens and dissident groups for years.'' ``From today's viewpoint, that is incomprehensible,'' said Krenz, who succeeded Honecker and was himself ousted six weeks later. Krenz, whose appearance before the commission was broadcast on East German television, also said that the former ruling Politburo had failed to consider ``negative developments in society.'' Beginning last summer, tens of thousands of East Germans began to flee the country, while at the same time pressure built from those staying at home. Another former Politburo member, Guenter Schabowski, told the commission that Honecker, working closely with then secret police chief Erich Mielke, had personally ordered the attacks on the protesters. ``Honecker took things into his own hands,'' Schabowski told the panel. The panel members are investigating possible criminal charges against the ousted leaders. Honecker and Mielke are targeted for an indictment for high treason. No formal criminal investigation of Krenz has been announced.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlinologist Sees Gorbachev Retaining Power
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev faces an unstable situation in his country, but he will likely remain in power because few of his colleagues have an alternative program, says veteran diplomat George F. Kennan. Kennan, 86, said economic difficulties in the Soviet Union along with ethnic unheaval have ``created a situation of great difficulty and danger for Gorbachev, who is viewed as personally responsible for all these crises and difficulties.'' Kennan, a former ambassador to the Soviet Union and a professor emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Studies at Princeton, N.J., made his comments Wednesday in an appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. So great are Gorbachev's problems that it is unlikely he could have remained in office for so long had he not attained such international prestige, an important asset for the Soviet Union, Kennan said. Moreover, Kennan said, none of Gorbachev's senior colleagues has ``any program to offer as an alternative to the one he has created and carried forward.'' Kennan said it is in the interests of the United States to see that Gorbachev stays in power as he moves to ease Cold War tensions. To that end, Washington should consider suspending trade restrictions such as the Jackson-Vanik amendment that denies Most Favored Nation trade status and export credits to the Soviet Union and most other communist nations that restricted the right of their citizens to emigrate, he said. On a related issue, The Washington Post reported that President Bush plans to lift the Jackson-Vanik restrictions from Czechoslovakia. Kennan also said the United States could take a ``more forthcoming attitude'' on negotiations to reduce conventional arms in Europe, and should consult regularly with Moscow about questions arising from the ``momentous changes'' in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Steps Up Demand for Soviet Troop Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: Hungary today stepped up its demand for a quick withdrawal of Soviet troops from its soil and made a surprise proposal for sharp cuts in all foreign troops stationed in Europe. Ferenc Somogyi, state secretary of the Hungarian Foreign Ministry, made the proposals as part of East-West talks on reducing conventional armed forces in Europe. His plan goes well beyond the manpower limits suggested by President Bush in the negotiations between the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the seven countries of the Warsaw Pact. Hungary has previously called for the Kremlin to remove its troops, but Somogyi modified the demand by saying his nation wanted the soldiers out this year or next year at the latest. ``There are no reasons be it of political, military security or arms-control character that would justify the stationing of foreign troops on the territory of Hungary,'' he told a news conference. Hungarian Premier Miklos Nemeth recently met with Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov to arrange talks on the issue. Nemeth had stressed that withdrawal depended on an agreement at the Vienna talks on cutting conventional, or non-nuclear, forces in Europe. Czechoslovakia also wants all Soviet soldiers out this year. About 10,000 Soviet troops already have left Hungary and Czechoslovakia under the phased withdrawal of 50,000 men from Eastern Europe. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced that withdrawal in December 1988. An additional 6,000 of the 52,000 Soviet troops said to remain in Hungary are due to leave this year, and an undisclosed number are scheduled to leave Czechoslovakia, where officials say there are 70,000 Soviet forces. Somogyi told reporters that his proposal for East-West troop cuts does not set a ceiling on the number of foreign soldiers that could be stationed in another country in Europe. But, he said, the overall foreign troop deployment in Europe should be much lower than Bush's proposal calling for the United States and the Soviet Union to pare their forces in Europe to no more than 275,000 each. To meet the Bush proposal, the Soviets would have to pull out 300,000 troops and the United States 30,000. Somogyi said his plan would apply to troops of all countries, not just the superpowers. The Soviet Union has been talking about a limit of 300,000 to 350,000 troops stationed abroad by each alliance. As Somogyi spoke, top military officers from 35 nations met for a third day to discuss East-West military strategies. The three-week meeting is part of negotiations designed to reduce military tensions in Europe. On Wednesday, military officers of Czechoslovakia, Poland and East Germany who are attending that meeting emphasized their governments' defense concerns rather than those of the Warsaw Pact. The shift reflects the political changes that have swept the East bloc and the emerging individuality of nations. ``We proceed from the fact that our national interests are fundamental,'' said Gen. Anton Slimak, chief of Czechoslovakia's general staff. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, said some East-bloc governments seemed to be making ``unilateral judgments'' on the structure of their armed forces. ``Yet they continue to say they are part of an alliance. So I think the Warsaw Pact alliance is shifting in its character to a more political institution,'' he told a news conference. No country gave any indication in private talks that it was thinking of leaving the alliance, Powell said.

DOC.HEAD: National Gambling Network Raided in Three States
DOC.TEXT: Three men with alleged mob ties were charged with running a $335 million-a-year sports betting network that used a nationwide toll-free number and fax machines to accept wagers, police said. Alleged kingpin Alfred Mart, 72, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and 40 other people were arrested on felony gambling charges during raids Tuesday and over the weekend in New York City, Point Pleasant, N.J., and Florida. Mart also was charged with racketeering, said New York police Inspector Frank Biehler. Biehler gave details of the case at a news conference Wednesday where investigators displayed a duffle bag containing gambling records and $1 million in $100 bills. Investigators also seized $700,000 in cash from three safe-deposit boxes, and froze $300,000 in deposits at New York City banks. The raids were timed for the heightened gambling during the National Football League playoff games, which took place last weekend, Biehler said. Mart's alleged chief lieutenants in New York were identified as Joseph Yedbovnick, 70, and Martin McDarby, 65, both of the New York borough of Queens. They were charged with felony gambling. All three were identified as associates with the Genovese crime family, Biehler said. ``We believe Yedbovnick and McDarby are `bookmaker's bookmakers.' They would not in our opinion accept anything that would be termed a small wager,'' Biehler said. Gambling records seized during the raids revealed numerous wagers of $25,000 to $50,000 and indicated the ring was doing $335 million worth of business a year, the inspector said. He said the ring laundered money through a check-cashing service in Florida, and instructed losing bettors to wire their money in amounts smaller than $10,000, to circumvent a federal law that requires information about checks over that amount. Biehler said the ring passed itself off as a legitimate business to obtain the toll-free number. ``Fax machines and WATS lines and toll-free numbers are not unknown in a lot of forms of criminality. As technology increases, the criminals certainly take advantage of it too,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Plans to Mothball Battleships Iowa and New Jersey, Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 8th graf, The Navy, with Iowa captain announcing retirement plans
DOC.TEXT: The Navy plans to mothball the battleships Iowa and New Jersey in a money-saving move that would leave only two active battleships, a Defense Department official says. The Iowa, which was damaged in the April 19 explosion that killed 47 sailors, would be repaired before being mothballed, the official said Wednesday night. ``It's as good as done,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But he conceded that political pressure from New York City, where the Navy had planned to base the Iowa, could cause another ship to ``be thrown into the pot'' to replace that one at that new base, now about 70 percent complete. It had been known previously the Navy would seek to mothball two battleships, but it was not known which two would be chosen. If the mothball plan is carried out, the Navy would retain one battleship, the Wisconsin, in the Atlantic Fleet, and one in the Pacific Fleet, the Missouri. Figures on how much the Navy expects to save by mothballing the ships were not immediately available. The Iowa explosion occurred when the middle 16-inch gun in the battleship's three-gun No. 2 turret exploded during firing practice in the Atlantic. The Navy has said the explosion was most probably the work of a member of the gun crew trying to commit suicide, a conclusion strongly opposed as unsupported by many members of Congress. Meanwhile, the Iowa's commanding officer, Capt. Fred J. Moosally, on Wednesday announced plans to retire after 24 years of Navy service. Moosally had received a non-punitive letter of caution last fall for ``administrative deficiencies'' aboard the ship but it was not made part of his permanent file. Moosally said of his reason for retiring: ``There's a lot of things, but I'm not going to get into specifics. I thought about staying in. That was an option.'' The Iowa entered the Norfolk, Va., Navy Yard earlier in the week for a 14-week refit that will cost $26 million and restore the crippled turret to full operation. In addition to the structural, electrical and equipment repairs needed in the turret, the Navy also plans to overhaul pumps, freshwater and saltwater piping, gunfire-control equipment, electronic equipment and steam, fuel and water valves. Under a plan to disperse the battleships, attacked by critics as pure pork-barrel politics, the Navy planned to base the Iowa and its four or five smaller escorting frigates and destroyers at a new base on Staten Island in New York City, and the New Jersey at Long Beach, Calif. The official gave no indication what would happen to the facilities lined up for the home ports. Commenting earlier this week on the possibility that the Iowa would be mothballed, Guy Molinari, borough president of Staten Island who has just resigned as the area's Republican congressman, said, ``It is my educated guess ... that we probably will not have the Iowa but we will have a surface action group coming to Staten Island and it will be a different configuration of vessels.'' Current plans call for the Wisconsin to be based at Corpus Christi, Texas, and the Missouri's group of ships to be split between Pearl Harbor, Hawaii and Long Beach. The New Jersey and the Iowa are the two older ships, launched during World War II in 1942 and entering service the following year. All four ships saw action in that war, served through the Korean War years and were mothballed in the 1950s. The four ships were brought out of mothballs starting in 1982, despite criticisms that they would be extravagantly expensive to operate because of the large crews needed _ 65 officers and 1,453 enlisted men each. If the New Jersey, which fired at targets in Lebanon in 1982, is returned to the inactive fleet, it will be for the third time. The ship also was used and deactivated during the Vietnam war. The ships are 887 feet long and displace 58,000 tons. In addition to 16-inch guns, they carry Tomahawk cruise missiles, Harpoon anti-ship missiles, 12 5-inch guns and four rapid-firing 20mm anti-aircraft guns for close-in defense.

DOC.HEAD: Mick Jagger and Longtime Companion Jerry Hall to Marry
DOC.TEXT: After two kids and 12 years together, Jerry Hall said today that she and Rolling Stone Mick Jagger will get married. She didn't say when _ but neither did Jagger when he announced, in 1983, that they would be tying the knot ``any day now.'' ``For the first time, we both think marriage is a good thing,'' Ms. Hall told reporters at the Lyric Theater, where she will be starring in ``Bus Stop,'' with singer Shaun Cassidy. The Texas-born model and actress refused to confirm that her large diamond ring was an engagement present from the rock singer, who is in the Caribbean. ``He gives me a ring like this about once a year,'' she said. Hall and Jagger have two children: Elizabeth Scarlett, 5, and Leroy Augustine, 3. Ms. Hall appeared in ``Bus Stop'' in 1988 in New Jersey, and the British production will open next week in suburban Watford before moving to London in February.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Defends Statement on Settling Occupied Lands
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today defended his statement that Israel must hold onto the occupied territories to settle large numbers of Soviet Jewish immigrants. The United States criticized the statement Sunday, but Shamir said it overreacted. Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc, said the statement was in line with his belief that Israel should never return the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in exchange for peace with Arab neighbors. ``Everyone knows what my positions and the positions of the Likud are concerning the future of Israel,'' he said in an interview with Israel radio. A peace settlement with the Arabs should not contain a territorial compromise, Shamir said. ``The country is very small. No new division can solve problems. It will just create problems,'' he said. In a speech Sunday, Shamir said Israel needs the occupied lands to settle an influx of Soviet Jews. U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler termed Shamir's suggestion ``not helpful.'' ``We do not think that building settlements or putting even more settlers in the territories promotes the cause of peace,'' Mrs. Tutwiler said in Washington. Asked whether his statement provided ammunition to Arab leaders seeking to pressure the Soviet Union to halt Jewish emigration, Shamir said: ``Arabs oppose all immigration, regardless of what has been said or not been said. For them, the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel in large numbers is a sign of defeat ... in their war against the state of Israel and Zionism.'' Moslem fundamentalists in the occupied lands today distributed leaflets urging Palestinians to increase resistance to Israeli rule to protest the arrival of Soviet Jews. ``Palestine is screaming,'' said the leaflet circulated by the Hamas, or Zeal, movement. ``America supports the Jewish state with money and weapons, and Russia is feeding Israel with people and experts. So where are the Moslems?'' Fewer than 100,000 Israelis have settled among some 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which Israel captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. As many as 100,000 Soviet Jews are expected to come to Israel this year. Jordan's King Hussein expressed alarm over Shamir's statement in an interview published today. ``Who will these thousands of immigrants replace, and what will happen to those who will be replaced by these new arrivals?'' Hussein told the Jordan Times newspaper. He indicated the settlement of immigrants could lead to mass expulsions of Palestinians to Jordan, which Israeli extremists argue is already a Palestinian state. Shamir today also criticized as ``very harmful'' a proposal by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, who said a 5 percent cut in U.S. aid to big recipients such as Israel would free funds to help fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe and Latin America. Israel receives $3 billion a year from the United States, more than any other country. Shamir said the Dole proposal comes at a time when Israel is seeking more aid from the United States to help in the absorption of Soviet immigrants. He said he did not believe the Dole statement was intended to press Israel to make concessions in Middle East peace efforts. The process is deadlocked because of Israel's insistence on written U.S. guarantees that the PLO be kept out of peace talks. PLO chief Yasser Arafat has threatened to resign if the U.S.-brokered peace efforts fail. In an interview published today, he said the problem is a result of Washington coddling Israel, and he said Arabs should use oil as a weapon to force concessions from the United States. Arafat told the magazine Al-Mussawar he will announce his resignation if the peace efforts reach a dead end.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor: Harlem's Death Rate A `National Disgrace'; Worse Than Bangladesh's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to CORRECT that doctors reviewed records form 1979 to 1981, sted 1978 to '81; CORRECT 4th graf pvs that Harlem death among men under 65 more than double that of U.S. whites, sted overall death rate. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `To dramatize...'.
DOC.TEXT: Harlem should be declared a health disaster area, according to a doctor whose study found that a man in Harlem has a worse chance of living past age 40 than one in poverty-stricken Bangladesh. ``We have a chronic disaster area right in front of our eyes that most people are not aware of,'' said Dr. Harold P. Freeman, director of surgery at Harlem Hospital. The report published in today's New England Journal of Medicine was compiled by Freeman, 56, and Dr. Colin McCord, 61, who worked in Bangladesh between 1972 and 1980 and noticed after returning to the United States that the mortality rates were worse in Harlem. The doctors reviewed records from 1979 to 1981 and found that the death rate among men under 65 in Harlem was the highest in New York and almost three times that of white U.S. men under 65. ``It's a national disaster and a national disgrace,'' said McCord, attending surgeon at Harlem Hospital. McCord said no formal study has been done through the 1980s, but a review of records from 1980 to 1987 shows deaths continued to increase with the onset of AIDS, crack, homelessness and increased use of illegal drugs. He said that during the seven-year stretch, deaths among those 25 to 45 years old rose 35 percent in Harlem. The findings of the formal study based on 1979 to 1981 figures stem from an analysis of New York's central Harlem health district, where 96 percent of the population is black and 41 percent live below the poverty line. The researchers found that 2,095 men under 65 died in Harlem from 1979 to 1981. If the death rate in Harlem had been the same as for white men under 65 across the United States, the number of deaths would have been only a little more than one-third as high _ 720. Among all Harlem residents, the death rate was more than 50 percent higher than the death rate for all U.S. whites, the researchers found. To dramatize their figures, the researchers compared them with Bangladesh. By age 40, the life expectancy of men in Bangladesh begins to exceed that of Harlem men. In Bangladesh, 55 percent of men and 50 percent of women live to age 65. In Harlem, 40 percent of men and 65 percent of women live that long. Freeman said the five-year survival rate of women who learn they have cancer in Harlem is 32 percent, but it is 75 percent for white women elsewhere in America. He blamed the results on lack of education, poor access to health care, substandard housing, isolation, alienation, a tendency to live day to day and malnutrition. Reacting to the study, a spokeman for Mayor David Dinkins said the city, already financially strapped, needs federal help after years of reduced health care during President Reagan's administration. ``Our hope would be in a kindler, gentler world that there'd be a greater federal involvement in financing the health system,'' Lee Jones said.

DOC.HEAD: Roofing Nails Put Dent In Police Speed Traps
DOC.TEXT: Someone apparently bent on taking the wind out of a police crackdown on speeders has been puncturing tires on patrol cars and motorcycles by sprinkling the officers' highway hideaways with roofing nails. Since May, more than 40 tires on patrol cars and motorcycles have been flattened by the roofing nails, authorities said Wednesday. After it happened more than once, Westminster police figured they were targets of booby-traps placed by someone who knew just where officers would park while looking for speeders. ``It was just too coincidental,'' said police spokesman Rick Kempsell. The latest incident occurred Wednesday on a ramp leading to westbound U.S. 36. Two tires on a police car were punctured. Police estimated 300 to 500 of the small nails were scattered along the ramp's shoulder, less than a quarter mile from police headquarters. Roofing nails also have been found scattered near emergency vehicle turnaround areas along the turnpike and Interstate 25. The three-quarter-inch mails have flattened at least 30 patrol car tires and ruined at least a dozen police motorcycle tires since May. Car tires can be repaired, but the motorcycle tires must be replaced at a cost of $127 apiece. Police said there's no way to know how many passing motorists also have had tires flattened by the nails.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Mayor Shot in Nagasaki
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to ADD past statements of suspect re terrorism, background on rightists in Japan. Pickup 10th pvs, `It was...
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Nagasaki, the target of death threats since he said Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot and wounded today. Police said they arrested the leader of a rightist group. The 67-year-old mayor, Hitoshi Motoshima, was rushed to surgery at Nagasaki Public Hospital after being shot in the back outside Nagasaki's City Hall. Doctors told Japan Broadcasting Corp. (NHK) television a bullet pierced his left lung, but he was not in serious condition. About five hours after the attack, police said they had arrested a man who confessed to shooting the mayor. Police identified him as Kazumi Tajiri, 40, of Tokyo, and said he was arrested at a hotel in Nagasaki, a city 600 miles southwest of Tokyo. A police spokesman described Tajiri as the leader of a rightist group called Sane Thinkers' School. Rightist groups in Japan venerate the imperial family and are strongly anti-Communist. They draw much of their inspiration from the militarism that prevailed before World War II. The police official said the Sane Thinkers' School has about 30 members in Nagasaki, more than any other rightist group in the city. It was established nine years ago, and some members have been arrested in the past for shooting at a district court judge and for other crimes, said the police official. City spokesman Megumi Nobeta said the mayor was shot as he was about to get into his car. The attack left a pool of blood in the street beside the car. The Kyodo News Service quoted witnesses as saying the gunman, a slim man wearing a dark brown suit, came out of City Hall and shot Motoshima at close range. Television showed Tajiri after he was arrested, and then broadcast a video of a 1987 interview in which Tajiri condoned terrorism. Asked in the 1987 interview if he would kill somebody he hated, Tajiri responded, ``Yes, because after all, right-wingers are terrorists.'' The comments were made after a 1987 shooting in which a reporter for a liberal-leaning newspaper was killed. Chief Cabinet Secretary Mayumi Moriyama said today's shooting was ``an extremely cruel crime, and it will have a strong impact on society.'' It was the first time a politician had been shot in Japan since World War II, National Police Agency records showed. But the records showed 25 previous attacks on key politicians by rightists using knives, swords, explosives or fists, the agency said. Such attacks, while not common, give credence to threats by rightist groups. The most dramatic was in 1960 when a right-wing student, in an assault at a Socialist Party rally that was being televised, stabbed party chairman Inejiro Asanuma to death on stage. Motoshima has been receiving threats from ultra-nationalists and others since December 1988, when he said at a city assembly session he believed Hirohito, then on his deathbed, ``shares responsibility for the war, as well as all of us who lived in that period.'' Motoshima said Hirohito could have ended World War II sooner and perhaps spared Nagasaki from the atomic bomb. Nagasaki was hit by an atomic bomb Aug. 9, 1945, three days after Hiroshima became the first city to be hit by a nuclear weapon. The mayor's comments enraged fringe groups that reject any criticism of the imperial family, and Motoshima continued to receive threats even after Hirohito's death one year ago. In December, a right-wing doctor, 62-year-old Shigeru Kajiyama, was sentenced to two years in prison for threatening to kill the mayor. Testimony at his trial said he had sent three anonymous letters containing live bullets to the mayor. In January 1989, a rightist was arrested after breaking into City Hall with a knife intending to force Motoshima into retracting his statement. Early last year, rightists mobilized about 100 sound trucks to circle City Hall and blare slogans denouncing the mayor. Police at one time had about 1,200 officers deployed to prevent trouble in the city. NHK reported that police had relaxed their special guard on Motoshima at the end of 1989 and no longer had officers following him when he was outside his office or home. Though the rightists made a great deal of noise, supporters of the mayor's position sent him a petition with some 286,000 signatures in April calling for more freedom to express opinions, even on taboo subjects such as the late emperor's war responsiblity. While many scholars believe Hirohito was a figurehead and the militarists made all important decisions during the war, the emperor was the nominal commander in chief and approved key decisions. Critics say Hirohito could have ended the war sooner, but during his life the late emperor never gave much detail on his role during the war. Motoshima was an independent supported by the long-governing Liberal Democratic Party, but his remarks on the emperor estranged him from the Liberal Democrats, who sent a delegation demanding he retract his opinion. He refused.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Drops Defamation Countersuit in Cincinnati Wiretap Trial
DOC.TEXT: A judge dismissed a lawsuit against the phone company by two former installers who say they were ordered to perform 1,200 wiretaps, but also made it tougher for the company to win its defamation case against the two men. Hamilton County Common Pleas Court Judge Fred J. Cartolano on Wednesday declared all the participants in the case public figures, which raises the standard of proof necessary for the jury to find defamation occurred. Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co., its parent, Cincinnati Bell Inc., and phone company managers James West and Peter Gabor accused Leonard Gates and Robert Draise of defamation for saying they were ordered to perform 1,200 wiretaps between 1972 and 1984. Gates and Draise, claiming they were injured because Bell officials called them liars, countersued. The judge dismissed the countersuit, ruling Wednesday that Gates and Draise failed to prove they were injured based on their status as public figures. The trial on the suit and countersuit has been going on for seven weeks. Closing arguments on the remaining issues were expected to begin today. The law says a public figure must prove he was libeled through a reckless or malicious disregard of the truth. A private figure must show only that an allegation was untrue, and that the person making it was careless in finding out whether it was the truth. Draise and Gates became public figures ``by injecting themselves into a public controversy,'' Cartolano said. ``They said they intentionally used the press to get their story out.'' Bell also qualifies as a public figure, Cartolano said. To rule otherwise ``would have a chilling effect on the community,'' because people would be afraid to criticize the company, he said. West and Gabor are public figures ``as agents of their employer'' and because they participated in a news conference Bell held last year in an attempt to refute Gates' and Draise's charges, Cartolano said. Bell contends Gates and Draise lied to get revenge against the company because they were fired for other reasons. Gates was fired in 1986, and Draise in 1979. Gates and Draise said they started doing the wiretaps for members of the Cincinnati police intelligence squad about 1972 and a few years later began getting their orders from West and Gabor. The taps originally were done on suspected criminals, but later included judges, lawyers, business and political leaders, police and journalists, according to Gates and Draise. Several former members of the police intelligence squad have admitted using Gates and Draise to do illegal taps in the early 1970s. But Bell, West and Gabor deny any knowledge of the activity.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0465, PM-Washington in Brief, second item, concerning computerized Supreme Court opnions, sent Jan. 17 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press article Jan. 17 incorrectly identified the members of a consortium that will provide the necessary equipment for dissemination of Supreme Court opinions via computer to media and legal organizations. Among the members of the consortium, called the Supreme Court Opinion Network (SCON), are the American Bar Association, C-SPAN cable television network, Knight-Ridder, Mead Data, United Press International and The Washington Post. The Associated Press is not part of SCON, although it intends to receive the opinions electronically from the court and make them available to its membership.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Airplane Hijacking Charged
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of trying to hijack an America West airplane to Cuba told a federal magistrate that he wanted to apologize to passengers and to the stewardess he's charged with assaulting. ``They were never in any danger,'' Jose Manuel Gonzalez-Gonzalez told U.S. Magistrate Stephen Capelle at his arraignment Wednesday. ``I took this course out of desperation.'' Gonzalez-Gonzalez, 39, of New Orleans, was charged with aircraft piracy and assaulting stewardess Stacey Wood in Tuesday night's incident aboard Flight 727 from Houston to Las Vegas, carrying 34 passengers and five crew members. Passengers said he grabbed Ms. Wood, announced he had a bomb and demanded to go to Cuba. The pilot landed the Boeing 737 in Austin, saying he had to refuel to make it to Cuba. Gonzalez-Gonzalez, a native of Cuba, said he came to the United States when he was 11 years old. He said he was not a U.S. citizen. After the plain landed at Austin's Robert Mueller Municipal Airport, Gonzalez-Gonzalez allowed the passengers and three of the crew members to leave the plane. He was apprehended by a police officer who climbed up an emergency chute and overpowered him, police said. No bomb was found. ``The facts speak for themselves. I'm guilty as charged,'' Gonzalez-Gonzalez told Capelle. ``My intention was to leave this country. I was being chased with constant threat of being murdered.'' He said someone wanted to silence him for things he knew, but did not elaborate. A criminal complaint, signed by FBI agent James Echols, said Gonzalez-Gonzalez told another FBI agent he thought U.S. authorities were hunting him. If convicted of the air piracy charge, he faces 20 years to life in prison. The assault charge carries a maximum 10-year prison term, Echols said. Capelle said he would appoint an attorney for Gonzalez-Gonzalez and ordered him held pending a Jan. 25 detention and bond hearing.

DOC.HEAD: News Clipping Betrays Fugitive
DOC.TEXT: A fugitive convicted of sex abuse charges was tripped up after police in another state arrested him on charges of failing to pay child support and found a clipping mentioning his ``most-wanted'' status in his pocket. Michigan state police arrested Curtis L. Howard, 45, in Detroit on Jan. 8 on charges of not paying child support. When they searched his pockets, they found he had been convicted for sexually attacking a 12-year-old girl and was on the Onondaga County Sheriff's Department list of 10 most wanted felons. Detective Ed Carravallah of the Wayne County Sheriff's Department in Michigan said he isn't sure why Howard carried a clipping indicating he was a fugitive. ``Maybe that was his 15 minutes of fame,'' Carravallah said. He said they didn't bother to file the child support charges. Howard was brought to Syracuse from Michigan on Wednesday by investigators with the Onondaga County Sheriff's Department, according to department spokesman Robert Burns. Burns said Howard would appear before County Judge William Burke for sentencing on his April 1988 conviction of two counts of first-degree sexual abuse and three counts of endangering the welfare of a child. Howard fled before he could be sentenced, Burns said. Each of the first-degree counts is punishable by a maximum term of seven years in prison, Burns said. Howard carried a New York state driver's license, but told police he was a Detroit resident.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Bans West Beirut Papers in Christian Enclave
DOC.TEXT: Maverick Gen. Michel Aoun today stepped up his drive to gag the press by banning papers published in Moslem west Beirut from newsstands in the Christian enclave after they defied his orders. Aoun's troops prevented a truck carrying copies of the French-language L'Orient-Le Jour from entering the Christian sector. The daily did not heed a directive Aoun issued Tuesday banning the media from referring to Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi as head of state. An official of the Lebanese Distribution Co., which delivers the newspaper to newsstands in the Christian enclave, said a captain of Aoun's army told the truck driver, ``L'Orient-Le Jour is banned for not abiding by the general's directives.'' The distribution official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, quoted the captain as saying: ``You call Hrawi president, so go and sell the paper in Hrawi's territory.'' L'Orient-Le Jour and An-Nahar, the nation's most prestigious daily, were the only two papers based in west Beirut that Aoun had allowed to be sold in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave northeast of the capital. An-Nahar has not been publishing since Wednesday morning in protest of Aoun's order. Aoun's directive said Hrawi should only be referred to as a former parliamentary deputy, noting that Aoun had declared parliament dissolved to prevent the election of a Syrian-backed head of state in November. He also ordered the media to stop referring to Salim Hoss as prime minister. Hrawi was elected president under an Arab League peace plan to end Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war, which has killed more than 150,000. Hrawi immediately dismissed Aoun as prime minister and army commander, but the defiant general held out in the Christian enclave, refusing to leave the presidential palace. Aoun opposes the peace plan because it does not call for the immediate withdrawal of all Syrian troops from Lebanon. The Phalangist Voice of Lebanon radio and the Voice of Free Lebanon, owned by the Lebanese Forces Christian militia, maintained a newscast strike for a third day to protest Aoun's directive. The Lebanese Broadcasting Corp., the television station of the Lebanese Forces, did not broadcast news Wednesday evening for a second day. The conservative newspaper Ad-Diyar, the leading daily in the Christian enclave, has been the only publication to defy Aoun. It was missing from newsstands today, a day after the prosecutor general in Aoun's area of influence ordered it to stop publishing for a week. Police ringed Ad-Diyar's offices in Beirut's Christian district of Hazmiyeh Wednesday evening, delivered a subpoena to publisher-editor Charles Ayoub. The police then withdrew. Prosecutor-General George Ghanem said he has started legal proceedings against Ayoub on a charge of ``infringement on national sovereignty,'' punishable by up to five years in prison. Ayoub told The Associated Press by telephone Wednesday that he was subpoenaed to appear before a military examining magistrate within 48 hours. An editorial that appeared Wednesday on Ad-Diyar's front page said that following Aoun's directive would mean ``suffocation ... it is a serious beginning to limiting the freedom of the press.'' The leftist newspaper As-Safir, which operates from west Beirut, said Aoun's news ban was the ``first step in a series of measures that the general wants to apply. He'll partition the unions, the economy and everything in Lebanon.'' The Syndicate of Newspaper Publishers under Mohammed Baalbaki, a Sunni Moslem, called for a day of solidarity with the press in Lebanon on Saturday and urged all Lebanese to express their rejection of ``police rules.''

DOC.HEAD: Wave of Illnesses Swamps D.C. Hospital Emergency Rooms
DOC.TEXT: An increase in respiratory diseases, particularly the flu, has forced the brief closings of emergency rooms at three District of Columbia hospitals in the past week, officials say. ``This is a problem that we are having throughout the city that for reasons that are related to the flu, to pneumonia, to an increased number of persons who are asthmatic and perhaps other factors which we are not completely aware of yet,'' Dr. Reed Tuckson, the District health commissioner, said Wednesday. The outbreak is the worst in several years, he added. Providence Hospital closed its emergency rooms Wednesday night and remained closed today because the 358-bed facility was swamped with patients, particularly the elderly, complaining of respiratory ailments, officials there said. ``We're almost always very crowded, especially January and February because people are generally sicker,'' said Terry Harnett, spokeswoman for Providence Hospital. ``Plus we are in a neighborhood with a high concentration of elderly.'' The emergency room of D.C. General Hospital, the city's public hospital, shut down from Tuesday evening until about 8 a.m. Wednesday morning because of shortage of beds for additional patients, Tuckson said. Over the weekend, Providence Hospital and Capitol Hill Hospital emergency rooms were closed for short periods. Tuckson said Washington hospital officials agreed Saturday on joint action to deal with the influx of patients. The health commissioner maintained that patients are being treated and the brief closings are not leaving ``the city in trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Hero Postman Gets Rebuke From Postal Service For `Lapse In Safe Practice'
DOC.TEXT: A postman who injured his shoulder when he knocked down a door and rescued two children from a burning building was reprimanded for a lapse in ``safe work practices'' _ but his boss says it was all a mistake. ``I got a letter chewing me out for getting hurt on the job,'' said Lodi postman Raymond Kaulfers, 49. But the reprimand was a mistake, Postmaster William B. Thomas acknowledged today. He said the wrong form letter had been sent to Kaulfers after the Dec. 26 rescue. Thomas, who oversees most post offices in Bergen and Passaic counties, said the U.S. Postal Service sent Kaulfers a letter of apology Wednesday. ``We begged his forgiveness and sent him an achievers' pin indicating he behaved in the highest standard of the Postal Service,'' Thomas said. The original letter said: ``It is my responsibility to provide safe working conditions and to develop a safe work force. It is your responsibility to adhere to safe work practices.'' Kaulfers said he did ``what everybody else would have done'' in rescuing the children.

DOC.HEAD: Kremlin Calls Up The Reserves To Deal With Caucasus Chaos
LaserPhoto NY4, LaserColor NY101 ^Eds: New thruout to ADD quotes from Gorbachev, sabotage in Nagorno-Karabakh, Azerbaijanis crossing border into Iran.
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin boosted military units to wartime strength in several regions and called up reservists in its struggle to end ethnic strife in two southern republics, the defense minister said today. The minister, Dmitri Yazov, called the Armenian-Azerbaijani warfare, which has left at least 66 people dead and more than 200 wounded, ``a great disaster.'' Most of the victims have been Armenians attacked by mobs in the Azerbaijani capital, Baku. Terrorized Armenians were said to still be fleeing by the thousands. Soviet troops ordered in Tuesday to enforce a state of emergency have become caught up in the fighting, their efforts hampered by defiant nationalists who set up blockades. Yazov told Soviet radio that ``in order to ensure order, we are compelled to bring up to wartime strength'' some units in neighboring regions. He did not say how many troops were being called up or from where. The republic of Georgia, which has its own ethnic quarrels, and the Russian federation are the areas nearest to Armenia and Azerbaijan. Moscow radio said some young men who recently completed compulsory military service were being recalled. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today made his first public comments on the civil strife between the Armenians, who are mainly Christians, and the neighboring Azerbaijanis, who are predominately Moslem. ``The problems which have been accumulating for tens, no, for hundreds of years have erupted,'' he told a meeting in Moscow. ``We are now busy trying to halt this process, to prevent it from going deeper and getting more acute,'' Gorbachev said in comments broadcast on state-run radio. ``We have resorted to the use of force against criminals, against this vandalism.'' The Kremlin on Tuesday poured more than 11,000 additional troops into the troubled region in a bid to quell the violence, the worst since a decades-old feud over the land of Nagorno-Karabakh began anew two years ago. The land is inside Azerbaijan but populated mainly by Armenians. The Armenian republic wants to annex it. Soldiers were authorized Wednesday to fire on gunmen who attack them or people who are trying to steal weapons. Yazov said their numbers were still insufficient to bring the situation under control. He said he understood reservists would be unhappy about being called up to maintain order in another Soviet republic, but emphasized that ``no one is setting them the task of killing, shooting, going onto some offensive. It is principally to protect public order.'' However, soldiers' lives have been endangered. An Interior Ministry lieutenant was shot and killed in Nagorno-Karabakh, and a private was mortally wounded, according to official reports. Radio Moscow, detailing the difficulties facing units sent to the Caucasus region, said Armenians seized one transport plane that arrived with troops and demanded to be flown to safety. The capital of Nagorno-Karabakh, Stepanakert, lost two-thirds of its water supply when saboteurs blew up parts of its water supply pipe, Tass said today. The reservist call-up was needed in part because recent cuts under Gorbachev's plan to slash the nation's armed forces have depleted the pool of units that can be moved to the Caucasus, Yazov said. He did not say how many of the newly mobilized troops would be sent to the area of fighting. Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin, in an interview printed today, said internal security forces were already feeling the pinch of trying to cope with the unrest while fulfilling their usual duties, which include guarding prisons and fighting crime. In comments to the youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda, Bakatin referred to the strife as ``civil war,'' becoming the first high-level member of the Soviet government to use those terms. Radio Moscow said anti-Armenian attacks continued in Baku, the Azerbaijan capital. No new killings were reported in the city over the past 24 hours, and 30 hostages held in one neighborhood were set free. The latest violence exploded Saturday with bloody anti-Armenian riots in Baku. That led to battles by bands of heavily armed Armenians and Azerbaijanis in and near Nagorno-Karabakh. In Moscow, Interior Ministry spokesman Dmitri Seleznev said the death toll was up to 66 and that 220 people had been wounded. He said 4,658 more Armenians had been evacuated from Baku since Wednesday, adding to the 7,000 evacuated earlier in the week. There were 45 ``pogroms,'' or ethnically motivated attacks, in the oil-producing center during the same period, and 26 people were detained, said Seleznev, speaking in a telephone interview. He said pickets were up at two military airfields in Azerbaijan and that attempts were made in Baku to block streets to obstruct the progress of troops trying to restore order in the city of 1.7 million. Members of the Azerbaijani People's Front said today they warned Moscow that if a curfew or martial law were imposed on Baku, they would launch a general strike in the strategic oil center. In Armenia, Seleznev said, people continued attacks on armories to steal firearms. Since Wednesday, 198 more weapons were seized including four armored cars and one World War II-vintage T-34 tank, which he said was towed away although it is not in working order. According to Soviet press reports and officials, the warring sides have helicopters, armored vehicles, machine guns and other arms seized from government arsenals or offered by compatriots. Many Armenian refugees streaming into Moscow blamed Gorbachev personally for failing to halt the violence. The government newspaper Izvestia said much of the violence in Baku involved Azerbaijani refugees from Armenia, who needed a place to live and were forcing Armenians to leave their apartments. Izvestia said tens of thousands of Azerbaijanis who fled ethnic violence in Armenia in late 1988 remain without homes or jobs in Baku. An Azerbaijani government spokesman today deplored the Baku killings at a news conference in Moscow but cited the Azerbaijani refugees' situation as a one cause. Zaur Rustam-Zade also said Armenian aggression against Azerbaijani villages in Nagorno-Karabakh led to ``response actions'' from Azerbaijanis, Tass said. In the Azerbaijani region of Nakhichevan, about 3,000 Armenians blockaded the village of Kerki, defended by 30 residents who were aided by 50 soldiers, Seleznev said. He said there had been shooting but no deaths. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev dispelled rumors that the borders with Iran and Turkey had been sealed. Iran's official Tehran radio said dozens of Azerbaijanis crossed into Iran today from the Soviet Union, chanting Islamic slogans as they arrived. The Soviet Azerbaijanis share the Moslem religion and language with Iranians in that country's region of the same name.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Quake Jolts Northern California
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake jolted the northern California coastline early today, but no injuries or damage was reported. The epicenter of the quake, which registered 5.1 on the Richter scale, was at the juncture of the San Andreas and Mendocino faults, about 30 miles northeast of Eureka, said Pat Jorgenson, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif. She said the quake struck at 3:45 a.m. ``We didn't get any reports of injuries or damage,'' said a dispatcher for the Eureka Police Department who declined to give his name. ``We did feel it here. It was a big, strong jolt, not a long, rumbling quake.'' The temblor was the second quake of greater than 5.0 magnitude to shake the region in less than 48 hours. A 5.3 quake struck about 50 miles south of Eureka Tuesday afternoon. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. A quake with a reading of 5 can cause considerable damage if it is centered in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Assured Of U.S. Support By Top Bush Aide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with governor accepting suspension. Pickup 16th pvs, ``At least...''
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Filipinos today protested a government plan to suspend a provincial governor linked to last month's coup attempt, but the official later agreed to step down. In Manila, a senior U.S. presidential adviser expressed strong support today for President Corazon Aquino amid rumors of another impending attempt to topple her government. The rumors have been sweeping Manila for weeks because many leaders of the failed coup Dec. 1-9 remain at large. Late today, Rodolfo Aguinaldo, governor of the Cagayan province, agreed to give up his post for 60 days while he is being investigated for his alleged role in the failed coup. Aguinaldo will turn over his post Friday to his vice governor, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos said. Local Governments Secretary Luis Santos tried to serve the suspension order to Aguinaldo earlier today in the provincial capital of Tuguegarao, 200 miles north of Manila. But 5,000 people confronted Santos' party, demanding that Aguinaldo be retained in office. Aguinaldo, a former lieutenant colonel, said in a radio interview Dec. 1 that he was sending tanks and artillery to Manila to support the insurgents. The National Bureau of Investigation says Aguinaldo's troops were turned back by loyal soldiers in northern Luzon island. The government's ability to enforce the suspension is widely seen here as an indicator of administration resolve to punish participants in coup attempts. Aguinaldo was implicated but never charged in an August 1987 coup attempt. Afterward, he resigned from the military and raised his own private army, ostensibly to fight Communist rebels. He was elected governor of Cagayan province by a landslide in the January 1988 regional balloting. In Manila, Robert Gates, deputy U.S. national security adviser, said President Bush sent him ``to express his personal support for democracy and the constitutional process in the Philippines.'' ``He authorized me to be able to give him a first-hand report on developments here, and after I had a very good meeting with President Aquino, I can do that,'' Gates told reporters. ``Among other things, I would tell him that she is very confident.'' In Washington, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Gates' visit indicated the United States ``very strongly'' supports the Aquino government and noted that Bush ordered air support to help put down the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. At least 113 people were killed and more than 500 wounded in the failed December coup, the sixth and bloodiest attempt to oust Mrs. Aquino since she took power in the February 1986 uprising that toppled the late President Ferdinand Marcos. In announcing Gates' trip Wednesday, Fitzwater acknowledged reports that military dissidents would try again to oust Mrs. Aquino. ``There, of course, are continuing reports of problems in terms of security forces and so forth,'' Fitzwater said. ``She is taking measures to deal with those, to prevent future coups. We simply want to consult with her on those efforts.'' Gates, onetime deputy CIA director, is the chief deputy to Brent Scowcroft, Bush's national security adviser. During the December coup attempt, Gates was a key figure in convening and running all-night meetings at the White House to monitor developments and plan the U.S. response while Bush was flying to Malta for talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Zhivkov Charged with Malfeasance in Office, Placed Under House Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with warning that revival of anti-Communism would be dangerous for democracy. Pickup 4th pvs, ``Zhivkov, 78...''
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov has been placed under house arrest on charges of inciting ethnic hostility, misuse of state property and malfeasance in office, the state news agency reported today. The announcement came more than two months after the hard-line party chief, who had ruled for 35 years, was ousted by a peaceful, pro-democracy revolution and replaced by more moderate Communists who have promised free elections and democratic reforms. Also today, sources said talks between the governing Communists and the fledgling opposition on the transition to democracy were suspended until at least Monday because of disagreements over opposition demands for a voice on state radio and television. The two delegations agreed to work out a compromise on the issue, said Western diplomats on condition of anonymity. The leader of the Communist Party delegation, Andrei Loukanov, said ``the revival of anti-Commmunism would be dangerous for the transition to democracy,'' the official BTA news agency reported. He did not elaborate but appeared to be referring to the anti-Communist slogans at a rally Sunday by more than 50,000 pro-democracy demonstrators. Zhivkov, 78, was charged with ``incitement of ethnic hostility and hatred, with unwarranted receiving of excessive amounts of public property and with gross malfeasance,'' the official BTA news agency reported. It said a team of prosecutors has been assigned to conduct the investigation and a warrant has been issued by the prosecutor-general's office to ``remand'' Zhivkov in custody. BTA said Zhivkov was not jailed but ``remained under guard'' at one of his residences, prevented from moving from the house. Zhivkov reportedly had been under government protection at a house near the capital, Sofia. It was unclear how far the proceedings against Zhivkov have gone, and the date of the arrest warrant was not known. Immediately after his ouster, Zhivkov was accused of corrupt practices in maintaining at least 30 holiday and hunting retreats throughout the country. BTA said the investigation was launched on the basis of materials supplied by a parliamentary commission of inquiry into the ``abuses and breaches of the law committed in the state, public and economic life by the previous regime.'' Like other ousted hard-line leaders in Eastern Europe, Zhivkov has been accused of abusing power by enriching himself at the people's expense and damaging the economy through cumbersome central planning. Zhivkov also has been accused of enforcing discrimination against the country's ethnic Turkish minority. Today's announcement made clear Zhivkov is now officially held responsible for the forced assimilation of the 1.2 million ethnic Turks, who are mainly Moslem. Under the forced assimilation policy, the ethnic Turks were forced to adopt ethnic Slavic names and their language and religious rites were banned. Last summer, 320,000 ethnic Turks emigrated to Turkey, citing unbearable living conditions under Zhivkov's harsh rule, but 80,000 later returned for lack of jobs and proper housing in Turkey. The new government overturned Zhivkov's assimilation policy on Dec. 29. Petar Mladenov, a former minister under Zhivkov, replaced him as Communist Party leader and promised reforms and free elections this year. On Monday, Parliament repealed the Communist's guaranteed monopoly on power, making Bulgaria the last Warsaw Pact country to formally do so. The party is still powerful, however, and opposition groups complain that it is not moving swiftly enough on reform. A wave of democratic reforms also has swept Poland, Hungary, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Romania, forcing out their hard-line Communist leaders. Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania was convicted of ``grave crimes'' under his 24-year rule and executed Dec. 25, three days after his ouster. The former East German leader, Erich Honecker, is under investigation for high treason, abuse of power and corruption. In Czechoslovakia, former Communist Party chief Milos Jakes was ousted on Nov. 24 and his fate is still unclear. A Communist Party commission investigating abuse of political power ordered Jakes to resign from the party. In Hungary, Janos Kadar was removed as party leader in 1988. He died in July. Only Poland's Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has managed to remain as president under a government now controlled by non-Communists.

DOC.HEAD: Rockets Land Near Israeli Border, Fire Returned
DOC.TEXT: Several rockets fired from south Lebanon exploded today near the Israeli border but caused no damage or injuries, the army said. It was the second such incident this week. The army said the Katyusha rockets landed in Israel's self-proclaimed security zone, a strip of land in south Lebanon that Israel carved out as a buffer against Palestinian and Shiite Moslem guerrilla attacks. The army said artillery salvos were fired at the source of the rockets, but it did not elaborate. The security zone is patrolled jointly by Israeli troops and about 3,000 militiamen from the mostly Christian, Israeli-trained South Lebanon Army. A number of Katyusha rockets landed in northern Israel on Sunday but also caused no damage or injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat: Will Resign If Peace Effort Fails
With PM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Yasser Arafat today was quoted as saying he will resign as the leader of the PLO if U.S.-brokered Middle East peace efforts fail. Arafat blamed the current deadlock on U.S. ``pampering'' of Israel and said the Arabs should use oil as a weapon to win concessions from Washington. His comments appeared in the state-owned magazine Al-Mussawar. ``I have told the Arab League this week that if current peace efforts reach a dead end and fail to solve our problem, I will call a meeting of the Palestine National Council that elected me,'' Arafat was quoted as saying. ``I will tell them: `I am hereby returning the mandate you gave me. Fend for yourselves, and the United States also should fend for itself.' I will immediately announce my resignation. ``I will never be a toy in American hands.'' The 450-member Palestine National Council, the Palestine Liberation Organization's parliament-in-exile and its highest policy-making body, named Arafat chairman in 1968. When it declared a Palestinian state in 1988 on Arab land occupied by Israel, the council proclaimed Arafat its president. Arafat said Washington's support of Israel is ``primarily responsible for Israel's intransigence.'' Israel currently is demanding U.S. guarantees that the PLO would be excluded from Palestinian-Israeli talks that have been planned for Cairo as a prelude to peace negotiations. Israel also wants to limit the agenda of the Cairo dialogue. The PLO insists on choosing Palestinian delegates to the dialogue and said the agenda should be open. Arafat cited U.S. vetoes of anti-Israeli measures at the United Nations and Washington's $3 billion annual aid to Israel, among other things. ``All these positions encourage Israel,'' Arafat told Al-Mussawar. ``With this American pampering, Israel has every right to take a hard line.'' Oil holds the key to forging U.S. neutrality, he said. ``In 1991, the United States will need Arab oil after depletion of the North (Sea) oil and America's own oil. ... So we want greater Arab pressure on the United States. We must be angry, angry, angry,'' he said. An Arab oil boycott against the United States and other Western countries after the 1973 Arab-Israeli war pushed the United States into initiating Arab-Israeli military disengagement the following year. Arafat said he is having difficulty restraining hard-liners because of the lack of progress in the peace effort. ``I'm facing Palestinian extremists, Arab extremists and Moslem extremists. Why don't they (Americans and Israelis) take all this opposition into account?'' Arafat said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker, Envoys Dubious of Drug Cartel Offer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with material from hearing
DOC.TEXT: A Senate committee chairman and Colombia's ambassador today joined President Bush in rejecting an offer by Colombian drug lords to quit their smuggling in exchange for immunity from prosecution. ``You, like us, are highly skeptical,'' Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., told Colombian Ambassador Victor Mosquera Chaux at a joint hearing of his Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Caucus on International Narcotics Control. Mosquera, in response to a question, said the government will not negotiate with the Medellin cartel despite the overture this week. ``The government has indicated that it will not negotiate with the traffickers and that even if they were to turn themselves over, they would be brought to justice,'' Mosquera said in Spanish through an interpreter. ``Even though I don't think that the war has been won, I think the Colombian government is very close to obtaining a total victory,'' he said. ``Otherwise this change in attitude of The Extraditables would be very hard to explain since it's very different from their past activities.'' The communique allegedly sent by The Extraditables, the armed wing of Colombia's powerful drug leaders, offered to declare Colombia's government the winner in its war on narcotics traffickers. It said the drug lords would halt illegal activities in exchange for ``constitutional guarantees.'' The drug cartel released two kidnap victims to back up its offer, which was similar to previous proposals that have been rejected by the government. The communique followed Colombian President Virgilio Barco's statement Tuesday night that his government is not ``inflexible'' regarding a negotiated settlement with drug lords. Previously, Barco ruled out talks. Asked Wednesday about the offer by the drug lords, Bush said, ``They've got a credibility problem with me.'' Biden said he was holding today's hearing with the ambassadors of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia primarily to discuss long-term plans to combat the cocaine problem. The envoys testified that drug trafficking was linked to problems of foreign trade, especially the lack of an international coffee pricing agreement, foreign debt and internal poverty, particularly among farmers. Mosquera proposed a one-time $1 billion economic support program to Colombia to ``mitigate the costs associated with the drug war, as well as the negative effects from the breakdown of the International Coffee Agreement.'' The breakdown of the agreement has cost hundreds of millions of dollars in losses to the Colombian economy, he said. Ambassador Cesar Atala-Nazal of Peru attended the hearing even though he had been recalled as a result of the U.S. invasion of Panama Dec. 20 to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``I am now back in Washington to participate in this hearing,'' he said, saying it was a gesture of ``respect and appreciation.'' ``Otherwise, the position of Peru in regard to Panamanian events remains unchanged,'' he said. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., also asked that the events in Panama not interfere with the Andean drug summit scheduled for Feb. 15 in Cartagena, Colombia. Bush and the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia had been scheduled to attend the summit. Peruvian President Alan Garcia has since said he would send a minister in his stead unless U.S. invasion troops are out of Panama before then. Bush said Wednesday, however, that the summit schedule would not force him to speed the troop withdrawal. ``We want (the troops) out of there as soon as possible,'' he said. ``It's my objective to get the troops out and get back to the levels before this military action. It has nothing to do with the summit in Cartagena at all. ... I'm not driven by the summit.'' ``Whatever our differences on that issue, all of us hope that the summit will be helpful, and that it will generate a new spirit of cooperation,'' Kennedy said. He added that ``we also regret the unfortunate controversy over the administration's proposal to locate U.S. warships off the coast of Colombia.'' Defense Department sources said last week that the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy has been chosen to lead an interdiction effort off Colombia but that no final decision had been made on deployment. Word of the proposed deployment off the Colombian coast touched off rumors around the hemisphere, denied here, that the United States might try to blockade Colombia or perhaps even invade it as a followup to the Panama invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Latvian Exile Goes on Trial Charged with Murder
DOC.TEXT: A Latvian immigrant who fled the United States to avoid possible deportation went on trial in West Germany today for his alleged role in the killing of 171 people during World War II. Boleslavs Maikovskis, 86, is charged with complicity in the shooting deaths of 170 residents in the village of Audrini in the Soviet republic of Latvia in January 1942. He also is charged with murder for allegedly ordering the hanging of a Jewish man from Audrini in May 1942 while acting as a commander of a pro-Nazi police force. Maikovskis, a former resident of Mineola, N.Y., fled the United States in 1987. He was facing proceedings that could have led to his deportation to the Soviet Union for alleged war crimes. The Soviet Union sentenced Maikovskis to death in absentia in 1965. Maikovskis applied for asylum in West Germany after leaving the United States, but was arrested at his home in Muenster in October 1988. He is in poor health and has been held in a prison hospital. Maikovskis today was questioned about his life in Latvia but not about his alleged crimes. Speaking through an interpreter, he described himself as a fighter for Latvia's independence and said he had joined a pro-German organization long before Latvia was occupied by Nazi troops. The organization later became an auxiliary police force that started wearing German uniforms in 1942. He said he joined the police force to help achieve Latvia's independence. Maikovskis told the court he withdrew with German troops to Germany in 1944. At the end of the war, he spent six years as a displaced person before receiving permission to emigrate to the United States in 1951. The United States began deportation proceedings against Maikovskis in 1976, but they were delayed by several appeals, the last of which was denied by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1986. The trial adjourned until Monday. It is expected to last until June.

DOC.HEAD: Some Quayle Stops in Latin America May Have to Be Postponed
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts 4 grafs after 12th graf, It is, with Caracas comments
DOC.TEXT: Some stops Vice President Dan Quayle wanted to make in Central and South America ``may have to be scheduled for a later time,'' the White House said today, as Latin countries continue to voice resentment over the U.S. invasion of Panama. ``It's not `don't come,'' Quayle acknowledged today in an interview with The Associated Press. ``It's a matter of timing on when you will come,'' he said, expressing the reaction he has gotten from nations he wanted to visit. Quayle said his trip will be important both symbolically, to show the administration's interest in keeping good relations with its neighbors, and diplomatically, to try and smooth any feelings injured by last month's invasion. The itinerary announced Wednesday by Quayle's office for his trip next week, with stops in Panama, Honduras and Jamaica, falls short of the journey indicated by President Bush's announcement Jan. 5. ``Some of the trips may have to be scheduled for a later time,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said today. He declined to comment on the reported resistance from Latin countries. ``When you're scheduling these kinds of things some can be scheduled earlier than others,'' Fitzwater told reporters. ``The question of when the meetings take place is not nearly as important to us as simply that the message is delivered'' that Bush wants to restore good relations with the Latin nations, Fitzwater said. Asked whether the countries were snubbing Bush in requesting that Quayle not visit at this time, Fitzwater said, ``Obviously there were concerns in Latin America following the Panama situation. Obviously there were reasons why the president felt it was necessary to reiterate our support and our interest in working with them.'' Quayle's trip to the Jan. 27 Honduran presidential inauguration has long been planned. On that trip, aides said Wednesday, he will stop in Panama, where he is expected to voice support for the U.S.-installed government of Guillermo Endara. He also is to visit Jamaica, which joined the 20-1 vote on Dec. 22 deploring the U.S. military invasion of Panama. Other than those stops, Quayle's office has been unable to set up any specific visits except the previously scheduled trips to Chile and Brazil for their mid-March inaugurations, said one official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Quayle's office said he would make stops yet to be determined as part of that trip. It is anticipated that he will use the three inaugural trips to meet with other presidents who attend. Venezuelan officials in Washington have told reporters they would prefer that Quayle not visit. In Caracas today, Venezuela's foreign minister, Reinaldo Figueredo, said, ``We understand he's not coming,'' but refused to say why. Figueredo said in a television interview Wednesday, however, ``Maybe his visit is not the most adequate step to be taken given the conditions that exist with respect to the U.S. invasion of Panama.''
