In addition, the head of Venezuela's main opposition party, Eduardo Fernandez, said Wednesday that a visit ``would not be convenient.'' Quayle aides Wednesday night declined to confirm or deny a report in today's editions of The New York Times that Quayle had dropped plans to stop in Venezuela and Mexico because of objections from those countries. Quayle said Wednesday that ``diplomatic sensitivities'' have held up scheduling of his trip. But he denied any lingering ``deep resentment'' among Latin leaders after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama. ``No country has said, `We don't want the vice president, period','' he told a luncheon gathering of the Hoover Institution. He later told The Associated Press, however, ``There are diplomatic sensitivities. There's a matter of timing on when you go. There's a matter of coordination. And these things have all got to be worked out.'' The Jamaica stop is another signal of the much friendlier relations between Washington and the government of Prime Minister Michael Manley, a onetime strident opponent of the United States. Latin officials have said this is not a good time for Quayle to visit their countries because of strong sentiment against the continued presence of U.S. troops in Panama. An official who spoke anonymously said all have indicated they will welcome Quayle eventually, but not this soon after the invasion. Subsequent reports that Bush was planning to use U.S. ships to intercept drugs off Colombia _ which surprised the Colombian government _ added further to the anti-American feelings, the official said. Bush, in assigning Quayle to visit the region, said he understood the sensitivities of the Latin Americans to the U.S. military action in their region and was sending Quayle to explain the action was not taken lightly or without rationale. Quayle told the lunch group he was not going to the region to apologize, but to consult with the leaders ``on how we make Panama a successful democracy.'' He told a reporter later, ``I do not believe that the heads of state are unhappy or resentful of our actions in Panama. I think they understand it. That's one of the reasons I'm going down, to find out what their true feelings are.'' Bush said Wednesday he wants to withdraw the invasion force from Panama ``as soon as possible,'' but he feels no pressure to get them out before the Feb. 15 drug summit. Peru's president, Alan Garcia, is refusing to attend the drug summit while the troops remain, but he plans to send a minister. Bush congratulated Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the commander of the U.S. invasion, at the White House on Wednesday for an ``outstanding job.'' The president denied difficulties in finding countries willing to host Quayle in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Antonio Cipollone, Awarded First Anti-Tobacco Damages, Dies at 66
DOC.TEXT: Antonio Cipollone, whose lawsuit against three cigarette makers in the death of his first wife resulted in the first jury damage award for a smoker's death, has died, his wife said today. Cipollone was admitted to Community Memorial Hospital in Toms River Jan. 4 and died Jan. 10 of pneumonia and heart failure, said Dorothy Cipollone. He was 66. A day after he entered the hospital, the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned a $400,000 judgment against Liggett Group Inc. But the court ordered a new trial and opened the door for other issues. The June 1988 award after a four-month trial was the first granted by a jury in a lawsuit brought by a smoker or relatives against the tobacco industry. Cipollone had carried on the suit brought by him and his first wife, Rose, who died at 58 of lung cancer in 1984. The suit named Liggett, Lorillard Inc. and Philip Morris Inc., which made the cigarettes Mrs. Cipollone smoked. Cipollone knew about the reversal, but ``it didn't seem to concern him in the least,'' said Dorothy Cipollone. ``He was happy that he had gone through with whatever his wife, Rose, had started. He never had regrets.'' Cipollone's attorney, Marc Z. Edell, said the family was still deciding whether to continue the case. No other family members were parties to the original suit. Cipollone was born in Italy and came to the United States at age 15, living first in New York City. He worked in construction and as a cable splicer for U.S. Steel and in his own business before retiring in 1986. He and Rose lived for years in Little Ferry, and he spent the last years of his life in Lakehurst.

DOC.HEAD: King Fahd Sends 1.6 Million Korans to Soviet Moslems
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd will ship 1.6 million copies of the Koran, the Moslem holy book, to the Soviet Union, it was reported Thursday. ``This is the largest operation in history for transportation and distribution of the Koran,'' said Abdullah Omar Naseef, secretary-general of the Mecca-based Moslem World League. The weekly newspaper Al-Muslimoon quoted Naseef as saying that if Aeroflot quotes a competitive price, it will be allowed to fly to Saudi Arabia to airlift the consignment. The ultra-religious kingdom has no diplomatic relations with any Communist nation. Naseef said it was the first consignment of Islamic books to the Soviet Union since the country lifted a long-standing ban on Islamic and Christian literature last summer. According to Al-Muslimoon, 600,000 of the Korans are in a variant of Turkish and the rest are in Arabic, the original language of the holy book. A three-man delegation will go to Moscow to arrange for the transport and distribution of the books, as well as explore the possibility of establishing a printing press in the Soviet Union for the Koran and other Islamic books, Naseef said. He said there are only 30,000 copies of Koran in the Soviet Union, where Moslems number 70 million. The Moslem World League is a non-governmental pan-Islamic organization funded mainly by Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Government Cancels Referendum on Death Penalty, Communist Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with government calling off national referendum. Pickup 10th pvs, `During the...
DOC.TEXT: The government has canceled a national referendum on whether to ban the Communist Party and reimpose the death penalty because the decision to hold it was not carefully thought out, a spokesman said today. Siviu Brucan of the governing National Salvation Front said the decision was made Wednesday night during a meeting of the Front's executive council. At the same meeting, the council ruled that the Communist Party's assets will be confiscated. ``The referendum will no longer take place,'' Brucan told a news conference. It was the second major turnaround by the revolutionary government in less than a week. On Saturday, President Ion Iliescu retracted a ban on the Communist Party that he had announced the previous day and instead said it would be on the referendum Jan. 28, along with the previously scheduled question of whether to reimpose the death penalty. Like Brucan today, Iliescu said he backed off his decision because it had been made too hastily. Brucan said leaders were guilty of ``almost panicky decision-making'' Friday when they promised the referendum to end huge protests by people demanding legalization of the death penalty and a ban on the Communist Party. Earlier today, government spokesman Dan Radulescu said the Front was considering either calling off or postponing the referendum because of time constraints. ``It is very difficult to organize a referendum in only 10 days,'' he said. The cancellation was the latest sign of the government's indecision over crucial issues and its difficulty coping with the public's lingering distrust of the government, which includes several former Communists. During the past week, several visting West European officials who have come to discuss aid to Romania have spoken out against renewal of the death penalty, which was outlawed after the executions Dec. 25 of ousted leader Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. Also today, two daughters of exiled King Michael flew from Geneva to Bucharest for their first visit to the country. The king, who went into exile in 1948, has offered to return as head of a constitutional moncharchy. Princesses Margarita and Sophie were expected to stay at least five days, but sources close to the family gave no further details on their trip. The minister of petroleum, Victor Murea, said in an interview that the country cannot produce enough natural gas to meet all its needs and will be forced to limit some energy supplies to non-essential industries. Murea told the newspaper Adevarul that the country can only produce natural gas to meet 60 percent of its needs and that production is dropping as resources are depleted. ``Daily production today is only 79 percent of what it was three years ago,'' he said. To conserve natural gas, some industrial users will have to switch to oil and others will have to be shut down at least temporarily, he said. ``Only those economic units that produce strictly necessary goods can be allowed to function,'' he said. On Wednesday, officials in the domestic food ministry said the country was also being forced to reimpose food rationing in some areas because of shortages. During Ceausescu's rule, heating and food supplies were strictly limited as an austerity measure to help Romania pay off a $10.5 billion foreign debt. After the otherthrow of Ceausescu on Dec. 22, the government immediately increased heat in apartments and offices and stopped rationing.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Iranians POWs Arrive Home
DOC.TEXT: Twenty sick or disabled Iranian soldiers captured by Iraq in their eight-year war arrived in Tehran on Thursday, a day after Iran repatriated 50 similar Iraqi prisoners, Tehran radio reported. The prisoners were welcomed at Tehran's Mehrabad airport by Mahmoud Aqamiri, an official in charge of Iraqi prisoners-of-war in Iran. Aqamiri deplored the lopsided exchange, saying that ``the fact that the Iraqi regime had released only 20 Iranian prisoners in exchange for 50 released by us the previous day, limits the possibility for other such exchanges,'' according to the broadcast, monitored in Cyprus. Aqamiri said that 53 Iraqi prisoners had been freed by Tehran Wednesday, but that three had requested asylum in Iran. The Iranians were flown to Iran aboard the same International Red Cross-chartered plane that carried the Iraqis. An Iraqi Foreign Ministry spokesman said the release of the Iranian prisoners was made ``in confirmation of Iraq's humanitarian policy and its commitment to international conventions.'' The Red Cross had mediated an agreement between Iran and Iraq to repatriate the ailing and disabled POWs immediately after the cease-fire, which took effect in August 1988. According to Red Cross estimates, more than 900 ailing and disabled POWs remain held by both sides, with a total of 50,000 other prisoners held by Iran and 19,200 by Iraq. United Nations officials and diplomats put the total number of POWs held by both sides at about 100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Bombs Explode at Two Airports in Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded in the parking lot of Islamabad's International Airport on Thursday, hours after a smaller bomb exploded outside the airport in the frontier city of Peshawar, police said. No one was injured in either incident. Police said seven people have been arrested in connection with the Islamabad bombing. The Islamabad airport was closed for several hours and three flights were delayed. The car in which the bomb was hidden was parked in a remote corner of the sprawling parking lot, police said. The bomb in Peshawar, the headquarters for Afghanistan's anti-Communist guerrilla leadership, startled residents who lived near the airport but caused no damage. U.S. Undersecretary of State Robert Kimmitt had arrived in Peshawar to meet with guerrilla leaders about an hour before the explosion. He is the highest ranking State Department official to visit Pakistan since Soviet combat troops left Afghanistan in February 1989. Scores of bombs have exploded in Peshawar in the past two years, with police blaming agents of Afghanistan's Communist government. Police have refused to speculate who was behind Thursday's bombing.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Democratic Social Security Plan `Charade'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files a0578-a0580-a0562
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today denounced as ``a charade'' a Democratic proposal to cut the Social Security payroll tax and said it was really an attempt to force him to raise other taxes. Bush also promised that he will not acquiesce in any move that would raise taxes or lead to lower Social Security benefits for older Americans. Reporters asked the president about the proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., at the start of a meeting between Bush and visiting Turkish President Turgut Ozal. Bush pointed to his foreign visitor and replied, ``We have the same feeling about it. We both draw a blank when we hear about it.'' ``It's an effort to get me to raise taxes on the American people by the charade of cutting them, or cut benefits, and I am not going to do it to the older people of this country,'' he said. It was Bush's first public comments on the sensitive Moynihan proposal, which has drawn support from Democrats and Republicans alike despite warnings from the White House that it was a trap for the GOP. Moynihan has suggested rolling back the recent Social Security payroll tax hike, saving workers $7 billion this year and $55 billion in fiscal 1991. Another Democrat, Sen. Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, has proposed a 5 percent value-added tax _ a national sales levy _ to raise $53 billion in 1991 and cover the revenues lost both by the Social Security tax cut and Bush's proposal to lower the tax on capital gains. ``First we had the tax cut and now we have the tax increase. Can cuts in benefits be far behind? Look out older Americans,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said earlier today. Fitzwater boasted that he was a prophet on Monday when he called the politically popular Moynihan proposal ``a wolf in sheep's clothing'' and just a ruse to force an increase in other taxes. Vice President Dan Quayle, in an interview Wednesday with The Associated Press, also labeled Moynihan's proposal ``a political trap'' that would lead to higher overall taxes later. The payroll tax, paid by both employers and employees, jumped to 7.65 percent on Jan. 1 from 7.51 percent, and it is now levied on wages up to $51,300 instead of $48,000. Self-employed people pay 15.3 percent. Moynihan contends the payroll tax should be scaled back now because of mounting surpluses in the Social Security trust funds. Under a plan endorsed by a Social Security rescue commission that Moynihan was part of in 1983, the trust funds are supposed to build up annual surpluses of tens and eventually hundreds of billions of dollars each year to help pay for baby boomers' retirement in the next century. But the excess now is being lent to the government, which uses the funds to pay for other federal programs and hold down the overall deficit. Hollings wants to impose a value added tax on sales of everything except food, health care and housing. It would be levied at each stage of production. Asked if he felt there was a conspiracy between Hollings and Moynihan, Fitzwater said: ``They're all part of the same party that has this interest in this proposal. But it's been clear from the beginning that if you cut the Social Security taxes at some point you got to raise taxes to get the money back or you got to cut benefits. We don't want to be associated with either one of those outcomes.''

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak Premier Quits Communist Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 5th, `First Deputy...' to ADD background on troubles faced by Communist Party. Pickup 6th `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: Premier Marian Calfa has quit the Communist Party, reducing the number of Communists in the 21-member federal government to seven, a government spokesman said today. Calfa is the third minister in the coalition government to leave the Communist Party in the last two weeks. Zbynek Fiala, head of the government's press department, made the announcement at a news conference. When asked by a reporter whether Calfa had in fact left the party, he replied, ``Yes, it is true.'' He did not say when or why Calfa had given up his party membership. First Deputy Premier Valtr Komarek, who is in charge of economic affairs, quit the party at the beginning of last week. He followed Vladimir Dlouhy, the head of the State Planning Commission, who took the same step. The Communist Party's troubles began Nov. 17, when police beat pro-democracy student demonstrators. The confrontation ignited Czechoslovakia's anti-Communist revolution, and hard-line party chief Milos Jakes and the rest of the leadership resigned a week later. The government headed by Calfa was sworn in in mid-December by former President Gustav Husak, who resigned afterward. Husak was replaced by Vaclav Havel, who had been Czechoslovakia's most prominent human rights activist before the revolution. Calfa, 44, participated in the negotiations the led to the current government, the first not dominated by Communists in 41 years, and was the first Communist official to publicly endorse Havel for president. Calfa is expected to make an official visit to neighboring Austria Jan. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say They Withdrew Some Planes from Cam Ranh Bay
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has withdrawn MiG-23 and Tu-16 planes from its base at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Thursday. Cam Ranh Bay, a former American base during the Vietnam War, is the Soviets' largest foreign base, according to U.S. military sources. As of 1985, a reported 30 ships were based there. A squadron with six to 10 aircraft remains at the field, said spokesman Vadim Perfiliev. He gave no other details. MiG-23s are fighters. Tu-16 Badgers are variously fitted out as bombers and electronic reconnaissance aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Carrying Solid-Fuel Rocket Motors Burns After Collision; 100 Evacuated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to add size of motors; SUBS last graf with 3 grafs to add detail.
DOC.TEXT: A tractor-trailer rig carrying 2-foot-long rocket motors for the military burst into flames after being struck by a car early today, killing the car's driver and forcing the evacuation of 100 people, authorities said. A car slammed into the side of the 18-wheeler at an intersection on U.S. 431 about 12:15 a.m., said state trooper Sgt. Ronnie Stinson. The car became lodged under the trailer and was dragged about 200 yards. The car caught fire, and the truck's cargo of several solid-fuel rocket motors began exploding, he said. Officials had to briefly evacuate about 100 people from nearby trailer homes and a store before calling Army explosive experts from Fort McClellan. The trooper said the driver of the car was killed, but authorities had not made a positive identification. However, officials at Wellborn High School identified the victim as a student there, Chris Corzine, 18. Principal Howard Waldrep said he already had informed Corzine's classmates of his death. Neither the truck driver, Larry Eller, 27, nor an assistant, Mike Ryan, 28, was injured. Stinson said the two men drove the tractor away from the trailer section of the rig as the explosions began. ``I wouldn't have wanted to do what they did,'' he said. Stinson said the truck, owned by Peninsula Trucking Co., was hauling rocket motors from Atlantic Research Corp. in Gainesville, Va., to the Huntsville offices of Wyle Laboratories, a government contractor. The truck had made a stop in Georgia, he said. Bill Meyer, manufacturing director for Atlantic Research, said the motors were for classified military use. Meyer said the company believed there may not have been any explosions, only the flashes of quick-burning rocket fuel. ``Their burn time is one second,'' he said. Gary Johnson, a spokesman with Atlantic Research, said six of the seven rocket motors on the truck contained fuel. The motors are about two feet long and two feet in diameter, and each contains 20-25 pounds of solid rocket fuel, he said. He described the engines as shroud motors, used to pull the nose cone cover off a missile during the flight, that were being sent to Lyle Labs for testing for the Air Force. But he wouldn't say which program these motors are used in. Johnson said Atlantic Research makes both the motor and the fuel.

DOC.HEAD: Shootings Rare in Japan
With AM-Japan-Mayor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shootings such as that of Nagasaki's Mayor Hitoshi Nagashima are rare in Japan, where weapons control has been strict since the samurai were forbidden to carry swords in 1868. About 315 gun battles between rival gangs during a 1985-88 underworld power struggle accounted for the bulk of the nation's shooting incidents in that period. Twenty-five people died in those shootings. Overall, murder has been declining in Japan, from about 1,650 cases in 1980 to about 1,450 in 1988. Of these, only a tiny fraction were committed with guns. In the United States, with twice the population, there were more than 20,000 murders in the same year, about half of them committed with firearms. Japan's overall crime rate has been estimated at about one-fifth that of the U.S. rate. Strict gun control under Japan's Firearms and Sword Control Law and a tradition of obedience are among reasons cited for the difference. Illegal possession of hand guns can result in prison sentences of up to 10 years. The maximum penalty for murder is death, carried out by hanging. In recent years, however, gunrunning from Southeast Asia, especially the Philippines, has been on the rise. The National Police Agency says it seizes about 1,500 firearms, mainly pistols, each year. The smugglers are mostly ``yakuza'' gangsters arming themselves for gang skirmishes. Some of the gangs reputedly have close ties to right-wing groups. Since the end of World War II, political assassinations have been rare. The shooting of Motoshima was the first attack on a major political figure with a gun since the war, police records show. But rightists have carried out 25 other attacks on key politicians using knives, swords, explosives or fists, the agency said. In the most famous case, on Oct. 12, 1960, Socialist Party leader Inejiro Asanuma was stabbed to death with a sword by a right-wing assailant during a televised rally. Assassinations were frequent in Japan during the 1930s, a period in which right-wing nationalism eventually led to de facto military rule. Prime Minister Osachi Hamaguchi was killed by right-wingers in 1930. In May 1932, Prime Minister Tsuyoshi Inukai was assassinated, and democratic government collapsed in Japan until its revival under the Allied occupation in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing to Cut Up to 5,000 Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. said today it expects to lay off 1,700 workers in the Puget Sound area by April and anticipates reducing its work force in the area by as much as 5,000 people this year. Attrition should account for about half the total reduction, the company said in a news release. Boeing, by far the largest private employer in Washington state, said about 1,400 of the 1,700 hourly employees expected to be laid off are at the company's Everett plant, where production startup for the new 747-400 jumbo jet has been completed. The announcement made no mention of layoffs at Boeing plants in other parts of the country. It had been rumored since late last year. ``Because the new 777 airplane program is still not formally approved and with uncertainties in the defense budget, Boeing will continue to review and revise its workforce requirements throughout the year,'' the company said. Layoff notices will be issued Friday to about 1,900 employees who might be among the 1,700 workers laid off starting March 20, the company said. It said it will provide counseling and help the laid-off workers find new jobs. At the end of 1989, Boeing had just under 106,700 employees in Washington state, and increase of almost 10,000 from the beginning of the year. Nationwide, Boeing employment had grown to 145,200, up 10,800 from the beginning of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Oscar Telecast to Have Golobal Satellite Participation
DOC.TEXT: Five foreign cites will take part, by satellite, in the 62nd Annual Academy Awards on March 26. For the first time, portions of the telecast will originate from London, Tokyo, Moscow, Sydney and Buenos Aires, it was announced at a news conference Wednesday. Billy Crystal will be host for the ceremonies, which will be telecast in the U.S. by ABC, Academy president Karl Malden and show producer Gil Cates said. Noting the Oscar telecast had developed into a ``monster variety show,'' Cates said, ``This year's strategy is to move it over to more of a social event and news program.'' Some announcements of winners may be made in the satellite cities, but the presentation of the Oscar statuettes will still be made at the Los Angeles Music Center. Last year's Oscar telecast was critically panned and opening ceremonies featuring Snow White brought a lawsuit from the Disney Studios that was settled out of court.

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Prison Officials Storm Office, Free Hostage Held Over A Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 graf to UPDATE with detail on rescue, add that one rescuer injured. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Rep. Tommy...'.
DOC.TEXT: A prison counselor held hostage by an inmate for more than 30 hours was freed after officers stormed the office where the standoff was taking place. The hostage, Nancy Boyd, 49, was not hurt in the assault that occurred near midnight Wednesday, prison spokeswoman Lee Mann said. Another counselor at the Mack Alford Correctional Center had been released earlier. The inmate, Otis Ray Vann, a convicted robber, was taken into custody and transferred to another prison. Corrections spokesman Jerry Massie said preliminary reports were that he suffered some internal and pelvic injuries, but did not require hospitalization. Vann, 39, took Ms. Boyd and another counselor, Paul Williams, hostage about 1:45 p.m. Tuesday, officials said. Vann reportedly was armed with a razor blade stuck in the end of an ink pen. A team of 11 rescuers armed with riot batons subdued Vann and rescued Ms. Boyd, authorities said. One of the rescuers, Derk McCarty, suffered an injured shoulder. Vann had released Williams, 50, early Wednesday morning in exchange for food after speaking with two state representatives, prison officials said. Williams was described afterward as shaken but unhurt. Rep. Tommy Thomas said Vann was rational and calm, and had ``made some comment that he hadn't been treated with as much respect as he should have been.'' Ms. Mann said that Wednesday afternoon, Vann made eight requests involving 11 issues, which were not disclosed. Massie said Vann took the counselors captive on the second floor of the prison's west dorm. He said the inmates normally housed in the west dorm were taken to the prison gymnasium for the night. Massie said Vann began serving a 15-year sentence for robbery with a dangerous weapon on Oct. 1, 1989, and also is serving a concurrent seven-year sentence for forgery and a concurrent five-year sentence for possession of stolen property. He also faces parole violation charges in Texas, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: European Parliament Calls for Aid to Armenians
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The European Parliament on Thursday urged the European Community to grant emergency aid to Armenia and the region of Nagorno-Karabakh, but did not specify how much. It also suggested a fact-finding mission be sent to the troubled region in the southern Soviet Union. In a resolution backed by almost all political groups in the 518-seat assembly, the parliament called on the Soviet government to order an end to the blockade of Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh and to guarantee the safety of people there. Parliamentarians said they were concerned that the ``repeated threats of secession'' would have dire consequences on the ``budding process of democratization in the Soviet Union.'' The largely Armenian population of Nagorno-Karabakh wants to be under the control of the republic of Armenia, not the republic of Azerbaijan. The parliament urged the European Community to ``make representations to the Soviet authorities ... (to order) the full and immediate lifting of the blockade imposed on Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh.'' The EC should also call on the Soviets to guarantee the ``freedom of movement and the safety of goods and persons'' between Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh, the parliament said. Noting that ``according to some sources, arms from Iran have been delivered'' to the Azerbaijanis, the parliament called on all nations, especially those bordering Armenia, ``to avoid all interference.''

DOC.HEAD: Attack on Mayor Latest Rightist Strike Against Free Speech
An AP Extra
With AM-Japan-Mayor, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It's still dangerous to exercise the right of free speech in Japan, especially in criticizing an imperial family that is held sacrosanct by a violence-prone rightist fringe. The shooting Thursday of Nagasaki Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima was a vivid demonstration that rightist death threats can become real. Motoshima, who provoked controversy for saying the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot in the back and seriously wounded. Five hours later, police arrested the leader of a rightist group on suspicion of attempted murder and said he had admitted the shooting. The government and some who have been targets of rightist attacks, including reporters, quickly condemned the attack. ``These sorts of attacks, using violence to curb freedom of speech, are unforgivable,'' said Osamu Asano, deputy secretary general of the Japan Newspaper Publishers and Editors Association. The attack shows the lingering threat from anti-Communist extremists, who have intimidated government officials and businessmen for years. The arrested leader of the Sane Thinkers' Group, Kazumi Tajiri, was on record saying he was willing to kill. Asked in 1987 if he would kill somebody he hated, Tajiri responded, ``Yes, because after all, right-wingers are terrorists.'' TV Asahi broadcast a tape of the interview after Tajiri was arrested. Rightists prowl the streets of Tokyo and other cities in huge black trucks decorated with the rising sun flag of the militaristic past, using powerful loudspeakers to harass their targets _ newspapers, embassies, government offices and companies _ with ear-splitting military music and epithets. The groups have scant public support, but the threat of a visit from them is enough to prevent many Japanese from speaking their minds. Executives doing business in socialist countries generally refuse to be quoted. Government officials responsible for relations with the socialist bloc are also reticent. ``If I allowed you to use my name, the trucks would be right outside the doors of our company and maybe even outside my home,'' said one businessman. ``They already give us enough trouble.'' Motoshima violated the rightists' most sensitive taboo in December 1988 when he said that Hirohito, on his deathbed at the time, was partly responsible for the war. Hirohito died Jan. 7, 1989, at age 87. More than 70,000 people died in Nagasaki on Aug. 9, 1945, when a U.S. plane dropped an atomic bomb on the city. Three days earlier, about 140,000 died in Hiroshima, the first city ever to suffer an atomic bomb attack. Japan surrendered six days after the Nagasaki bombing. Hirohito was worshiped as a living god before renouncing his divine status after the war, and the rightists still venerate the royal family. Motoshima received strong public support _ a group of Nagasaki residents sent him petitions with more than 286,000 signatures backing him. But he also got death threats and a procession of rightist sound trucks outside his office. ``Death to Motoshima!'' was a constant chant. The mayor received threatening letters containing bullets. City Hall was fired upon in March. Motoshima, an independent, is the 26th major politician in postwar Japan to be assaulted, police say. The most shocking case came in 1960, when a right-wing student fatally stabbed Japan Socialist Party chairman Inejiro Asanuma at a televised party rally. In May, two rightists slightly injured Socialist Secretary General Tsuruo Yamaguchi and another Socialist politician at a party gathering. In December, a rightist group reportedly sent a severed finger to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's residence to protest the government debate over funding inaugeration ceremonies for Hirohito's son, Emperor Akihito. Another rightist fired a pistol and barricaded himself inside a tax office near the Imperial Palace in central Tokyo in July to protest the inheritance tax levied on the emperor's $12.9 million estate. Nobody was injured. Left-wing extremists have launched attacks on the imperial family. Leftists recently fired projectiles at the home of Prince Hitachi, Akihito's younger brother, causing some damage but no injuries. Journalists also have been casualties of rightist attacks. In May 1987, a masked gunman walked into a bureau of Japan's second-largest newspaper, the Asahi Shimbun, and killed one reporter and wounded another. Other newspapers also have experienced attacks, and the Asahi Shimbun headquarters has been fired upon and harassed by rightist sound trucks. ``The people who attacked the Asahi Shimbun still haven't been caught,'' said Asano of the publishers' association. ``Violence of this sort threatens our freedom of speech and of the press.'' Author Sae Sawachi agreed. ``Using terror to threaten people who hold different opinions is the greatest threat to democracy,'' Sawachi said.

DOC.HEAD: Business Owners Sometimes Stung by Unwitting Dealings with Drug Lords
DOC.TEXT: Inga Lourey says she's never met a drug trafficker, but for seven months she and other business owners unwittingly paid rent to one. Now they're paying the federal government, which seized the property. Ms. Lourey and her husband, Carl, own a supermarket in the Park II Alto Mesa shopping center on El Paso's upscale west side. Unbeknown to them, the $4.3 million center was owned by Rafael Munoz Talavera, considered the ``premier godfather'' of cocaine smuggling from Mexico into the United States, government officials say. Federal investigators say he headed a smuggling ring that moved at least 60 tons of cocaine into the United States during 1989, including the 21.4 tons discovered last September in a warehouse in Sylmar, Calif. Munoz Talavera was arrested shortly after the warehouse was seized and now is jailed just a few miles from Ms. Lourey's store, across the border in Cuidad Juarez, Mexico. In November, the U.S. Marshals Service seized the shopping center and told the Loureys and other merchants who their landlord had been. Ms. Lourey said she had no idea who owned the shopping center. ``We just had an address we sent the rent to,'' she said. ``There are a lot of people doing business with criminals who do not have any way of being aware of it at the time,'' said Steven T. Boyle, spokesman for Marshals Service headquarters in Arlington, Va. The shopping center is one of more than 26,300 properties seized by the Marshals Service in 1989 _ from real estate to cars and personal belongings _ as the result of drug investigations, Boyle said. There is little anyone can do to avoid doing business with a drug dealer, Boyle said, since usually the first information linking someone with the illegal trade comes out when they're indicted or arrested. And by then, it probably is too late for the innocent business person to avoid feeling the consequences, as the Loureys found out. When the public learned of the shopping center seizure, some of Ms. Lourey's customers believed merchants there might be fronts for drug dealers. ``We had some snide remarks from customers. Some were saying: `If you're involved in laundering money, we're not coming to the store anymore.' Others said they would boycott the store,'' she said. Merchants became so worried that they got the U.S. Marshals Service to issue a statement saying their businesses are legitimate. But Ms. Lourey worries that something similar will happen again, and she doubts she could do anything to prevent it. ``Shopping centers change hands. If this happens again, are you going to ask (the landlord) are you OK? Is your money all right?'' she asked. Boyle said about the only tip-off to a drug connection is someone trying to buy something with a briefcase full of cash. The man who sold the shopping center said he, too, was a victim. He said he sold the property to, and did business only with, Rafael Munoz Tellez, the father of Munoz Talavera, not knowing the link. ``It hurt my business tremendously. I lost clients. A lot of people in town talk,'' said the property seller, who spoke only on the condition that his name not be used. He said more publicity would further erode his business, which is just beginning to recover. The shopping center was one of about a dozen residential and commercials properties seized in El Paso and Ruidoso, N.M., as a result of the September cocaine seizure in California. The federal government will maintain them until a court rules whether the suspects must forfeit the properties. The number of properties seized by the Marshals Service has been escalating with the drug war. Seven times as many properties were seized last year than were just three years ago _ 3,645 in 1986. Last year's seizures were valued at $1.09 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa Captain to Retire
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the USS Iowa has decided to retire from the Navy and someday may write about the turret explosion last April that killed 47 sailors aboard the battleship. ``Down the road, I might have a lot to say. But I've decided to save all that,'' Capt. Fred P. Moosally said Wednesday. A Navy investigation into the explosion concluded the blast probably was caused by sabotage by a disgruntled gunner's mate who died in the explosion. That conclusion has been challenged by some of the victims' families and members of Congress. In October, Moosally was faulted for ``administrative deficiencies'' in training and ordnance safety found during the investigation. Navy officials said the deficiencies had nothing to do with the explosion. Moosally, 45, may be the final captain of the Iowa. The Navy said Wednesday that the Iowa, now at the Norfolk Naval Shipyard for repairs to the turret and other maintenance work, will be mothballed afterward to save money. The Iowa's sister ship, the New Jersey, also will be taken out of service, leaving the Navy with two of its four active battleships. Moosally's request to retire is being processed and is subject to approval by the secretary of the Navy, a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet's Surface Force said Wednesday. Saying Moosally had ``24 years of distinguished service,'' Lt. Cmdr. John Lloyd said no pressure was placed on him to retire. Moosally, a 1966 graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy, said his decision to retire was made last weekend after discussions with his wife and his three children.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Will Reassess Bans on Groups
DOC.TEXT: The government will reassess the need for bans on the African National Congress, the South African Communist Party and other militant opposition groups, the justice minister said Thursday. A ``comprehensive review'' of the legal status of all restricted and banned organizations was beginning, said Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee. The ANC, outlawed since 1960, has listed the lifting of such bans as one of its preconditions for halting its guerrilla campaign and joining negotiations on a new political system that would include the black majority. Murphy Morobe, spokesman for the United Democratic Front, a national anti-apartheid coalition aligned with the ANC, said, ``If Mr. Coetsee really means what he says, it can only be welcomed.'' Coetsee's statement followed a defiant announcement Wednesday by the United Democratic Front that it would resume full-scale, overt operations. The front has been forced to operate clandestinely since February 1988, when it was among 17 groups prohibited from conducting any activities. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok, in response, invited the United Democratic Front to apply for the restrictions to be lifted but said its leaders could face prosecution of they resumed operations without getting permission. Morobe called Vlok's comment ``disturbing.' Morobe said, ``The government needs to learn that freedom of expression and association should never be dished out like an act of benevolence. It is a human right which we in the UDF strongly believe the government has no legitimate right to deny.'' The pro-government newspaper Beeld said in an editorial that the government should lift the bans that prohibit South African news media from quotiing designated opposition leaders, including many officials of the ANC and Communist Party. In the same edition, Beeld quoted banned Communist leader Joe Slovo as saying his party no longer endorsed the goal of a one-party system for South Africa. Business Day, a liberal daily, carried similar remarks by Slovo in its editions Thursday. There has been no indication either newspaper faces legal action.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Groups Plan Protests at Conference On Treaties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to update with confrontation and meeting recessed, picking up at the 4th graf pvs, ``Critics say.''
DOC.TEXT: More than 50 protesters rallied at a downtown hotel today, disrupting and forcing recess of a meeting sponsored by a Wisconsin lobbying group opposed to some Indian treaty provisions. The three days of meetings are sponsored by the Wisconsin Counties Association, a group of elected county officials in Wisconsin. Gov. Norm Bangerter has said Utah officials would shun the meeting. About 20 of the protesters, including Indians and their local supporters, picketed outside the hotel. Inside, 30 others lined up at the meeting room door, trying to gain entrance to the meeting from which most Indian tribal leaders were denied entry. Mark Rogacki, executive director of the association, said representatives of county governments in more than a dozen states planned to attend the conference. He said the conference would center on issues surrounding the exercise of rights within treaties and application of Indian governments on non-Indians. WCA Director Mark Rogacki recessed the session following an angry confrontation with David Hill, a Choctaw Indian from Konawa, Okla., who entered the room and refused to leave. When Rogacki told Hill he could not attend the meeting, Hill called Rogacki a ``cockroach,'' and said he would not voluntarily leave. Rogacki recessed the meeting. About a dozen police officers were called to the hotel and began clearing the meeting area. There was no violence. Critics say members of the association are trying to curtail Indians' off-reservation access to natural resources. ``They're out there to find reasons to abolish the treaties,'' Chippewa spokesman Michael Allen said in Wisconsin. Chippewa in Wisconsin have off-reservation rights to timber, wild grain, fish and game under 19th century treaties upheld by a federal court in 1983. Treaty opponents say the ruling discriminates against non-Chippewa businessmen, fishermen and hunters. Rogacki said the issues are complex, concerning water rights, mineral rights, gambling, the judicial process and tax exemptions. He said Wisconsin county governments have jurisdictional disputes with the Chippewa tribe. The treaties were signed originally with the federal government but federal officials refuse to help, he said, adding, ``the feds have taken a walk on this.'' Loretta Metoxen, recording secretary for the National Congress of American Indians, said the group seeks to abrogate the treaties and take away Indians' rights. ``I think the fact that the counties are meeting out there and not inviting Indians suggests something might be amiss,'' said Sue Erickson, a spokeswoman for the Great Lakes Indian Fish and Wildlife Commission, which oversees off-reservation fishing and hunting regulations for Wisconsin's Chippewa. Utah's governor is avoiding the conference and hopes to improve relations with Utah Indian tribes. Francine Giani, a spokeswoman for Bangerter, said Wednesday that he wants to avoid ``the appearance of anything that would threaten treaties.'' Giani said the governor has worked hard to improve relationships with Utah's various tribes and wants to continue to work with them. Conference organizers failed to make the meeting a cooperative affair between Indians and local governments, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin Calls for Delays in Some High-Tech Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of House Armed Services Committee called on the Bush administration Thursday to delay production of some high-tech weapons in light of budget pressures and a lessening Soviet threat. ``What we might do is pursue a real research and development system, rather than a develop and buy system,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said in a speech delivered to the National Strategy Forum in Chicago. A text of the address to the private group interested in national security issues was released in Washington. The Wisconsin Democrat said the Warsaw Pact can no longer be perceived as a cohesive military alliance ready to respond blindly to orders from Moscow. In response to areas where the threat has diminished, the United States should reduce its spending on defense. If an agreement is reached creating numerical parity among Warsaw Pact and NATO, the United States ``might not need to pursue expensive, risky, high-tech weapons designed to attack them. We have been pursuing such weapons,'' he said. Specifically, Aspin said full production of the Advanced Tactical Fighter, a top secret, stealth-like aircraft, might be delayed until it is determined whether a Soviet threat exists that requires a fighter plane of the future. ``For the budget year 1991, the House Armed Services Committee might hold up ATF and buy the current generation of fighters _ F-15 and F-16,'' the congressman said. But Aspin stressed the need for a new class of U.S. submarines, the SSN-21 or Seawolf class, in response to the greatly improved Soviet subs. Present day U.S. submarines cannot physically accomodate the necessary improvements, he said. Aspin said the Bush administration has made consideration of the 1991 military budget difficult because it failed to supply sufficient information about changes in the Soviet threat and began discussing budget cuts before presenting a strategy. ``The budget that comes to us in 10 days will undoubtedly be cut. The question is how wisely,'' Aspin said. ``What we hope to do with the strategy ... is give our colleagues a new way of dealing with the budget. Without such a strategy, the strongest guiding force may be the aroma of pork.''

DOC.HEAD: Worker Falls to Death on Biosphere Project
DOC.TEXT: A glazier working on the Biosphere II project fell to his death Thursday, the first of any accidents on the $30 million habitat experiment. Kathleen Dyhr, a spokeswoman for N.H. Ulmer Inc. contractors of Tucson, said Joseph Wayne Arrington, 36, of Catalina, Ariz., was installing glass panes on a 65-foot-high, steel-and-glass ``space frame'' when he slipped. The frame will enclose the 2-acre project, in which eight people plan to spend two years cut off from Earth's atmosphere. They will depend for food, water and oxygen on natural recycling after construction is finished in September.

DOC.HEAD: International Trade Ban Officially Enters into Force
DOC.TEXT: An international treaty to protect the dwindling herds of African elephants by banning trade in ivory went into force Thursday but leading producing and consuming nations refused to be bound by it. Five southern African nations that regularly cull their elephant populations have filed for exemption, while China has declared it will continue importing the prized tusks. Britain has asked for a six-month trading extension for Hong Kong to allow the colony to sell off its ivory stockpile of 670 tons, the world's largest. The trade ban was agreed after bitter debate at an October meeting of the 103-nation Convention on Trade in Endangered Species. Countries had until Thursday to file for an exemption to enable them to continue trade with those members who also filed reservations or with the 60 countries outside the convention. South Africa, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Botswana and Malawi submitted reservations by the deadline, said Jean-Patrick Le Duc, spokesman for the Swiss-based convention secretariat. South Africa and Zimbabwe, which both have large, well-managed elephant populations, have argued they need revenue from ivory sales to continue protecting the majestic beast successfully. At last year's conference, the southern African countries clashed with the pro-ban lobby, led by Kenya and Tanzania, which have seen their once thriving herds drastically reduced by poaching. Conservationists estimate there are between 400,000 and 700,000 elephants still roaming the African continent, compared with 1.5 million in 1978. The World Wide Fund for Nature, which says that 125,000 elephants were killed in 1988, warns that the largest land animal may become extinct in 10 years if the rate of slaughter increases. The world's biggest consumer of ivory, Japan, bowed to international public opinion and announced at the end of October it would respect the ban. In previous years the country had purchased about 40 percent of world ivory exports, buying about 106 tons in 1988. Britain had declared it would abide by the ban, but only hours before the deadline filed a six-month reservation for Hong Kong. The colony has no separate voting rights in the convention. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the extension to the trading period was designed to give traders time to dispose of the legally acquired stocks. A Greenpeace spokesman in London said the organization was ``horrified by this government's sacrifice of the African elephant to appease the greed of the Hong Kong ivory barons.'' News of agreement on the ban in October prompted demonstrations last year in Hong Kong, where about 4,000 people, many of them elderly craftsmen, earn their livelihood from carving ivory. Beijing has imported on average 50 tons of ivory each year and will be an important market for the African nations now that markets in the United States, Europe and Japan are closed. But an official from the international group said there was concern that despite government prohibitions, residual demand in Western countries will still be met by smuggled ivory, be if from poached or legally killed beasts. Bans on trade in a number of other animal and plant species placed on the endangered list at the October meeting also entered into force Thursday. These include the salmon-crested cockatoo, Pacific Island flying foxes and 60 types of orchid.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Prime Minster Urges Early Local Elections
LaserPhoto WAR51
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki asked parliament Thursday to move up the date for democratic elections for local governments, saying Communist holdouts are resisting reform. ``The government's most important task next to leading the nation out of economic collapse is the building of a strong and stable democratic foundation for a democratic system,'' Mazowiecki told the Sejm, the lower house of parliament. ``Until we create a real `self-government,' we will not defeat the resistance that we meet while introducing reforms.'' Parliament members rose to their feet and applauded his call for earlier elections, despite concern that Poles may blame the East bloc's first non-Communist government for suffering caused by the radical economic and political reforms it imposed. As a sign of that discontent, more than 6,000 miners demanding higher pay were on strike for a third day at five southern mines, the official PAP news agency reported. The strikes are the first significant labor protest since the government began implementing the reforms. The local elections had been expected in June or November, but Solidarity leader Lech Walesa on Monday urged earlier balloting. Mazowiecki said the reforms are being implemented too slowly at the provincial and municipal levels, where the Communist officials remain in power. During the 40-minute speech, Mazowiecki also announced that legislation abolishing censorship will be submitted next week. A law lifting restrictions on free speech and gatherings will be ready in February, he said. Communist President Wojciech Jaruzelski, who watched Mazowiecki's speech from a gallery, agrees with the new election timetable, the pro-Solidrity Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper reported Wednesday. With a non-Communist prime minister and the Communists' power waning as economic reform sweeps state-run industries, the provincial and municipal governments are a last area of control for the party apparatus. ``The government elected in free and autonomous elections is executing its power in the name of the people and answers directly to them,'' Mazowiecki said. ``We have never had such a self-government since World War II.'' The law has allowed the prime minister to approve candidates for mayor before they are elected by municipal councils. In that way, all local governments were ultimately controlled by the Communist-dominated central government. The Communist-run municipal governments, in turn, allowed the party apparatus to run local affairs, including commerce, allocation of scarce raw materials and distribution of a wide range of privileges. Solidarity candidates won an overwhelming victory in free parliamentary elections in June, leading to creation of the Solidarity-dominated government that ended four decades of Communist control of Poland. Mazowiecki said Polish-Soviet relations are now normal and no longer guided by ``ideology and relations between Communist parties.'' The prime minister praised Poland as a leader of East bloc reform and ``a stable point on the European map.'' ``Our society accepting with dignity and calmness the difficulties connecting with the repairing of the economy arouses respect in many countries,'' he said. ``The course of our reform stimulates changes in other countries of the region. The failure of our efforts could make more difficult the evolution occurring in Central and Eastern Europe,'' he said. The prime minister also assured Poles that price increases will lessen as the economy moves toward capitalism. He appealed to the increasingly restive agricultural sector to understand that the market must replace guaranteed prices for farm products.

DOC.HEAD: Loudon Declines Role in New `Annie'
DOC.TEXT: If a revival of ``Annie'' rises out of the ashes of ``Annie 2,'' it will be without Dorothy Loudon as the evil Miss Hannigan. ``Dorothy loves `Annie' but has decided not to do the revival,'' her agent, Lionel Larner, said. But director Martin Charnin confirmed Wednesday he was proceeding with the revival and would hold auditions here next week. Loudon, who won a Tony Award in 1977 for her performance in the original musical, reprised the role in ``Annie 2,'' a $7 million sequel which was subtitled ``Miss Hannigan's Revenge.'' It folds Saturday at the Kennedy Center in Washington. ``Annie 2'' was supposed to open in New York on March 1 after the Washington tryout, but its producers decided to close the show after overwhelmingly negative reviews. Producers Lewis Allen and Roger Berlind had announced Monday they were hoping to retain the stars of ``Annie 2,'' including Loudon, Harve Presnell who plays Daddy Warbucks and Danielle Findley who plays Annie, for the revival. It would use much of the sets and costumes from the sequel. No opening date and theater were announced. The producers of ``Annie 2'' are negotiating with the Goodspeed Opera House to rework the show later this year either at its theater in East Haddam, Conn., or at its second home in Chester, Conn., which has been used as a showcase for new musicals.

DOC.HEAD: Boyer: College Campus Life Should Be Improved
DOC.TEXT: College and university leaders should treat students as individuals and integrate academic life with the non-academic as a way to combat apathy, alcohol abuse and racial and ethnic conflicts, an educator said Thursday. ``What higher education needs today is not more rules, but a new post-in-loco-parentis theory of campus governance, a set of agreed-upon standards to guide the conduct of all members of the community and give direction to the institution overall,'' said Ernest L. Boyer, president of The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. Boyer, addressing more than 1,200 higher education leaders at an American Council on Education meeting, suggested five principles that can ``serve as a framework within which a vital community of learning can be built.'' Colleges and universities must integrate the academic life with the non-academic, honor the ``sacredness of the individual'' and vigorously affirm equality of opportunity, he said. Freedom of speech must be uncompromisingly protected and civility ``powerfully affirmed,'' he said. Colleges and universities must have well-defined procedures that ``guide behavior for the common good,'' as well as promote service and show support. Boyer said he was troubled by a 1989 Carnegie survey that found student apathy, alcohol abuse and racial and ethnic divisions. Those things, he said, ``weaken the vitality of many institutions.'' ``Administrators are understandably concerned about these problems. But they also are, we found, ambivalent about how they should respond,'' Boyer said. The study found two-thirds of the professors interviewed believe their students are not academically well-prepared; more than 60 percent said they are teaching undergraduates what the students should have learned in high school; and 55 percent said undergraduates were ``doing just enough to get by.'' A separate study found 77 percent of students spent fewer than 16 hours every week in out-of-class study. ``This is hardly surprising since, according to the latest ACE data, three-fourths of today's students have a job and work, on average, 37 hours every week,'' Boyer said. The survey, Boyer said, found a ``growing inclination among some students to use words ... as weapons of assault.'' More than 60 percent of the presidents at research and doctoral institutions say sexual harassment is a problem and about half listed racial harassment as a problem, he said. Boyer said two-thirds of all college presidents rate alcohol abuse a serious problem, while the figure is 82 precent at research and doctoral institutions. ``When we asked all presidents to name their greatest concerns, substance abuse, especially alcohol, was listed number one,'' he said. Boyer, a former U.S. education commissioner, said his proposals were a preview of an upcoming Carnegie special report called ``Campus Life: In Search of Community.'' The year-long study was launched in cooperation with the ACE, the coordinating body for higher education. The Carnegie Foundation, headquartered at Princeton University, was founded in 1905 as a policy center to strengthen American education.

DOC.HEAD: US Missions, Too, Are Well Armed
DOC.TEXT: Some U.S. diplomatic missions boast an impressive array of weapons, including anti-tank missiles, to protect America's envoys from armed attacks, according to a Bush administration official. The White House complained loudly after recently finding such weapons at the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence in Panama City and said the practice may violate international laws governing embassy activities. The residence was supposed to be off limits to outsiders but the U.S. forces had been led to believe that the ambassador lived elsewhere. President Bush called the incident a ``screw-up'' but criticized the Nicaraguan ambassador, Atenor Ferrey, for having ``weapons up to his eyeballs'' at the residence. The remark angered an administration official who said the United States' own efforts to rotect its diplomats sometimes include stashing large quantities of weapons at its missions. If a hostile group entered U.S. facilities in these countries, ``don't you think they would find RPG's (rocket-propelled grenades)?'' the official asked. ``You don't think we have TOW (anti-tank) missiles in some compounds?'' Several officials, all requesting anonymity, said the incident at the Nicaraguan embassy and others in Panama involving U.S. troops may make American diplomats the targets of reprisals. One administration official, accusing the U.S. military of failing to consider the possible fallout of its actions, said, ``We cannot conduct diplomacy on the basis of 25-watt thinking.'' Over the last decade, the State Department has been working to enhance security at posts where U.S. policies are highly controversial. The potential vulnerability of diplomatic missions was underscored by the 1979 Iran hostage crisis and the 1983 attack on the U.S. Embassy in Lebanon, which claimed 47 lives. The discovery of the weapons cache at the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama prompted an administration statement Jan. 8 questioning the legality of the Nicaraguan actions. The U.S. ambassador to the Organization of American States, Luigi Einaudi, said in a speech to the OAS that international law requires diplomatic missions to be used solely for diplomacy. ``It would appear that the existence of a substantial arms cache in the ambassador's residence in Panama is inconsistent with the diplomatic functions protected by the Vienna Convention,'' Einaudi said. But the union of career U.S. diplomats, the American Foreign Service Association, said the incident at the Nicaraguan Embassy and others at the Panamanian missions of the Vatican, Cuba and Peru may pose threats for U.S. envoys. The incidents ``put in jeopardy American diplomatic missions all over the world,'' said Perry Shankle, a former president of the association. He was the only official interviewed who was willing to be quoted by name. The association has expressed its concerns in a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Chaney. The State Department insists the United States subscribes fully to rules spelled out in the Vienna Convention of 1963, which set rules covering the rights and privileges of embassies. On the other hand, the department acknowledges that an ``unusual situation'' has prevailed in Panama. In an effort to track down Panamanians who had served deposed Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, American troops have been checking cars entering and leaving the Cuban mission. Some experts contend such vehicles apparently are exempt from such examination under international law. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler has said the Cuban ambassador's car ``has very dark, tinted windows which require troops guarding the mission to open the doors to identify the passengers.'' But one State Department official who asked not to be named said the action ``exposes every American ambassador to the possibility of an armed blockade. He would have to agree to be searched. This is appalling. This is the most appalling thing I've ever seen.''

DOC.HEAD: China Releases 573 Arrested During Pro-Democracy Protests
DOC.TEXT: China has released 573 people arrested for their part in pro-democracy protests last spring and held for six months or more without being formally charged, it was reported Thursday. The ``lawbreakers'' were released after ``they pleaded guilty and showed repentance,'' the official Xinhua News Agency quoted a Public Security Ministry official as saying. The report did not provide the names of any of the released and Chinese sources familiar with those being let go say it does not appear that any leading student activists from the April-June democracy movement are among the freed. Chinese sources reported recently that significant numbers of people were being released, including students, but none was a leader of the movement. The releases, like the lifting of martial law in Beijing last week, seemed directed at foreign governments that are considering whether to resume soft loans to China. The martial law decision did little to ease political repression in the capital, still guarded by larger-than-usual troop and police forces. Western nations have urged China to lift martial law and release political prisoners as measures needed to restore relations strained by the Beijing government's bloody suppression of the democracy movement. Thousands of students and their supporters were detained nationwide after the military attack of June 3-4 that killed hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of people. The official media have reported the executions of 20 people, none of whom were students, for rioting during the nationwide turmoil. Chinese sources say others have been executed secretly or sentenced to lengthy jail terms, but an official news blackout has left it unclear how many remain in prison and whether charges have been brought against the detainees. Chinese law says prosecutors must file formal charges in court within 45 days after a person is detained, but authorities may extend that period in serious cases, and the law is widely ignored. Also ignored is the legal requirement to notify families, many of whom received the first word on their relatives' fate when they were released. The ministry official said public security departments ``always strictly observed the law and proceeded from facts in dealing with these lawbreakers who took part in the counterrevolutionary riots.'' He said: ``Our policy is to educate anyone who can be educated and temper punishment with leniency.'' He said he hoped others who ``broke the law and obstinately stuck to the wrong course'' would repent and plead guilty for leniency. Chinese sources say that many of those released still must report to police once a week for further investigation and confession writing. Some have had their academic degrees withheld or are unable to get jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Flawed, Yes, But Not Child Molesters, Buckeys Assert
With AM-Preschool Molest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The issue Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, wanted the jury to consider was not whether they were perfect people, but whether they were guilty people. The Buckeys spoke openly at the McMartin preschool mass molestation trial about Buckey's problems with alcohol, his collection of pornographic photos and Mrs. Buckey's own molestation as a child. But they strongly argued that such dirty laundry, as they characterized it, fell far short of proving them to be child molesters. ``I never in my life have harmed a child, nor could I comprehend how anyone could harm a child,'' Buckey testified in a 1986 bail hearing in his first statements to the court. The Buckeys were the last remaining defendants in wha started out in 1983 as the largest and most sensational child molestation case ever, seven defendants accused of molesting as many as 125 children. Charges were dropped against five defendants, leaving the mother and son to face 64 counts of molestation and a shared count of conspiracy involving the alleged molestations of 11 children at their family-owned school. During a 2{-year trial, some of the former students testified in detail of being molested by the Buckeys and spoke of being photographed, playing games like ``Naked Movie Star'' and watching Buckey mutilate small animals. The Buckeys were jailed through much of the case. ``I've been isolated in a nightmare,'' Buckey said after his release in February on $1.5 million bail. His mother eventually was released on $295,000 bail. ``We are all innocent and have not done one thing wrong,'' Mrs. Buckey said in May. Mrs. Buckey, 63, was director of the preschool, which closed in 1984. She became involved in the 1960s, running one of two family-owned preschools. She took charge of both several years later when her mother and school founder Virginia McMartin began having health problems. In 1976, the schools merged. Fond of loud muumuus and flashy jewelry, Mrs. Buckey was described by parents as flamboyant, almost to the point of being tactless. She surprised many parents, for instance, when she admitted that as a girl she was molested by a neighbor. She also said she kept a close eye on her son, who started working at the school in 1981 after dropping out of San Diego State University. Among his duties were watching children as they napped or checking on children who stayed awake to play during the lunch hour. Mrs. Buckey watched her son so closely that, to allay the fears of a parent worried about a man working at the school, she checked to see if he became aroused when students climbed onto his lap. She said he did not. Mrs. Buckey characterized her son as a good teacher, except for a problem with maintaining classroom discipline. She said her son loved children and became a better teacher as he gained experience. ``He told me he felt very comfortable, that he enjoyed working with children and felt children accepted him,'' she said. ``He did not always feel that way about adults. The children liked him for what he was.'' Other witnesses, including Buckey himself, testified about his drinking problem, his use of marijuana and his habit of wearing shorts without underwear. Once, a student grabbed his genitals in a classroom, Mrs. Buckey testified. Buckey also said he collected adult photos which he used to sexually gratify himself. But Buckey denied he was guilty of child molestation. ``I have no sexual desire for children,'' he testified in August. ``I never have and never will.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Rulers Warn Against Disruption of Election
DOC.TEXT: The government warned political parties Thursday not to disrupt the May 27 elections after the most popular opposition figure was disqualified from running. A spokesman for the ruling military junta accused a foreign embassy and a political party of distributing anti-government pamphlets to other embassies and parties. Col. Than Tun did not identify the embassy or the party but said the pamphlets included U.S. State Department condemnations of the detention of opposition leaders Aung San Suu Kyi and Tin Oo. Other pamphlets contained the texts of Voice of America radio broadcasts critical of the government, he said. Than Tun said distribution of the pamphlets could be ``construed as a move to create unrest.'' Ms. Suu Kyi and Tin Oo, leaders of the popular National League for Democracy, were put under house arrest in July and accused of subversion. Tin Oo was sentenced last month to three years in prison at hard labor. Ms. Suu Kyi has not been formally charged but a regional office of the government-appointed Election Commission on Tuesday disqualified her from running in the election, the first multiparty balloting in three decades. Western diplomats in Rangoon said the capital was calm Thursday. They were contacted by telephone from Bangkok, Thailand, and spoke on condition of anonymity. Ms. Suu Kyi, an outspoken critic of alleged abuses by the military government, had applied to run for a parliamentary seat in Rangoon. She was barred partly because of alleged links to a banned student rebel group. Representatives of the National League have appealed to the central Election Commission. Ruling with the aid of tough martial law, Gen. Saw Maung's government has arrested thousands of dissidents and harassed politicians such as Ms. Suu Kyi, diplomats said. The junta seized power in a September 1988 coup when it crushed a national uprising for democracy. Troops killed several thousand dissidents that year in a series of crackdowns. U Nu, the country's last democratically elected prime minister, was put under house arrest in December and banned from the election after he refused to dissolve a parallel government he formed at the height of the 1988 uprising. The 83-year-old U Nu was elected in 1960 and ousted in 1962, the beginning of one-party military rule. More than a dozen ethnic groups are fighting the Burmese government for greater autonomy. One group, the Karen rebels, have been fighting for four decades along the border with Thailand. A Thai police officer said Thursday that Burmese troops rained mortar fire on sawmills run by the rebels, sending more than 1,000 civilians fleeing into Thailand. About 1,500 troops attacked the timber sawmills, just opposite Phob Phra district in Thailand's Tak province early Tuesday, the officer said on condition of anonymity. He said about 1,000 rebels and students were guarding the mills at the time. The Karens have financed their insurgency by controlling the black market trade in timber and other goods between Thailand and Burma.

DOC.HEAD: White House to Fed: Lower Interest Rates `Are Justified'
DOC.TEXT: The White House broke with its usual practice of not commenting on Federal Reserve policy Thursday by suggesting that cuts in interest rates ``are justified'' by current economic conditions. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the Jan. 8 reduction in the prime rate by banks, to 10 percent from 10.5 percent, ``hasn't been totally passed through'' and that the administration hoped it would be. Although it has engaged in more subtle forms of credit easing, the Fed has not changed its bellwether discount rate _ the rate for short-term loans it charges to banks and other financial institutions _ for nearly a year. The discount rate stands at 7 percent. Usually changes in that rate by the Fed result in changes in other interest rates throughout the economy. Asked whether the administration was intentionally sending a message to the independent central bank from the White House briefing room, Fitzwater said: ``This is not a new message. But it's important occasionally to point out that lower interest rates are normally good for the economy.'' His comments came amid reports that momentum for easing interest rates at the Fed may have ended. Fitzwater said recent economic reports argue for an easier credit policy. Fitzwater, in particular, said Thursday's report by the Commerce Department that housing starts fell by 8 percent in December was ``not good news'' and was ``well below market expectations.'' ``That's the best indicator we have. I mean, housing starts are more responsive to interest rates than anything else,'' he said. Fitzwater said Bush will tell the National Association of Homebuilders in Atlanta on Friday that ``interest rates are going down.'' The president will also tell his audience ``we hope'' lower rates ``will be translated into increased market sales and that we have always favored lower interest rates and we still do.'' Fitzwater also reacted to an article in Thursday's editions of The Wall Street Journal quoting two Fed members, Vice Chairman Manuel Johnson and Wayne Angell, as indicating that lower interest rates were not likely in the near future. ``We're hopeful that they (the Fed) will take a look at this morning's indicators and understand that these numbers are low and indicate that inflation has remained very steady over the last seven or eight years and that lower interest rates are justified,'' the spokesman said. The article said the comments of the two Fed members _ who have led the move for lower interest rates in recent months _ made further easing by the Fed unlikely for now. Although the Fed has not lowered the discount rate since last February, it has engaged in financial fine-tuning since last June that has relieved pressure on interest rates. The most recent was action last Dec. 20 in supplying extra reserves to the banking system that enabled banks to lower the rate they charge each other for overnight loans _ the so-called federal funds rate _ to 8.25 percent from 9.25 percent. To further bolster the administration's case that interest rates should be further lowered, Fitzwater cited the Labor Department's Thursday report that showed inflation had grown a moderate 0.4 percent in December, and had increased by 4.6 percent for all of 1989. Although it was the highest annual increase since 1981, Bush said the CPI report showed in general that ``inflation is low and under control.'' Asked whether Bush had spoken to Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan recently on the subject of interest rates, Fitzwater said: ``He has spoken to him so often, I'm not sure that's relevant.'' David Berson, an economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, said White House jawboning of the Fed is to be expected. ``Every administration wants lower interest rates,'' he said. ``I don't think the current administration is different from any administraion.'' Furthermore, he said he did not think the low housing start figure was evidence of any basic weakness in housing. ``It's evidence only that we had very bad weather in December,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Undersea explorer Jacques-Yves Cousteau said Thursday the six children he took along on his recent mission to Antarctica sometimes had a sweet view of what constitutes a good time. During one jampacked day when the group went to see colonies of penguins, seals and other creatures from the ice continent, they stopped at a Polish research station on the way back to their ship. Cousteau said when he asked one of the children if he'd had a good day, the child replied: ``Oh, it was great. They gave us cookies at the Polish station.'' Cousteau left Jan. 3 from Chile for Antarctica with one child from each of the six other continents. The children, ages 11 and 12, returned to Chile on Sunday. The mission was meant to symbolize that ``Antarctica belongs to future generations, not to us,'' he said. The Cousteau Society has joined an international initiative sponsored by the French and Australian governments to declare Antarctica a ``natural reserve and land of science'' and ban mining or other industrial activities. Cousteau said they built an igloo _ ``a symbolic home'' _ while there and some group members slept one night in it. ``The next morning we brought them a big thermos of hot chocolate and cakes,'' he said. ``They were happy like clams.''

Mick Jagger said ``any day now'' he'd marry Jerry Hall. That was back in 1983, but Hall said Thursday she and the Rolling Stone now both think it's a fine idea after two kids and 12 years together. ``For the first time, we both think marriage is a good thing,'' Ms. Hall told reporters at the Lyric Theater, where she will be starring in ``Bus Stop,'' with singer Shaun Cassidy. The Texas-born model and actress refused to confirm that her large diamond ring was an engagement present from the rock singer, who is in the Caribbean. ``He gives me a ring like this about once a year,'' she said. Hall and Jagger have two children: Elizabeth Scarlett, 5, and Leroy Augustine, 3. Ms. Hall appeared in ``Bus Stop'' in 1988 in New Jersey, and the British production will open next week in suburban Watford before moving to London in February.

Jane Goodall, who pioneered the study of primates in the wild, is joining the University of Southern California faculty. The British ethnologist will give occasional lectures and seminars as Distinguished Adjunct Professor of Anthropology and Occupational Science, the university said Thursday. She also will take graduate students into her various programs worldwide. Ms. Goodall, 56, who gained international acclaim during 30 years of research in Tanzania and for her close-contact studies of wild chimpanzees, will bring the university the most comprehensive records of animal behavior ever compiled.
