The materials represent ``really one of the most important ethnographic resources in the world,'' USC anthropologist Gary Seaman said. The facilities offered to organize her research materials was an important factor in her decision to join USC, Ms. Goodall said. She was born in London and lives in Tanzania. In the early 1970s she was a visiting professor at Stanford and served as curator of mammals at the California Academy of Sciences from 1985 to 1987.

Dethroned hotel queen Leona Helmsley is free pending appeal of a four-year sentence for tax evasion, but that didn't stop reporters from touring a prison she might get sent to if she does have to serve time. Khaki-clad inmates waved at cameras and shouted advice Wednesday for the woman who could end up their neighbor in the low- to medium-security Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury. ``You're going to get a new life here,'' shouted one of the 165 female inmates. There are also about 1,100 men in the prison. ``It's a nice camp. No bars, no guns and she would have her privacy and be treated as all other inmates,'' said Sylvia Jenkins, 52. Another inmate, Cora Cressey, 65, said the place was more like boot camp. Prison officials stressed that no final decision has been made on where Helmsley would be imprisoned if her appeal fails. Helmsley, convicted on 33 counts of income tax evasion, was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million.

Actor Don Johnson has asked a judge to throw out a lawsuit charging that he encouraged an employee to fire birdshot at a helicopter flying over his ranch on his wedding day. Johnson also filed a countersuit charging that Star magazine and pilot Burt Metcalf of Montrose invaded their privacy, were flying illegally and recklessly disregarded the safety of Johnson, his bride, actress Melanie Griffith and their guests. Johnson asked that the court absolve him of liability and force the plaintiffs to pay legal fees. Star, reporter Barry Levine and Metcalf sued in November, alleging that Johnson encouraged bodyguard Greg Isaacs to fire birdshot.

Actress Loretta Swit will help raise money for a new play area for five ``talking'' chimpanzees, which researchers at Central Washington University say are the first non-humans to learn sign language. Swit and Gov. Booth Gardner were scheduled hosts for a $150 per plate fund-raiser Thursday night, which was to include wild chimpanzee researcher Jane Goodall. The effort is for the Washoe Project at the campus in Ellensburg, about 125 miles to the east. Washoe is the pioneering chimp who was the first animal ever to learn a human language, said researcher Roger Fouts. The Legislature approved $1.5 million to build the chimpanzees a new home. They had been living on the third floor of a university building. But lawmakers didn't include money for a recreation area. ``Washoe hasn't seen the sun in 10 years,'' Fouts said.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Promise on Borders Signals Compromise to Appease Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, long vague about the eastern border of an eventually reunified Germany, appears to be abandoning claims to what is now Polish territory as a means of easing European fears of German revanchism. A day after Kohl assured Poles that Germans do not covet territory lost after World War II, the leader of the Free Democrats who share power with Kohl's party called Thursday for formal recognition of the current Polish borders. Kohl made his most convincing promise to date about the security of the Polish-German border during a speech in Paris on Wednesday before the French Institute of Foreign Relations. ``We want a durable reconciliation with Poland, and to that belongs the certainty that those in Poland know that they live within secure borders,'' Kohl said. ``No one wants a second exiling, as the first one was horrible enough.'' After the Nazi defeat in World War II, millions of Germans were driven from their homelands when the territory was deeded to Poland. About 2 million of the impoverished and defeated Germans died during the forced exile. Kohl has been criticized for failing to assure Poland that its current western border would be respected by a reunified Germany. Calls by some Bonn government figures for reunification within the 1937 borders have made European neighbors fearful of a revanchist Germany _ one that would seek to recover territory lost with the war. Finance Minister Theo Waigel, leader of the arch-conservative Christian Social Union of Bavaria, is most prominent among those West German officials to have openly coveted the lost German territories. Waigel's CSU and the liberal Free Democrats under Otto Graf Lambsdorff are the junior partners in Bonn's three-party governing coalition. Lambsdorff fanned the border issue during a parliamentary debate Thursday when he proposed that the Bundestag and the East German parliament jointly declare recognition of the border between Germany and Poland to be the Oder and Neisse rivers, the current delineation. Kohl has contended only a formal peace treaty between Poland and Germany could establish permanent boundaries. But he made no effort to contradict his coalition partner during the Bundestag session he attended. The chancellor said in his speech on the 50th anniversary of the Sept. 1, 1939, Nazi invasion of Poland that West Germany holds no claims to territory in Poland. But then, and again before his November visit to Warsaw, Kohl argued he could not commit an eventually reunified Germany to the border policies of the western state. Prospects for return to a single Germany have brightened considerably over the past two months, since the Berlin Wall and other borders were thrown open and East Germans began welcoming closer ties with their western brothers. Poles and other Europeans have grown increasingly uneasy during that time, fearing that those in East Germany and West Germany could seek to recover the former German territories now part of Poland and the Soviet Union. Kohl's speech in Paris offered no concrete promises. But its tone and references to the horrors of exile appeared aimed at assuring Poles and others that the border would not be tampered with. ``The Germans _ and no one should doubt it _ have no intention of starting in tomorrow's Europe a discussion about frontiers which would necessarily compromise the order of European peace to which we all aspire together,'' he said. West German newspapers on Thursday hailed the Paris speech as Kohl's clearest signal on the unsettling border issue. ``Kohl gives political guarantee for the Oder-Neisse line,'' the respected Sueddeutsche Zeitung of Munich heralded across the top of its front page. The more conservative Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung said Kohl ``stood without ifs or buts for European responsibility,'' and correctly predicted a definitive statement on the border issue would be avoided at the parliamentary session.

DOC.HEAD: Legal Teams Were Evenly Matched In Molestation Case
With AM-Preschool Molest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: They were evenly matched, two against two, veteran prosecutors and defense attorneys equally obsessed with the McMartin preschool molestation case that consumed their careers for years. In the prosecution corner sat Lael Rubin, 47, English teacher turned prosecutor whose belief in the guilt of the defendants propelled her to push on in a case many said was unwinnable. Ms. Rubin, a 1978 graduate of the University of West Los Angeles School of Law, spent nearly six years on this crusade and for half of that time was assisted by Roger Gunson, 50, a taciturn prosecutor who once saw his most famous defendant _ Roman Polanski _ slip out of the country to avoid sentencing. Gunson, a graduate of UCLA Law School, stepped in when two prosecutors bowed out in a storm of controversy. On the defense side of the courtroom sat two lawyers as different as opposite sides of a coin. Danny Davis, 43, a Texas-born advocate with a smooth voice and an inexhaustible supply of verbiage, represented Raymond Buckey with a zeal that bordered on excess. He argued Buckey's innocence with the fervor of a revival preacher and personally attacked those who opposed him. Davis is a former Marine Corps captain and a graduate of the University of Texas at Austin. He handled corporate and civil litigation but few criminal cases before he took on Raymond Buckey's defense. His co-counsel, Dean Gits, 45, a Los Angeles defense attorney since 1972, was so soft spoken that sometimes he could not be heard in court. Gits always gave polite deference to his client, Peggy McMartin Buckey. He fought hard in his quiet way to defend a woman he believed was innocent. Overseeing the combatants was the stern Superior Court Judge William Pounders, a legal scholar who often seemed pushed beyond his endurance by the McMartin case. Once, he told participants he felt that everyone who ever touched the case was ``poisoned'' by it. And he spoke of his own attraction to it as ``a moth to a flame.'' To his chagrin, the case stretched over 2{ years, becoming the longest and costliest in U.S. history with a price tag over $15 million. Buckey, 31, and his mother, 63, were charged with 65 counts of conspiracy and molestation at their family owned preschool in Manhattan Beach. Five other defendants originally charged had their charges dismissed after a preliminary hearing. Pounders' nemesis in the long trial was Davis, and he often denounced the defense attorney's tactics. He used a computer to keep track of how long Davis spent on each cross-examination and scolded him for prolonging the trial. Once, after listening to Davis question a burly ex-felon for five days about Buckey's purported jailhouse confession, Pounders declared he was ending Davis' inquiry. ``At some point, you've got to sit down and shut up, and I'm saying that time is now,'' he told Davis. ``I trust the court is not angry with counsel,'' Davis replied, unflustered. ``Yes, I am,'' Pounders snapped. ``I don't want to spend the rest of my life sitting here being bored to death.'' Pounders, 50, was appointed to the Los Angeles County Superior Court in April 1985 after serving almost 13 years as a deputy attorney general and two years as a Los Angeles municipal judge. A Loyola Law School graduate, Pounders is regarded as a highly intelligent jurist who has compiled a meticulously organized file of more than 20,000 notations on index cards as references for his rulings.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The Alabama Senate is sometimes called ``a circus,'' and its members got into some serious clowning around Thursday while voting to honor a real star of the big top. State Sen. Larry Dixon got the Senate to pass a resolution honoring animal trainer Gunther Gebel-Williams, who is on his final tour with Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus after 20 years as a star of the center ring. Dixon said the Senate would present the resolution to Gebel-Williams at the Statehouse on Feb. 1 and then lawmakers would go to a luncheon hosted by the circus, which will be appearing in Montgomery. He said circus clowns would be at the luncheon. State Sen. Ann Bedsole jokingly questioned the resolution, saying: ``An awful lot of people around the state already call us the Alabama state circus.'' She also questioned the propriety of having professional clowns wandering around the Senate chamber, but Dixon corrected her, saying the clowns would only be at the luncheon. ``They can't bring the professional clowns in here because we have no room on the floor for any more,'' he said.

Park the latest General Motors Corp. concept truck near Waikiki Beach and someone may toss a worn-out lei in the back. Or say ``you're welcome.'' In a linguistic gaffe, the world's largest automaker tagged its latest show pickup the Mahalo. In the recently ended North American International Auto Show, GM said the word meant ``hang loose.'' Nope. Nohea Lani Wallace, who teaches at the Center for Hawaiian Studies at the University of Hawaii, said ``mahalo'' means ``thank you.'' He said it often appears on trash cans in the Aloha State to thank people for not littering. Now, how many guys would be willing to take their buddies hunting in a pickup called a ``thank you.'' ``Basically, what we found out is that we were wrong,'' a GMC spokesman said Wednesday. He said the mistranslation originated in the division's marketing department. GMC will continue to use the name when the truck makes the rounds of future auto shows.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Closes Second Newspaper, Bars Another from Christian Area
DOC.TEXT: Christian Gen. Michel Aoun escalated his drive to muzzle dissent in the media Thursday by suspending the operations of one newspaper and barring another from the Christian enclave he controls. The Al-Bayrak newspaper was ordered to stop publishing for seven days. It was the second such order by Aoun this week. Aoun also started legal proceedings against the newspaper for defying a directive he issued Tuesday, which barred the media from referring to Elias Hrawi as the president of Lebanon. Aoun refused to accept Hrawi's government because it was formed as part of a peace accord that Aoun opposed. Until now, Lebanon's press, the freest in the Arab world, had remained unfettered throughout the 14-year-old civil war. The latest measures left only the conservative newspaper An-Anwar functioning in the Christian enclave. An-Anwar has adhered to Aoun's rules, calling Hrawi ``Mr. Elias Hrawi'' and referring to the prime minister, whom Aoun also refuses to recognize, as ``Professor Salim Hoss.'' Hoss holds a doctorate in economics. The Christian region's leading daily, Ad-Diyar, was ordered Wednesday to cease publication for a week because it defied Aoun. Al-Bayrak followed Aoun's order Wednesday, but on Thursday, publisher Milhem Karam published a front-page editorial in which he vowed to defend press freedom. Radio and TV stations in the Israeli-controlled zone in south Lebanon, usually sympathetic to the Christian army commander, also ignored Aoun. So did Middle East television, a branch of the Rev. Pat Robertson's fundamentalist Christian Broadcasting Corp., which broadcasts from the southern zone. Three radio stations maintained a news strike for a third day to protest Aoun's measures. The army general's troops stopped a truck carrying copies of the French-language L'Orient-Le Jour from entering east Beirut from the Moslem sector in the west. An official from the distribution company said an army captain told the truck driver, ``L'Orient-Le Jour is banned for not abiding by the general's directives.'' The An-Nahar newspaper, the nation's most prestigious Arabic-language daily, did not publish for a second straight day to protest Aoun's orders. It is published in west Beirut, but most of its editorial staff live in the Christian enclave and commute daily. L'Orient-Le Jour and An-Nahar had been the only west Beirut-based papers allowed by Aoun to sell in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The remaining four dailies operating in west Beirut have not been allowed into the Christian enclave for more than a year because of their strong opposition to Aoun's policies. The leftist newspaper As-Safir, which operates from west Beirut, said Aoun was ``isolating the media in east Beirut in preparation for declaring his own state of free Lebanon in the enclave.'' The ban, the paper said, was the ``first step in a series of measures that the general wants to apply. He'll partition the unions, the economy and everything in Lebanon.'' Aoun's directive said Hrawi should only be referred to as a former parliament deputy. Hrawi was elected president under a peace plan worked out by Lebanese legislators in October. Aoun opposed the peace plan because it did not include a deadline for the withdrawal of Syrian troops who were deployed in Lebanon in 1976 to quell civil war fighting. Aoun said the Syrians abrogated their mandate by siding with the Moslems in the war, and he has vowed to drive them out.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Palestinian Activist Accused of Helping Uprising Group
DOC.TEXT: A leading Palestinian activist was accused in court papers Thursday of giving money to a PLO-backed underground group and supporting its plans for guerrilla attacks in Israel, army radio said. In another court case, the army filed charges against Col. Yehuda Meir, the highest-ranking officer to face trial during the 25-month-old Palestinian revolt in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Soldiers shot and wounded 17 Palestinians during stone-throwing clashes in in the occupied lands, Arab hospital officials said. The army said it was checking the reports. Palestinian Feisal Husseini was listed as an unindicted co-conspirator in documents filed at the start of a trial of five other Palestinians. A military court in Lod has charged the five, ages 19 to 35, with forming a PLO-supported ``popular army'' unit to carry out the orders of the underground leadership of the uprising. According to court documents, Husseini gave the men $450 to buy uniforms in October. Military prosecutor Capt. Roni Shapira told the court that a member of the group informed Husseini of its plans to carry out attacks in Israel, the army radio said. Husseini voiced support for the idea and agreed to discuss guerrilla action, but the suspects were arrested before they could meet, court papers say. Husseini denied the claims. ``There is no truth to that story,'' he said in an interview. Husseini, 49, heads the now-closed Arab Studies Society in east Jerusalem. He spent 18 months in Israeli prisons at the start of the uprising but was never charged or tried. In recent weeks Israel has issued two orders banning him from traveling to the occupied lands and abroad. The bans also applied to six other Palestinians and drew a strong protest from the United States, which said the move could hurt the Middle East peace process. Husseini, scion of a large and influential Palestinian family, is expected to play a leading role if Israeli-Palestinian peace talks are held. He has said that the uprising's most pressing aim this year is to win the confidence of Israelis who deeply distrust Palestinian declarations of peaceful intentions. Earlier this week, Attorney General Yosef Harish said he will investigate remarks Husseini made at a news conference that allegedly supported collaborator killings. During the uprising, Palestinians have killed at least 170 fellow Arabs, accusing them of helping Israeli authorities. Another 648 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis; 43 Israelis also have died in the violence. Meir, who served as military commander of Nablus, the largest town in the West Bank, is charged with ordering soldiers to beat and break the limbs of 20 bound and gagged Arabs in January 1988, Israel radio said. Troops under Meir's command left beaten and bound Palestinians in a field until other Arabs arrived and rushed them to a hospital. The army's chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, reprimanded Meir and gave him the choice of leaving the army or facing trial. Meir resigned but the Supreme Court last month overturned the military's decision not to prosecute him. Meir is charged with improper conduct, abuse and causing grievous bodily harm. If convicted, he faces a prison sentence of up to 20 years, Israel radio said.

DOC.HEAD: Armenians Again Observing a Sorrowful Christmas
With Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For the second year in a row, tragedy in the Armenian community in the Soviet Union has muted Christmas festivites for Armenian Christians here. The small Armenian community in Israel canceled some Christmas Eve festivities Thursday because of the ethnic fighting in two southern Soviet republics that has left dozens of Armenians dead and thousands homeless. Jerusalem's Armenian patriarch, Yeghishe Derderian, accused Moscow of not doing enough to stop the violence, in which Moslem Azeri Turks are battling Christian Armenians in the latest round of a protracted ethnic conflict. ``We condemn the negligent attitude of the Soviet authorities in the past,'' Derderian said. He appealed to world leaders ``to act with the utmost speed to stop the continuing bloodbath.'' The Soviet Union sent thousands of troops to the area, but scores of people have been killed since Saturday, many of them Armenians who were attacked by mobs in the Azerbaijani capital, Baku. Terrorized Armenians were fleeing the region by the thousands. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek, who met with Derderian this week, said Thursday that he offered his assistance to bring Armenian refugees to Jerusalem. Kollek said he also sent messages to the mayors of cities with large Armenian populations, including New York, San Francisco and St. Louis, asking them to ``speak up and protest the bloodshed.'' Armenian Christians in Israel said they would mark Christmas with religious services but not exchange gifts or hold parties. ``I don't see any reason why we should be celebrating,'' said Nassri Nasser, 43, a municipal employee in Bethlehem. ``It's even worse than last year.'' On Dec. 7, 1988, 25,000 Soviet Armenians were killed in an earthquake, casting a pall over Christmas festivities for Armenians in Bethlehem. ``We are going through a tough time,'' said George Hintlian, an aide to the patriarch. ``We decided there will be no festivities, only religious services.'' The highlight of the Armenian Christmas is the midnight Mass celebrated by Derderian in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem. The patriarch arrived at Manger Square on Thursday, escorted by Israeli troops and police. About 4,000 Armenian Christians live in Israel and the occupied West Bank. The Armenian Church is one of the Eastern rite churches that are organized along ethnic lines and accept the authority of the pope but have considerable autonomy in ritual and questions of discipline. Armenian Christians celebrate Christmas on Dec. 25, Jan. 6 or Jan. 18, depending on the sect they belong to.

DOC.HEAD: Felons' Right to Bear Arms Debated Before Maine Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: Maine voters never intended to give felons the right to carry guns in amending the state constitution two years ago, a state attorney told the Maine Supreme Judicial Court on Thursday. But a lawyer whose client escaped prosecution on a charge of possession of a firearm by a felon on the basis of the constitutional amendment said its wording leaves little room for any other interpretation. ``You would have to call black white,'' Daniel Bates said during an hourlong hearing dominated by spirited exchanges between the justices and the lawyers. Assistant Attorney General Charles K. Leadbetter said the trial judge committed a fundamental error in dismissing the charge against Edward Brown of Cumberland. Leadbetter said that state lawmakers, in sending the amendment out to the voters, made clear in their statements that it was intended simply to clarify the right to bear arms, not to supplant any existing restrictions on who may carry guns. ``The Legislature expressly addressed itself to that,'' Leadbetter said, asserting that ``it makes absolutely no sense, from logic or law'' to ignore the legislative history. ``What you're saying is that nothing changed'' with the passage of the amendment, said Justice David G. Roberts. Leadbetter said nothing changed in the voters' perception. Some of the justices questioned how comments made by legislators prior to the referendum could override its clear wording. ``The enactors were the people, not the Legislature,'' said Justice Caroline D. Glassman. ``The Legislature gave its opinion.'' Bates said Maine lawmakers could have included language stating that certain restrictions are allowed, as about 40 other states have done. The Brown case fostered an unusual alliance among the National Rifle Association, the national Center to Prevent Handgun Violence, the Sportsman's Alliance of Maine and the Maine Chiefs of Police Association, all of which supported the state's appeal. Last July, a lower court judge dismissed a charge of possession of a firearm by a felon against Brown, who previously had been convicted under the state's habitual offender law for operating a motor vehicle after his driver's license had been revoked. Superior Court Justice Stephen L. Perkins cited the constitutional amendment that voters approved in November 1987 and also found ``no rational connection'' between Brown's earlier conviction and his possession of a firearm. Perkins' ruling did not affect the portion of the law restricting the possession of guns by people convicted of crimes involving the use of dangerous weapons. The amended state constitution reads: ``Every citizen has the right to keep and bear arms, and this right shall never be questioned.'' The amendment deleted wording that said the right was ``for the common defense.''

DOC.HEAD: Quayle May Settle for Visiting Latin Leaders Outside Their Countries
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, facing resistance to proposed visits to several Latin American nations, may have to settle for talks with some leaders outside their home countries, administration officials indicated Thursday. Without going into detail, Quayle said that by the end of a March trip to presidential inaugurations in Brazil and Chile _ following a Jan. 27 trip to the inauguration in Honduras _ he believed ``we will have personally communicated with almost every leader in the hemisphere.'' However, several countries have signaled that it is too soon for Quayle visits because of simmering resentment over the U.S. military invasion of Panama, officials said. Quayle, speaking Thursday of his scheduled trip to the inauguration in Tegucigalpa, said, ``There'll be a lot of leaders there if we are able to work in the schedule and meet most of them. It's not necessary just to go and pay a courtesy call'' in each individual nation, he said in an interview with The Associated Press. He is expected to carry President Bush's explanations regarding the Dec. 20 Panama invasion, which rankled the Latin world. Aides said other, as yet undetermined stops are expected on the mid-March trip to Brazil and Chile. Quayle said he will not meet with the leaders of Peru, Colombia and Bolivia because Bush will see them Feb. 15 at the Colombia summit meeting on how to fight illicit drugs. The vice president's aides are scheduling at least four bilateral sessions with heads of state who attend the Honduras inauguration, said his press secretary, David Beckwith. He did not specify the countries. Aides have said scheduling of the trip has been bogged down by reaction from countries such as Venezuela where some officials have said it would not be good for Quayle to come while troops remain in Panama. In Caracas, Venezuela's foreign minister, Reinaldo Figueredo, said Thursday, ``We understand he's not coming,'' but refused to say why. Figueredo had said a day earlier, however, ``Maybe his visit is not the most adequate step to be taken given the conditions that exist with respect to the U.S. invasion of Panama.'' Quayle on Thursday characterized the Latin response as: ``It's not `don't come.' It's a matter of timing, when you would come.'' A day earlier he acknowledged that ``diplomatic sensitivities'' had come into play in planning the trip. The administration on Thursday tried to play down those problems at the same time it acknowledged inability to schedule visits to some capitals. ``Some of the trips ... may have to be scheduled for a later time, but we'll continue to work on that,'' said White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``Obviously there were concerns in Latin America following the Panama situation. Obviously there were reasons why the president felt it was necessary to reiterate our support and our interest in working with them,'' he said. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler sought to deflect reports that Quayle is unwelcome at this time by stating that Bush in announcing Quayle's trip, ``did not list a specific time; he did not list specific dates. He very clearly said how important this region is to us.'' Bush announced Jan. 5 he would dispatch Quayle to explain to the Latins that he had not unleashed the U.S. military in Panama without a rationale. But Quayle said his goal is not to ``go down on any fence-mending mission, or going down to apologize, but essentially create an understanding of how do we go about establishing a democratic government in Panama.'' He said he would push for countries to recognized the U.S.-installed government of Guillermo Endara.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Gag Order in Case of Upstate New York Killings
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Thursday denied requests for a gag order and for questioning of grand jurors about their objectivity in the case of a man authorities say killed 11 women. Attorney David Murante sought the gag order to prevent police and other officials from commenting further on the case of Arthur J. Shawcross. A grand jury is to begin hearing evidence Friday in the case. Murante said many comments made by police and the district attorney to the press about Shawcross have appeared to convict his client before he is tried. ``I don't know how my client can ever hope to receive a fair trial,'' he said. ``I don't see how any grand jury can hear this case fairly.'' But Monroe County Judge Charles T. Maloy said a gag order would be impractical. ``There always will be sources and news leaks,'' he said. Shawcross was at the hearing but did not speak. Murante also asked that the grand jury investigation be postponed 45 days and that jurors be questioned individually to determine if publicity about the case had influenced them. Maloy denied both requests, but said he will remind jurors to base decisions solely on the evidence. Prosecutor Charles Siragusa said a gag order is an extreme measure that would have been impossible to enforce over the eight months to a year it could take before the case comes to trial. Shawcross, 44, was arrested Jan. 3. He has been charged with nine counts of murder in the deaths of nine women. The grand jury is to review those charges as well as two other killings police believe he committed. He was paroled to Rochester in 1987 after serving 15 years in prison for the 1972 strangulation of an 8-year-old girl in Watertown.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Says It Will Decide On Seabrook License Within Three Weeks
DOC.TEXT: The federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Thursday it will make a decision within three weeks on licensing the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant. The announcement by NRC Chairman Kenneth Carr came after the commission listened for three hours as plant operators and the NRC staff reported that the long embattled plant is ready to begin producing electricity at full power. In a victory for plant opponents, the NRC agreed to rule on several contested issues, including emergency evacuation plans, before deciding on the license. Under the schedule outlined Thursday, a decision to grant a full-power license could mean that Seabrook would be producing enough electricity to power a million New England homes by May. ``There is reasonable assurance that the plant can and will be operated without endangering the health and safety of the public,'' the NRC staff concluded in its report to the commission. ``The staff recommends commission approval to issue a full-power license.'' Thomas Murley, the NRC's director of nuclear reactor regulation, told the commission that ``emergency preparedness at Seabrook is adequate to support full-power operations.'' Conceived more than two decades ago, the plant built near a salt marsh two miles north of the Massachusetts border cost $6.4 billion and the price tag is still rising. Seabrook has generated mass protests by environmentalists, lawsuits by Massachusetts officials and bankruptcy protection for its beleaguered principal owner, Public Service Company of New Hampshire. According to opponents, there are three crucial issues under dispute which the NRC must consider: whether evacuation plans are adequate; what is the definition of ``adequate;'' and how to resolve a disagreement between to lower-level NRC boards over aspects of the New Hampshire evacuation plans _ aspects that include the availability of shelter for beach crowds and the role of school teachers in an emergency.

DOC.HEAD: Rabin Foresees Steady Aid Levels to Israel Through Next Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs `Senate Republican ...' with 1 graf to DELETE redundant reference to Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin wound up talks with Bush administration officials Thursday saying he had ``reason to believe'' U.S. assistance to his country would hold steady at $3 billion a year through 1991. But Rabin registered concern beyond next year, saying Israel's budget is strained by a rising influx of Soviet Jews and increased Soviet weapons shipments to Syria, Iraq and Libya. He also indicated that Secretary of State James A. Baker III was unable to resolve a diplomatic impasse that is delaying Mideast negotiations on the future of the Israeli-held West Bank and Gaza. ``There are still gaps that remain between the Palestinians and Israelis,'' Rabin told Israeli reporters. The key question is whether the Palestine Liberation Organization will have even an indirect role in the negotiations that Baker hopes to launch. Rabin stressed Israel's budget problems, and concerns about U.S. aid, after he saw Baker. ``When it comes to the Middle East the glasnost is not seen there,'' Rabin said. He referred to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of openness, which has lowered barriers to Jews seeking to emigrate. At the same time, Rabin said, the Soviets had increased both the flow and quality of arms to the three Arab countries. ``In view of all this, we believe that we deserve the continuation of the level of support that we get,'' Rabin said. Israel is the largest recipient of American foreign assistance, receiving $1.8 billion in military aid and $1.2 billion in economic aid out of a worldwide budget of $14.6 billion. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas, apparently with the support of the administration, proposed this week diverting about $400 million from current recipients to Eastern Europe and Panama. But congressional sources said Thursday that President Bush planned to ask Congress to boost spending on foreign aid and other international operations by about $1.8 billion in 1991, forgoing cuts in assistance to Israel, Meanwhile, it was learned the U.S. Ambassador to Israel, in an assessment for the State Department, concluded Israel could get along with less than the $1.2 billion it receives in economic aid. A U.S. official, who declined to be identified, said Ambassador William Brown's assessment, first reported in The Washington Times, was the sort American embassies make periodically throughout the world. Still, Dole's proposal, and assertions Tuesday by the State Department it seeks ``flexibility'' in distributing foreign aid, has raised concerns in Israel. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said Baker had told Rabin that ``the United States has always supported Israel and will continue to support Israel.'' Asked if U.S. aid would be trimmed, Ms. Tutwiler said: ``I have never heard Secretary Baker discuss any cuts for Israel or for any other country specifically, for this year.'' Israel's concerns go beyond 1991, however, and while there seems little doubt U.S. aid will go to the country, the question is whether it will be less than $3 billion. Rabin did not say who assured him that Israel could count on current levels, at least through fiscal year 1991, which ends Sept. 30, 1991. But he made the statement in discussing a meeting he held Wednesday evening with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. ``I believe that for this fiscal year the budget is approved, and unless there will be cuts, which I hope will not take place, there will be continuation,'' Rabin said. ``When it comes to fiscal year 1991, I have the reasons to believe there will be no reduction in the support to Israel.'' Asked if he meant both military and economic aid, Rabin replied: ``The answer is yes.'' Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams, asked if it were true that foreign aid to Israel would not be cut, responded: ``That's fundamentally correct.'' Rabin met alone with Baker for 40 minutes. The discussion continued in the presence of U.S. and Israeli aides for another 20 minutes. Asked if there was a breakthrough on the diplomatic front, spokeswoman Tutwiler said: ``We're still working.'' Baker has been trying for three months to arrange a meeting in Washington with Foreign Ministers Moshe Arens of Israel of Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt. The main obstacle is disagreement over the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israel seeks to preclude any PLO role in the session and future negotiations leading up to elections on the West Bank and Gaza. Baker is due to meet on Friday with Abdel-Meguid, their third session this week.

DOC.HEAD: Government Scraps Referendum, Says It Acted Too Fast
With AM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government Thursday called off a national referendum on outlawing the Communist Party and reimposing the death penalty, saying it promised the vote in a fit of near panic and had made a mistake. The leadership made clear it will stick to its earlier decisions to ban capital punishment and allow the Communist Party to be legal _ moves that prompted huge protests one week ago. The governing National Salvation Front tried to appease the angry demonstrators by scheduling a referendum Jan. 28 to decide the death penalty issue, and by announcing a ban on the Communist Party. The following day, President Ion Iliescu revoked the ban, saying it had been a hasty decision. He said the party's fate also would be put on the referendum. During a news conference announcing the cancellation, spokesman Silviu Brucan also disclosed more abuses of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. He said officials learned that Ceausescu had access to dozens of ``palaces'' and villas and ran agricultural enterprises that provided hard-to-get food items to the Communist elite. The decision to call off the vote was made Wednesday night during a meeting of front leaders. At that meeting, Iliescu, vice president Dumitru Mazilu and premier Petre Roman admitted the decision to hold the referendum was ``a political mistake,'' Brucan said. He said the leadership was guilty of ``almost panicky decision-making'' under the pressure of the demonstrators Jan. 12 and added it would be impossible to arrange such a vote in such a short amount of time. Brucan bristled when asked whether the decision meant the government does not view public demonstrations as a form of dialogue. Countries in the West put limits on demonstrations, he responded, and added: ``Don't ask us to be more democratic than the British or Americans.'' The council agreed Wednesday that future decrees on political matters will be discussed by the entire council before being announced, he said. ``The Romanian people are learning democracy and we are learning to govern democratically,'' he said. ``Learning presupposes (that you) make mistakes. My hope is we will not make too big ones.'' The front outlawed the death penalty after the Dec. 25 executions of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, who were found guilty by a military court of genocide and of ruining Romania's economy. After the executions, Brucan said, ``we joined the civilized world by abolishing the death penalty maintained by Nicolae Ceausescu against the spirit of the Romanian people.'' Brucan said those who led Ceausescu's regime ``will be punished very severely ... for life.'' The decision follows statements against the death penalty by several European leaders who have visited Romania recently to discuss foreign aid. The ban on the Communist Party was reversed because it was ``anti-democratic and against the principles of the National Salvation Front,'' Brucan said. ``In the world, there is no democracy that forbids by law the existence of the Communist Party,'' he said. Brucan quoted Iliescu as saying that all those who served in high places in the Communist Party and the state under Ceausescu ``should gradually be removed.'' But Brucan also said this policy should take into account their ``professional competence and moral character.'' Romanian newspapers and opposition figures have complained that several of leading members of the National Salvation Front also were leaders under Ceausescu. They include Brucan and the vice president, Mazilu, who led anti-Communist chants at the Jan. 12 demonstration. Brucan said Mazilu apologized Wednesday night for allowing himself to be pressured by the crowd. Brucan said the assets of the Communist Party ``will become the property of the entire Romanian people and will belong to the state.'' These include Ceausescu's former residences in Bucharest, the nearby resort of Snagov and the mountain resorts of Sinaia and Predeal, which were among what Brucan termed 21 ``palaces'' the dictator used. In addition, he said Ceausescu had a villa available for his use anytime in each of Romania's 41 counties, and 20 hunting lodges. The ``Carpati'' trust run by the party managed 60 enterprises with a yearly profit of $420 million, including $220 million in hard currency, Brucan said. The Communist Party also controlled 45 agro-industrial enterprises employing 80,000 people who produced 40 million tons of meat, 20 million tons of milk and 40 million eggs each year to feed the Communist elite, he said, besides exporting produce at a profit of $15 million a year. Under Ceausescu's 24-year rule, many of Romania's ordinary citizens endured severe hardships, incuding shortages of heat and food, while the dictator focused on paying off the country's foreign debt. A military-civilian uprising drove Ceausescu from office Dec. 22. Brucan said the government will now focus on organizing national elections. The National Salvation Front proposed the election for April, but opposition leaders want it put off at least until June so they have more time to organize. A key dispute in planning the election will be whether the army, which made Ceausescu's overthrow possible by backing the revolt, will be allowed to sit in Parliament, Brucan said. He noted that Romanians have had no experience with free elections since World War II and that the government may accept international supervision of the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Morris Says Error Caused Worm To Go Berserk
DOC.TEXT: The worm program that disabled thousands of computers nationwide was intended simply to enter computers, but an error caused it to go haywire, the graduate student who designed it testified Thursday. ``My purpose was to see if I could write a program that would spread as widely as possible,'' Robert T. Morris told jurors in his federal computer tampering trial. ``The worm spread on the network far faster than I expected,'' said Morris, 25, who spoke publicly for the first time about the November 1988 attack that paralyzed an estimated 6,000 computers linked to the Internet network. The suspended Cornell University student said he designed the worm to break into Internet when questioned by federal prosecutor Mark Rasch. Morris said he gathered passwords from various universities and without permission decoded them to ensure the worm would spread widely. He also said he took steps to make the worm harmless and protect it from easy eradication. During questioning by defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni, Morris said he included mechanisms to limit the worm's growth and programmed the worm so it would not cause permanent damage to existing files in computers it attacked. Morris said it was difficult to limit the worm's growth, and safeguard against easy detection of the worm to stop it from entering their systems. Morris thought the worm would duplicate a few times a day or every few hours, but he made a programming error that caused the worm to replicate wildly. ``Once I released it I had essentially no contacts at all (with it). I couldn't control it,'' he said. Morris said he let the worm enter the Internet network through computers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. After releasing the worm from Cornell at about 8 p.m. on Nov. 2, 1988, he went out for dinner. When he returned about three hours later, he said, he noticed Cornell's own computer was slow to respond to commands. On finding copies of the worm in the Cornell system, he said he knew it was spreading and was not working right. He said he started to get scared. Morris said he considered sending out a second worm to track down and destroy the first one, but decided against that after seeing the unpredictable nature of the first worm. He also was unsure he could get into the computer system once the worm had begun to cripple it, he said. Instead, he said he called Andrew Sudduth, a friend at Harvard University, and asked him to send a message on an electronic bulletin board read mainly by Internet users. Morris said he wanted to apologize for unleashing the worm and tell users how to eliminate it. Sudduth testified at Morris' trial Wednesday that he eventually did send a warning message. But it didn't show up on the computer system for two days because the route he picked to keep his identity a secret already was backed up with mail, Sudduth said. Lawyers said they expected to give closing statements Monday. If convicted, Morris, of Arnold, Md., faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Navy: Trident 2 Missile Problems Solved
DOC.TEXT: The Navy declared its newest and deadliest missile program ``on track'' Thursday for a March deployment, announcing that the problems that caused submarine-launched Trident 2 missiles to spin out of control have been cured. ``My confidence is fully restored that we've solved the problem beyond a shadow of a doubt,'' Rear Adm. Kenneth Malley told reporters at a Pentagon briefing. Two of the first three submarine tests of the 44-foot, $26.5 million missile, formally known as the D-5, failed when the missiles self-destructed. Following two successful undersea launches earlier this week, Malley predicted the missiles will be deployed aboard the submarine Tennessee on schedule. The Navy has touted the Trident submarines and their new missiles as the ``the most effective strategic platform in the world today.'' ``The Trident 2 program is now on track. ... It still looks like it's very solid for the end of March,'' the admiral said of plans to have the submarine armed and ready for patrols. The USS Tennessee will be the first of 24 subs to go to sea, each with 24 of the weapons. The Trident 2 is capable of hurling as many as 12 nuclear warheads to individual targets more than 4,600 miles away. Malley said that the missile's motor nozzle system, blamed for two test failures of the Trident 2 missile earlier this year, has been redesigned. The admiral said that ``five separate fixes'' had been developed to solve the complex problem on the 130,000 pound weapon, which involved water entering the missile's nozzle system and a build-up of pressure that caused elements of the direction system to fail. That made the missile go into a pinwheel and self-destruct. The overall cost of the missile weapon program is $35.5 billion, a figure that includes the planning and procurement of 871 missiles through fiscal year 2001. Eventually, the missiles will be deployed aboard 21 Ohio-class submarines, the Navy said. Greenpeace protesters tried to halt a Trident 2 launch Dec. 4 by sending the 190-foot vessel MV Greenpeace, with 25 people aboard, into the Tennessee's launch safety zone. A Navy ship intercepted the intruding vessel and damaged it by repeatedly bumping it and using fire hoses to pour water down the smokestacks, stopping the engines. Navy sailors in swift boats corraled two Greenpeace high-speed rafts that tried to approach the Tennessee, cut their fuel lines and towed them out of the safety zone. Greenpeace had halted a Trident 2 test with the same tactics in July.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Blasts Sandinista Election Harassment
DOC.TEXT: Opposition candidates in Nicaragua have been subjected to intimidation and violence, the State Department said Thursday. The incidents raise ``grave questions as to whether there can truly be free and fair elections in Nicaragua'' next month, department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. The ruling Sandinistas, she said, have violated pledges to refrain from using state resources, including the government-controlled media, to further their own candidacies. Ms. Tutwiler issued the statement after the release Wednesday of an Organization of American States report that raised some of the same concerns. OAS Secretary General Joao Baena Soares said in a statement that he believes ``the electoral process in Nicaragua is coming along normally.'' ``This does not mean, however, that I fail to recognize that there had been some occurrences, such as violence, the use of television and acts of intimidation, which are reflected in the report,'' he said. Ms. Tutwiler said media reports this week indicated that Sandinista police tried to arrest the media adviser of the leading opposition group on the grounds that his car resembled one that had been stolen. Later, two Sandinista thugs threw rocks at his house, she said.

DOC.HEAD: East Bloc Leaders at a Glance
With AM-Bulgaria Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Communist leaders of East bloc nations and how they and some associates have fared since the revolutionary changes in those countries:
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Ceausescu was executed Dec. 25 along with his wife, Elena, his virtual second-in-command. Former Party secretary Emil Bobu will be tried on charges of bringing economic ruin on Romania and aiding genocide in the killing of thousands during the December uprising. At least half a dozen members of the Ceausescu clan, including sons Nicu and Valentin and daughter Zoia-Elena, are also under arrest and awaiting trial.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker was ousted by his own Politburo on Oct. 18. Prosecutors investigating Honecker, who is 77 and ailing, probably will try him on charges of high treason and corruption. Eight other members of his regime are in prison awaiting trial, including former economics czar Guenter Mittag and secret police chief Erich Mielke.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA
DOC.TEXT: Todor Zhivkov was dumped by party comrades Nov. 10 after 34 years in power. He was placed under house arrest Thursday and faces charges of inciting ethnic hostility, misuse of state property and malfeasance in office.
DOC.HEAD: CZECHOSLOVAKIA
DOC.TEXT: Former Prague party boss, Miroslav Stepan, is under arrest, charged with abuse of power for allegedly ordering a bloody crackdown on demonstrating students Nov. 17 that triggered the nation's peaceful revolution.
DOC.HEAD: HUNGARY
DOC.TEXT: Janos Kadar was removed as party leader in 1988 in the face of growing demands for reform. He died in July. Kadar's successor, Karoly Grosz, was relieved last year by a new group of reformers who dissolved the Communist Party and established a new Western-oriented Socialist Party.
DOC.HEAD: POLAND
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who decreed martial law in December 1981 to crush the Solidarity independent labor union, was elected president July 19 by the Polish National Assembly and has worked closely since then with the Solidarity-led government.

DOC.HEAD: Group Promises to Make Billions Available for Affordable Housing
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of the insurance, banking and thrift industries on Thursday promised a ``social compact'' with the nation's distressed neighborhoods to expand by billions of dollars the available loans and investment capital needed to produce affordable housing. ``Commercial banks, thrifts and insurance companies are committing to increase their conventional lending _ their market-rate lending _ to low- and moderate-income borrowers and in low- and moderate-income neighborhoods,'' said William A. Whiteside, executive director of the Neighborhood Reinvestment Corp. at a news conference. The additional private financing would be combined with below-market rate capital from local, state and federal governments, foundations and the NRC over the next 10 years for single-family home purchases, Whiteside told reporters. The new funds would be used to expand a 17-year-old loan-buying program administered by the NRC through Neighborhood Housing Services of America. ``The savings and loans have been and are America's primary housing financer,'' said Robert B. O'Brien Jr., vice chairman of the League of Savings Associations and chairman of the New Jersey-based Carteret Savings Bank. The thrifts have helped NHSA purchase more than $40 million in loans in 300 low-income neighborhoods with few defaults nationwide, O'Brien said. Area residents whose income equal 80 percent of a neighborhood's median income _ about $15,000 to $25,000 in most low-income neighborhoods _ would qualify for loans, he said. ``We think we can provide billions of dollars to rehabilitating the urban neighborhoods with market-rate investments,'' said Wayne E. Hedien, chairman of Allstate Insurance Co. ``This is a demonstrable coming together of private, neighborhood and public entities to accomplish a major goal and that's what we mean by the social compact,'' said Preston Martin, chairman of the California-based WSGP Financial Management Co. The expansion program amounts to a commitment in the financial community to help save older sections of the country's urban and rural areas, said Martin, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Thursday's speakers offered few specifics on how soon or how much money would be budgeted for the program. However, an annual $50 million interest rate subsidy mandated by last year's federal savings and loan bailout legislation would be included in any final figures, O'Brien said. A written statement promised that a group of 20 industry representatives, the ``Social Compact Leadership Group,'' shortly would announce ``goals for both direct and indirect increased lending and investment in such neighborhoods all across America throughout the '90s.'' The group is recruiting additional program sponsors.

DOC.HEAD: Boston University Board Grants Sabbatical for Office-Seeking President
DOC.TEXT: Boston University President John Silber was granted a sabbatical leave with pay to run for governor by the BU board of trustees in a unanimous vote Thursday. The 63-year-old Texas native announced Wednesday he would seek the Democratic nomination at the party's June convention. At Silber's request, he will take leave of his job at the helm of the 26,000-student private university starting Friday. He won't be expected to report back to work until the general election Nov. 6, although he is free to return anytime before then if he drops out of the race. The board appointed as interim president Jon Westling, currently the school's executive vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Elementary School Starts Random Drug Tests
DOC.TEXT: Some students at a Roman Catholic elementary school are reporting to a hospital to give urine samples in what may be the nation's first primary school drug testing program, school officials said Thursday. The first of the 25 students chosen at random from the sixth through eighth grade at St. Sabina Academy were taken by their parents Wednesday night to Little Company of Mary Hospital for the test, Principal Linda Bond said. Testing is to continue through Friday evening. A lottery to choose a different group of students for testing will be held each quarter of the school year. ``Then we wait for the results and if any kids are tested positive they are going to be going through counseling,'' Bond said. Jay Miller, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Illinois, called the testing ``outrageous,'' but said it couldn't be challenged on constitutional grounds in court because it had been adopted by a private school. ``It's the first case I've heard of in this country of any testing being done on children in this age group,'' Miller said. ``I think it's a terrible overreaction.'' But many youngsters at the all-black school and their parents are proud that the school may be the nation's first to test pupils for drugs. ``I care about the lives of these children,'' says the Rev. Michael Pfleger, pastor of St. Sabina's Church. ``When you talk about rights, if a child dies on drugs, he has no rights.'' Pfleger, who has gained a national reputation as an anti-drug crusader, said officials doubt a drug problem exists at the school, ``but we're doing the preventative stuff to make sure we don't.'' The Chicago Archdiocese's Office of Catholic Education rejected a proposal by Pfleger that drug testing be introduced in all local parochial schools, but said it wouldn't block individual schools from introducing such programs. St. Sabina's school board approved the random drug test program in November after a survey found that 210 parents favored it and only five opposed it, Pfleger said. ``The overwhelming majority of parents are behind the program, although we've encountered opposition from some parents who feel strongly about the psychological effects and invasion of privacy,'' said parent Sheila Grace. Grace's 13-year-old son, Sherman, an eighth-grader at the school, said he was glad to participate in the program. ``I'm proud to be a part of it because we are making history in showing that our school wants to be drug-free,'' said Sherman, who was to be tested Thursday. The school held a lottery this week in which the names of 25 students were pulled out of a container holding the names of the school's 200 or so sixth-, seventh- and eighth-graders. About 500 students attend St. Sabina, which offers classes from preschool to eighth grade. Pfleger, Bond and three teachers also volunteered to be tested. Pfleger said the testing is only one component in the school's comprehensive anti-drug program which also includes classroom teaching, faculty and staff training, parent education and community outreach.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes Continue at Coal Mines
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of coal miners continued their strikes for a third day Thursday at five mines in southern Poland, demanding higher pay and reforms in the industry, the official PAP news agency reported. The strikes are the first significant labor protest since the Jan. 1 implementation of radical economic reforms that have sharply raised prices but checked wage increases while trying to create a market-oriented economy and curb inflation. About 6,000 workers went on strike Tuesday at the Czerwone Zaglebie mine and another 40 at the Niwka Modrzejow mine, both in the city of Sosnowiec outside Katowice, a major industrial center about 185 miles south of Warsaw. Strikes also continued at Thorez, Walbrzych and Victoria, three mines in Walbrzych, a city 12 miles from the Czechoslovak border, PAP said. The agency reported the strike committee ``sharpened discipline'' when some of the 130 miners began to leave the occupation strike at the Thorez mine. ``To prevent this, the miners have been practically barred from entering or leaving the mine and resuming coal mining,'' PAP reported without elaboration. The miners at the Czerwone Zaglebie mine are demanding a $26 supplement to their wages for December. The miners in Walbrzych have similar demands for higher pay, PAP said. All the striking miners are calling for retention of special shopping privileges for miners, a reduction in administrative workers in offices and no repercussions against strikers. The negotiations resulted in the April 17 legalization of Solidarity after a seven-year ban and free elections in June. Solidarity's overwhelming victory led to formation of the East bloc's first non-Communist government.

DOC.HEAD: Chuck Berry Sues Magazine Over Nude Photos
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with denial from publisher.
DOC.TEXT: Rock 'n' roll pioneer Chuck Berry says pictures of him in the altogether with female companions were stolen, and he is suing the magazine for $10 million that published them. But the publisher of the magazine, High Society, said in New York Thursday that the pictures were purchased and the magazine has a signed release from the seller. Berry considered the photos his private property, attorney Melvin Belli said Wednesday after he filed the lawsuit in San Francisco Superior Court. Berry, 63, said he had the photos taken because, ``I've seen too many times when girls misused their relationship with fellas. I wanted something to show everything was merry-merry.'' Berry and his companion are posing side by side in most of the photos. No sexual acts are depicted. Berry said the photos were stolen in September from his business office in St. Louis and he does not know who turned them over to High Society. The photos were printed without Berry's permission and the magazine ignored requests not to print them, said Paul Monzione, the attorney handling the lawsuit for the Belli firm. High Society Publisher Gloria Leonard said that the magazine hadn't yet been served with the lawsuit documents Thursday. ``We legitimately purchased those photos and we have a signed release from the party from whom we purchased it,'' she said referring to the package of photos. Leonard refused to identify the seller. High Society runs many celebrity photos, and the magazine's attorneys are very scrupulous to ensure everything is checked out before publication, she said. ``We felt that he was certainly an interesting character, an icon of American culture, and we never (meant) to hurt him in any way. We have great respect for him,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: AZT At-a-Glance
With AM-AIDS Survival
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures about AZT, the drug used to treat AIDS: _ AZT, or zidovudine, does not cure AIDS. It does reduce the severity of symptoms and can prolong the lives of AIDS patients. It also delays the onset of symptoms in those infected with the virus who are not yet sick. _ It works by inhibiting reproduction of the AIDS virus. _ It has strong side effects including nausea, headaches and injury to bone marrow that can make transfusions necessary during treatment. _ It was the first anti-AIDS drug certified by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which approved its use for seriously ill AIDS patients in March 1987. _ It is marketed by Burroughs Wellcome Co. under the name Retrovir. _ It costs between $2,700 and $6,500 per year, depending on the dose. _ It is derived from herring sperm and was originally synthesized by Dr. Jerome Horowitz in the 1960's in a search for an anti-cancer drug. AZT failed those tests, but was revived when it demonstrated success against the AIDS virus. _ The first AZT tests against the AIDS virus occurred in February 1985, and tests on AIDS patients were performed in July 1985. _ AZT is now available in a new strawberry-flavored syrup that is easier for children to swallow than capsules and allows dosages to be adjusted for body size.

DOC.HEAD: Underage Gambler Sentenced for Another Violation
DOC.TEXT: A woman described by her father as a ``poster child for compulsive gambling'' was fined $750 Thursday for underage gambling in a pattern that stretches back four years. Debra Kim Cohen, who turns the legal gambling age of 21 on Feb. 8, also received a suspended 30-day sentence and a year's unsupervised probation as part of her agreement to plead guilty to charges of violating her probation and playing blackjack Dec. 13 in Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino while underage. Municipal Prosecutor Steve Smoger said Ms. Cohen, of Ventnor, failed to follow terms of her original probation. He said he didn't know what more could be done for her since she will soon turn the legal gambling age. Her original probation included counseling and attendance at Gamblers Anonymous sessions, neither of which she did, Smoger said. ``She's now making the transition from underage gambler to possibly compulsive gambler,'' Smoger told Municipal Judge Bruce Weekes. ``She will have to deal with the problem as she sees fit.'' Smoger said later that the fines are the largest ever imposed on an underage gambler in Atlantic City. When Ms. Cohen was a 17-year-old high school student, she received complimentary dinners and limousine rides from casinos in a series of incidents in 1987. A complaint was filed in October of that year and five casinos later paid $18,000 in fines and made donations of $162,000 to compulsive gambling programs. Ms. Cohen denied outside the courtroom that she gambles compulsively. Her father disagreed. ``I pray that when she turns 21 ... the excitement of the game no longer exists,'' said Leonard Cohen, an Atlantic City police detective. ``Kim has pretty much become a poster child for compulsive gambling.'' Cohen, who wrote letters to the casinos long before his daughter was first caught, also blamed the gaming halls for weaving an illusion they are the ``way to wealth.'' Smoger said his investigation showed the casino acted properly. Wayne G. Marlin, a spokesman for the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, said the agency's investigation is continuing. Weekes said in sentencing Ms. Cohen that she can no longer blame others for her problems. Smoger said he grew tired of hearing Ms. Cohen's reasons why she could not attend counseling, one of which was that she felt uncomfortable at Gamblers Anonymous meetings because she was surrounded by older men.

DOC.HEAD: US May Lift Barriers to Czech Exports
DOC.TEXT: The United States is considering extending trade benefits to Czechoslovakia to help smooth the transition there from communism to a free market economy, the State Department said Friday. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the administration is considering a waiver of an amendment which bars Czechoslovak exports from entering U.S. markets at the lowest possible rates. The amendment, applied mostly to the Soviet bloc since its adoption 15 years ago, is aimed at countries which restrict emigration. It has made most of the products of these countries uncompetitive in U.S. markets. One of the co-authors of the amendment, former Rep. Charles Vanik, D-Ohio, wrote to President Bush last month and called Czechoslovakia ``a revitalized nation'' that has ``clearly met all the conditions'' of the legislation. ``The most important thing America can do (to help Czechoslovakia) is provide an immediate, fair and equal access to our markets,'' Vanik wrote, according to an account in Thursday's editions of The Washington Post. Czechoslovakia has moved toward the establishment of a free market economy since the collapse of the hard-line communist government at the end of November.

DOC.HEAD: Thursday's East Bloc Developments at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Thursday's East bloc developments:
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Ministry called up reserve troops to help 29,000 soldiers quell ethnic violence between Azerbaijanis and Armenians in the Caucasus that has killed at least 66 people and wounded more than 220. At least 10,500 Armenians have fled the Azerbaijani capital of Baku. Interior Minster Vadim Bakatin termed it a civil war.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, the hard-liner who ruled for 35 years, was been placed under house arrest on charges of inciting ethnic hostility, misuse of state property and malfeasance in office. Sources said talks between the Communists and the opposition on the transition to democracy were suspended until Monday because of disagreements over opposition demands for a voice on state radio and TV.
DOC.HEAD: POLAND
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki asked parliament to move up the date for democratic elections for local governments, saying Communist holdouts are resisting reform.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested a former Politburo member under investigation for corruption and abuse of power and put him in prison to await trial, along with seven other ex-leaders. Communists and opposition groups held their eighth round of talks, with the opposition demanding a role in dismantling the hated secret police force.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA
DOC.TEXT: The government called off a national referendum Jan. 28 on outlawing the Communist Party and reimposing the death penalty, saying it promised the vote in a fit of near panic and had made a mistake. The leadership made clear it will stick to its earlier decisions to ban capital punishment and allow the Communist Party to be legal _ moves that prompted huge protests a week ago.

DOC.HEAD: British Move on Elephant Ivory Seen as Threat to Ban on Trade
DOC.TEXT: British refusal to join a ban on trade in ivory threatens the international effort to save the African elephant from poachers, the World Wildlife Fund said Thursday. The United States and most other countries have joined in the ban. Illegal slaughter of elephants has greatly reduced their numbers in recent years. ``We're afraid Britain's action will collapse the whole international agreement,'' said Dana Lauren West, a press officer for the organization. ``It's a shock, a complete reversal of the British position. They did it to protect Hong Kong's trade,'' Ms. West said. China is due to take Hong Kong back from Britain in 1997, but Britain still acts for the colony in world affairs. Hong Kong is among the leading processors of ivory. ``They're sitting on 600 tons of it now,'' Ms. West said. China opposed the trade ban from the start. It was to go into effect on Thursday as a result of a vote last Oct. 17 by representatives of 103 governments meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland. All are members of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. South Africa, Zimbabwe and Zambia also submitted ``reservations'' _ in effect exempting themselves from the ban. They supply both raw and carved ivory. Ms. West said there was an unconfirmed report that they are now being joined by Botswana as well as Britain. Member countries have until midnight Thursday to make their decisions. After that, environmentalists will have to get together, review the effects of the defections amd decide what to do next, she added. Japan and Singapore, which had been mainstays of the ivory trade, have so far said they are ready to go along with the ban, Ms. West reported. The fund said in an earlier statement that Singapore has several tons of stockpiled ivory and a flourshing industry in carving it into goods for export. Ms. West said that British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday transferred authority on the issue from her Environment Ministry to the Foreign Ministry, which submitted the British reservation. ``Because Britain belongs to the European Economic Community, we're afraid it may serve as a funnel to the other countries,'' she added. Goods flow with few restrictions among the 12 members of the community, which include the main countries of Western Europe. ``It's appalling,'' said Ginette Hemley, head of the fund's unit that monitors trade in wildlife. ``England's and China's decision ... is a green light to ivory poachers. ... It's ironic that Great Britain, one of the first European countries to ban ivory, is the only Western nation to oppose the ... decision. While Japan, one of the largest consumer countries of ivory, has remained steadfast in its promise to uphold the ban.''

DOC.HEAD: Bandits Offer Hot Goods on TV `Swap and Shop' Show
DOC.TEXT: What looked like a good buy wound up as a good bust after police arrested two men who had advertised stolen property at cut-rate prices on a TV shopping program, police said Thursday. Dino Blanco, 18, and Frederick Hallock, 20, both of Hampton Bays, were each charged with two counts of burglary after their arrest, said Southampton police Detective Richard Loos. According to Loos, the pair called WLNG's ``Swap and Shop Program'' on Wednesday and offered a television and microwave for a low price. But a buyer became suspicious when the sellers insisted on meeting in a parking lot instead of a home, the detective said. The buyer called police, who sent two plain clothes detectives to meet Blanco and Hallock. The detectives determined that property had been swiped from two homes, Loos said.

DOC.HEAD: FAA, Airlines Huddle Over Bomb Threats
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration is appealing to the nation's airlines not to go public when they receive terrorist threats against passenger flights, an FAA spokesman said Thursday. The agency plans to make its case during a meeting Friday with industry representatives in the hope a consensus will emerge. The FAA called the meeting in the aftermath of the decision by Delta and Northwest airlines to publicize recent threats against some of their flights. The disclosures ran counter to traditional policy in the airline industry to take threats seriously but not to publicize them. FAA officials believe such publicity is counterproductive, disruptive and serves only to boost the number of false threats, a spokesman said. But Bert Ammerman, the head of an organization formed after the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, strongly disagreed, arguing that airlines should tell passengers _ but not the press _ of any threats against their flights. ``It is unconscionable that the FAA would be meeting with the airlines to suppress information that is the right of every traveling person to have, based on the circumstances that presently exist,'' said Ammerman, a New Jersey school administrator who is president of ``Victims of Pan Am Flight 103.'' His brother, Tom, was among 270 people killed in the December 1988 bombing. Ammerman contends that telling passengers of threats is essential because airlines cannot now provide adequate security to protect their flights. ``Right now, their attitude is, ``We can't protect you, we are not going to tell you, so therefore, passengers, please continue to play Russian roulette,'' Ammerman said. Ammerman and his organization are calling for the creation of an independent agency to increase security at airports, train security personnel and evaluate performance. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar said that in a typical year some 200 to 300 bomb threats are received of which only a tiny fraction, perhaps ``less than half a threat,'' are genuine. ``Our position up to now is that such threats should not be publicized,'' Farrar said. ``We are going to be talking with the airline representatives about whether it is a good idea.'' ``We know from experience that in excess of 99 percent of the threats that are received are hoaxes,'' Farrar said. ``When terrorists are involved they do not advertise their intentions.'' Publicizing a threat serves only to ``gratify some kind of urge'' and will likely lead to further threats, he said. Additionally, he said, making a threat public causes people to disrupt travel plans out of what is in most cases ``needless concern.'' ``That is not to say that we take these threats lightly,'' Farrar said. ``They are all checked out and any measures that need to be taken are taken.'' Ammerman said he is not advocating that the airlines give threats wide publicity but rather convey them privately to passengers holding tickets on the flights involved. ``I'm not saying it should be given to The Associated Press and United Press International and sent out around the world,'' he said in an interview. ``You would be telling a lot of people that making a threat is a fun thing to do.'' ``I am saying that passengers should be told of the threat when they come to the counter in the terminal, that they should be told that measures have been taken, and then the offer should be made to make other travel arrangements if they are not comfortable,'' he said. ``You have to allow the traveling public to make a decision,'' Ammerman said. Doug Miller, a spokesman for Northwest Airlines, said its policy is similar to the one Ammerman suggests. ``We have a policy not to make any bomb threats public unless we feel there is a specific and credible threat to a specific flight, and then we will tell only the passengers,'' Miller said. ``The passengers are the only ones that are impacted by the bomb threat and we feel they are the only ones with an absolute right to know about the threat,'' he said. Miller said Northwest had planned to follow that policy in the case of a threat to a recent specific ight between Paris and Detroit. But he said news organizations learned of the threat, prompting the airline to confirm it because ``we felt it would be naive of us to deny it.''

DOC.HEAD: Warm Spell Is Luxury For Some, Annoying To Ice Golfers
DOC.TEXT: The unseasonably warm weather that washed across the eastern half of the nation this week has been a blast for outdoor vendors and others who have to be outside, but it put a crimp in some winter recreation. ``It's such a great day,'' JoAnn Melonie said as she rushed back from her lunch break in Camden, N.J. ``It's too nice to be inside.'' The nice weather even forced postponement of a golf tournament. The 20th annual Polar Ice Cap Golf Tournament on Spring Lake at Grand Haven, Mich., scheduled for Saturday, was postponed because ice on the lake was getting too thin. It got into the 50s Wednesday. ``We're supposed to have winter and here we have spring,'' complained Crystal Shipe, a staff member with the Grand Haven Chamber of Commerce, which co-sponsors the event. ``People are confused by this. We should be able to play golf.'' The week started with record highs in the Mississippi Valley, but as cooler air moved in the record highs Thursday were confined to the East. They included 62 at Boston and Newark, N.J.; 70 at Baltimore; 57 at Concord, N.H.; 64 at Philadelphia, 58 at Portland, Maine; 71 at Roanoke, Va.; and 68 at Washington. But as a reminder of what time of year this is, Thursday's low in Yellowstone National Park was 22 degrees below zero. Catherine Geiger said The Boardwalk Peanut Shoppe where she works on the Boardwalk in Atlantic City, N.J., benefited from extra foot traffic drawn out of the casinos and down to the shore. ``Business has been great,'' she said. ``It hasn't exactly doubled, but it's better by far.'' The balmy temperatures also are good for the hot dog business. ``It's incredible, at this time,'' said Gladys Mendes, who has been selling franks outside Newark City Hall for five years. ``Two weeks ago: cold. No business. The people, too cold, keep in the office.'' The warmer air formed an inversion over parts of northern New Jersey and New York City, trapping pollutants and creating unhealthy conditions Thursday,for the elderly and the sick, officials said. The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said there were high levels of smoke and particulates. Buffalo, N.Y., got 3 feet of snow during December's record cold wave, but it was nearly all gone by Thursday because of the warm weather. Wednesday's high was 55. But the heat wave did not disrupt the city's Winterfest _ city officials decided in September to cancel it because warm weather played havoc with it the last three years. Out West, Denver doesn't have any snow and that concerns the producers of the new movie ``Die Hard II,'' starring Bruce Willis, who planned 10 days of filming in the city starting Monday. ``It can't be 70 degrees,'' said ``Die Hard II'' publicist Marcy Bolotin. ``The film happens at Christmas, when it's cold and dark. We need snow. It all depends on your weather.''
