In Minnesota, the warm spell was not enough to thaw a 42-inch layer of frost in the soil that could prevent much moisture from soaking into the ground during the spring thaw, weather officials say. That deep a layer of frozen soil is as much as usually develops during an entire winter, officials say. ``When spring arrives, the snow will all run off,'' said Jim Campbell of the National Weather Service in Minneapolis. That's a problem because parts of the state are 40 months into a drought. Thanks to modern snow-making equipment and the December cold snap that allowed production of very thick layers of man-made snow, many ski resorts were able to weather the warmth and keep at least parts of their slopes open. Even in Georgia, Sky Valley at Dillard had three of its five slopes open this week. The temperature hit 58 Wednesday and 500 skiers turned out, said Janie Yearwood, the resort's director of recreational activities. ``We're still doing extremely well, although some people are disappointed when they come to find out how we make snow and we can't do it because it's not cold enough,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With Turkish President
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Turkish President Turgut Ozal discussed Thursday the implications for NATO of the changes in Eastern Europe and reaffirmed close U.S.-Turkish security ties. An administration official, who asked not to be identified, said Bush also assured his guest that he will ```vigorously oppose'' a pending Senate resolution to designate April 24 as a day of remembrance for Armenians allegedly massacred by Ottoman Turks decades ago. Bush, at the outset of his Oval Office meeting with Ozal, expressed to reporters his ``delight'' with a Sen. Bob Dole proposal to shake up U.S. foreign aid allocations and give the White House, not Congress, more say over where the money goes. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that in the Oval Office meeting and a private lunch, Bush and Ozal talked at length about ``the Middle East and the sweeping changes in Eastern Europe, with special reference to the Balkans.'' They also discussed the conventional force reduction talks in Vienna and ``NATO's vital role in a changing Europe,'' Fitzwater said. Turkey plays a major defense role on NATO's southern flank and is home to strategically important U.S. bases. ``The president and President Ozal agreed to continue their pattern of close consultations and stressed the importance of U.S.-Turkish security cooperation at this time of rapid change in Europe and in East-West relations,'' he said. The two leaders also reaffirmed their support for United Nations-sponsored negotiations to solve the Cyprus question. Turkey hotly disputes charges that Ottoman Turks massacred 1.5 million Armenians between 1915-23. Ozal said in a speech at the International Club of Washington Wednesday night that, ``This is a matter for historians, not political people'' to decide. A resolution designating April 24, 1990, as a day of remembrance for the Armenians passed the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last fall despite strenuous lobbying by Turkey and strong White House objections. The White House source said Bush assured Ozal his administration will ``vigorously oppose'' the resolution in its current form when it comes before the Senate, which returns next week from a holiday recess. Bush also indicated a willingness to work with Congress ``on a balanced resolution,'' the source said. Ozal met earlier Thursday with Dole, the Senate minority leader from Kansas and author of the Armenian resolution. Asked if he planned to discuss Dole's proposed foreign aid cut, Bush replied, ``I won't be talking about that. I'll be talking about my delight that somebody understands that it's the president that ought to set these priorities and that's why I'm very pleased about it.'' ``I want to see it put the power where it should be on this matter, and not mastermind foreign policy through 138 subcommittees allocating funds,'' Bush told reporters at the outset of the Oval Office meeting with Ozal. Dole has said he will propose legislation cutting allocations to Turkey and the four other biggest recipients of U.S. foreign aid by 5 percent to free $330 million to help the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. Dole's proposal would seek to curtail the common congressional practice of ``earmarking'' chunks of the $14 billion in U.S. foreign aid for specific countries and projects. ``I'd like to see it done the way I think the founding fathers intended for it to be done. And don't worry about our friends, Turkey. We will take care of that,'' said Bush. Ozal said Wednesday that his country would refrain from interfering in the conflict raging in the Soviet Caucuses, and he took pains to distance Turkey from its ethnic ties to the Azerbaijani people. Ozal is on a 10-day visit to the United States that includes meetings with the heads of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and American investors.

DOC.HEAD: Atmosphere is Seen Ripe for Afghan Political Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Najib as single name is cq
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Undersecretary of State Robert Kimmitt said Thursday that warmer U.S.-Soviet relations have created an opening for a political end to Afghanistan's protracted civil war. Kimmitt hinted that the two superpowers have embraced a more conciliatory approach to Afghan peace talks. While Washington still insists that Marxist President Najib be removed, his departure is no longer seen as a prerequisite to opening peace talks. Moscow has resurrected a year-old offer of a ``transitional'' government, which Washington believes means Najib's eventual removal, Kimmitt said. A senior U.S. administration official said Eastern Europe's rejection of single-party Communist rule coupled with unrest in the Soviet Union's own republics increased pressure on Moscow to stabilize its relations with Washington. Washington plans to capitalize on this to find a political end to Afghanistan's brutal war, but one that does not include Najib, said the official, who spoke on condition he was not identified, He said, however, U.S.-backed rebel fighters would likely be willing to ``talk to elements within Kabul.'' This is seen as a concession to Moscow, which has demanded the ruling Communist Party take part in a postwar settlement. ``The resistance has indicated it is prepared to talk to elements within Kabul,'' those they euphemistically refer to as ``good Moslems,'' he said. ``Their greatest hatred has been Najib and criminal elements around him.'' Kimmitt's three-day visit to Pakistan was part of U.S. preparations for next month's meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Kimmitt was the highest-ranking State Department official to visit Pakistan since last year's withdrawal of Soviet combat troops from Afghanistan. He told a news conference the Soviet Union, which has sent huge arms shipments to its communist allies in Kabul, ``is prepared to discuss in good faith'' an end to the 11-year-old war. More than 1.5 million people have reportedly died in Afghanistan's guerrilla war, which was launched in 1979 to rout Soviet combat troops sent by Moscow to crush a burgeoning Moslem insurgency and replace one communist government with another. The Red Army left Afghanistan after only managing to fight U.S.-backed rebels to a stalemate. Najib's government was expected to collapse within weeks of the withdrawal of more than 103,000 Soviet soldiers last Feb. 15. But almost a year later, Najib controls all of Afghanistan's major cities and the rebels control most of the countryside. Washington has shipped millions of dollars worth of weapons to the anti-Marxist rebels, who call themselves mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. But bitter internal feuding among rebel leaders, headquartered in Pakistan, has paralyzed a so-called guerrilla government. Many Afghans and Western observers say the rebels have failed miserably on the political front, unable to attract minority groups or rebels living in Iran to their self-styled government. But the senior U.S. official noted that Moscow dug up its offer of a transitional government while Kabul's ruling communists had the upperhand in the civil war. He said this may mean Moscow is ready to talk, despite the rebels' shortcomings. Western diplomats say the Soviet Union spends about $300 million a month supplying Afghanistan with arms and humanitarian aid. On Wednesday the guerrillas unveiled a complicated formula to select a new leadership. The announcement, made to coincide with Kimmitt's visit, fails to unite the fractious rebel leadership, or include those living in Iran. Hard-line Islamist Gulbaddin Hekmatyar, leader of Hezb-i-Islami rebel group, dismissed the formula, demanding elections instead. Kimmitt refused to comment on the proposal but was expected to meet with guerrilla leaders in the border city of Peshawar before leaving for New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: Garment Steamers Being Recalled
DOC.TEXT: A national retailer is recalling more than 1,000 electric garment steamers that present a possible burn hazard to users, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Thursday. The agency said the J.C. Penney Co, Inc., voluntarily recalled the steamers after consumers reported that the locking mechanism on the fill plug can be broken during use. Breaking the locking mechanism can cause the fill plug to pop out, releasing hot water and steam onto the user, the commission said. At least five people have suffered first and second degree burns to their hands, arms, face or other parts of the body in incidents involving the steamers, the commission said. Consumers can return the approximately 1,100 steamers sold since August 1988 and marked JCP Lot No. 784-1008 to any J.C. Penney store for a full refund.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Would Buy Coca Crop Under Peruvian Plan
DOC.TEXT: The United States would provide aid to help buy Peru's coca leaf crop under a plan proposed Thursday by the Peruvian ambassador. Cesar Atala Nazal said Peruvian farmers ``would dream to be on the side of the law'' even if it meant earning slightly less by growing other crops. The coca leaf is used to make cocaine. Growers in the Upper Huallaga Valley face continual harassment from both police and drug traffickers, Atala said, adding that the growers' share of the huge profits from the drug trade is very small. Atala said the Upper Huallaga Valley produces 180,000 metric tons of leaves with an average price of $1,300 a ton. The average farmer in Peru, he said, does not make more than $1,000 a year. The purchase plan would last only a few years, until crops could be substituted and other economic improvements are made. Payments to the farmers _ about $234 million for one year's worth of crops _ would find their way into the economy as well, Atala said, noting that last year's drug-fighting aid totaled $254 million. ``I am absolutely convinced that the farmers themselves would profit by getting this money but working within the law rather than continue being the victims of traffickers, the terrorists and the Peruvian police,'' he said at a news conference. Atala offered the proposal at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Caucus on International Narcotics Control. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said the proposal sounded feasible but doubted many would favor it. He said it would have to be done in conjunction with operations against traffickers and producers. Ambassador Jorge Crespo Velasco of Bolivia also supported the proposal. Most of the cocaine that enters the United States comes from Peru, Bolivia and Colombia. Representatives of those three countries will meet with President Bush at a Feb. 15 drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia. Also at the hearing, Atala reiterated criticism of last month's U.S. invasion of Panama. Atala and Colombian Ambassador Victor Mosquera Chaux said at a news conference that participation by U.S. warships in drug interdiction efforts off the Andean nations' waters is unwelcome and unnecessary. ``What your armed forces could do, we could do if necessary,'' Atala said. Mosquera Chaux said ``U.S. naval forces could begin by trying to control the entry of narcotics within their own waters.'' Biden called Thursday's hearing to gather comment on his proposed debt-for-drugs legislation, under which the United States would exchange debt relief for anti-drug efforts by drug-producing countries. The proposal is modeled after similar notions of exchanging debt for equity or debt for protection of natural resources. Biden acknowledged that the administration was cool to the idea, but said he hoped it would be included on the summit agenda next month. The three ambassadors told the panel that the drug trade was inextricably bound with other economic problems, some of which they blamed on the United States. Mosquera Chaux proposed a one-time grant of $1 billion to offset the economic consequences of the war on drugs and the breakdown of an international coffee agreement he said will cost Colombian growers $600 million this year.

DOC.HEAD: Detained Lockheed Engineers Hope to Leave Chad by Sunday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tchadienne is cq
DOC.TEXT: Three U.S. technicians working for Lockheed Aircraft Corp. hope to leave Chad early Sunday after being detained for two weeks, a negotiator for the company said. Len R. Webb, Lockheed's regional manager for Africa and the Middle East, said Thursday it was possible the three will leave N'Djamena for Paris early Sunday on an Air Afrique flight. The three _ Irving Thrash, Marvin Gambill and Ernest Ruse, all from the Atlanta area _ refused comment other than to say they would be glad to leave the North African country. They remained under house arrest Thursday at N'Djamena's largest hotel, the Hotel Tchadienne, part of the French-owned Novotel hotel chain. Police took the men into custody Jan. 5, releasing them only last Monday on condition they not leave the hotel while Lockheed negotiated their freedom with the Chadian government. Their passports also were confiscated. Webb has termed the detention a ``misunderstanding'' that involved the destruction of a manual for a Lockheed C-130 military transport aircraft purchased for the Chadian air force. It was the first Lockheed plane _ of several in use in Chad _ that was purchased new by President Hissene Habre's government. The contract called for a team of three technicians from the Lockheed Aeronautical Systems-Georgia subsidiary to be stationed in Chad for a year to teach the Chadians how to maintain the plane. The year ended in December. Webb said the dispute was over a single ``high-level technical overhaul document'' not needed for day-to-day maintenance. The technicians destroyed the document as they prepared to leave Chad, but the Chadians thought it was sold with the plane. Lockheed did not have the State Department's export permit for the document, Webb said, but authorization now has been obtained and the Chadians provided with a new copy. Chadian authorities are believed to have since made maintenance arrangements with another company. Webb, who is based in Amman, Jordan, says the three technicians were not held hostage and have not been mistreated or harassed. Lockheed headquarters are in Calabasas, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Dominates GOP Gathering; Effort to Endorse Pro-Life Platform Fails
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs to include black GOP official's complaints, picking up 4th graf pvs, bgng, Ayre was...; SUBS graf 10 pvs, bgng, The party ... to include Atwater's private discussion with members; edits to conform references to Bush, Atwater
DOC.TEXT: The Republican Party's internal debate over abortion boiled into the open Thursday, with a party committee refusing to consider a resolution affirming the GOP's fervent anti-abortion stance. The action came on the opening day of the Republican National Committee's winter meeting, a session dominated by public and private discussions about whether the party should moderate its official stand on abortion as 1990 elections approach. The session also included a complaint from the leader of a black GOP group, who said despite minority outreach commitments from party chief Lee Atwater some state chapters ``overlook'' blacks. Fred Brown, head of the National Black Republican Committee, also said that while he has been unable to organize a presidential dinner as an organization fund-raiser, Jesse Jackson and other prominent black Democrats ``constantly meet with the president.'' But abortion overshadowed other topics as the RNC convened in a hotel blocks from the White House. One RNC member, Idaho state GOP Chairman Randy Ayre, sought to offer a resolution endorsing the party's 1988 platform recognition of the ``sanctity of life.'' Ayre was told that his request would not be considered because he had not submitted a formal resolution in advance of the gathering and that perhaps the issue would be discussed at the next RNC meeting in June. ``But we have elections coming up,'' he said, to no avail, during a meeting of the RNC's resolutions committee. Ayre said after the session, taking a stance similar to that of Atwater, that he personally opposes abortion and believes the party should, too, but that the GOP should not use a candidate's position on abortion as a litmus test for party support. Still, he said: ``I just feel that we should reaffirm the party's longstanding position on the issue.'' Ayre appeared uncomfortable speaking to reporters about his attempt, and an impromptu session with several ended abruptly when an Atwater deputy summoned him out of the room with a message that he had a telephone call. Atwater and other prominent Republicans _ including Bush and Vice President Quayle _ have sought in recent months to portray the GOP as an umbrella organization that welcomes candidates with varying views on abortion. And, mindful of the role abortion played in several major elections won by Democrats last year, Atwater has been urging Republican candidates to state their position on the issue early and firmly to attempt to diminish abortion's campaign role. The party chairman has been criticized by some in the GOP's conservative wing who believe the party should hold firmly to its anti-abortion stance. Atwater aides said he would dedicate a good portion of his Friday speech to the issue, giving what one called ``a better version'' of how he feels candidates should deal with the topic. He also participated in a lengthy discussion about abortion politics at a private luncheon with RNC members, sticking to his theme that the party is a ``big tent'' with room for differing opinions. Even some staunchly anti-abortion RNC members said privately they would have difficulty supporting a resolution such as Ayre's because of the problems such a stance might cause some GOP candidates. ``Those who are pro-life can point to the 1988 platform and those pro-choice can point to the president's remarks about inclusion,'' said one RNC member privately. ``It does us no good to stir this thing up.'' Ayre, in his brief session with reporters, disagreed, saying he proposed his resolution ``because of the timeliness of the issue.'' Another member of the resolutions committee, Iowa national committeeman Stephen Roberts, said the decision to quash Ayre's request would only delay an inevitable _ and difficult _ decision by the party. ``It's clearly an issue,'' he said. Roberts said he wanted to speak to other members before deciding what tack he would encourage the party to take. He and others said abortion was a major topic in conversation and private sessions of the meeting. He also joined Ayre in saying RNC rules need to be improved so that resolutions considered at party meetings are meaningful. ``God, motherhood and the flag'' was how he summed up the committee's business, which included passage of resolutions praising the Bush administration, pro-democracy movements in Eastern Europe and the invasion of Panama. ``If you're going to have any meaning to it you've got to deal with the issues of the day,'' he said. Other members, however, were more comfortable leaving the abortion debate off the public agenda except at presidential nominating conventions _ and perhaps even then. ``This is an issue of conscience,'' said Haley Barbour, an anti-abortion RNC member from Mississippi and a key GOP strategist in the South. ``Not everyone has to agree with me.'' A sign of the party's reluctance to debate abortion publicly came when the resolution committee considered suspending its rules to consider a resolution from the RNC's Puerto Rico delegation that was not submitted by the deadline. The resolution was virtually identical to a GOP platform plank endorsing statehood for Puerto Rico if its residents voted in favor of such a move. RNC member Elsie Hillman of Pennsylvania, at Barbour's suggestion, ruled the motion out of order after saying agreeing to consider it ``would make it harder to deny any other resolutions brought to us at the last minute.''

DOC.HEAD: Corporate Group Criticizes Congressional Proposals
DOC.TEXT: A group representing the nation's largest corporations criticized congressional proposals to clean up air pollution Thursday as being too expensive and said some of the most stringent provisions could force plants to shut down. The Business Roundtable, an association of 200 major corporations, presented a study it commissioned that maintained that legislation before Congress to tighten the federal Clean Air Act could cost business $54 billion to $104 billion a year. The cost figures were sharply higher than any that have surfaced so far in the debate over the legislation, which has been given a high priority by congressional leaders and the White House. Senate floor debate on a clear-air bill was to begin next week. Administration officials called the business group's cost predictions too high. Environmentalists said the estimates were inflated. ``This is part of an industry ritual on the eve of any pollution control debate in Congess. They release inflated figures,'' said Richard Ayres of the Natural Resources Defense Council. Earlier Thursday, President Bush renewed his call for Congress to ``break the stalemate'' and pass clean-air legislation as soon as possible. Aides have said privately for weeks that Bush would like to have a toughtened air pollution bill in hand to sign as part of Earth Day celebrations in April. Bush, speaking to administration officials, urged Congress to ``preserve the careful balance'' of legislation he proposed last summer ``to clean up the air and preserve jobs.'' The administration has estimated the cost of the Bush proposal as between $14 billion and $19 billion a year. The cost to industry of a similar version advancing in the House has been put at about the same level, but administration officials have opposed parts of a Senate bill because they claim it would be more expensive and possibly threaten economic growth. Earlier this week, staff members of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee disputed claims that the Senate bill would add significantly to the cost of legislation proposed by the president. A spokesman for Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chief sponsor of the Senate bill, called the Business Roundtable cost estimates far too high and said the Senate bill's costs ``are comparable to the president's proposal.'' According to the Commerce Department, air pollution control measures currently cost business and industry an estimated $32 billion a year. But the study presented by the Business Roundtable said a ``best estimate'' of complying with provisions of the Senate bill would be an additional $54 billion a year and could soar as high as $104 billion if businesses were required to meet the toughest health-based standards suggested by the legislation for toxic chemical emissions. Dale Denny, author of the report, said compliance with stringent health-based toxic emission controls from industrial plants could add from $25 billion to $62 billion onto the cost of compliance if companies were required to curb emissions to levels that pose no more than a 1 in 1 million cancer risk. The Senate legislation calls for such risk levels to be a ``goal'' but would allow regulators to issue exemptions and set less stringent limits if economic or technological conditions warrant. Philip Masciantonio, vice president for environmental affairs for U.S. Steel Corp., said, however, that the toxic chemical controls in the Senate bill could result in ``reduced industrial production, job losses, employment dislocations and possibly shutdowns of industries.'' The steel industry's coke oven operations are threatened by the Senate bill because they would be unable to meet some of the standards envisioned by that bill, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Amal Displays Higgins' Alleged Prison Site
DOC.TEXT: The Shiite Moslem Amal militia on Thursday displayed an underground prison where it said U.S. Marine Col. William Higgins was briefly held before his reported death. Melhim Qanso, Amal's spokesman in south Lebanon, said the seven-cell prison, dug behind a car painting shop in this southern village, was used by the pro-Iranian Hezbollah ``to hold innocent victims, including foreign hostages.'' ``Higgins was held here for three days shortly after his abduction,'' Qanso told reporters. He said Amal has arrested an underground Hezbollah network in Kawthariet Assiad, 11 miles southeast of the port of Sidon. ``Its members confessed that Higgins was here,'' Qanso said. Higgins, who headed a U.N. observer team in south Lebanon, was kidnapped near the southern port of Tyre Feb. 17, 1988. The Organization of the Oppressed on Earth claimed it killed him last July after Israel kidnapped a Hezbollah sheik. U.S. intelligence officials believe Higgins, of Danville, Ky., was killed a year earlier in retaliation for the downing by an American warship of an Iranian Airbus in the Persian Gulf, killing 260 people. Hezbollah is the umbrella group for several pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions holding most of the 18 Western hostages _ including eight Americans _ in Lebanon. Longest held is Terry A. Anderson, Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped off a Beirut street on March 16, 1985. Qanso said blood stains littered the cells upon discovery of the dusty prison by Amal's security apparatus last week. The two-foot-thick concrete door is concealed behind shelves, where a few paint canisters were lying. Qanso led journalists through the narrow corridor to a series of air-conditioned cells equipped with iron doors that had a small opening with shutters Amal said were used to pass food. Weapons, including Israeli-made silencer-equipped Uzi submachine guns and mortars, as well as mines, were displayed in an Amal ammunition depot in the adjacent village of Insariyeh. Qanso said the weapons, which belong to Hezbollah, were found in the prison. He also showed torture equipment including ropes, chains and whips that he said were discovered in the jail. Qanso said two members of the network were executed for plotting to assassinate Amal's chieftain Nabih Berri recently. He refused to disclose further details. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting each other intermittently since 1987 for mastery of the 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect. By police count, 929 people have been killed and 2,744 wounded in the confrontation.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Weather, From Nevada To The Plains
DOC.TEXT: Up to 14 inches of snow fell Thursday over the mountains of the West and extended onto the southern Plains, while locally heavy rain fell over parts of the South. Record high temperatures were posted in the East. Overnight snow accumulations in Nevada included 14 inches at Mount Charleston, 12 inches at Goodsprings and Sandy Valley and 8 inches at Red Rock. Mount Charleston had 36 inches of snow on the ground at 9 a.m. Snowfall Wednesday and overnight into Thursday across Arizona included 18 inches at Ash Fork, up to 10 inches at Prescott, 5 inches at Cottonwood, and 1 to 3 inches at Flagstaff, Grand Canyon, Sedona, Payson and Bisbee. In southern Colorado, 4 inches of snow had fallen at the San Luis Valley at midmorning and snow was falling at the rate of 1 inch an hour at Wolf Creek Pass. Wind gusted to near 70 mph at Albuquerque, N.M., and to 80 to 100 mph in eastern sections of the city. In Texas, 2 inches of snow covered the ground at Amarillo at noon, with 5{ inches across the west side of town. ``The plows are out, it's still snowing and it's slick in spots,'' said a Department of Public Safety dispatcher in Dalhart, Texas. By 3 p.m., 6 inches of snow had fallen on the northern Panhandle city, and it was still snowing heavily. Two- and 3-inch overnight snowfalls were reported over the western two-thirds of the Oklahoma Panhandle. And 2 inches of snow fell during the morning at Hugoton, Kan. Ahead of the snow, showers and thunderstorms reached across northern Texas, western and southern Oklahoma, Louisiana, southern Arkansas, Mississippi, and southern Alabama. Tyler, Texas, got 1.71 inches of rain overnight, Longview, Texas, got 2.01 inches and up to 3 inches of rain was reported over Houston County. Thunderstorms also produced almost an inch of rain during one hour along with small hail at Abilene, Texas. Rain also fell over sections of southeastern California, southern Nevada and northern Arizona, changing to snow at higher elevations. Light rain was scattered over northeastern Ohio and northwestern Pennsylvania. Record highs included 70 at Baltimore; 62 at Boston; 54 at Burlington, Vt.; 57 at Concord, N.H.; 66 at Harrisburgh, Pa.; 64 at Philadelphia; 58 at Portland, Maine; 71 at Roanoke, Va.; 68 at Washington; and 65 at Wilmington, Del. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 22 degrees below zero at Yellowstone National Park. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 6 degrees below zero at Yellowstone to 85 at Tampa, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: DoT Warns of a New Kind of Fake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Some tour packages being offered for the Super Bowl don't include a ticket to the game, the Transportation Department warned Thursday. The department's consumer affairs office said that if a ticket to the National Football League's Denver-San Francisco extravaganza in New Orleans on Jan. 28 is not specifically mentioned in an advertisement for the package, or is not listed as a feature of a tour package, it probably is not included. Fans should read promotional material carefully, the department said. And it advised paying by credit card, ``which provides some degree of protection under fair credit practice laws.'' The department said that Super Bowl packages involving public charter flights offer some clear advantages. ``If the charter tour is supposed to include a game ticket and you do not receive one, you are entitled to a full refund of the entire package price when you return,'' it said. Customers may also cancel travel arrangements and receive a full refund if there is a change in the cities where flights originate, if a hotel not named in the brochure is substituted or if a price increase of more than 10 percent is imposed, it said. In order to avoid being turned away at the loading gate because of check-in time limits imposed by both scheduled and charter airlines, the department advised Super Bowl fans to get to the airport well ahead of time.

DOC.HEAD: Zhivkov Under House Arrest, Opposition Talks With Communists Break Down
LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.TEXT: Former leader Todor Zhivkov was put under house arrest and charged with abuse of power and fomenting ethnic unrest during his 34-year reign, the government-run news agency BTA reported Thursday. The state agency also said opposition talks with the ruling Communists broke down Thursday over access to Bulgaria's broadcasting networks. The prosecutor-general's office issued a warrant for the deposed dictator, who was toppled in a November uprising, charging Zhivkov with malfeasance in office, inciting ethnic hostility and misuse of state property. The 78-year-old Stalinist was not jailed, according to BTA, but was instead put under guard at an undisclosed location. That makes him the second East Bloc leader now under official investigation for abuses disclosed by the upheavals that have convulsed Eastern Europe. Former East German party leader Erich Honecker, now hospitalized, faces a charge of high treason. The charges against Zhivkov indicate he is being personally blamed by his reformist Communist successors for the nation's severe ethnic and economic problems. Zhivkov was the author of so-called ``Bulgarization,'' the persecution and forced assimilation of the nation's 1.5 million ethnic Turks and other native Bulgarian Muslims, known as Pomaks. After his ouster, Zhivkov was accused of corruption when it was revealed he had maintained at least 30 holiday and hunting retreats throughout this poor Balkan nation. Zhivkov's often-violent forced assimilation policy banned Moslem religious practices and required ethnic Turks and Moslems to forsake their own names and take Bulgarian ones. Most of Bulgaria's 9 million people belong to the Bulgarian Orthodox Church. More than 300,000 ethnic Turks emigrated to Turkey to escape the harsh Bulgarization campaign, but about 80,000 later returned, citing lack of jobs and housing in Turkey. The talks with the reformist government of party chief Petar Mladenov have foundered over the government's refusal to allow the opposition to use the electronic media to spread its democratic message throughout this mostly rural nation in advance of promised national elections. ``We are left with the impression that the delegation of the official authorities has no intention to carry (out) serious negotiations,'' said the Union of Democratic Forces, the umbrella grouping of opposition organizations, according to a statement carried by BTA. Western diplomats said if the opposition and government liaison groups come to agreement on their differences, another negotiating session is likely Jan. 22. Earlier this week, the Communist Party agreed to allow the opposition to publish its own newspaper and promised it office space. Faced with the plummeting fortunes of the Communist Party in other Eastern European states, Bulgaria's Communists appear to be trying to preserve as much power as possible, and their total control of radio and television is key to that power. The government-run media continues to attack opposition leaders in a clear attempt to discredit them with any potential electorate. The government has proposed two-stage legislative elections in May and November. However, opposition figures claim May is too soon for them to organize an effective election campaign. During Thursday's session of the talks, the Communist delegation leader, Andrei Loukanov, issued a thinly-veiled warning against anti-Communist activities, saying, ``the revival of anti-Communism would be dangerous for the transition to democracy,'' according to BTA. Loukanov was referring to anti-Communist slogans at Sunday's pro-democracy demonstration in the capital Sofia by more than 50,000 people, one of the largest demonstrations in recent Bulgarian history. The demonstration testified to the fast-growing popularity of the opposition, which had been banned until Zhivkov's ouster.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: No More Plea Bargaining in Marcos Case
DOC.TEXT: The lead prosecutor in the racketeering case against Imelda Marcos said Thursday that plea-bargain discussions with her lawyers have been suspended. ``We're going to trial,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella told reporters at federal court in Manhattan, where the trial of the widow of former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos is scheduled to begin March 13. Last month, Mrs. Marcos's lawyers said that during plea-bargaining talks held in California it was recommended that Mrs. Marcos plead guilty to mail fraud and obstruction of justice and agree to return millions of dollars to the Philippine government. In return, she would receive a suspended jail sentence. But the prosecutor said Thursday that no discussions about a plea bargain for Mrs. Marcos were currently being held. LaBella declined to comment on statements by Philippine government officials that he had told them that Mrs. Marcos's lawyers had failed to respond to the plea offer by the government's deadline on Monday. Calls to lawyers for Mrs. Marcos were not immediately returned. Mrs. Marcos and her husband, who died last September, were indicted in 1988 on charges of embezzling $106 million from the Philippine treasury and fraudulently borrowing $165 million from American banks. Mrs. Marcos, who is living in Hawaii, pleaded innocent to the criminal charges and has been free on $5 million bond. Her husband was ousted in the February 1986 uprising that propelled Corazon Aquino into the presidency.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0700 AM-Ivory to change keyword line which duplicates a0617
British Move on Elephant Ivory Seen as Threat to Ban on Trade
DOC.TEXT: British refusal to join a ban on trade in ivory threatens the international effort to save the African elephant from poachers, the World Wildlife Fund said Thursday. The United States and most other countries have joined in the ban. Illegal slaughter of elephants has greatly reduced their numbers in recent years. ``We're afraid Britain's action will collapse the whole international agreement,'' said Dana Lauren West, a press officer for the organization. ``It's a shock, a complete reversal of the British position. They did it to protect Hong Kong's trade,'' Ms. West said. China is due to take Hong Kong back from Britain in 1997, but Britain still acts for the colony in world affairs. Hong Kong is among the leading processors of ivory. ``They're sitting on 600 tons of it now,'' Ms. West said. China opposed the trade ban from the start. It was to go into effect on Thursday as a result of a vote last Oct. 17 by representatives of 103 governments meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland. All are members of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. South Africa, Zimbabwe and Zambia also submitted ``reservations'' _ in effect exempting themselves from the ban. They supply both raw and carved ivory. Ms. West said there was an unconfirmed report that they are now being joined by Botswana as well as Britain. Member countries have until midnight Thursday to make their decisions. After that, environmentalists will have to get together, review the effects of the defections amd decide what to do next, she added. Japan and Singapore, which had been mainstays of the ivory trade, have so far said they are ready to go along with the ban, Ms. West reported. The fund said in an earlier statement that Singapore has several tons of stockpiled ivory and a flourshing industry in carving it into goods for export. Ms. West said that British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday transferred authority on the issue from her Environment Ministry to the Foreign Ministry, which submitted the British reservation. ``Because Britain belongs to the European Economic Community, we're afraid it may serve as a funnel to the other countries,'' she added. Goods flow with few restrictions among the 12 members of the community, which include the main countries of Western Europe. ``It's appalling,'' said Ginette Hemley, head of the fund's unit that monitors trade in wildlife. ``England's and China's decision ... is a green light to ivory poachers. ... It's ironic that Great Britain, one of the first European countries to ban ivory, is the only Western nation to oppose the ... decision. While Japan, one of the largest consumer countries of ivory, has remained steadfast in its promise to uphold the ban.''

DOC.HEAD: Few Soviet Citizens May Be Classified Refugees
DOC.TEXT: Only 5,000 to 10,000 people from among 400,000 or more Soviet citizens wishing to leave the Soviet Union for the United States will be accorded refugee status this fiscal year, the nation's top immigration official said Thursday. Gene McNary, Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, also said he expects an increase in the number of Armenians seeking refugee status or asylum in the United States as a result of the violence against them in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. Dozens of Armenians have been killed in the fighting which has escalated in recent days to civil war proportions. ``My guess is, it'll increase the numbers'' of Armenians seeking to come to the United States, McNary said at a news conference. As many as 2,000 Armenians could be allowed into the United States each month under a category known as humanitarian parole, which entitles them to some federal assistance but not to automatic citizenship. About 12,000 Armenians came here last year. McNary said 40,000 to 45,000 of the 50,000 refugee slots allocated by Congress for Soviet refugees in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 will be reserved for applicants already waiting in Italy. These applicants left the Soviet Union last year and applied in Rome for permission to enter the United States as refugees. The Rome channel was shut off by the Bush administration as of Oct. 1 under a new system which only allows Soviets to apply in Moscow. But Attorney General Richard Thornburgh pledged to clear up the backlog in Rome before closing down the transit facility there this year. Classification as a refugee is desirable because admission to the United States is done outside the regular immigration quotas and the U.S. government pays for travel and resettlement, and the refugees may become citizens. The new system does not automatically assume, as previous policy did, that Jews leaving the Soviet Union are entitled to refugee status, which the United States grants people with a ``well-founded fear of persecution'' on religious grounds. Instead, consular officers have to investigate individual cases. The shortage of slots for Soviet refugee applicants, the vast majority of whom are Jews, has become acute over the past year with a lifting of many previous restrictions on the emigration of Jews, Armenians and Evangelical Christians. After years of demanding the Kremlin allow more Soviets to leave, the United States is now faced with exit permits far outstripping U.S. budget ability to take in the emigres. More than 71,000 Jews left the Soviet Union last year, the highest annual rate ever, and 36,147 of them came to the United States as refugees. Jewish community officials say at least 100,000 additional Soviet Jews have applied to leave and are waiting to be processed by the U.S. Embassy in Moscow. McNary said as many as 300,000 more could apply in the coming months. McNary said the INS was increased its staff in Moscow to 24, and had begun operating an office in suburban Washington to help in the processing of the Soviet applications. On another matter, McNary said the INS had received 3,720 applications from Chinese studying or working in the United States for permission to stay here in light of the repression against pro-democracy movements in China. Of these, more than 2,800 have been approved, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Discount Chain's Founder Undergoes Cancer Therapy
DOC.TEXT: Sam Walton, the 71-year-old founder of the Wal-Mart discount chain empire, has undergone treatment for bone-marrow cancer, a company spokesman said Thursday. Walton, once the richest person in America, has received two sessions of chemotherapy and some radiation therapy since Sunday for multiple myeloma, said Don Shinkle, a Wal-mart spokesman. Myeloma is a malignant tumor in the bone marrow. It is generally made up of abnormal plasma cells. A Wal-Mart statement said Walton was expected to recover fully from treatment he underwent in Houston at M.D. Anderson Hospital. It is the second time Walton has faced cancer. In 1982, he was diagnosed as having leukemia and also was treated at M.D. Anderson. The leukemia has been in remission for several years. ``Along with Mr. Sam's doctors, we are very encouraged that because of early detection and treatment a full recovery is expected,'' the statement said. ``His doctors have advised him that they have had good success treating this type of cancer if it's detected in time,'' Shinkle said. ``He's in very good spirits.'' Shinkle said Walton probably would spend another couple of weeks in Houston. ``The bottom line, we hear from the doctors, is that they caught this in time, in the early stages,'' he said. Walton had experienced aches and pains for several months, but felt better after the therapy, Shinkle said. ``I feel so much better already,'' Walton said in a two-page memo to Wal-Mart employees. Shinkle said the memo was issued because Walton wanted employees to hear news of his illness from him, ``rather than have them to hear a lot of rumors, because many might be exaggerated or untrue.'' Shinkle said Walton may be initially slowed down, but that he expects to resume visiting outlets in a few weeks, a common Walton practice. After this week's treatments, Walton visited a Sam's Wholesale Club in Houston. Walton has been known to drop in on local Wal-Mart managers with little advance notice to stay in touch with the retail business at the customer level. The memo also described Wal-Mart accomplishments during the 1980s, which Walton credited to the employees of the chain's 1,300 stores. It said Walton looked forward to more success. Based on his holdings of Wal-Mart stock, Walton has been listed for the past several years by Forbes magazine as one of the wealthiest men in the nation. He was the wealthiest until he split his stock among family members. Walton stepped down as chief executive officer of the retail chain in 1988, and chose David Glass to oversee the chain. The chain blossomed under Walton's philosophy of tight management and general marketing principles that the customer is always right. Born in Kingfisher, Okla., Walton grew up as the son of a farm-mortgage banker. He graduated from the University of Missouri with an economics degree in 1940 and joined J.C. Penney Co. as a management trainee in Des Moines, Iowa. After serving three years in the Army, he went to Arkansas and opened a Ben Franklin five-and-dime. In 1962, Sam and his brother James L. Walton, opened the first Wal-Mart Discount City. Three of his four grown children are involved with the company in various capacities.

DOC.HEAD: Battleships Iowa and New Jersey Candidates for Mothballs
DOC.TEXT: The Navy will propose that the U.S.S. Iowa and New Jersey, two of its four battleships, be mothballed as a cost-cutting maneuver in the next Pentagon budget, Defense Department sources said Thursday. All four warships have become targets of budget-cutters on Capitol Hill and elsewhere, but Navy brass _ and the lawmakers from some states where the ships were to be based _ have been fighting to retain the decades-old vessels. ``It's going to be proposed,'' one military source said Thursday. ``It's going to be the Iowa and the New Jersey.'' Another Pentagon official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said that while political pressure could result in a reversal of the decision the action ``seems to be a fait accompli.'' ``I haven't seen the final paperwork on it, but it's as good as done,'' the official said.ck Cheney that it must trim programs in its 1991 spending plan. President Bush is slated to send the budget to Congress on Jan. 29. Under a plan attacked by critics as pure pork-barrel politics, the Navy planned to place the battleships at four bases around the country. The Iowa was slated to be at a new, $300 million base on Staten Island in New York City, while the New Jersey is at Long Beach, Calif. Plans call for the Wisconsin to be based at Corpus Christi, Texas, and the Missouri at a West Coast base, as yet undecided. The officials said they had no indication what would happen to the facilities lined up for the homeports, although the second official indicated that other ships might be sent to placate local officials concerned about job cutbacks or economic impact. Some New York politicians continued to voice hope that the Staten Island base would survive, even in a stripped-down state. ``My gut feeling is the homeport is going to survive,'' said Rep. George Hochbrueckner, D-N.Y., a member of the House Armed Services Committee. Lawrence Korb, a former assistant secretary of defense, disagreed. ``I think it's dead,'' said Korb, director of the Brookings Institution's Center for Public Policy and Education. The New Jersey and the Iowa are the older ships, launched in 1942 during World War II and entering service the next year. All four ships saw action in that war, served through the Korean War years and were mothballed in the 1950s. The four ships were reactivated starting in 1982, despite criticism they would be extravagantly expensive to operate because of the large crews needed _ 65 officers and 1,453 enlisted men each. If the New Jersey, which fired at targets in Lebanon in 1983, is returned to the inactive fleet, it will be for the third time. The ship also was used and deactivated during the Vietnam War. The ships carry 16-inch guns, Tomahawk cruise missiles, Harpoon anti-ship missiles, 12 5-inch guns and four rapid-firing 20mm anti-aircraft guns for close-in defense. The Iowa, which was damaged in the April 19 explosion that killed 47 sailors, is undergoing repairs in Norfolk, Va. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, called the prospect of the Iowa and New Jersey being mothballed ``a grave disappointment.'' Warner said future U.S. operations may require amphibious assaults and the battleships are key to that type of work.

DOC.HEAD: Union Democracy, Politics Behind Ford Labor Conflict, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: The struggle for union democracy that has closed a Ford Motor Co. plant for 11 days and left one worker dead is the latest example of the rank-and-file dissent after years of close union-management cooperation. Workers occupying the Cuautitlan plant 15 miles north of Mexico City accuse union leader Hector Uriarte of being pro-management and say the Mexican Labor Federation put him in office after a fraudulent election. The dissidents want Uriarte booted and refused an offer of a referendum because union officials wouldn't agree to provisions for ensuring a fair vote, said dissident leader Salvador Fuentes Reyes. Other demands are secondary, said Fuentes. ``Now it's not a question of profits,'' Fuentes said. ``The basic problem is democratic life in the union.'' The refrain is a common one as organized labor searches for its footing in a changed Mexican political and economic environment. Dominated for decades by government-allied leaders known for manipulating funds and using their posts as springboards to public office, rank-and-filers lack leaders and experience in fighting for better conditions. Seven years of economic crises have eroded raises and the once-bountiful fringe benefits old-school leaders were able to hand out to pacify workers and turn out the vote for the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. Many of the entrenched bosses under attack are close to Fidel Velazquez, who is 89. For 45 years he has ruled the 2.5 million member Mexican Workers' Federation, known as CTM for its Spanish initials. In his drive to restore prosperity, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has kept labor off balance. He opened the door to new boldness by cracking down on corruption and jailing the boss of the powerful oil workers' union. But deposed bosses have been replaced by leaders also aligned with the government, and Salinas has left no doubt his priority is streamlining production. Privatization of government-owned industry has cost thousands of jobs. Last year, a monthlong strike by dissidents in the 1.1 million-strong national teachers' union forced the removal of their boss of 17 years. His replacement, though pro-government, has allowed the dissidents a greater voice in union affairs. In a months-long battle that began with a gunbattle between rival union groups at a luxury hotel, dissident members of the musicians' union managed to get rid of Venustiano Reyes, a Velazquez crony. But the dissidents are still barred from union offices and continue to press their cause in concerts from a makeshift bandstand at one of the busiest corners in town. At the Ford plant, workers and newspaper accounts said 150 to 250 thugs inside the plant began firing guns and beating workers as they arrived for the morning shift Jan. 8. Ten workers were injured; one died two days later. Workers accused Uriarte and the company of being in cahoots, saying the attackers arrived in Labor Federation buses. ``The company let them in,'' said Jose Antonio Galindo Hernandez, a dissident who has been fired. Galindo and other workers said the attackers wore company uniforms and identification badges. ``Ford has filed a criminal complaint with authorities to clarify this situation and fix responsibilities,'' said company spokesman Carlos Bandala when asked about the accusations. About 1,500 workers occupied the plant in around-the-clock shifts. Workers have accused armed Uriarte hirelings of going to dissident employees' homes and threatening them. In newspaper ads, Ford said it would not reopen until there was security for the plant's 3,800 workers. ``Anyone who says (Ford) wants to close the plant is not right,'' Bandala said. He said production had been increased from 360 to 450 units a day the past six months and 800 to 900 new workers were hired. He did not have an estimate of how much the shutdown was costing the company.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Buying Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, which has been buying U.S. wheat lately, has added soybean meal to its shopping list, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Officials said private exporters sold 100,000 metric tons of meal to the Soviets for delivery by Sept. 30 under a long-term grain agreement between the two countries. The current pact began its seventh year on Oct. 1 and will expire on Dec. 31. Negotiations on a new agreement are scheduled to resume March 21-22 in Vienna. Most sales have been grain, including about 11 million tons of corn and more than 2.2 million tons of wheat for delivery during the seventh year. Sales of soybean meal now total 895,000 tons for 1989-90 delivery; soybeans, 217,900 tons; and barley, 7,300 tons. All of the wheat, including 525,000 tons announced earlier in the week, has been sold at prices subsidized under the department's Export Enhancement Program. Only wheat is approved for sale to Moscow under the subsidy program. The new sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department. No selling prices or further details were released. Meal prices at Midwest processors have been around $180 per ton of 2,000 pounds each, according to USDA market reports. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds, indicating a value of about $198 per metric ton, or a total estimate of around $19.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: Government Offers Incentives for Crackdowns on Drunken Drivers
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Transportation offered financial incentives Thursday to states and cities that take tough new steps to crack down on drunken drivers. ``Real success in the fight against drunk drivers calls for action at the state and local levels,'' Transporation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said in a statement. ``These grants will help to get strong, tough laws implemented across the board.'' Jerry Ralph Curry of the department's National Highway Safety Administration said cooperating states will share $4 million in the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30. States will be eligible for grants if they provide for the suspension of offenders' drivers licenses and maintain an anti-drinking program that includes ``aggressive enforcement, prosecution, sentencing, education and public information activities,'' the department said. The basic grant may be increased if the state can complete the suspending of a license within 15 days of an arrest. Curry said 10 percent bonuses will be awarded to states that: _Prohibit the consumption of alcohol or the possession of an open alcohol bottle or can in the passenger compartment of a motor vehicle. Rigorous enforcement and stiff penalties could increase the bonus to 25 percent. _Require a blood-alcohol test after crashes involving serious injury and in which alcohol is suspected as a cause. _Prevent drivers under age 21 from buying alcoholic beverages by providing an easily distinguishable license. _Cancel vehicle registration and recall license plates of drivers convicted more than once of an alcohol-related offense or who drive after their license has been suspended for such an offense.

DOC.HEAD: Daughters of Exiled King Visiting Country
With AM-Romania
LaserPhoto XBUC3
DOC.TEXT: Two daughters of exiled King Michael of Romania flew to Bucharest Thursday on their first visit to the country. Their father has offered to return as head of a constitutional moncharchy. A source close to the family said Princesses Margarita and Sophie planned to stay at least five days. Their program was not disclosed and phone calls to the family's residence near Geneva were unanswered. Both daughters were born after Michael went into exile in January 1948. He has never renounced the throne, saying he was under coercion when he signed an act of abdication shortly before he left the country. He told a news conference Dec. 22 after the overthrow of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu that he was ready to return to his country as head of a constitutional monarchy ``if the people want me to come back.'' Michael, who holds now a British passport, moved to Switzerland more than 30 years ago. Margarita is his oldest daughter and is the first in line to succeed him as head of the royal house. She has been an official with the Rome-based United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization but joined her father after the first reports of turmoil in Romania. She is fluent in French and English but does not speak Romanian.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Preventable Chronic Diseases Kill Many, But Get Few Dollars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 12th, `Comparable figures...,' to UPDATE with outside comment, background.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials said Thursday that nine preventable chronic diseases are responsible for more than half the deaths in this country _ but get only 2 percent of the public health dollars spent by the states. Meanwhile, another preventable cause, injuries, remains the leading cause of ``premature loss of life'' with suicide and homicide and AIDS also ranking high. The national Centers for Disease Control reported that nine chronic diseases _ diseases with long periods of onset or suffering _ by themselves accounted for 1.1 million deaths in 1986, 52 percent of the deaths nationwide. They are stroke, heart disease, diabetes, obstructive lung disease, lung cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, colorectal cancer and cirrhosis of the liver. ``They're all largely preventable _ or preventable to some extent,'' said Dr. Robert Hahn, a CDC epidemiologist. The preventable risk factors for those nine chronic diseases include cigarette smoking, overweight, high blood pressure, drinking and lack of exercise. ``We know what the risk factors are,'' Hahn said. ``We know less about how you get people to act on them.'' According to a report from 45 states and the District of Columbia, less than 2 percent of state public health expenditures are allocated to prevent and control chronic disease, the CDC said. ``That's low,'' Hahn said, noting that other chronic diseases not included in the CDC's dangerous nine also could be targets of increased public health efforts. The average state expenditure on chronic disease control and prevention is 66 cents per person per year, Hahn said. That amount includes money spent on efforts such as disease screening programs, but does not include education or direct doctors' camparable figures on federal public health spending for chronic disease were not available, Hahn said. Many of the federal government's health programs concentrate on research, epidemiology and education, not the traditional screening and prevention efforts of state-funded health clinics. Dr. Robert Blendon, chairman of the Department of Health Policy and Management at the Harvard School of Public Health, said the bulk of state health expenditures in this country are tied up in Medicaid, and the situation has grown worse with the mounting federal deficit in the 1980s. ``Most public health activities at the state level were always paid for by federal grants,'' Blendon said, noting that those grants are now gone, and states are left scrambling to fund Medicaid care of their sickest citizens. ``Prevention of chronic disease became the residual that disappeared,'' he said. `It's very frustrating; we just don't have the early-warning prevention systems, the minimal stuff that anybody who looks sensibly at this would want to do,'' Blendon said. The tne chronic diseases included 593,000 deaths from heart disease, 149,000 from stroke, 125,000 from lung cancer, 71,000 from obstructive lung disease, such as emphysema, and 55,000 from colorectal cancer. Four others caused fewer deaths, but made the CDC's list of nine because they can be prevented or controlled: breast cancer, 40,000 deaths; diabetes, 37,000; cirrhosis, 26,000; and cervical cancer, 4,500. The total of 1.1 million deaths is down about 10 percent from 1979, Hahn said, largely becaus of decreases in heart disease and stroke. Leading causes of death not on the chronic disease list include unintentional injuries, which killed some 95,000 people, according to 1987 reports, and pneumonia and flu, which killed about 69,000. Death rates from the nine preventable chronic diseases listed by the CDC were generally lower in the West, the agency reported. The highest 1986 death rate was in Michigan, 518 such deaths per 100,000 people; lowest was in Hawaii, 327 per 100,000. Meanwhile, the CDC said Thursday, unintentional injuries take the greatest toll when age is factored into death statistics to measure years of potential life lost. The CDC routinely studies the leading killers of young people by measuring years not lived by people who die before 65; 65 is an arbitrary cutoff, since the nation's life expectancy is somewhat higher. In 1988, the latest year for which analysis is available, deaths from unintentional injuries robbed their under-65 victims of an estimated 2.3 million years of life, the CDC said. Such injuries kill about 28,000 Americans under 65 every year. Cancer took 1.8 million years of potential life, heart disease accounted for 1.5 million years, and suicide and homicide together accounted for 1.4 million years. The numbers of actual premature deaths in 1988 were not available. However, 1987 totals were: unintentional injuries, about 28,000 victims under 65; cancer, 160,000; heart disease, 141,000; and 24,000 suicides and 20,000 homicides. AIDS was the sixth leading cause of lost years of life in 1988, after birth defects, and robbed its victims of an estimated 472,000 years of life. It was seventh in 1987, when 13,000 deaths accounted for 363,000 years of life lost, or 30 percent less than in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Former Politburo Member Arrested in East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with opposition wants to speak in parliament, Meyer's statement, details. Picks up 11th, `The New ... and DELETES final 3 grafs, `The latest ..., now redundant
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Thursday arrested a former Politburo member under investigation for corruption and abuse of power and put him in prison to await trial, along with seven other ex-leaders. Communists and opposition groups held their eighth round of talks, with the opposition demanding a role in dismantling the hated secret police force. The opposition also demanded the right to speak in Parliament. Negotiators unanimously approved a resolution calling on Communist Premier Hans Modrow to give them periodic written updates on the dissolution of the secret police force, which is to be dissolved by June 30. The negotiators also called on the secret police to turn in their guns, grenades and other weapons by the end of this month. The imprisoned ex-official was identified as Hermann Axen, who was once the Communist Party's top foreign policy representative. Axen, 73, was jailed after returning from an eye operation in Moscow, the official ADN news agency said, quoting government authorities. Seven other members of the disgraced regime of Erich Honecker also are in prison awaiting trial on charges they abused their positions of power. ADN said authorities found additional evidence against Honecker, who was forced from office Oct. 18, and against former Politburo members Guenter Mittag and Erich Mielke. Mittag, the former economics czar, is blamed for the nation's industrial slump, while Mielke headed the secret police. They are in prison. Honecker is hospitalized after undergoing an operation last week to remove a kidney tumor. He and Mielke are expected to be tried for high treason. The latest threat to Modrow's coalition government appeared to have been defused, at least temporarily. Christian Democratic leader Lothar de Maiziere said his threat on Wednesday to quit the government was ``premature.'' A final decision is expected soon. De Maiziere had complained the Communists held too much power. Modrow has appealed to his coalition partners to hold the government together until the nation's first free elections less than four months from now, spokesman Wolfgang Meyer told a news conference in East Berlin. ``The government is standing firm in its responsibilities,'' Meyer said. Strikes and demonstrations have kept up the pressure on the government, while boosting opposition forces before the May 6 balloting. The New Forum opposition group opened Thursday's negotiations with a call to maintain the ``peaceful revolution'' that has swept the country since October. It also demanded full access to documents regarding the secret police. Government officials say the number of agents and informants was nearly 200,000. In presenting the resolution, New Forum representative Reinhard Scult called the secret police ``a danger to development of society, and a danger to internal peace.'' The secret police force, known as the ``Stasi,'' used strong-arm methods to suppress dissent during the Honecker era. Negotiators Thursday asked that former Communist Party leader Egon Krenz be forced to reveal comprehensive information about the secret police when he appears before the panel next week. On Wednesday, Krenz cited an oath of secrecy in refusing to divulge such information to a commission investigating the brutal tactics used by police to disperse pro-democracy protests Oct. 7-8. Honecker has denied responsibility for the brutality, but on Wednesday ousted Politburo member Guenter Schabowski said Honecker was to blame. ``Honecker took things into his own hands,'' Schabowski said. ``All decisions and orders that led to the police actions against demonstrators and to their arrrest went exclusively through Honecker and Mielke.''

DOC.HEAD: Mistrial On White House Drug Sale; Convictions on Other Charges
DOC.TEXT: A judge declared a mistrial again Thursday on a charge that an 18-year-old supplied the cocaine that President Bush used as a prop in a speech last September. A jury convicted the young man, Keith Jackson, on three other drug counts. After two days of deliberations, the jury was unable to reach verdicts on two charges against Jackson _ selling crack cocaine to an undercover federal agent in Lafayette Park across the street from the White House last Sept. 1, and using a telephone to arrange the sale. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin declared a mistrial on those two counts. The jury convicted Jackson of distributing crack cocaine at a shopping mall and twice near a high school in the District of Columbia between last April 24 and July 27. Jackson was retried on the five charges after another jury failed to reach verdicts on any counts in December. Sentencing was set for March 16. Under federal sentencing guidelines, he faces a minimum of 12 years in prison and a maximum of more than 15 years, according to the U.S. attorney's office. Judges may depart from the guidelines, but substantial departures can be appealed. Much of the testimony at Jackson's two trials focused on events surrounding the president's speech. White House aides decided to have the president hold up a bag of crack for the camera. Drug Enforcement Administration officials changed the location of a pending undercover purchase to accommodate a White House request to get the drugs near the White House. The president noted the location of the purchase in his speech. DEA officials have said they had difficulty getting Jackson to come to Lafayette Park because he didn't know where the White House was. Jackson's lawyer, Charles Stow, brought out in court that a DEA agent in the Lafayette Park transaction wore a body microphone that didn't work. A cameraman who was supposed to videotape the transaction was unable to do so because he was assaulted by a homeless person.

DOC.HEAD: Popular Radio Satirist Shot to Death
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A popular radio satirist who was shot twice by an unidentified assailant while walking home from work died Thursday, Radio Metropole said. Jean-Andre Destin, 33, had finished a late-night broadcast at the capital's Radio Cacique when someone in a passing car shot him in the chest about 1 a.m. Wednesday, private Radio Metropole said. After lying unattended on the sidewalk for about three hours, Destin was taken to General Hospital where he underwent two operations. He died before dawn Thursday. ``In past months, journalists have been targeted by the verbal attacks of the government, and now the attacks have ended in bloodshed,'' Dischler Marcelin, general secretary of the Haitian Association of Journalists, said Thursday. Marcelin said his group demanded an immediate police investigation. In the past Haitian police have ignored calls to investigate killings. In recent months the state-run daily L'Union has accused the journalists' association of ``acting above the law,'' while military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril has accused the press of ``disinformation.'' Destin, who regularly lampooned public figures on his program, had a wide following among the Creole-speaking masses of the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Examines Effect of Candidates' Stands of Abortion
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 8th graf: ``The pitfalls,'' to make it pro-choice Democrats sted anti-abortion Democrat; also changes Emily to EMILY throughout
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Republicans-Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: All else being equal, a married, pro-choice Democratic woman would easily defeat a married, anti-abortion Republican man in a hypothetical election held today, according to a survey released Thursday by a woman's political organization. The poll conducted for EMILY's List shows a 12-point margin between two such candidates in a hypothetical election. It was the widest spread among the combinations of candidates presented to poll respondents. The results are ``a key to electing more Democratic women, which is not an easy task,'' said Ellen Malcolm, president of the organization, which raises money and identifies political opportunities for female Democratic officeseekers. The poll said that when marital status and sex were not specified, ``pro-choice'' Democrats would have a 10-point advantage over ``pro-life'' Republicans. EMILY's List said it used the terms ``pro-choice'' and ``pro-life'' because of the strong images they present and because of the likelihood that candidates would use one of the terms to describe themselves. Malcolm said the survey was designed to single out the affects of being ``pro-choice'' or ``pro-life'' and therefore did not offer respondents any other information about the hypothetical candidate besides that, party affiliation, sex and marital status. The release of the survey coincided with a meeting of the National Republican Committee, which was expected to focus on how GOP candidates should deal with abortion in elections this year. After Democrats demonstrated in Virginia and New Jersey in 1989 that a pro-choice stand was key to winning statewide offices, Republican leaders began saying the GOP was ``a big tent'' with room for both views, despite opposition to abortion from President Bush and the party platform. The pitfalls of that position were reflected in the EMILY's List poll, which had hypothetical pro-choice Republicans doing ``less well overall'' than hypothetical pro-choice Democrats because the Republicans were not supported by conservatives. ``We wish the Republicans luck in trying to find a place in their tent for all the members of their party,'' said Malcolm. The only bright spot for Republicans in the poll's findings was for those running as pro-choice against anti-abortion Democrats. ``Republican candidates who are pro-choice have a 5-point advantage over Democratic candidates who are `pro-life,''' said Celinda Lake of Greenberg-Lake The Analysis Group Inc., which conducted the poll. Her telephone survey was conducted from Dec. 12-16, 1989, among 810 randomly selected registered voters. Each state was represented in proportion to its share of the nation's population. The responses should be within 3.5 percentage points of those that would have been obtained if all registered voters had been questioned, said Lake. The survey also included a sample of 200 Hispanic voters who proved to be ``remarkably pro-choice,'' according to Lake. She said 37 percent of Hispanic voters supported keeping abortion legal under all circumstances, 51 percent under certain circumstances. Twelve percent were against legalized abortion. A difficult issue for pro-choice candidates is whether minors should have to secure a parent's approval to have an abortion. ``As in other surveys, voters overwhelmingly support parental consent,'' Lake said, with ``68 percent in favor to 27 percent opposed'' in this survey. Malcolm said pro-choice candidates must show great concern and sensitivity about the question of parental consent. She said her organization had no pat strategy for pro-choice candidates in states where parental consent is in the legislative forefront. ``What we will say is, `You need to look at the landscape in your district,''' she said. EMILY's List was founded in 1985, principally to raise seed money for candidates. Its name is an acronym for ``early money is like yeast'' _ it makes the dough rise. The group in 1986 helped make Barbara Mikulski of Maryland the first Democratic woman elected to the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Accelerates Timetable for Pullout of Soviet Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf `Czechoslovakia said' with 1 graf to CORRECT that Czechoslovakian officials want 75,000 Soviet troops to leave their country sted Poland. Pickup 5th `Walesa said...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bulgaria, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hungary on Thursday demanded that the estimated 52,000 Soviet troops in its country go home in 1991 at the latest, accelerating its timetable for a pullout. At East-West arms control talks, it also broke ranks with the Soviet Union and proposed dramatic cuts in foreign troops, including U.S. soldiers, stationed in Europe. The surprise announcements by Ferenc Somogyi, state secretary of the Hungarian Foreign Ministry, were another sign of the growing independence of members of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Czechoslovakia said this week wants the 75,000 Soviet troops within its borders out by the end of 1990. In Poland, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa made a similar demand Thursday in talks with Soviet Ambassador Wladimir Browikow. Walesa said he told Browikow the Soviet troops should have been withdrawn ``a long time ago because a situation may occur when it will be hot and people start to protest.'' In the drive toward democracy, the Budapest government has told Moscow it wants its troops withdrawn but gave no deadline. Somogyi insisted Thursday that they must leave this year or 1991 at the latest. ``There is no political or military reason which would justify or call for the foreign troops ... in Hungary,'' he told a news conference. He said the Hungarian armed forces was capable of defending its own territory. In 1956, the Soviets sent troops and tanks into Hungary to silence a popular uprising against Stalinism. Reformist Premier Imre Nagy was later convicted of treason in a show trial and executed. Hungary's cuurent premier, Miklos Nemeth, recently met Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov to arrange talks on a pullout. Nemeth had stressed that withdrawal depended on an East-West agreement to reduce conventional, or non-nuclear, forces in Europe. About 10,000 Soviet troops already have left both Hungary and Czechoslovakia under a gradual withdrawal of 50,000 soldiers from Eastern Europe, announced in December 1988 by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. An additional 6,000 of the 52,000 Soviet troops said to be left in Hungary are due to leave this year. An undisclosed number are to leave Czechoslovakia, where officials say there are 75,000 Soviet troops. Somogyi also said he formally proposed greater cuts in foreign troops than previous U.S. or Soviet proposals at the 23-nation negotiations on reducing conventional arms in Europe. President Bush has suggested the United States and the Soviet Union trim their forces stationed in Europe, outside their home territory, to 275,000 on each side. That would require the Soviets to pull out 300,000 troops and the United States 30,000. The Soviet Union has talked about a limit of 300,000 to 350,000 troops stationed abroad in each alliance. That would cover not only American, but also British, French and other Western forces stationed in West Germany. Somogyi said his plan would go farther. The ceiling, he said, should cover all foreign forces and ``be brought much below the currently negotiated level of 275,000 troops.'' He gave no number. He said Hungary believes there would be no need of foreign troops in Europe were the current political developments to continue. But he said it would be unrealistic now to push for total withdrawal. The arms negotiations is between the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the seven of the Warsaw Pact. NATO wants to reach an agreement this year troops, tanks, artillery and other conventional arms. Senior military officers from 35 nations also were meeting in Vienna for a third day to discuss East-West military strategies. Romania's military chief, Gen. Vasile Ionel, said the new government was working to create a democratic society. He said the government wanted a military budget that provided the minimum amount necessary for national defense.

DOC.HEAD: Former Ecuadoran President Ordered Arrested for Embezzlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th `The people' to UPDATE with police use tear gas to break up pro-Febres Cordero demonstration, details. Picks up 11th, `Febres Cordero's...'
