DOC.HEAD: Bush's Cabinet Still Intact as Administration Begins Second Year
DOC.TEXT: The moderate, pragmatic Cabinet members brought into office by President Bush are still at their desks as the administration begins its second year, but if history is any guide one or more of them will be leaving soon. Critics have targeted Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos as the weakest link in the Bush Cabinet, and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh as probably its biggest disappointment. Yet, such criticism is no barometer of staying power. The surest bet at the start of Bush's second year is that his administration will not follow the pattern of the Reagan presidency when the first Cabinet official to depart was the secretary of state, Alexander M. Haig Jr. Bush's secretary of state, James A. Baker III, is a long-time ally. ``There is no doubt that James Baker is the strong man of the Cabinet,'' said presidential scholar Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution. Year Two of an administration generally sees the first departures from the Cabinet. Martin Durkin resigned as secretary of labor during President Eisenhower's second year. Both John Kennedy and Richard Nixon lost their secretaries of health, education and welfare in the second year: Abraham Ribicoff for Kennedy and Robert H. Finch for Nixon. Jimmy Carter's original appointees, on the other hand, lasted from his inauguration in January 1977 to July 1979, when he shook up his Cabinet in a whirlwind game of musical chairs. Thornburgh has been in his position longer than any of the others. He was named attorney general by Reagan in August 1988, and was kept on by Bush. He had been governor of Pennsylvania and, before that, an assistant attorney general. ``When he was appointed, I rejoiced,'' said Norman Ornstein, a scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. ``I thought at that time that he had the potential to be a great attorney general. He still has that potential.'' But Ornstein and others said Thornburgh has not lived up to expectations. ``He had a good reputation as a really broad-minded person, but he has taken the narrowest perspective on national security,'' said Landis Jones, a professor of political science at the University of Louisville and former director of the White House Fellows program. ``I am a former Pennsylvanian and I would have thought he might have been much better.'' The attorney general has drawn criticism, particularly from liberals, for steps to tighten control on public information from his department and for legal moves he says are needed to protect state secrets in Iran-Contra cases. He also was accused of heavy-handed dealings with Congress in the unsuccessful fight to have William Lucas confirmed as his civil rights chief. On the other hand, Gary Bauer, White House domestic policy adviser under Reagan and now head of the Family Research Council, said that ``basically conservatives, and certainly our group, feel very good about him.'' And Amy Moritz, executive director of the National Center for Public Policy Research, told the Heritage Foundation in a recent survey, ``It's good to have an attorney general with guts.'' Justice Department spokesman David Runkel dismissed criticism of his boss as ``a lot of inside the Beltway chatter by people who haven't taken the time to find out what's going on in the Department of Justice.'' Runkel called assertions that Thornburgh has difficult relations with Congress ``absolute nonsense.'' ``We got the biggest budget increase in the history of the department out of Congress,'' he said. ``Congress doesn't give that kind of money to people they don't have respect for.'' However, the budget increase for the Justice Department could be attributed to the congressional rush to support efforts to combat drugs rather than a particular endorsement of the attorney general. Hess, a White House aide in the Eisenhower administration, said, ``One would have thought that Thornburgh, not only as a person who has been an assistant attorney general in a previous administration but been a very successful governor who had the usual fine antenna of the politician, would have had a far less rocky first year than he has had.'' While Thornburgh is one of the most politically experienced of the Cabinet, Cavazos, a former university president and medical school dean, is one of the least. The Washington Post recently carried a front-page article headed ``Cavazos Gets Low Marks'' that quoted critical remarks by educators about the education secretary's effectiveness. Cavazos responded by saying he remained ``committed to helping George Bush be the education president,'' and White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters, ``He has the job as long as he wants it.'' Still, there have been suggestions that he could be the first to go. ``It is quite clear that Cavazos is the weakest in terms of political support,'' said Ornstein. The low-key Cavazos suffers in some eyes by comparison with his flamboyant predecessor, William J. Bennett, now director of the federal drug control program. Hess described the Education Department as ``in many ways a very modest agency'' but said, ``You can, as Bill Bennett proved, turn it into a bully pulpit ... It just strikes me that this fellow doesn't have those sort of skills.'' Bauer said, ``The jury is still out on whether you are going to get the kind of attention that I think you need to get if you are going to put education on the front burner.'' Bush's Cabinet consists of the heads of the 14 departments plus Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Carla Hills, U.S. trade representative. Bauer said conservatives, many of them skeptical of Darman because of his long association with Baker, ``have been pleasantly surprised that he has held the line on things like taxes.'' As for Baker, many conservatives have never liked him, and they still don't. In the Heritage Foundation survey, which asked five conservative leaders to give report card grades to the Cabinet members, Baker's marks ranged from C to D-minus. But then, conservative political consultant Craig Shirley said in an interview, ``It may be one of those situations where, whoever is secretary of state, conservatives aren't particularly satisfied, because they don't like the State Department anyway.'' Most observers interviewed expressed no strong views one way or another on the remaining Cabinet members. ``Most of the Cabinet members have been out of sight most of the time,'' said Robert Roberts, an associate professor of political science at James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va. David Caputo, professor of political science and dean of humanities at Purdue University, said, ``Jack Kemp (secretary of housing and urban development) has been fairly visible, but I think some of the Cabinet members have taken a low profile.'' Hess, a long-time student of presidential performance, said Bush differs from Reagan and some of his other predecessors in how he handles his Cabinet. ``He gives the Cabinet officer his head, a proper authority to come up with the right solutions and the right management if he or she is capable of it,'' he said. ``Very often the weight of the White House staff under Reagan was the heavier one.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Jan. 21

DOC.HEAD: Farming in City Shadow May Be One Way To Survive, Says Advocate
DOC.TEXT: In the cold light of statistics, a farm that sells less than $40,000 worth of products a year is pretty small potatoes. The big outfits are the ones that really count. It depends whose statistics are being looked at, and by whom. Millions of city families depend on nearby ``small'' farmers for much of their food, says Bud Kerr, director of the Agriculture Department's Office for Small-Scale Agriculture. But despite his missionary zeal to convert mind-locked bureaucrats and others about the growing worth of small farmers, Kerr admits he is fighting some mighty impressive statistics. For example, in the 1988 calendar year farmers sold more than $151.4 billion worth of crops and livestock, a record level of cash receipts from farming operations in the United States. Livestock accounted for nearly $78.8 billion, crops for $72.6 billion. Cash receipts are one of the most useful indicators of farm production, in an overall sense. Big farms produce more and have big receipts, small farms produce less and have small receipts. The latest analysis by the department's Economic Research Service says that the largest farms _ those with annual sales of $500,000 or more _ accounted for 36.6 percent of the 1988 cash sales. A middle group of farms in the sales class of $100,000 to $499,999 collectively accounted for 40 percent of the sales. Those in the $40,000 to $99,999 category sold 13.6 percent. Thus, the larger farms _ those with sales of at least $40,000 a year _ produced 90.2 percent of the crops and livestock that Americans consume, plus huge quantities that are sold abroad. That leaves the smallest category, the ones with sales of less than $40,000 a year, producing only 9.8 percent of the nation's food and fiber. But Kerr and other USDA experts note that the smallest sales category accounted for 1,554,000, or 70.7 percent, of the nation's 2.2 million farms in 1988. The ``commercial'' farms of more than $40,000 annual sales represented only 643,000 farms, or 29.3 percent. The very largest category _ those with $500,000 or more each year _ included only about 30,000 farms, or 1.4 percent of the total. The largest farms produced 36.6 percent of the total farm products sold in 1988, according to the figures. Kerr said it is sometimes easy to overlook the real structure and impact of small farms when such statistics are recited. So he recites some of his own. Small farms control one-third of all agricultural resources, such as land, buildings, machinery and equipment, he said. Small-farm families are major buyers of agricultural ``inputs'' such as fertilizer and other supplies, consumer goods and services. ``They contribute to the well-being of their rural communities and are likely to be an integral part of the community where they farm, supporting community schools, churches and other social and civic activities,'' he said. One of Kerr's recent publications, ``Small-Scale Agriculture Today,'' said that even in areas designated as metropolitan by the Census Bureau, 90 percent of the land is actually rural and 40 percent of it is in farms. ``While farmers in the city's shadow face their share of problems, they also can exploit opportunities that their country counterparts might relish,'' the report said. By being close to city consumers, these metro farmers have direct access to ready-made markets for high-value produce. Overall, they account for 76 percent of the nursery and horticultural crops sold; 67 percent of the vegetables, sweet corn and melons; and 65 percent of the fruit, nut and berries. ``Ten percent of metro farmers sell directly to the consumer, accounting for 60 percent of U.S. direct-marketing sales, and that doesn't include direct sales of nursery and horticultural products,'' the report said. The average metro farm, at 247 acres, is half the size of the 518 acres of non-metro farms, and about 60 percent are less than 100 acres. The number of metro farms increased 4 percent between 1974 and 1982, while non-metro farms declined 6 percent. Kerr said in his report it is important to remember that ``as urbanization encroaches on rural areas, the appropriate response is to adapt, not surrender.'' One way to cope with city sprawl and development is to sell off unproductive land and abandon ``land-extensive enterprises'' such as grass pastures for livestock and then focus on high-value, intensive production. ``It is better to make money on a small farm meeting consumers' demands than to lose money on a big one growing `conventional' crops,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Timing of Social Security Tax Cut Proposal Turns Old Idea Into an Issue
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan shouted tax cut in an empty theater and then left town. Nobody noticed at first, but now his proposal to scale back Social Security taxes has become the issue of the hour. It has the administration nervous, and it could give the Democrats a tax cut to boast about _ even if they don't pass it _ as Congress reconvenes for its election-year session. And it isn't even new business. Indeed, when Moynihan, a New York Democrat, addressed the matter months ago, it was in partnership with a Republican senator. Even then he was repeating an old refrain of his. That went largely unnoticed, too. The revival, and the punch the issue carries these days, is a lesson in the way the Washington echo chamber works, especially during a holiday recess. Moynihan proposed the Social Security tax cut at a news conference on Dec. 29, as the New Year's weekend began. His was about the only show in town that day. He went abroad soon afterward, and was traveling in Africa and the Middle East while the proposal took hold as an issue. That happened during the quiet days of early January, with Congress in the recess that ends Tuesday. The administration was at work on the budget President Bush will present at the end of the month, and the tax cut Moynihan proposed would have a major impact on the deficit projected in that spending plan. The conservative Heritage Foundation issued a paper praising the Moynihan tax cut. The liberal Institute of Policy Studies praised it, too, as a boon to middle and lower income working people. So did the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. It played well with business interests because employers match the Social Security taxes paid by their workers. The White House rejected the idea. ``Democrats seem to want to fiddle around with the Social Security system,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, Bush's press secretary. ``We do not.'' Nice try, but it didn't settle the matter. Democrats started talking about the Moynihan measure as a counterattack on Bush's renewed bid for a cut in the capital gains tax, an alternative they could press as a tax cut for the average American. There were signs of some Republican support for the tax cut, too. Off-balance, the administration finally figured out its own counter-offensive Thursday, arguing that the Moynihan measure would force an increase in other taxes and would lead inevitably to future cuts in benefits. ``It's an effort to get me to raise taxes on the American people by the charade of cutting them, or cut benefits, and I am not going to do it to the older people of this country,'' Bush said. ``Let me tell you something,'' Vice President Dan Quayle said in an interview. ``Cut these taxes the way that Moynihan is talking about, you have got to cut benefits at some time.'' The new Bush budget is to include plans to prevent the use of Social Security reserve funds to offset other spending and thus mask deficits _ the practice that got Moynihan started on the subject. That would be done gradually, over at least two budget years. Moynihan's tax surgery would force the issue by reducing the reserves. The bill he is introducing would roll back a Social Security tax increase that took effect Jan. 1, and lower the rate in 1991. He said that would put the system on a pay-as-you-go basis, limiting reserves and using the tax to pay benefits due now. In the process, it would undo measures adopted in 1983 to build up the Social Security trust fund now in order to meet soaring benefit costs that will come when the baby boom generation begins reaching retirement age in about 20 years. Moynihan served on the commission that recommended that plan, but he said it has been subverted by the use of the Social Security reserves to underwrite spending and conceal the real size of federal deficits. That's done by investing the reserves in Treasury securities, which produces funds for other programs. And without the trust fund reserves, which offset $52 billion in deficit spending in the last budget year, the government wouldn't have come close to meeting its mandated deficit reduction timetable. Moynihan, chairman of a Senate subcommittee on Social Security, said the way the reserves are being used now amounts to thievery. His tax reductions would reduce Social Security revenues by $7 billion this year and by $55 billion in 1991. The General Accounting Office already had suggested a possible tax reduction to ``eliminate the illusory buildup of reserves that now represents little more than a mechanism for using the payroll tax to finance the general operations of government.'' Nearly nine months ago, Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., and Moynihan joined in pressing that argument as the Senate adopted their resolution saying that the trust fund reserves should not be counted in deficit reduction calculations. The measure was approved without dissent on May 3, but it was not binding and it was ignored. So, for all the stir, the Moynihan proposal is hardly a secret weapon. The senator said last spring that if the indirect use of Social Security reserves to finance current deficit spending wasn't stopped, the alternative would be to cut the tax ``so the money is not there to be diverted to inappropriate and, indeed, immoral purposes.'' He got yawns then. Now he's got an issue.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 26 years.

DOC.HEAD: Longest Liver Transplant Survivor Celebrates 20th Anniversary
With BC-EXP--Liver-List
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's been 20 years since transplant surgeons gave a little boy's liver to Kim Hudson, unsure how long the 3{-year-old girl would last beyond the operation, indeed whether she would last at all. Kim Hudson is now Kim Rasmussen, wife of an Air Force sergeant and mother to three cats, three dogs and any other animal that strays her way. Being the world's longest-surviving recipient of a liver transplant is a distinction she'd just as soon forget. ``I don't like to talk about it,'' she said. ``I hate hospitals. I do not like doctors that well _ I associate them with transplants. It's all scary. I shake when I go in to get my blood work. They thought I was going to pass out a couple months ago. I hate it, and it doesn't get any better.'' Every so often, when she's back in Polo, Ill., visiting her parents, she's approached by well-wishing, curious folks. ``When they start mentioning it, you know they want to start talking about it. I just want to run.'' Kim fears her luck will run out if she brags about her Jan. 22, 1970, transplant and how well she has done. Nevertheless, thoughts of the transplant _ and the ever-present risks _ follow her everywhere. ``I think about my health all the time. I pray every day I stay healthy. I pray that it all keeps working.'' Her family is used to her constant anxiety and refusal to discuss anything even remotely connected to transplantation. ``She does so well, she feels it will somehow jinx her,'' said Ethel Hudson, her mother. ``She knows a lot of other ones who have died after getting back from it,'' said her father, Bob. Even Dr. Thomas E. Starzl, who performed the transplant at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center, can't explain Kim's ``uninterrupted good health for practically all the time since we did her.'' ``You could call it providential if you were inclined that way,'' said Starzl, who is now at the University of Pittsburgh. Starzl performed the world's first liver transplant, in 1963, as well as the 31 other liver transplants in Denver that preceded Kim's. Only a handful of medical centers were transplanting livers at the time. During that first decade, children had a 30 percent to 35 percent chance of living one year beyond surgery. For adults, it was 10 percent. ``They were successful if they didn't die on the table ... and got out of the hospital,'' said Paul Taylor, a transplant coordinator who worked with Starzl at the University of Colorado. The Hudsons learned of those early efforts from an article in a medical journal. Their daughter had been born with biliary atresia, a blockage of the bile ducts, and time quickly was running out. Family doctors advised against the risky, experimental procedure. Relatives said they'd be killing the child. Undaunted, the Hudsons persuaded their doctors to send Kim's medical records and blood samples to Denver. Ten months after her name was placed on the waiting list in 1969, a matching liver was found. By the time Kim received the liver and gall bladder of a 7-year-old boy killed in a car accident on Jan. 22, 1970, only four of the 32 previous recipients still were alive. By mid-1975, all four were dead. Kim lived on, though, followed by more and more survivors. Twenty-eight of the 170 patients transplanted by Starzl through February 1980, in fact, still are alive. For Starzl, each one was a ``moon walker.'' ``Up until then, people with those diagnoses and those conditions, really, they had no hope. This at least provided some hope. As it turned out tangible hope,'' he said. ``Kim Hudson, I think, was the symbol of all that.'' The real breakthrough came in 1980, when Starzl began testing an anti-rejection drug known as cyclosporine on liver transplant patients. One-year survival rates soared, eventually settling at today's 70 percent to 80 percent. As the number of transplants grew _ a record 1,680 nationwide in 1988 _ so did the number of those seeking treatment. As of Jan. 15, 834 Americans were awaiting livers, according to the United Network for Organ Sharing. Cyclosporine, approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for general use in 1983, now is being surpassed by an even stronger drug. Known as FK-506, the Japanese drug is believed 50 to 100 times more powerful than cyclosporine. Starzl has conducted the U.S. clinical trials since February 1989. Doctors hestitate to change Kim's medication, though, since she has yet to experience organ rejection. As a result, she takes drugs prescribed long before the advent of cyclosporine. As with any anti-rejection drug, she must swallow her pills every day for the rest of her life. There are side effects to all the drugs, which help prevent rejection by suppressing the immune system and thereby increase the risk of infection. So far, Kim's only major side effect has been cataracts. ``It's nothing to worry about,'' she said. ``I'm not going to get myself all worked up.'' Kim goes out of her way to avoid germs and sick people. She was particularly careful in Okinawa, where her husband, Curt, 24, was stationed for three years. He was transferred to McConnell Air Force Base, Kan., last summer, and the couple just bought a house in nearby Derby. She works part time at the base commissary. The rest of the time she spends with her animals. ``I enjoy life,'' she said. ``But ... it gets scary like when people get around me and they're sick. I've been real lucky.'' She plans to celebrate the 20th anniversary quietly by going out to dinner with her husband, and has but one wish: ``I hope I live to be an old lady.''

DOC.HEAD: With BC-EXP--Longest Liver
DOC.TEXT: Here are some milestones in liver transplantation: _March 1, 1963: The world's first liver transplant, by Dr. Thomas E. Starzl at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Denver. The patient, a 3-year-old, dies that day. _July 23, 1967: The world's first successful liver transplant, in which the patient survives a year, by Starzl. The patient, a 1{-year-old girl, dies 13 months later. _Jan. 22, 1970: Kim Hudson, a 3{-year-old Illinois girl, receives a liver at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center. _March 15, 1980: The anti-rejection drug cyclosporine is administered, on an experimental basis, to a liver transplant patient for the first time in the United States. _1983: The Food and Drug Administration approves cyclosporin for general use. _Feb. 2, 1988: The world's first successful attempt to split a liver and transplant the parts into two patients, at the University of Hannover Medical School in West Germany. _Feb. 28, 1989: A Japanese drug believed to be 50 to 100 times more powerful than cyclosporine in preventing organ rejection, FK-506, is given on an experimental basis to a liver transplant patient for the first time in the world. Starzl oversees the trials at the University of Pittsburgh. _Nov. 27, 1989: The nation's first living-donor liver transplant, in which part of a healthy adult's liver is put into a dying child, at the University of Chicago Medical Center.

DOC.HEAD: Seeds From Satellite To Be Studied in Schools
DOC.TEXT: Students _ not scientists _ will harvest whatever discoveries are yielded by 12.5 million tomato seeds the space shuttle Columbia returned to Earth aboard the rescued Long Duration Exposure Facility. The seeds contributed by Park Seed Co. of Greenwood were sent into space in 1984 aboard the LDEF, a 21,400-pound satellite intended to study how materials, systems and products withstand long exposure to conditions in space. The satellite was to have been retrieved after 10 months, but scheduling problems and the 1986 Challenger disaster delayed retrieval. Atmospheric drag had been pulling the satellite toward Earth about a half-mile a day; if it had not been retrieved Jan. 12 by Columbia astronauts, it was expected to fall to earth about March 9, destroying the 58 scientific experiments. ``You can imagine that the scientific community would like to get their hands on the material,'' said Jim Alston, Park's research director. Instead, it will package the surviving seeds into 150,000 experiment kits for schools. ``We don't want professional scientists pre-empting what the kids will find.'' Researchers expect some mutations, Alston said, but ``We really don't know what to expect as results. The question always comes up, `Are we going to have killer tomatoes or anything like that?' No, that's not going to happen. ``There's 12.5 million seeds; there can be any number of mutations. There's also the possibility a very desirable plant or characteristic will pop up that can be developed for a commercial release, or a new tomato type or something.'' The seeds will be delivered to elementary and secondary schools and colleges chosen by NASA. The schools will be asked to submit experiment results to Oklahoma State University, which will publish a report on the findings. ``If our dreams come true, we'll have about 4 million school kids participating in this project towards the end of this semester,'' Alston said. ``The (schools) that do send in the report will get a certificate from NASA. The more that do report, the better our database will be.'' Park Seed also placed aboard the LDEF an additional 1.9 million seeds of 106 varieties for its own experiments. It will study growth rates, percentage that failed to survive and the fruits, vegetables and plants the seeds produce. The produce from the seeds will be edible because they're ``not picking up enough residual radiation to be any problem,'' Alston said. ``In fact, there probably will be no more than here on Earth right now.'' It is not the first time Park Seed has been involved with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. One of the nation's largest mail-order seed companies, Park Seed participated in a 1983 shuttle experiment, prompting the chief scientist for this mission to ask the company to devise a project involving a large number of students.

DOC.TEXT: America's trade deficit widened to $10.5 billion in November, its worst showing in 11 months, as U.S. exports took a tumble caused in part by a strike at Boeing Co. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that while imports dipped slightly from an all-time high set in October, U.S. exports sales declined even more, falling to their lowest level since last March. As a result, the trade deficit, the difference between imports and exports, rose 2.4 percent.

Industrial production rose a strong 0.4 percent in December, the government said. Analysts attributed virtually all of the strength to abnormally cold weather and the end of a major aircraft strike. Record cold weather over much of the nation boosted utility output by 6.3 percent while the settlement of the Boeing Co. strike in late November returned production there to normal the following month, the Federal Reserve Board reported Wednesday.

U.S. crude oil production last year recorded its biggest decline ever while oil imports reached a 10-year high, the American Petroleum Institute said. The institute, a trade association of the major oil companies, also said Wednesday that although U.S. oil consumption increased only slightly, imports rose to 46 percent of total supplies. That was the second-highest level on record.

Facing an end to federal protection from takeovers in April, Conrail announced Wednesday a plan to buy back $1.3 billion of its stock and establish a $300 million stock ownership plan for non-union employees. Consolidated Rail Corp. officials said a $1 billion tender offer for up to 21 million of the railroad's 67.1 million common shares would open today at a price of $43 to $53 per share. Conrail's shares closed Wednesday at $46.12{ in New York Stock Exchange trading, down 37{ cents. Its restructuring was announced after the market closed.

International Business Machines Corp. said its fourth-quarter earnings fell 74 percent, due to restructuring-related costs that some analysts said were somewhat bigger than expected. The world's biggest computer company said Wednesday it posted a profit of $600 million, or $1.04 a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31. That was down from $2.3 billion, or $3.97 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue totaled $20.5 billion, up 2.3 percent from $20 billion a year earlier.

The Supreme Court has ruled that American corporations may be sued for allegedly bribing foreign government officials. The court Wednesday permitted a lawsuit against W.S. Kirkpatrick and Co., which has been accused of bribing Nigerian government officials to win a contract in 1982 for development of a medical center at Kaduna Air Force Base in Nigeria. The court held that a doctrine restricting U.S. court review of foreign policy does not automatically shield corporations from such suits.

Top officers of Campeau Corp.'s department store divisions held closed meetings to plan how they will to operate under bankruptcy court protection, following signals that they would resist liquidating stores. Company executives would not comment Wednesday on how debt-ridden Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. might try to reorganize and pay their creditors. Retailing analysts speculated that store sales seemed a foregone conclusion.

Housing Secretary Jack Kemp killed a program that allows private lenders to commit the government to insuring mortgages and that has cost taxpayers nearly $1 billion because of sour loans. Because of projects in the approval pipeline, Kemp said Wednesday that the program would have to be phased out, a period Department of Housing and Urban Development officials said was likely to last several months or perhaps longer because of necessary regulatory approvals. In the interim, Kemp ordered, effective immediately, that private lenders preparing to approve a co-insured loan first submit all documentation to HUD for approval.

Production rates at three Chrysler Corp. assembly plants will be cut in March, resulting in the indefinite layoffs of more than 2,000 workers, the company said. The company on Wednesday blamed the moves on slow sales. The cuts are due at Chrysler's plants in Belvidere, Ill., Newark, Del., and Toledo, Ohio, which make some of the company's most profitable cars and Jeeps. The reductions come in addition to previously announced temporary and indefinite layoffs that will affect more than 25,000 Chrysler workers in February.

Stock prices fell to an eight-week low Wednesday under a barrage of late selling attributed to disappointing economic and earnings news. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 33.49 to 2,659.13, its lowest close since 2,656.78 on Nov. 22. The dollar fell against most foreign currencies. Bond prices finished mixed. Oil and gasoline futures prices plummeted; precious metals futures rose; livestock and meat futures were higher; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Groupe Bull Announces Plans for Zenith Acquisition, New Model
DOC.TEXT: Groupe Bull, the French computer company that bought the computer business of Zenith Electronics Corp. in late December, says it plans to keep the Zenith operation a separate division with its own identity. ``Zenith Data Systems will be our PC arm, with responsibility for microcomputer product marketing and development on a worldwide basis,'' said Francis Lorentz, Groupe Bull's chairman and chief executive. Groupe Bull also announced Wednesday a series of management changes. Under them, Roland Pampel, president and chief executive of Bull HN Information Systems Inc., was named chairman of Zenith Data Systems as well as senior executive vice president of Groupe Bull. Pampel, 54, previously was president and chief operating officer of the former Apollo Computer Inc. Bull HN Information Systems is Bull's other U.S. computer division, which consists primarily of the former Honeywell computer line. In addition, the French company unveiled a new logo for the Zenith division that incorporates the Zenith name _ but not the zigzag ``Z'' used by Zenith Electronics Corp. _ with Bull's stylized tree logo. Bull said it would keep Zenith Data Systems' headquarters in suburban Chicago and its manufacturing plants in that area and in St. Joseph, Mich. With the addition of Zenith Data Systems, Bull says it now has a complete product line, ranging from Zenith's popular portable and desktop computers to Bull's existing powerful mainframes. Analysts have generally praised Bull's purchase of Zenith's well-regarded computer division, which was announced in October and completed last month. They say it was a savvy move by Bull to extend its product line. ``I think if Bull manages it right they're going to have a winner here,'' said Bob Tasker, an analyst for the research firm International Data Corp. Tasker said that before the purchase, Bull was weak in the desktop market. In addition, he said, the Zenith acquisition should help Bull tackle its poor name recognition in this country. Another benefit to Bull is that the Zenith acquisition opens up a wide variety of software to use on a combination of Zenith and Bull computers, Tasker said. The existing Bull machines can use only a narrow range of software, while the Zenith machines can run on a huge number of software packages, he said. By linking the Zenith machines with Bull computers, Bull can sell computer systems compatible with ``huge horizons'' of programs, he said. Also Wednesday, the Zenith division unveiled its first desktop machine that conforms with an industry standard Zenith helped establish in 1988. The standard, called Extended Industry Standard Architecture, was proposed by nine computer makers as a competitor to the microchannel computer architecture developed by International Business Machines Corp. In addition to being based on the new architecture, Zenith says the new machine offers greatly increased access to its computer disc, which would be useful in applications where 30 users or more are hooked up to the computer system.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Bankruptcy Judge Is Former Newspaperman
With PM-Campeau, Bjt
LaserPhoto CS10 of Jan. 17
DOC.TEXT: The judge who will oversee the bankruptcy reorganization of Campeau Corp.'s department store empire has a reputation as a quietly efficient jurist _ but in this mammoth case he also may want to fall back on his reputation for humor. Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who has been a U.S. bankruptcy judge for 14 months, also is an amateur poet who two years ago presented to the City Council a tongue-in-cheek ode on the merits of a proposal to include bronze, winged pigs in a sculpture marking Cincinnati's 1988 bicentennial. Critics said the pigs _ a reference to Cincinnati's 19th century prominence in hog butchering _ made the city look silly. Part of Aug's 18-line verse read: ``I've heard a recent nasty rumor; Cincinnati has no sense of humor; Now the question's grown so big; Shall we adopt the flying pig?'' The pigs eventually were retained. Aug, 43, faces a more arduous task in guiding the reorganizations of Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. Six thousand pages articulating the largest Chapter 11 filing in U.S. retailing history was filed with Aug's court Monday. Riding on the fates of the Cincinnati-based divisions of Campeau are 100,000 employees and 258 department stores nationwide, including the locally based, 14,000-employee Lazarus chain. Aug, who also has worked as a private attorney and newspaperman during his career, is no stranger to the federal bench or bankruptcy cases. He was appointed in 1976 to an eight-year term as a U.S. magistrate in Cincinnati and was reappointed in 1984. Magistrates handle arraignments and certain cases under supervision of federal district court judges. Aug became one of Cincinnati's two federal bankruptcy judges on Dec. 1, 1988, when he filled a vacancy created when Judge Randall J. Newsome transferred to a similar job in San Francisco. Aug handled some bankruptcy cases as a Cincinnati lawyer from 1974 to 1976 as an attorney in private practice, and before then was a staff attorney with the federal courts in Washington. His father, J. Vincent Aug Sr., is a Cincinnati lawyer. Aug declined a request by The Associated Press for an interview because he did not wish to comment on the Federated-Allied case, an aide said. Martha Perin, executive director of the Cincinnati Bar Foundation and former director of the Cincinati Bar Association, described Aug as low-key but efficient. ``He's very capable, quiet, very unassuming but very diligent,'' she said. Aug was born in Indianapolis and educated in Cincinnati schools. After graduating from St. Xavier High School, he went to Georgetown University, where he received a bachelor's degree in 1968. He served two years with the Peace Corps in Kenya, then was a newspaper reporter in 1970 for The Cincinnati Post. He received his law degree in 1973 from the University of Cincinnati and took a job that year as a staff attorney with the Judicial Panel on Multi-District Litigation in the federal court system's Washington administrative office. Aug served as a columnist for The Cincinnati Enquirer from 1978 to 1983, was an adjunct faculty member at the University of Cincinnati College of Law from 1982 to 1985, and was president of the Cincinnati chapter of the Federal Bar Association in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Federated, Allied Executives Meet; First Boston Responds
DOC.TEXT: The financial house listed as the biggest unsecured creditor in bankruptcy filings by Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. says it's owed about half of what the documents indicate. First Boston Corp. issued a statement Wednesday saying that the filings accurately list Federated's and Allied's combined unsecured obligations to First Boston Corp. as $526 million. But the New York-based firm said other factors limit First Boston's total exposure to $293 million, including exchange notes resulting from a temporary loan it made to Federated. The filings value securities at face, or par, value, but First Boston acquired many of those bonds at substantial discounts, the company said. The filing also includes custodial holdings for the firm's customers, First Boston said. In addition, the filing accounts for zero-coupon bonds at their full value at maturity, even though the bonds do not mature until 2004 and their value today is significantly less, First Boston said. Troubled Campeau Corp. put its Federated and Allied divisions, which operate 258 department stores, under federal bankruptcy court protection Monday to allow the companies to operate while they work out a plan to satisfy creditors. The U.S. retail units now operate under the corporate umbrella Federated Stores Inc. G. William Miller, the former treasury secretary and Federal Reserve Board chairman named Tuesday as chairman of Federated, met Wednesday in Cincinnati with the heads of the Campeau's nine U.S. department store chains. The company would not comment on how Federated and Allied would reorganize and pay their creditors, but retail analysts continued to speculate that sales of store groups are imminent. ``I think they'll be selling off some assets. They have some great names there and some wonderful stores they could sell,'' said Karen Sack, an analyst for Standard & Poor's Corp. in New York. ``There are a lot of other retail chains around that would like to pick up the retail chains they have.'' Federated's stores are Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Lazarus of Cincinnati, Burdine's of Miami and Rich's of Atlanta. Allied's stores are The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Maas Brothers of Tampa and Stern's of Paramus, N.J. In their Chapter 11 filing the companies listed assets of $9.1 billion and liabilities of $7.7 billion, much of it debt used to finance Toronto-based Campeau's purchases of Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. ``The debt must be significantly reduced. That was the cause of the problem, and that is the only cure,'' said Monroe Greenstein of Bear Stearns & Co. Inc. ``The operating company is basically a good sound company, until this huge overhang of debt hit it.'' James M. Zimmerman, president of Federated and Allied, has said that executives want to resist selling divisions of the company to pay creditors. The only exception is Federated's 17-store Bloomingdale's chain, which it put up for sale last year. The chains, whose operations had been profitable before the Chapter 11 filing, should be able to operate normally now that they are temporarily relieved of their debt burden, said Jack Seibald of Salomon Brothers Inc. ``The thing that got to them was not the operations, it was the debt,'' Seibald said. Joseph Chervin, a New York bankruptcy lawyer who is representing some of Federated's and Allied's creditors, said those at greatest risk during the bankruptcy court proceedings are investors who bought bonds Campeau sold to finance its venture into American retailing. ``Everybody's getting paid except the bond holders,'' Chervin said. ``The banks that put money in (after Monday's filing) are getting taken care of, the suppliers are getting taken care of.'' Creditors from before the filing will have a chance to vote on acceptance of the retailers' reorganization plan, which must be approved by the federal bankruptcy court, said Neal Colton, a Philadelphia bankruptcy lawyer. Colton said bond holders could be asked to accept reduced interest payments or longer repayment periods. ``The difference in a reorganization of this magnitude is that it is unclear whether there will be enough money to pay off everyone who holds debts,'' Colton said. Documents Campeau filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission earlier this month warned that even the sale of all its store groups might not raise enough money under certain conditions to pay off all the debts.

DOC.HEAD: Second Service May Become More Likely Option Following AT&T Problems
DOC.TEXT: The aura of invincibility that AT&T managed to create with heavy advertising and dependable service has unraveled a bit with Monday's network outage, but the company will not be abandoned by its customers, analysts say. A more likely result will be a hard-sell by American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s competitors to get companies to add a backup carrier to their service. ``They can now go to large customers and say, `See, this is what can happen. You need us as a backup,''' said Audrey Stevoff, an analyst with the Chicago investment firm Duff & Phelps Inc. ``AT&T is up there with motherhood and apple pie and perfection,'' Ms. Stevoff said Wednesday. ``It shook everybody up, including the company. It really did tarnish their image. It showed that they reallyaren't perfect.'' No. 2 MCI Communications Corp. and No. 3 US Sprint wasted no time in capitalizing on AT&T's embarrassing misfortune. ``This is a competitive business and beating up on the competition is the name of the game,'' said Geoffrey Johnson, a telecommunications analyst at Argus Research Corp. in New York. ``MCI and Sprint were both just handed a giant club.'' Sprint came out swinging. Sprint, which controls about 8 percent of the long-distance market, placed a full-page ad in several newspapers Wednesday informing customers how to access its service if they have problems with other carriers: dial 10333, then 1, the area code and the number. The procedure is the same for MCI except the access code is 10222. ``We don't want to rub salt in anybody's wounds,'' said Sprint spokesman Sid Courson. But, he added: ``AT&T has been heralding its system and its history of utter reliablity and it just ain't so. ``We have never lost the whole network,'' he said. ``They did.'' AT&T, which has 70 percent of the long-distance market, was planning to offer a day of reduced-rate calling or another customer benefit to help atone for the inconvenience Monday, when half its calls didn't go through, said spokesman Harry Baumgartner. The plan could be announced today, the company said. It was possible AT&T would ask its competitors to agree to temporarily transfer customers to each other should any of them run into similar problems, Baumgartner said. On Monday, AT&T operators at first refused to provide access codes for customers to reach MCI or Sprint. The policy was abandoned when the seriousnes of AT&T's problem became apparent, the company said. Baumgartner said: ``We have focused on quality like no other. That's why this is so painful for AT&T.'' He said the computer software glitch that knocked out service was an aberration and most of the company's customers will understand that and not jump to other carriers. Courson said Sprint's Dallas office, which concentrates on medium and large businesses, averaged 20 unsolicited calls an hour Tuesday and Wednesday from companies asking about the service. He said that prior to Monday's outage, the company averaged about 11 unsolicited calls per day. Many large corporations already have backup carriers, but many others do not, probably because they never experienced such problems with AT&T and did not expect to, Ms. Stevoff said. AT&T spokeswoman Sue Fleming said virtually all of the company's large business customers have the capability of adding a backup service with little expense. But adding a backup carrier usually reduces the number of lines for the primary carrier, she said. Figures on the percentage of AT&T customers that also use a second carrier were not available from AT&T, MCI or Sprint. The inconvenience of this week's problems may push those with a single carrier _ regardless of which company it is _ to sign up a second carrier. John Hauser, an MCI spokesman, said his company's strategy was similar to Sprint's. ``We're not going to have to do anything more than we have been doing,'' he said. ``We just have to announce louder that we're around and that businesses probably shouldn't put all their eggs in one basket.'' A spokesman for Du Pont Co., one of AT&T's largest customers, said AT&T's failure affected all of his company's communications because none of its long-distance traffic moves on private, dedicated lines. The spokesman, John Wheeler, said Du Pont is constantly evaluating its communications system because the network is vital to its business. Du Pont does about 40 percent of its business overseas. ``Let's just say there was a very long pause in our business day,'' he said. ``But I've heard no suggestions here that Du Pont is either backing up or getting rid of AT&T.''

DOC.HEAD: British Airways Chief Calls for Global Task Force on Airline Problems
DOC.TEXT: The chief executive of British Airways PLC has called for the creation of a special international task force to help solve the airline industry's lack of capacity worldwide. Colin Marshall, chief executive and joint deputy chairman of the British airline, said Wednesday an ``action group'' should be set up under the International Air Transport Association to deal with crowded airports, runways and air traffic corridors. ``What we need is an action group under the aegis of IATA, one which can approach the problems bluntly and directly, operating from a basis of self-interest and at the same time of overall industry concern,'' Marshall said in a speech to the Wings Club, an aviation industry group. ``If we cannot create something like this, then I suspect the constantly growing `airweed,' a cousin to that which can eventually stop even the largest oceangoing ships, will bring us to a moribund halt,'' he said. Trump Shuttle President Bruce Nobles said he agrees with Marshall about the capacity problems but isn't sure an international task force is the solution. ``It's an interesting idea but I don't know how necessary it is,'' he said in an interview following the speech. Nobles is a member of the Partnership for Improved Air Travel, a U.S. lobbying group seeking to have money in the Airport and Airway Trust Fund earmarked for system improvement. Because of pressure to reduce the federal budget deficit, neither the White House nor Congress has been willing to dip into the aviation trust fund, which is supplied by an 8 percent tax that is included in air fares. The Air Transport Association, a U.S. industry group in Washington, D.C., also said it found Marshall's proposal interesting. ``The U.S. airlines would certainly be willing to consider any measure that would have a realistic prospect of improving the world's airports-airways capacity problem,'' said ATA spokeswoman Kathleen Rosenauer. She declined to elaborate. In his speech, Marshall suggested that six or seven ``capable'' senior airline executives should get together with IATA to determine how to set up an international task force. ``British Airways would be willing to offer the services of one of its best managers,'' he said, adding that ``we ... should not have any greater part in it than anyone else.'' Asked whether he was offering himself as a potential participant, Marshall replied, ``I'm not accustomed to hiding my light under the bushes, so why not?''

DOC.HEAD: CEO Fights Perception of Woman-Run Bank as `Feminist' Business
DOC.TEXT: All Christine M. Weakley wants to do as head of Paces Bank & Trust is run a successful business. But as one of the few female chief executive officers of a bank, she finds herself in the position of having to knock down misconceptions that Paces is a ``women's'' bank. Though the majority of the bank's stockholders, directors and senior managers are women, ``our interest first and foremost is to be a good bank,'' Ms. Weakley said. Stressing highly personalized service, Paces caters mainly to small businesses. The Atlanta bank opened last month and had, as of Dec. 31, $1.5 million in deposits and $500,000 in loans. Because of the attention she has received as CEO and president, several misconceptions have arisen about the bank, Ms. Weakley said. ``There are always various and sundry comments, that we're all feminists out to right the wrongs of the world, that we only bank with women. We've even been called a pro-choice bank,'' Ms. Weakley said. ``One man who came in was real uncomfortable and said he had to talk to a man,'' Ms. Weakley recalled during an interview at her office Wednesday. ``He said, `No offense, but women in banking to me is like men selling Avon.''' Ms. Weakley is no newcomer to banking. She worked for nine years at the First National Bank of Cobb County before deciding to open her own bank. The preponderance of women in the organization helped Paces qualify for the federal government's minority banks program. The program helps open the door to accounts for such banks by making them eligible for deposits from government agencies and certain corporations. ``The government still considers women a minority,'' Ms. Weakley said. ``I've never been a rabid feminist and don't plan to be. I simply saw it (the program) as a way to get started quicker.'' The minority status has been a mixed blessing for Paces and Ms. Weakley. It has helped the bank get a foothold in the competitive Atlanta market, but also has given it a label that makes some potential customers wary. ``Unfortunately, it has been turned around that we're automatically making a social statement,'' Ms. Weakley said. ``When the publicity first started, that was the angle the media used _ a women's bank opens in Atlanta.'' Ms. Weakley's experiences with people uneasy about her position are not uncommon among women in high-ranking executive jobs, said Patricia McDougall, an associate professor of management at Georgia State University who specializes in issues involving women. ``It's very common for female executives to face the problem of being stereotyped and their sex being reacted to rather than their expertise,'' Ms. McDougall said. She said the problems occur especially at the higher levels of the corporate world because women in middle management positions now are not considered unusual. Ms. McDougall said negative reactions have accompanied most instances where women have done things that previously were taboo. ``It goes back to when the first female walked out and filled your car with gas. It was a shock,'' she said. ``Now we think nothing of seeing women stand at self-service pumps.'' Ms. Weakley said she and her bank have been accepted by those in the banking business, but the misconceptions remain largely among the public, which she said is not accustomed to seeing women run banks. Indeed, Ms. Weakley said that in most cases when she has been given the chance to talk to a wary potential customer, she has overcome their hesitance. ``A lot of people, if they sit down long enough to talk to you, they get over a lot of the preconceptions,'' she said. A Treasury Department roster of banks qualifying under the federal minority program lists 98 institutions across the country, but does not distinguish between those that qualified because they are run by ethnic minorities and those run by women. A Treasury official in Washington, who asked not to be identified, said most of the banks in the program are run by ethnic minorities. ``The fact of the matter is there were more women banks in the country and more in our program. But for whatever reason, many of them folded. It seemed to be an idea whose time hadn't come,'' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Conrail Announces $1.3 Billion Buyback of Stock In Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Conrail's restructuring plan met with praise from a railroad analyst who said the $1 billion stock repurchase and $300 million employee stock plan will help ward off any takeover attempts. ``They probably couldn't come up with a better plan,'' said analyst Anthony B. Hatch of PaineWebber Inc. ``This is a prudent way to help them in the short- and long-term.'' Officials of Consolidated Rail Corp. said Wednesday they would launch today a $1 billion tender offer for up to 21 million of the railroad's 67.1 million common shares, with the price range for the ``Dutch auction'' at $43 to $53 per share. Conrail's shares closed Wednesday at $46.12{ in New York Stock Exchange trading, down 37{ cents. The restructuring was announced after the market closed. Although company officials would not comment on their motive, analysts noted that Conrail, the nation's fifth-largest railroad in terms of revenue, loses its government protection against takeovers April 2. Hatch speculated the restructuring was a move to head off any takeover attempts by ensuring that its stock was fairly valued. Conrail could attract a corporate raider because of the railroad's small long-term debt and cash reserves of about $600 million, analysts said. They say Conrail could be worth more broken up and sold off than the cost of all its stock. Conrail's move was made possible in part by recent legislation that allows the freight railroad to buy back significant amounts of its own stock. The Philadelphia-based company, created by federal legislation to rescue the Penn Central and five other bankrupt railroads in 1976, was sold by the government to the public in 1987. However, the government retained some power over the company, such as limiting its repurchase of stock. Also Wednesday, Conrail, which operates in 14 Northeastern and Midwestern states and Quebec, reported 1989 earnings of $148 million, or $2.17 per share, down from $306 million, or $4.44 per share, in 1988. The 1989 earnings reflected a special charge of $234 million, or $2.16 per share, related to layoffs, consolidation of operating and administrative functions and a larger reserve fund for expenses related to accidents. The special charge was taken in the fourth quarter, which showed a loss of $81 million, or $1.20 per share, compared with earnings of $78 million, or $1.13 per share, for the same quarter in 1988. Hagen said the company's board of directors undertook the restructuring ``to improve performance and structure and thereby enhance shareholder value.'' Under the repurchase plan, which expires Feb. 14, the company will conduct a Dutch auction, meaning stock owners will offer their shares to the company for a price that falls within the range Conrail specified. The company, in turn, will select a share price within the range that will enable it to buy the number of shares it set out to buy. As part of its repurchase plan, Conrail said it will spend $200 million to $400 million to buy additional shares on the open market after the Dutch auction is completed. The amount of the repurchase will depend in part of the results of the Dutch auction, it said. Conrail spokesman Saul Resnick said the railroad established the $300 million employee stock ownership plan for non-union employees but is still considering a similar plan for union employees. For the fourth quarter, Conrail's revenue totaled $823 million, compared with $904 million in the same quarter of 1988. Revenue for all of 1989 was $3.41 billion, compared with $3.49 billion in 1988. Hagen said fourth quarter revenue was affected by a 4.7 percent drop in traffic volume, with the largest declines in metals and related product shipments, down 23.6 percent, and in automotive shipments, down 15.2 percent. He predicted a further downturn in traffic in 1990, due to projected declines in auto and steel shipments. Meanwhile, Standard & Poor's Corp., a credit-rating agency, lowered its rating of Conrail's debt in response to the restructuring, which it said would weaken the company's credit standing somewhat. S&P lowered its rating of Conrail senior debt to A from AA- and its equipment trust certificates to AA from AAA, its highest rating.

DOC.HEAD: Jobless Rate Falls to 5.8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 5.8 percent in December, its lowest level in more than nine years, the government said Thursday. The seasonally adjusted rate compared with a revised rate of 5.9 percent in November, and a rate of 7.2 percent a year ago, the Department of Employment said. The number of jobless fell by 17,100 in the latest month, compared with declines of 22,900 in November and 67,800 a year earlier. Without seasonal adjustment, the number of unemployed was 1.64 million in December, compared with 1.61 million in November and 2.05 million in December 1988. Employment Secretary Michael Howard said unemployment is now at the lowest rate since October 1980.

DOC.HEAD: The Hottest of the Hot Cars? Chevrolet Camaro
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The 1986 Chevrolet Camaro topped a list of the nation's most-stolen vehicles, thanks in part to the interchangeability of its parts with other General Motors Corp. cars, an insurance valuation company said. A list compiled by CCC Information Services Inc. of Chicago showed the 1986 Camaro again in first. It was followed by the 1987, '84 and '85 models of the Camaro. Camaros also held the top four spots on the most-stolen list for 1988. The 1988 Hyundai Excel GL, at No. 10, was the only car not made by GM in the top 10. Car thieves, for the most part, are parts suppliers, CCC Vice President William Geen said Wednesday. And interchangeability of parts, such as between the Firebird and Camaro, makes those cars more likely candidates for theft. ``If the belief is that the No. 1 reason that people steal cars is for the parts, it would seem to be common sense that they would always appear on top,'' Geen said. The 1988 Ford Mustang, No. 43 among stolen cars, was the first non-GM, domestic car on the list compiled by CCC and used by the insurance industry to provide theft data. GM is banking that in later reports, newer Camaros will drop in rankings. ``We're confident that our new `PASS-Key' system will greatly reduce the number of thefts,'' said GM spokeswoman Ruth Bouldes. The system, which shuts down the fuel system if someone tampers with the ignition system, originally was introduced on the 1986 Corvette and the 1989 Camaro. The annual report also reflected the growing popularity of light trucks, especially pickups, not only among buyers but among thieves. The 1986 and 1985 Chevrolet full-size pickup trucks zoomed to 13th and 14th places, respectively, on last year's list. Neither vehicle was in the top 100 in 1988. ``The number of light duty trucks sold in the last two to three years is just off the charts,'' Geen said. Sales of domestic and foreign light trucks jumped to 4.7 million in 1989, up 9.3 percent from the 1985 level. The increased popularity, he said, increases the likelihood of them becoming theft targets for parts suppliers.

DOC.HEAD: Fatal Air Crashes Reached 21-Year High Last Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. airlines had their most fatal air crashes last year since 1968 but the government says the overall accident rate for commercial air carriers and commuters declined. In all, 278 people were killed in 11 crashes in 1989 involving scheduled and non-scheduled air carriers, down slightly from the 285 in 1988, the National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday. The most deadly year of the decade was 1985 when 526 people were killed in seven fatal commercial aviation accidents. The least destructive year was 1980 when only one fatal accident took place, killing just one person. Also last year, 763 people died in accidents involving private or general aircraft, the safety board said, the lowest figure for that category since it began keeping statistics. There were 781 deaths involving general aviation accidents in 1988. The board said the fatal accident rate for general or private aviation continued ``an improving trend that lasted most of the decade.'' Despite the high number of airline accidents involving fatalities last year, the overall accident rate for commercial air carriers and commuters declined, the safety board said. There were 28 accidents involving U.S. scheduled and charter airlines last year, a decrease from the 32 accidents recorded in 1988. The 11 involving fatalities were the most since the 15 of 1968. The fatal accident rate was 0.144 for every 100,000 scheduled and charter departures, up from 0.026 in 1988. The major scheduled U.S. airlines had 24 accidents last year, down from 31 the previous year. Of those two dozen accidents, eight involved fatalities, the most since 1973. Accidents involving scheduled airlines took 131 lives last year, 111 of them when a United Airlines DC-10 crashed in Sioux City, Iowa on July 19. The safety board noted a passenger who died 31 days after the accident was not registered in its statistics. The scheduled-airline accident rate for each 100,000 departures was 0.328, down from 0.412 in 1988. The fatal accident rate rose from 0.027 to 0.109. Charter airlines experienced four accidents during the year, three of them involving fatalities. A total of 147 people died, all but three of them in the Feb. 8 crash of an Independent Air B-707. There were no fatal accidents involving chartered aircraft in 1988. Here are other aviation accident statistics for 1989: _Commuter flights: There were 18 accidents, one fewer then in 1988. Five fatal accidents, up from 2 in 1988, took 31 lives. That was 10 more than in 1988. The accident rate: 0.621 for each 100,000 departures compared to a rate of 0.654 in 1988. The fatal accident rate rose from 0.069 to 0.172. _Air taxis: Accidents rose from 98 in 1988 to 110. The number of fatal accidents declined from 27 to 23. But fatalities increased from 58 to 80. The accident rate rose from 3.45 to 3.83 for every 100,000 aircraft hours. But the fatal accident rate dropped from 0.95 to 0.80. _General aviation: The accident rate dropped for the seventh year in a row from 7.97 for each 100,000 aircraft hours in 1988 to 7.25. The last increase in the accident rate took place in 1982 when it was 10,06. The fatal accident rate declined to 1.40 for each 100,000 hours from 1.52 in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Federal Government Should Close Hispanic Pay Gap
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The federal government should close the 14 percent pay gap between Hispanic employees and other civil servants to improve its ``disturbing'' Hispanic employment rate, according to an advocacy group. The average salary for Hispanic white collar civil servants in 1988 was $3,918 less than for the their counterparts, according to a report released Wednesday by the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials. The pay gap damages the government's efforts to hire Hispanics, said Harry Pachon, the group's national director. Richard McGowan, a spokesman for the Office of Personnel Management, said several factors affect white collar workers' salaries, including experience, education and seniority. Hispanics made up 5.2 percent of executive branch employees and accounted for 7.3 percent of the private sector workforce in 1988, the most recent year for which the information was available, according to the study. ``It's a disturbing thing, because if anybody should be exhibiting fair employment practices that represent the ethnic makeup of the country, it should be the federal government,'' said Robert Paral, a researcher for the association. Only one of 13 federal agencies _ the Justice Department with a 9.3 percent Hispanic employment rate _ exceeded the private sector average, said the report, which reviewed 1988 affirmative action information. Of 1,227 civil servants working at executive office agencies such as the Office of Management and Budget, only 13, or 1.1 percent, are Hispanic, the report said. ``The lack of Hispanics in those jobs is especially bothersome because these are the people who have the president's ear,'' Paral said. In a speech last month to Hispanics, OPM Director Constance Newman acknowledged that Hispanics remain under-represented in the government's 2.1 million civilian workforce. She said the government has programs to recruit Hispanics. The report showed five of the agencies have Hispanic employment rates of less than half the national average. For instance, Hispanics make up 3.2 percent of the Department of Education's workforce. The government's hiring rate for Hispanics has steadily increased over the past 15 years, growing from 3.7 percent in 1976 to 5.3 percent as of March 1989, McGowan said. The number should increase as minorities and women make up a larger portion of the workforce, he said. Hispanics account for about 9 percent of the nation's population, Paral said. Since 1980, the number of adult Hispanics who are citizens and therefore eligible for federal government jobs has increased by more than 45 percent, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Plans Fall Through For Heiress to Buy Shipyard, But New Plan In Works
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Plans for a Polish-born heiress to buy the shipyard where Solidarity was born fell through this month after her representatives demanded a five-year strike ban and wages of 50 cents an hour. A newspaper says a portrait of Barbara Piasecka-Johnson, the New Jersey heiress who last year offered to invest up to $100 million in the shipyard, has now been replaced at the complex by one of Polish-born Pope John Paul II. Ms. Johnson had been hailed as a savior for offering the cash to keep the Lenin Shipyard afloat. Now, officials say they're drawing up a plan to sell shares in the yard to workers and investors alike. The shipyard's future has been uncertain since October 1988, when Poland's government _ then run by Communists _ announced plans to close the sprawling facility in the spirit of economic reform. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, who took charge of the independent movement that transformed the Communist bloc during a 1980 strike at the shipyard, called the government move a provocation. The Communist authorities said the shipyard was unprofitable, and closing it was just the sort of hardship workers would have to endure if Poland's economic slide was to be reversed. Mrs. Johnson, who married the head of the Johnson and Johnson pharmaceutical firm and inherited his fortune, signed a letter of intent to take a controlling interest in the shipyard. During visits to Poland from her New Jersey home, she appeared frequently smiling and joking at Walesa's side. But terms were never reached and the letter of intent expired Jan. 1, although Mrs. Johnson offered to continue the talks. James Whisenand, a Miami attorney who represents Mrs. Johnson, was not immediately available for comment Wednesday. Zbigniew Lis, who negotiated for the Solidarity local during talks with the government on the yard's future, told the Communist Youth daily Sztandar Mlodych that Mrs. Johnson's conditions made it difficult for the workers to accept what she proposed. He said her business representatives wanted a five-year ban on strikes and a 50-cent hourly wage for the same period. Other joint ventures pay double that amount, he said. A new proposal to save the shipyard has been put forth by the Solidarity-led government. It would allow the yard to reorganize as a joint stock company, with workers being allowed to buy shares. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska told a Jan. 5 news conference that foreigners, including Mrs. Johnson, would be allowed to buy into the joint stock company. There have been no indications if Mrs. Johnson intends to participate. However, before the actual transformation of the shipyard into a joint stock company, Parliament must pass legislation on privatization of government-owned industries. That is expected to take six months, the newspaper said. Meanwhile, counting on Mrs. Johnson's offer, the shipyard may have passed up other potential offers from various foreign investors, Sztandar Mlodych reported Jan. 8. The newspaper said that workers had taken down a portrait of Mrs. Johnson, replacing it with one of the pope in the showcase at the main Gate 2 entrance to the shipyard.
