DOC.HEAD: Southmark Offers Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp., once a high-flying real estate company built with junk bonds, would be left with only a weak Texas thrift controlled by creditors under a reorganization plan filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court. The plan filed Wednesday envisions selling off all Southmark assets except San Jacinto Savings and Loan, paying off most secured creditors and giving junk bond holders pennies on the dollar. When Southmark filed for protection from its creditors in July, it had assets of $9.1 billion. Since then, losses, revaluations and asset sales have left it with $5 billion, most of which is tied up in San Jacinto, Texas's ninth largest thrift. Officials said San Jacinto, based in Bellaire, is losing an average of $10 million a month. Under the plan, which must be approved by creditors and the bankruptcy court, Southmark would inject $100 million into San Jacinto, bringing it into compliance with some, but not all, government regulations. All other assets _ insurance, oil and nursing home companies, interest in casinos in Atlantic City and San Juan, numerous real estate partnerships _ would be sold. Southmark acquired the assets mainly through financing provided by high-risk, high-yield junk bonds sold by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The high-cost debt, together with the collapse of the Southwest real estate market, led to Southmark's demise, said William G. Forster, a managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. who has advised Southmark since it filed for bankruptcy. Southmark Chairman Arthur G. Weiss, hired a year ago, said the speedy liquidation was the only way to leave even a small amount of money for creditors, who also will retain ownership in a reorganized Southmark under a new management and board of directors they will select. ``The object was to take the assets that are here and to preserve the pie,'' Weiss told reporters Wednesday. He estimated the bankruptcy was costing Southmark and the creditors about $3 million a month in legal and administrative fees. In addition, federal claims against San Jacinto, estimated to be potentially $2 billion, would have wiped out any assets otherwise available to debtholders, he said. ``We've got slices of the pie that have to be divided up,'' Forster said. ``But the basic theory is that if we don't pull the pie out of the oven, it will burn to a crisp.'' Under the plan, holders of about $600 million in Southmark junk bonds would get the first $200 million from sales of assets. Anything above that would go to other debtholders, but Forster estimated that they would receive less than 10 cents for every dollar owed. Southmark officials admit creditors may initially balk because of the low payback, but Weiss said, ``We think that we have put forward a plan that ought to be appealing,'' and ``at the end of the day,'' creditors will vote to go along. The plan envisions emerging from bankruptcy by mid-1994 and foresees San Jacinto as a much smaller thrift engaged in more traditional savings and loan businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Starts End Year At Lowest Level Since 1982
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf from end, Starts rose, to include number of starts in West; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts, slowed by record cold weather over much of the nation last month, declined 8 percent in December and ended the year at the lowest level since the recession year of 1982, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said the December decline helped slow construction of new homes and apartments to 1.37 million units in 1989, compared to 1.49 million units the previous year, a 7.6 percent drop. The 1.37 million starts last year were the lowest since 1982 when 1.06 million units were built. Both the Federal National Mortgage Association and the National Association of Home Builders are forecasting about 1.37 million starts in 1990. Before the abnormally cold weather hit last month, the housing industry had been held back through much of this year by high interest rates, which have moderated recently. Starts dropped from a high of 1.68 million units last January to 1.26 million units in September before rebounding to 1.43 million units in October. Starts fell again in November, to 1.34 million units, pulled down by a 15.3 percent decline in multi-family projects. According to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.78 percent at the end of December after peaking over 11 percent last March. The department said new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.24 million units in December, down from a revised 1.34 million units in November. Construction of single-family homes in December fell 10 percent to an annual rate of 904,000 units after falling 2 percent in November. That was the lowest since 862,000 units were started in December 1982. Apartment construction declined 2.4 percent to an annual rate of 331,000 units, compared to a 15.3 percent decline in November. The Northeast posted the steepest decline, down 23.3 percent to 138,000 units. That was followed by a 10 percent drop in the South to 439,000 units and a 9.8 percent decline in the Midwest to 268,000 units. Starts rose only in the West, where they gained 3.4 percent to 39,000. Applications for building permits, a barometer of future housing activity, bore potentially bad news for the New Year. They were down 0.4 percent from the previous month. During all of 1989, 1.34 million permits were issued, the lowest amount since 1 million in 1982.

The stock market declined broadly today, extending its early-1990 slide amid uneasiness over weak corporate earnings and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.37 points to 2,646.76 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 194 up, 862 down and 388 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 25.82 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the market was unsettled by a series of adverse corporate earnings reports over the past couple of days. The latest came this morning when Digital Equipment posted earnings for its fiscal quarter ended Dec. 30 of $1.25 a share, against $2.20 a share in the like period a year earlier. Digital's shares tumbled 5] to 82{ after a delayed opening. Selling continued, meanwhile in Aluminum Co. of America, down ~ at 66, and International Business Machines, down } at 98[, after the two companies reported lower quarterly profits on Wednesday. At the same time, brokers said fears of a developing recession were intensified by recent upward pressure on interest rates in this country and in other leading industrialized countries. Rising rates in Japan, Germany and England are seen as a deterrant to any move soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Fed policymakers are believed to be concerned that lower rates in the United States would prompt a flow of money out of American credit markets into foreign securities with increasingly attractive yields. That perception has helped push U.S. interest rates higher in the past several days. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.09 to 185.77. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.96 at 366.10. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.49 to 2,659.13, its lowest close since it stood at 2,656.78 on Nov. 22. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 7 to 5 on the NYSE, with 633 up, 867 down and 464 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 170.47 million shares, against 186.07 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Times Publishes Material from Ernst & Young Confidential Document
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times today published information from secret Ernst & Young documents detailing partner profits at the accounting giant, which won a court order preventing their publication in a newsletter last week. The Times said the material showed partners at Ernst & Whinney will take home roughly 65 percent of all profits they earn jointly with Arthur Young for the next three years, while Arthur Young's partners will share the rest. The firms merged last year, creating one of the largest accounting agencies in the world. The merged company has sought to squelch the release of the secret information, contending it was an invasion of privacy. The Times account said the confidential documents showed Ernst & Whinney was by far the stronger of the two firms and its partners historically out-earned their peers at Arthur Young. Senior Ernst & Young officials did not return telephone calls to The Associated Press this morning for comment on the Times story. A secretary at the company's New York headquarters said they were in a meeting. The Times didn't explain how it got a copy of the documents, which also were leaked to Bowman's Accounting Report and Accounting Today, two trade publications. Ernst & Young won a court order Jan. 8 stopping publication of the documents by Bowman's and has asked Accounting Today to return them. A hearing on the court order against Bowman's by New York Supreme Court Judge Beatrice Shainswit was scheduled for this morning. Editor Robert Crane of Accounting Today, a twice-monthly newsletter based in New York, said Wednesday that it planned to publish the material in its Feb. 5 edition, mailed to subscribers Jan. 30. Crane said he did not believe the content to be very significant outside of the accounting profession. Crane said he believed Ernst & Young was reacting more to what it felt was a violation of its internal affairs. ``You have to keep in mind that accountants take confidentiality very seriously,'' Crane said. ``In this instance, one of their own leaked proprietary information.'' The court order won by Ernst & Toung has attracted enormous attention from news organizations, which claim it violated the constitutional guarantee of press freedom. The Associated Press, New York Times, Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Wall Street Journal and other media groups have joined Bowman's in charging that the order was unconstitutional.

DOC.HEAD: Nisshin Steel Chairman Abe Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Nisshin Steel Co. Chairman Yuzuru Abe, who led Japanese steelmakers in investing in the United States, has died, the company said Thursday. He was 73. Nisshin said Abe died Sunday at his home in Tokyo of liver disease. Abe, a native of Tokushima in southwestern Japan, joined Nihon Seitetsu, then Japan's leading steelmaker, in 1938 after graduating from Tokyo University. In 1970, he became an executive director of Nippon Steel Corp., which became the nation's largest steelmaker when it was formed in a merger between Yahata Seitetsu and Fuji Seitesu. Abe became an executive vice president of Nippon Steel in 1977. He moved to Nisshin Steel in 1980 as president and had been chairman of the company since 1985. Under Abe's leadership, Nisshin Steel became the first of Japan's leading steelmakers to enter a joint venture in the United States. In 1984, Nisshin joined with Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp., the eighth-largest U.S. steelmaker, to produce and sell aluminum and galvanized steel sheets in the United States. The Japanese government decorated Abe with the Order of the Rising Sun for his contribution to the development of the nation's steel industry.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Quarterly Earnings Decline 44 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp., citing a slow U.S. computer market, Thursday reported a 44 percent drop in second quarter earnings, but the company said investments in new technology should help boost future sales. Digital, the world's second-largest computer company, said earnings totaled $155.4 million, or $1.25 per share, for the fiscal quarter that Dec. 30. That compared with earnings of $279.6 million, or $2.20 per share, for the year-ago period. Operating revenues for the second quarter were relatively flat at $3.18 billion, less than a 1 percent increase from the second quarter of the previous fiscal year. ``Depressed earnings come as no surprise,'' said Terry Shannon, an analyst with Framingham, Mass.-based International Data Corp., computer market researcher. But while he said the magnitude of the drop was surprising, Digital should rebound in the next 12 months once customers become more acquainted with products the company has introduced within the last year. Digital's announcement followed similar news Wednesday by industry leader International Business Machines Corp., which reported a 75 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings and 35 percent drop the year. ``It appears that the overall market for computers in Europe and Japan is good, but in the U.S. the market is still slow,'' Kenneth Olsen, president of Maynard-based Digital, said in a statement. ``Uncertain economic conditions are affecting customer purchasing intentions and slowing down the computer industry,'' he said. ``Consequently, we expect continued pressure on operating results.'' Digital, plagued by slumping sales, saw earnings decline 22 percent for the fiscal year ended July 1, 1989. The company last year froze salaries and transferred hundreds of employees from manufacturing to sales jobs. Olsen said Digital has invested heavily in products that will allow customers to work on a variety of computers. ``This means major investments, and in the first six months of this fiscal year alone we have invested $796 million on research and development,'' he said. ``But it is, we believe, the cost of success in this industry.'' For the six-month period, Digital reported net income of $306.2 million, or $2.44 a share, down 39 percent from $502.9 million, or $3.90 a share in the year-ago period. Operating revenues were $6.3 billion, up 3 percent from $6.1 billion the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: White House Asks Fed for Lower Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The White House, breaking with its usual no-comment stance on activities of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that ``lower interest rates are justified.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said recent economic reports show that the economy could benefit from an easier monetary policy. ``We had a recent drop in the prime (rate). That hasn't been totally passed through. But we nevertheless remain hopeful that it will be,'' Fitzwater told reporters. Major banks lowered the prime interest rate on Jan. 8 to 10 percent, down from 10.5 percent. The independent Federal Reserve, however, has not lowered its bellwether discount rate, the rate it charges to other banks, for nearly a year. It stands at 7 percent. Asked whether sending a message to the central bank from the White House briefing room ran counter to the administration's general policy of not commenting on matters before the Fed, Fitzwater said: ``This is not a new message. But it's important occasionally to point out that lower interest rates are normally good for the economy.'' Fitzwater, in particular, said today's report by the Commerce Department that housing starts fell by 8 percent in December was ``not good news'' and was ``well below market expectations.'' ``Housing starts are more responsive to interest rate than anything else,'' he said. He said that, when Bush addresses the National Association of Homebuilders in Atlanta on Friday, he will tell his audience that ``interest rates are going down.'' Fitzwater was asked about a story in today's edition of The Wall Street Journal quoting two Fed members, Vice Chairman Manuel Johnson and Wayne Angell, as indicating that lower interest rates were not likely in the near future. ``We're hopeful that they will take a look at this morning's indicators and understand that these numbers are low and indicate that inflation has remained very steady over the last seven or eight years and that lower interest rates are justified,'' the spokesman said. In addition to the weak housing starts report, Fitzwater cited the Labor Department report that showed inflation had grown a moderate 0.4 percent in December, and had increased by 4.6 percent for all of 1989, the highest annual increase since 1981. Asked whether Bush had spoken to Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan recently on the subject of interest rates, Fitzwater said: ``They speak so often, I'm not sure that's relevant.''

DOC.HEAD: Bear Stearns Earnings Tumble 54 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Bear Stearns Cos. Inc. said Thursday its second-quarter earnings tumbled 54 percent because of the continuing turbulence on Wall Street. The investment firm said it earned $29.1 million, or 29 cents a share, down from $63.3 million, or 63 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Bear Stearns reported second-quarter revenue of $578 million, down 9 percent from $632.6 million. The company attributed the downturn to unfavorable conditions in the financial markets, including a lack of risk arbitrage opportunities and a drop in mergers and acquisitions. The last three months of 1989 saw heightened uncertainty among investors and volatility in the financial markets _ including Wall Street's plunge on Oct. 13, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points. Bear Stearns said the results also reflected an increase in its common stock dividend. For the first half of its fiscal year, Bear Stearns said it earned $51.2 million, or 51 cents per share, down 39 percent from $83.8 million, or 82 cents per share, a year earlier. First-half revenue totaled $1.16 billion, up 5 percent from $1.11 billion the previous year.

Stock prices showed another broad loss today, extending their early-1990 slide amid uneasiness over weak corporate earnings and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 33.49 on Wednesday, dropped 2.77 points to 2,656.36 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 397 up, 821 down and 506 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 60.17 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said the market was unsettled by a series of adverse corporate earnings reports over the past couple of days. The latest came this morning when Digital Equipment posted earnings for its fiscal quarter ended Dec. 30 of $1.25 a share, against $2.20 a share in the like period a year earlier. Digital's shares tumbled 5| to 82\ after a delayed opening. Selling continued, meanwhile in Aluminum Co. of America, down ] at 66{, and International Business Machines, down ] at 98{, after the two companies reported lower quarterly profits on Wednesday. At the same time, brokers said fears of a developing recession were intensified by recent upward pressure on interest rates in this country and in other leading industrialized countries. Rising rates in Japan, Germany and England are seen as a deterrant to any move soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Fed policymakers are believed to be concerned that lower rates in the United States would prompt a flow of money out of American credit markets into foreign securities with increasingly attractive yields. That perception has helped push U.S. interest rates higher in the past several days. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .45 to 186.41. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.22 at 366.84.

DOC.NOTE: $adv22
For release Monday Jan. 22
DOC.HEAD: `Wonder Horse' Gallops into the 1990s
DOC.TEXT: Hobbyhorses date back to ancient Greece but remain a favorite toy for space-age tots. Ask Chuck Sakolsky, who was in charge of making and selling nearly $5.5 million worth last year. ``The funny thing is that even though it is a rocket-ship world, kids' interest in horses has never gone away. The hobbyhorse is as basic to the toy business as anything there is,'' said Sakolsky, general manager of the Wonder Products Inc. factory in northwest Louisiana's Bossier City, near Shreveport. The Wonder horse _ a heavy-duty plastic horse molded in mid-gallop and held up by strong steel springs _ is a 20th century descendant of the hobbyhorse, a stick with a horse's head at one end. Toy historians have traced hobbyhorses to the time of Socrates and to illustrations in a French book of Hours in the 15th Century. No references to rocking horses are known before the 17th century, but whenever they were invented, they had become immensely popular by the 1800s. Wonder introduced the spring-mounted horse in 1939, Sakolsky said, and bouncing horses had all but eliminated American-made molded rocking horses from toy departments by the middle 1970s. ``Mostly what's out there are flat pieces of wood put together to look like a horse,'' he said, adding that most of today's molded horses on rockers are imported and are either expensive or cheap. The Wonder company plans to reintroduce its rocking horse this year, capitalizing on growing nostalgia among parents and older people. Like the rocking horse, Wonder is coming back from almost nothing. The company was founded in Memphis; the move to Bossier City came after it had been sold twice. CBS Inc., the broadcasting and entertainment concern that owned a Louisiana swingset company called Gym Dandy, put the two together. ``CBS got out of the toy business a couple years back.... They sold the company to some of its managers. They really didn't have the wherewithal to keep it going,'' he said. Basic or not, the company went under. Rotocast Plastic Products Inc. of Miami bought it for $2.5 million last year at a sheriff's sale and brought in Sakolsky to run it. ``We've doubled our business since 1987 and we'll double it again in 1990,'' he said. Sakolsky estimated that Wonder sold about $3 million worth of toys in 1988, $5.5 million in 1989 and will probably sell nearly $10 million worth in 1990. He declined to give the number of toys sold but said the company has relationships with retailers ranging from large toy chains to small shops. ``At one time, we had close to 70 percent of the market,'' he said. ``In 1988, I think we had around 30 percent. I believe we'll have 50 percent of the market by 1990.'' The company's mainstay remains the spring-mounted horse, which retails anywhere from $40 _ for a 28-inch model suitable for a 2-or 3-year-old _ to more than $100. ``We have palominos, roans, pintos ... we're coming out with a dapple gray,'' he said. Sakolsky also has gone back through 40 years of catalogs to find products worth bringing back, and has created a couple of his own. Last year the company introduced a horse of a brighter color _ a hand-painted replica of a 1914 carousel horse, painted in vivid merry-go-round hues, priced at $150. The same horse, mounted on a brass pole and sold as furniture, retails for up to $500. ``It is the Rolls Royce of the ride-on horses,'' said Sakolsky. ``I sort of think of these as grandmother horses, because it's the sort of thing a grandmother looks at and says, `Gee _ that's what my grandchild has to have.'''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday Jan. 22

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Prices Up 0.4 Percent in December, 4.6 Percent in 1989
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 9 grafs new with market reaction, Fed-White House interest rate dispute, real earnings report; picks up at pvs 6th graf, Food prices; minor editing; also moved general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer prices rose a moderate 0.4 percent in December, despite a cold-weather jump in fuel oil costs, bringing inflation for 1989 to an eight-year high of 4.6 percent, the government said today. The rise in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index marked a modest acceleration over the 4.4 percent rates posted in 1988 and 1987. Still, it was the steepest increase since 1981, when prices shot up 8.9 percent in a lingering aftershock from the double-digit inflation of 1979 and 1980. The seasonally adjusted increase in December was a bit lower than many analysts predicted, but financial markets declined anyway. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 2.77 points in the first 90 minutes of trading to 2,656.36. Traders cited concern over lackluster corporate earnings and rising interest rates. Worry over higher rates was fueled by comments from two Federal Reserve Board members, who were quoted in The Wall Street Journal today. Their remarks are being interpreted as suggesting the central bank won't reduce short-term interest rates, at least for now. Countering that, the Bush administration broke with its usual no-comment stance on Fed policy. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said ``lower rates are justified'' and expressed concern over a sharp decline in housing starts last month. The Commerce Department said housing starts dropped 8 percent in December as the cold weather slowed construction and ended down 7.6 percent for the year, the lowest level since the recession year of 1982. It said 1.37 million units of new homes and apartments were started last year, compared with 1.49 million units in 1988. Most analysts predicted starts would rebound in January. Meanwhile, the Labor Department said in another report that Americans' inflation-adjusted earnings were unchanged in December after falling 0.6 percent in November. Average weekly earnings were $340.81 in December, up 3.2 percent from a year earlier _ not enough to keep up with inflation. Food prices jumped 5.6 percent in 1989, their steepest rise in nine years, beating the drought-induced increase of 5.2 percent in 1988. For December, food costs were up 0.4 percent, the same as November. Many analysts had expected the unseasonably cold weather near the end of the month to drive up fruit and vegetable prices. However, those prices actually fell 1.3 percent. The full force of the freeze, which dipped as far south as Florida and Texas, likely will show up in January prices. Dairy products rose a sharp 2.2 percent in December, bringing the increase for the year to 10.3 percent. Economists say dairy prices in 1989 were still reacting to increased slaughtering of herds during the previous summer's drought. The price of meat, poultry fish and eggs jumped 1.0 percent in December. Much of that was attributed to a 3.7 percent advance in egg prices, which climbed 35.4 for the year. Energy prices gained 5.1 percent last year, driven up by a 19.5 percent rise in fuel oil prices. Fuel oil increased 3.8 percent in December and a congressional committee is investigating allegations that oil companies used the cold weather as an excuse to grab profits. Gasoline prices, which soared early in the year, fell in six of the last seven months of 1989, including a 2.0 percent drop in December. For the year, they were up 6.5 percent. Natural gas prices increased 2.1 percent last month, while electricity rose 0.8 percent. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors rose 0.4 percent in December and 4.4 percent for the year, a drop from 4.7 percent in 1988. Analysts often look to this figure as a better indicator of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy. They attribute the slowing in 1989 to economic sluggishness induced by the Federal Rserve Board, which fought inflation in the first half of the year by boosting interest rates. Most economists are expecting a modest improvement in overall inflation this year but some warn that inflation will be stubborn, largely because the low unemployment rate is keeping wages rising. The cost of services, the catagory most heavily influenced by wages, rose 0.4 percent in December and 5.1 percent for the year. In other details: _New car prices jumped 1.0 percent in December, but for the year were up only 2.3 percent, held back by repeated discounting as dealers faced sluggish sales. _The cost of medical care rose 0.5 percent last month and 8.5 percent for the year. Medical care costs have consistently risen faster than the general inflation rate. _Clothing costs fell 0.7 percent in December, the result of pre-Christmas reductions. For the year, they rose only 1.0 percent. Analysts say the relatively strong dollar has held down the price of clothing imports. Before taking into account normal seasonal changes, the Consumer Price Index stood at 126.1 percent in December. That meant a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $126.10 last month, up from $120.50 a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Rumors Lift Soybean Futures; Grains Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices opened slightly higher today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk of Soviet buying interest. Wheat and corn futures were narrowly mixed. Traders said exporters reported indications that the Soviets bought about 150,000 metric tons of U.S. soybeans in recent days. But others said the early rally was technically inspired after four days of lower prices. The dull opening in the wheat and corn markets reflected a lack of significant new supply-and-demand developments. Traders discounted a rumor that China had bought 200,000 metric tons of U.S. corn. The Soviet Union was said to be bidding for 500,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices, but that business has been largely factored into the market already. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.01\ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to { cent higher with March at $2.42 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2 cents lower with March at $1.37{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 1{ cents higher with January at $5.58{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .08 cent to .33 cent higher with February at 78.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .30 cent higher with January at 83.77 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .43 cent higher with February at 50.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .40 cent to .90 cent higher with February at 57.05 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures made strong gains on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Proposes Discounts To Make Up For Outage
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. today proposed to offer its residential, business and international customers special Valentine's Day discounts on long-distance calls to try to make amends for the near collapse of its network earlier this week. In a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, the company said it was seeking approval to declare Feb. 14 as an additional day of holiday calling. AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen said: ``We are making this gesture to underscore how much we value our relationship with our customers, knowing there is no way to make up for the inconvenience they may have experienced.'' AT&T's special holiday prices, discounted by an average 33 percent from regular weekday prices, will apply on all out-of-state, direct-dialed calls made by customers on AT&T's public network. In addition, AT&T said price discounts also would apply for customers of its 800 services. AT&T suffered a nine-hour outage to long-distance service nationwide on Monday that was traced to a bug in a new software program. Allen on Tuesday said he believed the outage in a call-switching network was a ``one-time hit'' against a network that serves 80 million long-distance customers. AT&T handles about 70 percent of the nation's interstate calling. Until the problem was contained, more than half of the calls placed on AT&T's nationwide network did not go through, the company said. The company had said that billings would be adjusted to reflect the outage, but details were not given in today's statement. AT&T said said the problem stemmed from a bug, or ``logic'' problem, inadvertently written into the software in a New York computer that helps direct calls through the vast network. The problem spread to more than 100 switching centers. Allen said he could not estimate losses to AT&T or its customers. AT&T has insurance to cover customers' losses stemming from the trouble with its 800-number toll-free service but does not have coverage for business customers using regular long-distance circuits. Some analysts said the disruption could be a boon to AT&T's rivals.

DOC.HEAD: National Australia Bank To Buy Yorkshire Bank
DOC.TEXT: Yorkshire Bank PLC shareholders announced Thursday they agreed to sell the regional bank to National Australia Bank for the equivalent of $1.65 billion. Under terms of the deal, which must be approved by British regulators, National Australia Bank, one of Australia's big four commercial banks, will pay $1.6 billion in cash plus interest. Yorkshire Bank is owned by National Westminster Bank PLC, which has a 40 percent stake; Barclays PLC, with 32 percent; Lloyds Bank PLC, with 20 percent; and the Royal Bank of Scotland PLC, with 8 percent. The banks, which put the Yorkshire bank up for sale in October, said the proceeds would be used to strengthen their individual reserves. Natwest Chairman Lord Alexander said shareholders decided to sell Yorkshire because it was now fully competitive, and the price represented a good return on their investment. National Australia Bank, which bought Clydesdale Bank, Northern Bank and National Irish Bank in 1987, said it intends to preserve Yorkshire's separate identity and build on the existing management team. National Australia Bank Chairman Sir Rupert Clarke said he believes in a hands-off approach to its subsidiaries and would allow Yorkshire a good deal of independence to develop. Yorkshire, market leader in the number of personal accounts in its northeast region, operates 250 branches. It had after-tax profit of $117 million in 1989, up from $104 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: World Steel Output Rises to Record Height in 1989
DOC.TEXT: World crude steel output rose to a record of 783.5 million metric tons in 1989, up 0.5 percent from 1988, the International Iron and Steel Institute said Thursday. The rise was led by developing countries, which increased output by 3.7 percent to a record 100.9 million tons, from 97.3 million tons in 1988, the institute said. In the Western nations, production stood at 495.9 million tons in 1989, up 1.4 percent from 488.9 million tons in 1988, the survey of 33 steel producing countries showed. Japanese steel producers lifted output by 2.1 percent in 1989 to 107.9 million tons, from 105.7 million tons a year earlier, while the 12-nation European Community increased production 1.5 percent to 139.8 million tons, from 137.7 million tons. Steel production in other countries showed small decreases, the institute said. In the Soviet Union and other East bloc nations, steel output dipped 2.4 percent to 219.5 million tons, from 224.8 million tons in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Morris Testifies He Wanted To Produce Controllable Computer `Worm'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The student charged with creating a ``worm'' that crippled about 6,000 computers testified today that he intended to make it controllable but it grew to be unstoppable in the time it took him to go out to dinner. Under questioning from his defense attorney in federal court, Robert Morris said he thought the computer worm would duplicate a few times a day or every few hours. Instead, the worm spread ``far faster than I expected,'' he said. ``My intention was that it should not grow,'' Morris said. ``Once I released it ... I couldn't control it.'' The Cornell University graduate student said he released the worm into the Internet computer network about 8 p.m. on Dec. 2, 1988, then went out for dinner. When he returned about three hours later, he said, he noticed Cornell's own computer was slow to respond to commands. Morris testified that he released the worm into the national network through computers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass. In computer terminology, a worm is a variant of so-called ``virus'' programs that can cause damage when they duplicate in computers. Morris said that when he found copies of the worm in the Cornell system in Ithaca, N.Y., where he was working from, he knew it was spreading and he realized it wasn't working right. He said he started to get scared. Morris said he considered sending out a second worm designed to track down and destroy the first worm. But he decided it wouldn't work because of the unpredictable nature of the first worm and the way it curtailed his own access to the computer system. Instead, he said he called Andrew Sudduth, a friend at Harvard University, and asked him to send a message on an electronic bulletin board read primarily by Internet users apologizing for unleashing the worm and explaining how to eliminate it. Sudduth testified at Morris' trial Wednesday that he eventually did send a warning message, but that it didn't show up on the computer system for two days because the route he picked to keep his identity a secret was backed up with electronic mail. Defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni has argued that Morris had no criminal intent in designing the worm because he never realized it would cripple the computer network. If convicted, Morris, 25, of Arnold, Md., faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. A government witness testifying Wednesday, Harvard graduate student Paul Graham, said Morris frantically called him for help. ``He sounded like he had a final the next day that he hadn't studied for. He sounded miserable. He sounded in a state of shock and horror,'' Graham told the jury. Morris stressed in testimony today that he had no intention to read anyone else's private computer files, or cause damage or leave any permanent files on the computers that were attacked.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Only version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 137,002 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 79,623, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 246,728 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 86,498 cars this week, compared with 49,234 a week ago and 153,472 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 50,504, compared with last week's 30,389 and last year's 93,256. Canadian automakers were to build 13,080 cars this week, up from 9,327 a week ago but down from last year's 19,811. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 14,494, compared with 12,753 a week ago and 21,741 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Texaco Posts Lower Fourth-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Texaco Inc.'s profit slipped in the fourth quarter due mainly to a $355 million charge for environmental improvement programs, while annual earnings nearly doubled, the oil company reported Thursday. For the three-month period ended Dec. 31, Texaco's after-tax earnings were $287 million, or 99 cents a share, down 3 percent from $296 million, or $1.21 a share in the comparable 1988 period. Revenue rose 9 percent to $9.2 billion from $8.5 billion. Texaco, the nation's third largest petroleum company behind Exxon Corp. and Mobil Corp., said it established financial reserves totaling $355 million for environmental improvement programs planned at its manufacturing, marketing and production facilities. ``The company is committed to its role in safeguarding and maintaining the environment in which it operates,'' said James W. Kinnear, president and chief executive officer of the White Plains, N.Y.-based company. Texaco officials would not elaborate on the company's decision to set aside the reserves. It comes nearly a year after Exxon's image was tarnished by the nation's worst oil spill in Alaska last March. More recently, Exxon has come under scrutiny for an underwater oil pipeline leak that fouled a New York City waterway. Exxon originally blamed the mishap on a faulty leak-detection alarm. Texaco said fourth-quarter earnings also reflected the devaluation of an investment in an offshore California oil production facility. For all of 1989, Texaco's earnings soared 85 percent to $2.4 billion or $9.12 a share, from $1.3 billion or $5.35 a share the previous year. Revenue edged up about 2 percent to $35.7 billion from $35 billion. Included in the yearly figures was a net restructuring gain of $1.6 billion, or $6.02 a share, mainly from the sale of its lucrative Texaco Canada Inc. subsidiary to Exxon's Imperial Oil Ltd. of Canada for about $3.24 billion. Texaco said the latest results showed gains in exploration and production earnings. Earnings from downstream, or marketing and refining, businesses suffered due to rising crude oil costs, while its petrochemicals earnings also declined, Texaco said.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Cuts Managers' Merit Raises
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines has frozen merit raises for its managers in the latest of a series of employee cutbacks. Continental managers said they were told last week not to expect the merit raises normally available every six months until later this year. ``Merit increases are being postponed until sometime in the fall,'' Continental spokesman Art Kent said Wednesday. A week ago, Houston-based Continental laid off about 150 employees nationwide, mostly middle-level managers. But company officials said the group represented a small fraction of its 35,000 workers, some 11,000 of which are in Houston. Kent said managers were told about the raises when they met in Houston last week to discuss the airline's performance. ``Every so often during the year we bring all the management people into Houston,'' Kent said. ``We brought everybody up to date on 1989, what our plans were for 1990.'' Continental, reacting to skyrocketing jet fuel costs in recent weeks, led an industrywide effort to increase fares by 4 percent to help offset the costs. Jet fuel prices rose from a low of 49.4 cents a gallon in November 1988 to 65.9 cents in November 1989. In December, prices hit $1.10 a gallon and many airlines this week were still paying more than 90 cents a gallon. At the same time, Continental launched new fares _ some as low as $9 one way _ to help boost weak winter passenger traffic in 11 cities in Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana. Continental's sister carrier, Eastern Airlines, has been restructured as a smaller airline in the wake of a crippling strike that started last March 4. Eastern has about 20,000 employees, mostly non-union replacement workers, down from 32,000 before the strike. Continental and Eastern are the main subsidiaries of Houston-based Texas Air Corp., the nation's largest airline company.

DOC.HEAD: Pillsbury Announces Investment Program Resulting in Job Eliminations
DOC.TEXT: Pillsbury Inc. said Thursday it plans to reorganize and consolidate several product lines, resulting in the closing of some plants and the elimination of up to 1,300 jobs. The company, a subsidiary of Britain's Grand Metropolitan PLC, said the $140 million plan would finance expansion and modernization of some plants and distribution centers in a strategy to strengthen positions of its bakery products, Green Giant and frozen pizza businesss. Pillsbury plans to close its Fridley, Minn., plant sometime after mid-summer and transfer the manufacturing operation to its Wellston, Ohio, facility. In addition, a coupon redemption processing operation in Golden Valley will be transferred to an outside company. Most of the expected 1,300 job eliminations will take place in 1991. However, about 800 new jobs will be created during the next 18 months of the investment program's implementation, the company said. Among other key changes: _Grocery product lines in its Springfield, Ill., plant, and dry grocery activities in Terre Haute, Ind., would be transferred to a facility in Murfreesboro, Tenn. _A distribution center in Chattanooga, Tenn., will be closed and the activity taken over by the Murfreesboro distribution center. _In the pizza and frozen vegetable division, the Wellston, Ohio, plant will be expanded and a 160,000-square-foot frozen distribution center will be created. Wellston also will receive new pizza capability for its Jeno's and Totino's brands, plus new vegetable processing lines for its Green Giant brands. Frozen distribution capability in Belvidere, Ill., also will be created. _Vegetable processing at the Watsonville, Calif., plant will shift to Wellston and other existing facilities over the next year. The long-term status of Watsonville is reviewed. Paul S. Walsh, Pillsbury's chief operating officer, said the investment program is ``a continuation of efforts to make Pillsbury even better equipped to compete successfully in the fast-changing global food industry. These actions will create a stronger company for the 1990s...'' Walsh said the plans were announced ``as early as possible to allow our employees to take full advantage of outplacement counseling, skills assessment, benefits counseling and educational workshops.'' He said the programs would be included in extensive job transition assistance available at all affected locations.

DOC.HEAD: Lufthansa Orders Engines, No Jet Orders Planned
DOC.TEXT: Lufthansa German Airlines said Thursday it is buying enough General Electric engines to power up to 56 planes, but is not ready to announce any aircraft purchases. Spokeswoman Lucille Hoshabjian in New York said the airline may convert options for 15 Boeing Co. planes to firm orders but has no announcement planned. Reports on Wednesday had indicated the airline would order as many as 41 747-400s from Boeing. The airline has an outstanding firm order for 15 747-400s, five of which have been delivered. The 747-400 is the world's largest passenger jet, with advanced technology that a crew of two instead of the three required for comparable aircraft. It carries up to 509 passengers depending on its configuration.

DOC.HEAD: Top Regulators Agree on Emergency Comunications Steps
With AM-Japan-Market Rumors Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The top securities regulators of the United States and Japan agreed Thursday to take steps to ensure instant communications during sudden market plunges. Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Japanese Finance Ministry's Securities Bureau said they had designated facsimile lines and bilingual contact people for emergency communications in times of turmoil. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard Breeden also requested greater access to information on insider trading, which his Japanese counterpart, Masahiko Kadotani, promised to consider. Breeden said a 700 percent growth in Japanese participation in the U.S. securities market and a 500 percent increase in U.S. trading in Japanese equities since 1985 required greater cooperation on investor protection. ``Just as capital flows across borders, so does fraud,'' Breeden said. Kadotani said he requested information about computerized program trading from the U.S. delegation because the method of trading stocks and stock-index futures simultaneously is new in Japan. Program trading, in which millions of shares can be traded rapid-fire, has been blamed for accelerating sudden swings in the market. Breeden said his data showed program trading made up 30 percent of market volume at times during a 190-point plunge on the New York Stock Exchange last Oct. 13. Asked whether program trading was responsible for recent sharp declines in the Tokyo market, Kadotani said its role was not significant but could become so in the future. At the fourth annual meeting between the sides, the countries' top financial regulators also nudged each other to open each other's markets. ``Among our objectives is moving toward a system where securities offerings can occur simultaneously in the U.S. and Japan,'' Breeden said. But he admitted this would not occur soon and added, ``It is an objective that will enhance the efficiency of capital flows around the world.'' Kadotani, director general of the Japan's Securities Bureau, said he had requested that Japanese firms be allowed to operate investment trusts, such as mutual funds, in the United States. Breeden said the SEC had recommended introducing such legislation in 1984, but that Congress had not passed it. But in a climate in the United States demanding more access to Japanese markets, he said, ``congressional willingness to pass such legislation will be affected by progress in Japan'' on allowing similar foreign activity.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Finish Sharply Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: updates thruout with close, details, no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished a volatile session sharply lower Thursday as nervousness over the outlook for global markets continued to undermine trading.' Early weakness on Wall Street sent investors running for cover, abandoning equity positions, dealers said. At the London session drew to a close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off more than 23 points following a 33-point decline Wednesday. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index ended the session down 37.0 points, or 1.6 percent, at 2,336.9. In the last two weeks, the index has lost roughly 150 points, confounding market watchers who had generally predicted a sharp January rally. ``It's been very volatile but volume is poor which tends to exaggerate things all the more,'' a dealer said. Market watchers said investors were jittery over declines in world bond markets and rising concern about interest rates. In addition, instability in the Soviet Union, domestic worries over wage inflation and upcoming strikes also soured any interest in equities, dealers said. The Financial Times 30-share index lost 30.9 points to close at 1,864.4. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 18.99 points to 1,275.64 at the close. Volume was a modest 450.2 million shares, compared with 429 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Starts Slump in 1989 to Lowest Level Since 1982 Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts slumped in 1989 to their lowest level since the 1982 recession, the government said Thursday, but many analysts looked for further drops in mortgage rates to improve the situation in 1990. ``The drop in December housing starts is primarily due to severe weather in most of the nation last month,'' said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. The frigid weather pushed December starts to their lowest monthly level since October 1982, which in turn contributed to the year's downturn. The Commerce Department said construction of new homes and apartments tumbled 8 percent in December and helped drop total 1989 starts to 1.37 million units _ the lowest since 1982's 1.06 million units. Starts totaled 1.49 million in 1988. The housing industry had been sluggish through much of the year as the Federal Reserve pushed up interest rates by keeping a tight rein on credit as it sought to slow the economy and curtail inflation. But as concerns grew that the economy might be slowing too much, the Fed allowed interest rates to fall gradually in recent months. Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, which looks for 1.45 million starts this year, said the forecast ``is predicated on our belief that rates are headed down.'' David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, also is counting on a ``moderate decline in interest rates in the first half of the year'' to sustain his organization's forecast for 1.38 million starts in 1990. On the other hand, David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, looks for interest rates to edge up for much of the year and for starts to edge down. Commerce said new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.24 million in December, down from a revised 1.34 million in November and 1.42 million in October. Construction of single-family homes plummeted 10 percent to an annual rate of 904,000 units after a 2 percent drop in November. That was the lowest since 862,000 units in December 1982 as the economy began emerging from the recession. But Fannie Mae's Berson said conditions were such that, if it had not been for the weather, single-family starts would have gone up. And if January's improved weather continues, he said starts might rebound and even steal some that otherwise would take place in February. Apartment construction fell 2.4 percent to an annual rate of 331,000 units, compared with a 15.3 percent decline in November, and analysts said overbuilding in recent years will keep this sector weak. The severe weather was widespread east of the Rockies, and starts in those regions posted the biggest declines. Starts were down 23.3 percent in the Northeast to 138,000 units, down 10 percent in the South to 439,000 units and down 9.8 percent in the Midwest to 268,000 units. Starts rose only in the West, where they gained 3.4 percent to 390,000 units. Applications for building permits, a barometer of future housing activity, edged down 0.4 percent in December. During all of 1989, 1.34 million permits were issued, the lowest number since 1 million in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Union Pacific Earnings Drop 11 Percent in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Union Pacific Corp. said Thursday fourth-quarter net earnings fell 11 percent from a year ago, when results included gains from the sale of refinery operations. The Bethlehem, Pa.-based company, whose assets include railroad, energy, trucking, waste management and real estate, said it earned $166.8 million, or $1.64 a share, down from $187.4 million, or $1.65 a share, in the comparable 1988 period. Revenue totaled $1.74 billion, up 10 percent from $1.6 billion. Union Pacific Railroad, the nation's third-largest in freight revenue, earned $143 million in the quarter, up $700,000 from a year earlier. The railroad operates in 19 states, primarily in the West and Southwest. For the year, Union Pacific's profit dropped 8 percent to $594.5 million, or $5.62 a share, on revenues of $6.5 billion. That compares with net income of $643.9 million, or $5.65 a share, on revenues of $6.1 billion in 1988. The railroad reported a record annual profit of $547.3 million, up 6 percent from $516.1 million in 1988, despite tough market conditions and a 20 percent increase in fuel costs. Carloadings increased 1 percent, including traffic added by the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad, commonly known as the Katy, which Union Pacific bought in 1988. Traffic was hampered by severe winter weather, slow auto sales, a sluggish grain market and a decline in housing starts. ``Our financial results for 1989 were very encouraging in light of the highly competitive marketplace,'' said Drew Lewis, chief executive officer. ``If the economy does not take a serious downturn and energy prices remain strong, we should have a solid earnings performance in 1990.'' Separately, Union Pacific told industry analysts Thursday it is exploring the possibility of a joint venture with its energy and minerals subsidiary, Union Pacific Resources Co., which had earnings of $51 million, up 18 percent after discounting the sale of the refineries. The company said in a statement it is also considering the sale of less than 20 percent of the subsidiaries' shares. Union Pacific Resources also announced it had made four offshore discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico that could produce up to 100 million cubic feet of natural gas per day.

Stock prices fell again today, extending their early-1990 slide amid uneasiness over weak corporate earnings and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 33.49 on Wednesday, dropped 14.29 points to 2,644.84 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 404 up, 1,048 down and 461 unchanged. Analysts said the market was unsettled by a series of adverse corporate earnings reports over the past couple of days. The latest came this morning when Digital Equipment posted earnings for its fiscal quarter ended Dec. 30 of $1.25 a share, against $2.20 a share in the like period a year earlier. Digital's shares tumbled 6[ to 81} after a delayed opening. Selling continued, meanwhile in Aluminum Co. of America, down 1\ at 65|, and International Business Machines, down \ at 98|, after the two companies reported lower quarterly profits on Wednesday. Alcan Aluminium, which also posted a quarterly earnings decline, dropped ] to 20~. At the same time, brokers said fears of a developing recession were intensified by recent upward pressure on interest rates in this country and in other leading industrialized countries. Rising rates in Japan, Germany and England are seen as a deterrant to any move soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Fed policymakers are believed to be concerned that lower rates in the United States would prompt a flow of money out of American credit markets into foreign securities with increasingly attractive yields. That perception has helped push U.S. interest rates higher in the past several days. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.04 to 185.82. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.36 at 365.70. Volume on the Big Board came to 133.80 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Drop Slightly In Last Quarter
DOC.TEXT: PPG Industries Inc., a producer of glass, coatings and chemicals, said Thursday its earnings dropped 0.8 percent in the final three months of 1989, partly because of weak construction activity. PPG said other reasons for the decline were the cost of product development and plant operation and reduced demand for fiber glass textile. For the fourth quarter, earnings totaled $101.4 million or 93 cents per share on sales of $1.4 billion. That compared with $102.3 million or 94 cents per share on sales of $1.4 billion in the same period a year earlier. PPG said its coatings business benefited during the quarter from strong automotive refinish activity. Reduced coatings sales to U.S. automakers were offset somewhat by increased sales to transplant automakers, the company said. Earnings for all of 1989 fell 0.5 percent to $465.2 million or $4.18 per share on sales of $5.7 billion, from $467.6 million or $4.26 per share on sales of $5.6 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Rumors Rankle `Red-Chip' Market
DOC.TEXT: In a stock market driven up partly by ``red chip'' shares, is it any surprise that rumors about Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev contribute to nervous moves in share prices? No, say watchers of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, where capitalists have been placing some of their gambles on the Communists. This turn of events, unthinkable a few years ago, has its own internal logic. Peace is good for business, especially in Japan, where the defense industry is a small sector of the economy. Gorbachev and President Bush made progress toward better relations at their Malta summit. Eastern European countries are opening their doors to outside business, and Japanese firms with possible deals in Poland, Hungary or the Soviet Union _ the ``red chip'' stocks _ could be winners. The Tokyo Stock Exchange rode these two trends in the East bloc to a record high at the end of 1989. But since then the key Nikkei stock index has been moving almost exclusively downward. Since the Soviet Union internal situation appears increasingly chaotic, doing business in the old East bloc may not be simple. If Gorbachev were to leave office for any reason or if he is forced to abandon plans for a more open economy, business prospects could dim. So rumors hinting at the Soviet leader's resignation or diminution of power tend to lower confidence, and recent rumors in part explain the market's downtick. If such events occur, investors may unload ``red chip'' shares in trading companies and firms dealing in consumer electronic goods and environmental equipment, thought most likely to be able to do well in Eastern Europe. ``Some market participants here are not so interested in fundamentals,'' such as the price of the dollar or movement of interest rates, said Jan VanDenBerg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch & Co. in Tokyo. Sales people, she said, ``have a tendency to couch something in terms of a rumor rather than in terms of a fundamental.'' On Jan. 5, the second day of trading this year, the Tokyo Nikkei 225-share index plunged 438 points, more than 1 percent, on rumors that Gorbachev had canceled all meetings with foreign visitors to deal with domestic problems. The Soviet president had put off a meeting with British Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock, but former Japanese Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe soon after announced a trip to Moscow to talk with Gorbachev. When the Tokyo exchange closed Wednesday, the Nikkei 225-share index was at 36,821.14, about 5 percent below the record quote of 38,915.87 at the end of 1989. Again, rumors that Gorbachev was on his way out were part of the reason, analysts said. ``Gorbachev will probably have to die a thousand times in such rumors this year,'' Yamaichi Securities analyst Kenji Maeshiro said. The ``peace dividend'' feeling that pulled the market up in December _ a belief that U.S.-Soviet tensions would be reduced by Eastern Europe's democracy movement _ was buttressed by a consensus that Japan's central bank would not raise interest rates until after a national election in February. But the bank confounded that consensus by raising the discount rate on Dec. 25, contributing to a loss of momentum. The dollar also has been strong against the yen, which could boost inflation in Japan, another confidence-cutter. Lately, though, rumors have been center stage, not a new phenomenon for stock exchanges. Several years ago, the London markets took shock dips over rumors that President Reagan had died. A broker at a foreign securities firm who asked not to be named said Wednesday's rumor about Gorbachev ``losing his power base'' probably came from ``a bored investor'' in the foreign exchange market. He said a Gorbachev resignation story last week started when someone misread a news item. The broker then passed on something that may or may not be as true as a Gorbachev rumor _ his guess that ``the market is now oversold and shouldn't go down any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Fall On Heavy Precip Forecast
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices closed at 3{-month lows Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade after tumbling late in the session on forecasts for heavy snow and rain in the heart of the U.S. winter wheat country. Oat futures also retreated while corn and soybeans advanced. The heavy precipitation predicted for Thursday night and Friday in the winter wheat fields of the Southern Plains would help relieve the unusally dry conditions that have prevailed there since late autumn. ``They are likely to get as much snow today, tonight and tomorrow as they usually get in January or February,'' said Katharina Zimmer, a grain-market analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. ``This is the biggest rain event since September,'' she said. The soybean market was supported by indications that the Soviet Union bought about 150,000 metric tons of U.S. soybeans in recent days. At the close, wheat futures were 1} cents to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.97{ a bushel, its lowest close since Sept. 28. Corn futures were \ cent to 1} cents higher with March at $2.42 a bushel; oats were { cent to 1} cents lower with March at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 3{ cents higher with January at $5.61 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: More Mixed Results from Leading Banks
DOC.TEXT: Five major U.S. banks reported mixed 1989 results Thursday, with problem Third World debt and a depressed real estate market plaguing some while others benefited from expansion and profitable financial operations. BankAmerica Corp. enjoyed the best year in its history, but precautions taken to cover potentially bad Third World debt put Chemical Banking Corp. in the red and pushed Bank of New York Co.'s earnings sharply lower for the year. Bank of Boston was adversely affected by a depressed real estate market in New England, but super-regional NCNB Corp. continued to plug away at developing new markets and reported a highly profitable year. San Francisco-based BankAmerica, the nation's second-largest bank holding concern behind New York's Citicorp, said earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31 totaled $270 million, or $1.21 per share, a slight increase from the $265 million, or $1.36 per share, from the year-ago period. Earnings for the full year soared 52 percent to $1.1 billion, or $5.19 a share, the highest annual profit in its history. In 1988 the bank earned $726 million, $3.79 per share. The performance marks a dramatic comeback for BankAmerica, parent of Bank of America, that included a nearly $1 billion loss in 1987. Chemical Banking Corp., the sixth-largest banking concern, said fourth-quarter earnings fell to $95.9 million or $1.04 a share, down 67 percent from $288.5 million or $4.66 a share in the final quarter of 1988. For the year ended Dec. 31, Chemical reported a net loss of $482.2 million, or the equivalent of $8.29 a share, compared with a profit of $753.6 million, or $12.02 a share in 1988. The loss resulted partly from a $600 million increase in Chemical's reserves for problem loans to less developed countries, which was taken in the third quarter. Chemical joined a long list of major U.S. banks that moved to bolster their reserves to cover possibly bad debt. No. 10-ranked Bank of New York Co., bolstered by its acquisition of Irving Trust Co., reported fourth-quarter earnings nearly doubled to $106.6 million, or $1.43 a share, from $54.7 million, or $1.10 a share in the final quarter of 1988. For the full year, however, a $600 million increase in Bank of New York's allowance for loan losses, which was recorded in the third quarter, pushed earnings down 76 percent, to $50.7 million, or 27 cents a share. In 1988 the bank reported earnings of $213 million, or $5.21 a share. No. 14-ranked Bank of Boston Corp. was hit by the depressed New England real estate market. The region's largest bank holding company said earnings plummeted 89 percent in the fourth quarter to $9 million, or 8 cents a share, from $83 million, or $1.13 a share in the final quarter of 1988. For the full year, earnings plunged 78 percent to $70 million, or 80 cents a share, from $322 million, or $4.43 a share a year earlier. Bank of Boston increased its reserves to cover bad real estate loans to $923 million, from $690 million a year earlier. The company said its portfolio of troubled U.S. commercial real estate assets had climbed to $1.1 billion as of Dec. 31, compared with $618 million the previous year. Many New England banks have been hurt by the real estate slump, as developers have had trouble making loan payments on projects that were approved during a building boom earlier in the 1980s. No. 16-ranked NCNB Corp., the fast-growing bank holding company based in Charlotte, N.C., reported fourth-quarter earnings catapulted 112 percent to $136.2 million, or $1.30 a share, from $64.3 million, or 69 cents a share in the period a year earlier. For the full year, NCNB said earnings rose 77 percent to $447.1 million, or $4.62 a share, compared with profits of $252.5 million, or $2.90 a share in 1988. Bank officials attributed the performance in part to the acquisition of NCNB Texas, which NCNB Chairman Hugh McColl noted was completed four years ahead of schedule.
