DOC.HEAD: Japanese Legislator Says He Wrote Book to Spur Debate
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese legislator who created a firestorm with a book attacking America said Thursday he is simply trying to spur a more honest debate between the world's two economic superpowers. Shintaro Ishihara's book, entitled ``The Japan That Can Say `No,''' is a runaway best seller in Japan, with 500,000 copies sold. While no authorized version exists in English, bootleg copies translated by the Defense Department are creating quite a stir in Washington. In the book, Ishihara argues that Japan needs to be more assertive in standing up to America in policy disputes. He boasts about Japan's technological superiority, calls America's military shield for Japan an illusion and complains that ``Americans behave more like mad dogs than watch dogs.'' He dismisses American criticism of Japan as racially motivated and suggests that unless America changes its tune, Tokyo might stop supplying the microchips the Pentagon needs for accurate targeting of U.S. nuclear missiles and sell them to the Soviets instead. Such a decision, Ishihara speculates in his book, ``would instantly change the balance of military power.'' In an interview Thursday, Ishihara did not recant any of his comments although he contended that the ``pirated'' version now in circulation in Washington leaves out certai clarifying comments. With Japan accounting for almost half of America's $111 billion annual trade deficit, efforts to stem the flow of Japanese imports and boost U.S. export sales are a prime topic on Capitol Hill. Ishihara's book is being cited by critics of Japan as a prime example of Japanese intransigence in dealing with trade problems. During an interview, Ishihara said that relations between the United States and Japan were in a transition phase in which Japan needed to play a more assertive role. ``We have come to a new era where a redefinition of the U.S.-Japan relationship is called for,'' he said, adding that he hoped his book would contribute to a franker discussion of the real issues between the two countries. Ishihara, a member of the Japanese parliament and one of the front-runners for prime minister last year, disputed contentions that his views were out of the mainstream, citing the popularity of his book as proof that many Japanese agree with his thoughts. Ishihara's book comes at a time when public opinion polls in both the United States and Japan reflect a growing uneasiness. Americans now rank Japan's economic prowess as a greater threat to the United States than the Soviet's military might while a majority of Japanese in a recent poll complained that the United States was unfairly pressuring Japan on trade issues. During his Washington visit, Ishihara, 57, a member of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's conservative Liberal-Democratic Party, was meeting with members of Congress and journalists, promoting the idea of debates between Japanese and American lawmakers. He said he hoped to return to the United States after the Japanese elections in February to hold the first of these debates. He also plans to bring out the authorized English version of his book in April, absent the portions in the Japanese version written by Sony Corp. Chairman Akio Morita. Morita, who wrote several less inflamatory chapters of the original book, has said he regretted his collaboration and is refusing to participate in the English-language edition. Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., was one of the lawmakers who met with Ishihara during his visit. After the session, Levin, whose district includes Detroit, said he was not optimistic that there will be any quick resolution to the trade problems separating the two countries. He called Ishihara's views ``a minority point of view'' but one which American policy-makers ``need to take seriously and respond to it.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Banking Regulators Closing on CenTrust
DOC.TEXT: About the only bright spot for troubled CenTrust Savings Bank in recent days has been the spotlights illuminating its 47-story downtown Miami tower. Just one day after announcing a $119 million fiscal year loss, Florida's biggest thrift on Wednesday abandoned a proposal to merge with Ensign Bank, a financially troubled institution led by cruise ship magnate Ted Arison. Now, CenTrust is left with unbalanced books, a $1 billion portfolio of high-risk junk bonds and the cost of operating 63 branches it hopes to sell to a California thrift. Some analysts speculated Thursday that federal regulators may be close to taking over the institution. ``It looks to me that the time is growing nigh for federal regulators to take over the show,'' said Henry Peltz, a banking analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in New York. Meanwhile, state officials are preparing a hearing to seek the ouster of CenTrust Chairman David Paul, who is blamed for encouraging the bank's lavish and unorthodox spending, which has included a $30 million museum-quality painting collection, a company yacht and huge salaries. Terrence McElroy, a spokesman for the Florida Office of Comptroller, said a hearing date has not been set. CenTrust is appealing a Dec. 20 state order to remove Paul, who had a $4.8 million salary from January 1988 to September 1989. The proposed merger with New York-based Ensign, announced two weeks ago, was seen as one of few options left by CenTrust to avoid federal takeover. Arison, estimated to be worth $2.86 billion by Forbes magazine, was the deep pocket the thrift needed. Miami-based banking consultant Kenneth Thomas estimated CenTrust would need at least $200 million from Arison or from privately held Hamilton Holding Co., Ensign's parent, before it could be considered solvent under current federal standards. Paul and Arison have worked together on several arts projects in Miami. But the proposed deal was dropped following a chilly reception from federal regulators, according to a statement from CenTrust and Ensign. Analysts said federal banking regulators are discouraging mergers of troubled thrifts. ``Their theory is putting two troubled institutions together doesn't solve problems, it just multiplies them,'' said Richard Freeman, at Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. Ensign, which has 27 branches in metropolitan New York and Florida, was more than $140 million insolvent, according to figures by Sheshunoff Information Services in Austin, Texas. Arison, majority owner of Miami-based Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. and 50 percent of the National Basketball Association's Miami Heat, could not be reached for comment Thursday. Paul did not return telephone calls to his Miami office, but New York-based CenTrust spokesman Roy Winnick said no new plans are expected ``in the immediate future.'' Thomas said officials from the Office of Thrift Supervision had enough evidence to take over CenTrust in December, when regulators seized control of First American Bank and Trust in Lake Worth and City Federal Savings Bank of Bedminster, N.J., which had extensive Florida real estate holdings. He estimates CenTrust could be spending more than $100,000 a week on legal fees to fight the state order to remove Paul and other federal court action concerning CenTrust spending. In addition, Thomas predicts CenTrust could take another $100 million loss this year from defaults and cut-rate sales of its junk bond holdings. CenTrust is seeking federal approval for a $150 million sale of 63 of its 71 branches to Great Western Bank of Beverly Hills. Calif. But some analysts say it is doubtful regulators will allow CenTrust to lose most of its relatively healthy, consumer-oriented operations. ``If CenTrust is valuable at all, it will be whole, not in pieces,'' said Thomas. Moody's Investors Service in December downgraded CenTrust's bonds and long-term deposits to among its lowest ratings, and predicted federal intervention. ``It's a pretty negative situation,'' said Moody's analyst Mara Hilderman.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Soars, Gold Falls
Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply Thursday against key foreign currencies in active trading as the market appeared more confident the Federal Reserve wouldn't cut interest rates any time soon. Gold prices declined after gaining overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $410.20 a troy ounce, down $2.30 from Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $410.880 an ounce, off $2.10. Currency dealers said the dollar was bolstered by a report in Thursday's Wall Street Journal quoting two Fed officials as saying they wouldn't support a cut in short-term interest rates unless economic conditions changed. Firm interest rates tend to support the dollar. Both the officials, Manuel Johnson, a Fed vice chairman, and Wayne Angell, a Fed governor, had led a move toward lower interest rates in recent months. Those statements were in contrast with sentiment from the White House, which on Thursday broke with its usual practice of not commenting on Fed policy by suggesting current economic conditions justified rate cuts. Still, Ronald H. Holzer, a vice president at Harris Trust & Co. in Chicago, said, ``With the inflation picture looking as bad as it does, the market was anticipating that the Fed had stopped easing. These statements (by Johnson and Angell) confirmed it and brought out good buying for the dollar.'' Some dealers said the Fed had tried to thwart the dollar's rise Thursday by selling dollars for yen, but the market ignored that intervention. Also boosting dollar-buying interest Thursday was the continued unrest in the Soviet Caucasus. The dollar is often seen as a safe haven in times of political turmoil. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed at 145.66 Japanese yen, up from late Wednesday's 145.52. The dollar traded at 146.05 yen in London, and at 146.35 yen in New York, up from 145.395 yen. The dollar was stronger against the British pound, too. Sterling bought $1.6445 in London, down from Wednesday's $1.6525, and $1.6435 in New York, down from $1.65235. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.7150 West German marks, up from 1.6873; 1.5245 Swiss francs, up from 1.5055; 5.8275 French francs, up from 5.7325; 1,276.75 Italian lire, up from 1,256.50; and 1.17135 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16515. Late European rates for the dollar compared with Wednesday: 1.7095 marks, up from 1.6905; 1.5185 Swiss francs, up from 1.5023; 5.8090 French francs, up from 5.7250; 1.9130 Dutch guildrs, up from 1.8990; 1,272.00 Italian lire, up from 1,254.75; and 1.1713 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1640 Gold rose in London to $413.75 an ounce from $409.75 Wednesday. The late bid in Zurich was $413 an ounce, up from $409.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $413.95 an ounce, up from $410.35. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.190 a troy ounce, down 6.6 cents. Silver rose in London to $5.26 an ounce from $5.23.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices ended mixed in volatile trading Thursday, as crude and heating oil bounced back from Wednesday's losses. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil rallied after Wednesday's steep declines. The February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 66 cents to $22.76 a barrel after a 68-cent drop on Wednesday. March crude closed 33 cents higher at $21.59 a barrel while April advanced 27 cents to $20.97. Among refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale heating oil for February delivery climbed 1.32 cents to close at 61.84 cents a gallon. The contract lost 3.51 cents Wednesday. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for delivery in February slipped 0.71 cent to 60.71 cents a gallon, continuing its slide from the previous session, when it lost 2.88 cents. Traders said gasoline was under pressure after excessive gains in recent sessions. Heating oil appeared to be stabilizing after recent losses, analysts said. Heating oil futures had rallied sharply after December's unseasonably frigid weather that delayed shipments and slowed refinery output in normally warm-weather areas like Texas and Louisiana. Prices had receded in recent days as spring-like temperatures knocked the punch out of the rally. ``The warm weather is already built into the market so prices have stabilized,'' said Richard Redoglio, energy broker with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Futures prices fell broadly on Wednesday largely in response to an industry report that showed a sharp rise in stocks of crude oil and refined products in the nation's storage tanks. Analysts said Thursday's rise in crude oil resulted from a combination of factors. ``It might be motivated by the tight situation on good-quality crudes because of delays in Brent loadings in the North Sea,'' said Bob Baker, analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``But it just might be a follow-up to the declines earlier this week.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Prices Rise to 8-Year High; Housing Starts Tumble
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf bgng Financial markets... with 1 new graf to UPDATE with closing.
DOC.TEXT: Inflation increased modestly in 1989 to an eight-year high of 4.6 percent, boosted by double-digit price increases for dairy food, eggs, tobacco and fuel oil, the government said Thursday. Construction of new housing, meanwhile, plunged 7.6 percent last year to 1.37 million units, the lowest level since the recession year of 1982. In December, consumer prices climbed a moderate 0.4 percent despite a sharp rise in fuel oil costs during the holiday cold snap. The weather also prompted a seasonally adjusted 8 percent decline in housing starts from November to December, the steepest in 10 months. Economists attributed both the relative stability of consumer price increases and a weak housing industry to the Federal Reserve Board's tight money policy. Although the central bank has eased its grip on credit in recent months, the Bush administration quickly blasted a suggestion from Federal Reserve policy-makers that interest rates will not fall again anytime soon. ``These numbers ... indicate that inflation has remained very steady over the last seven or eight years and that lower interest rates are justified,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said in rare public criticism of the central bank. The administration is counting on strong economic growth to bolster tax revenues and help it meet budget deficit targets. But Fed Vice Chairman Manuel Johnson and board member Wayne Angell, in remarks published in Thursday editions of The Wall Street Journal, suggested little prospect of another interest-rate cut in the near future. Financial markets, which have been spooked in recent weeks by inflation fears, were mixed in volatile trading. Bond prices plunged, while the Dow Jones industrial average, after a roller-coaster ride, closed at 2,666.38, up 7.25. Traders said the market was reacting more to disappointing corporate earnings reports and worry over interest rates than to the slightly better-than-expected inflation news. The 1989 rise in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index marked a modest acceleration over the 4.4 percent rates posted in 1988 and 1987. Still, it was the steepest increase since 1981, when prices shot up 8.9 percent in a lingering aftershock from the double-digit inflation of 1979 and 1980. Most economists expect inflation to hold steady or decline slightly in 1990. The relatively low unemployment rate, at 5.3 percent in December, will keep wages rising and prevent a dramatic improvement, they said. ``What it boils down to, ultimately, is a political judgment,'' said economist Sandra Shaber of the Futures Group, a Washington consulting company. ``It's a trade-off between the degree of inflation and the degree of unemployment.'' The Labor Department said in another report that Americans' inflation-adjusted earnings were unchanged in December after falling 0.6 percent in November. Average weekly earnings were $340.81 in December, up 3.2 percent from a year earlier but not enough to keep up with the rise in prices. Food prices jumped 5.6 percent in 1989, the steepest in nine years; December food costs were up a moderate 0.4 percent. Dairy products rose a sharp 2.2 percent in December, bringing the increase for the year to 10.3 percent. The price of meat, poultry fish and eggs rose 1 percent in December, with much of that attributed to a 3.7 percent advance in egg prices, which climbed 35.4 percent for the year. Energy prices gained 5.1 percent last year, driven up by a 19.5 percent rise in fuel oil. Fuel oil increased 3.8 percent in December and a congressional committee is investigating allegations that oil companies used the cold weather as an excuse to grab profits. Gasoline prices, which soared early in the year, fell in six of the last seven months of 1989, including a 2 percent drop in December. For the year, they were up 6.5 percent. Natural gas prices increased 2.1 percent last month, while electricity rose 0.8 percent. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, considered by many analysts to be the best indicator of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy, rose 0.4 percent in December and 4.4 percent for the year, a drop from 4.7 percent in 1988. The cost of services, the category most heavily influenced by wages, rose 0.4 percent in December and 5.1 percent for the year. New car prices rose 1 percent in December, but for the year were up only 2.3 percent. The cost of medical care rose 0.5 percent last month and 8.5 percent for the year. Clothing costs fell 0.7 percent in December, the result of pre-Christmas reductions. For the year, they rose only 1 percent. Tobacco prices were up 2 percent last month and 14.7 percent for the year. Before taking into account normal seasonal changes, the Consumer Price Index stood at 126.1 in December. That meant a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $126.10 last month, up from $120.50 a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Announces Lower Profits, Layoffs in Two States
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. Thursday announced layoffs affecting 1,200 workers in two states, citing a 34 percent decline in fourth-quarter profits and a 19 percent decline for the year. Industry analysts said the announcement was not worrisome and that Caterpillar remains in strong financial condition. ``Caterpillar competitively is in better shape than it's been in in the last 15 years,'' said John Mackin, a machinery analyst for Morgan Stanley & Co. in New York. For the fourth quarter, Caterpillar reported net earnings of $107 million or $1.05 a share, down from $163 million or $1.61 per share in the year-earlier period. The company blamed higher costs and smaller profits among its affiliates for the dip in profits. Fourth-quarter revenue rose to $2.76 billion from about $2.66 billion a year ago, due to higher prices and a $16 million rise in its financial subsidiaries' revenues, the company said. Caterpillar, which had difficult times in the early 1980s but made a strong comeback in the second half of the decade, makes and markets large construction and earthmoving machinery. For the year, Caterpillar's after-tax profit fell to $497 million, from $616 million in 1988. Revenue rose 7 percent to $11.13 billion from about $10.44 billion. Caterpillar, which employs more than 60,000 worldwide, said it would place 200 employees in Aurora, Ill., and York, Pa., on indefinite layoff. Another 1,000 workers, at Illinois facilities in Mapleton and Mossville, would be idled by temporary shutdowns, the company said. ``Two-hundred (indefinite) layoffs is peanuts,'' said Alex Blanton, a machinery analyst for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. ``Frankly, they might be laying people off because they're getting more efficient.'' Caterpillar predicted Federal Reserve policy would ``push the U.S. economy into a recession,'' which in turn would diminish sales of some durable goods and equipment, but said it remained positive about its outlook. ``We remain very optimistic overall about Caterpillar opportunities in the '90s,'' said Caterpillar Chairman George Schaefer. Merrill Lynch's Blanton said the company has not raised prices sufficiently. ``The reason they aren't raising prices ... is that they are scared to death there is going to be a recession. ... Therefore, they are forecasting profits will remain under considerable pressure for the rest of the year.'' ``My feeling is, things are going to turn out a lot better than they expect,'' Blanton said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were widely mixed Thursday in a volatile session marked by uneasiness over weak corporate earnings and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down nearly 20 points at midsession, closed with a 7.25 gain at 2,666.38. Declining issues outnumbered advances, however, by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 584 up, 899 down and 495 unchanged. Analysts said blue chips benefited late in the day from buying by professional traders engaged in multiple computer-program strategies. But they described the overall news background as bleak. The market has been unsettled lately by a series of adverse corporate earnings reports for the last three months of 1989. The latest came Thursday morning when Digital Equipment posted earnings for its fiscal quarter ended Dec. 30 of $1.25 a share, against $2.20 a share in the like period a year earlier. Digital's shares tumbled 5~ to 82 after a delayed opening. Selling continued, meanwhile in Aluminum Co. of America, down ] at 66{ after the company reported lower quarterly profits on Wednesday. At the same time, brokers said fears of a developing recession were intensified by recent upward pressure on interest rates in this country and in other leading industrialized countries. Rising rates in Japan, Germany and England are seen as a deterrant to any move soon by the Federal Reserve to relax its credit policy. Fed policymakers are believed to be concerned that lower rates in the United States would prompt a flow of money out of American credit markets into foreign securities with increasingly attractive yields. That perception has helped push U.S. interest rates higher in the past several days. U.S. Air fell 2 to 28}. The company described its operating results for the fourth quarter as extremely disappointing, and said it expected to post a loss for all of 1989. Gainers in the blue-chip sector included Philip Morris, up ~ at 39]; General Electric, up | at 63|; Procter & Gamble, up 1 at 69{, and DuPont, up ~ at 122{. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 178.59 million shares, against 170.47 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 210.01 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $1.68 billion, or 0.05 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks edged up .21 to 187.07. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose .83 to 388.82, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up .79 at 338.19. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 1.16 to 437.52. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 366.17, down 1.89.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Contracts
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended Jan 8., the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,214.8 billion from a revised $3,222.1 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,042.2 billion from a revised $4,046.3 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $793.5 billion from a revised $805.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.6 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.3 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,199.7 billion, a 7.5 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,029.9 billion, up 3.1 percent, while M1 rose 0.6 percent to an average of $792.4 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $197 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $136 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $299.4 billion in the two-week period ended Jan. 10, up from $295.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $5.29 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 488 money-market mutual funds rose $5.29 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise, to an all-time high of $381.11 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $6.82 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 243 general purpose funds rose $1.85 billion to $126.66 billion, assets of 98 broker-dealer funds increased $1.41 billion to $161.81 billion, and assets of 147 institutional funds rose $2.03 billion to $92.65 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.74 percent from 7.80 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.88 percent from 7.92 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 38 days, unchanged from the previous week, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.32 percent as of Wednesday from 6.33 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was unchanged at 5.07 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.87 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.90 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.92 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.93 percent; 7.89 percent on 2{-year CDs, unchanged; and 7.91 percent on 5-year CDs, also unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Raytheon 4Q Earnings Climb 8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Raytheon Co. said Thursday net profit rose 8 percent in the fourth quarter, and a backlog of government orders should protect it from looming cuts in defense spending. For the final three months of 1989, Raytheon earned $137 million, or $2.07 a share, compared with $127 million, or $1.92 a share, a year ago. Sales edged up to $2.24 billion from $2.21 billion. Larry McCracken, a Raytheon spokesman, said the company was encouraged by its backlog of orders, which will help ensure steady earnings and sales gains. At year's end, the company's total backlog was a record $9.59 billion, including U.S. government orders of $6.97 billion. ``Entering the '90s, when defense budgets are under question, it's comfortable to enter the year with record backlogs,'' McCracken said. For the year, Raytheon, which designs, engineers and manufactures advanced electronic devices for both commercial and government customers, earned $528.8 million, or $8.01 a share, up 8 percent from $489.6 million, or $7.35 a share, in 1988. Sales for the year totaled $8.79 billion, compared with $8.19 billion in 1988. Thomas Phillips, Raytheon chairman and chief executive, said in a statement the company demonstrated its strength through diversity. The company had particularly strong growth in its aircraft products segment, as pre-tax profits climbed 58 percent to $43.9 million. Raytheon said it had a decline in government aircraft sales, but strong results from corporate and commuter airline customers. The company also recorded growth in its largest segment, electronics, from $4.9 billion in sales in 1988 to $5.3 billion. That included a $274 million Navy contract for surveillance radar systems and $231 million from the Air Force for satellite communications terminals. Raytheon had 9 percent growth in its appliance sales, which totaled $1.07 billion, thanks to improved profits from the company's Amana and Speed Queen products. The company also said it had acquired 1.2 million of its own shares under an ongoing plan authorized by the board of directors. Raytheon has acquired 21.3 million company shares toward a goal of 25 million shares, and has about 66 million shares outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Buying 25 Percent of Infonet
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. said Thursday it has agreed to purchase 25 percent of the outstanding shares of Infonet Services Corp. for $27.5 million. MCI said it will purchase the shares formerly held by Computer Sciences Corp. and become the largest shareholder in Infonet, an El Segundo, Calif.-based data network that operates in more than 100 countries. The other shareholders in Infonet, which provides integrated computing and communications services, are the major telecommunications administrations of European and Asia Pacific nations, MCI said. They are: the Deutsche Bundespost Telekom of West Germany; Transpac-France Telecom; PTT Telecom Netherlands; Regie Des Telegraphes et des Telephones of Belgium; Singapore Telecom International; Swiss PTT; Telecom Australia; Swedish Telecom International; Telefonica International of Spain; and Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co. of Japan. Washington-based MCI, the nation's No. 2 long-distance carrier, describes itself as the world's second-largest telecommunications network.

DOC.HEAD: Updated Descrambler Introduced
DOC.TEXT: General Instrument Corp. on Thursday introduced an updated descrambling device aimed at helping satellite TV programmers protect their signals from pirates while giving viewers the chance to receive more channels. Piracy has been a major problem for the backyard satellite dish industry. General Instrument said its unit, called VideoCipher II Plus, was designed to make it more difficult for electronic tinkers to alter descramblers and receive signals from such services as Home Box Office, ESPN, the Disney Channel, MTV and Showtime. The new descrambler also will make it possible to increase the number of satellite channels offered to viewers, by raising from 56 to 256 the number of ``tier bits'' the devices can unscramble, General Instrument said. Tier bits are the encrypted data codes programmers use to secure their signals. The new system also expands to 50 million households the potential satellite TV subscriber capacity, the company said after showing the unit at a news conference in Alexandria, Va. Company spokesman Rick Griffin said the new unit will not add to the cost of satellite dish systems, and existing dish owners still may use their older descramblers. But Bob Phillips, chief executive officer of the Washington-based National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative, said the older models will become obsolete if and when programmers decide to go beyond the current 56-bit capacity, which currently is filled with signals. However, Phillips added that no programmers have announced plans to expand to the higher tier-bit capacity. The unit is a second generation of the VideoCipher II descrambling system, which is virtually the only descrambler legally available to the nation's 2.7 million backyard satellite dish owners. The older unit, which is being used by 50 satellite programmers, has been criticized for being easily defeated by video pirates. ``There were too many pirates out there that were compromising the system,'' Griffin said in a telephone interview. ``Now we have an improved, more secure type of scrambling technology.'' Phillips said General Instrument has sold 1.4 million to 1.6 million VideoCipher II units, but General Instrument has activated only about 641,000 of them. The remainder of those sold presumably have been altered to steal signals, Phillips said. ``There's a huge discrepancy there,'' he noted. The Federal Communications Commission, under orders from Congress, is considering establishing an universal encryption standard that would formally establish one type of descrambling device. Phillips said his organization, which represents 550 rural electric and rural telephone systems, thinks the FCC should regulate General Instrument's VideoCipher technology since it is the de facto standard in the industry.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Storm Drives Wheat Futures Down, Cattle Up
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices dropped and cattle futures climbed Thursday as an intense winter storm system muscled into the Southern Plains, bringing badly needed moisture to the winter wheat crop and slowing livestock marketings. On other commodity markets Thursday, orange juice futures fell sharply; most energy futures rose; and precious metals retreated. Meteorologist Harvey Freese of Freese-Notis Weather Inc. in Des Moines, Iowa, said the winter storm was likely to bring the largest snowfall amounts in two years to the Texas and Oklahoma panhandles. Snow amounts of up to five inches were already reported in Texas on Thursday afternoon and the precipitation was expected to continue into Saturday, Freese said. Snow and rain was expected to spread over a wide area, including western Kansas and western Nebraska, before the system pushes north and east into the Midwest. The heavy downfall will help relieve the unusally dry conditions that have prevailed in winter wheat country since late autumn. ``This is the biggest rain event since September,'' said Katharina Zimmer, a grain-market analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. ``They are likely to get as much snow today, tonight and tomorrow as they usually get in January or February,'' Wheat futures settled 1{ cents to 3\ cents lower on the Chicago Board of Trade with the contract for delivery in March at $3.97} a bushel, its lowest close since Sept. 28. Corn futures finished { cent to 1} cents higher with March at $2.42 a bushel; oats were { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $1.38\ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 3{ cents higher with January at $5.60} a bushel. Expectations for a storm-related slowdown in cattle marketings helped to boost live cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, where contracts for February and April delivery posted new life-of-contract highs. Live cattle settled .05 cent to .58 cent higher with February at 78.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .20 cent higher with January at 83.77 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .30 cent higher with February at 49.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies finished 1.35 cents lower to .08 cent higher with February at 55.52 cents a pound. Orange juice futures plunged on the New York Cotton Exchange amid profit-taking by speculators who participated in the market's spectacular 60 percent runup following the Christmas freeze in Florida's citrus belt. ``It's about time we have a correction after a 75-cent move'' to $2 a pound, said analyst Celeste Georkakis of Cargill Investor Services Inc. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures finished 1.7 cents to 5.5 cents lower with January at $1.907 a pound. Petroleum futures ended mixed in volatile trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange as crude and heating oil bounced back from Wednesday's losses. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 6 cents to 66 cents higher with February at $22.76 a barrel; heating oil was .56 cent to 1.32 cents higher with February at 61.84 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .71 cent lower to .91 cent higher with February at 60.71 cents a gallon. Gold and silver futures sank on selling that analysts attributed to abundant silver supplies and perceptions of an industrial slowdown, which would reduce demand for silver in industrial applications. Gold settled $1.80 to $2.50 lower with February at $411.20 a troy ounce; silver was 5.4 cents to 6.8 cents lower with March at $5.24 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Pfizer Blames 6 Percent Drop in 4th Qtr Net on Strong Dollar
DOC.TEXT: Pfizer Inc. said Thursday the strength of the dollar helped depress its net income by 5.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 despite a 9.2 percent increase in sales. For the three months ended Dec. 31, the pharmaceutical company's net income fell to $133.3 million, or 79 cents a share, from $141.6 million, or 84 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter sales rose to $1.49 billion from $1.37 billion. The dollar's strength against foreign currencies, increased marketing expenses for new products and continued high research spending contributed to an 8.1 percent decline in net income for all of 1989, even though sales increased 5.3 percent, Pfizer said. ``Although these investment expenses will again be high in 1990, the sales momentum of our new products is increasing,'' Chairman Edmund T. Pratt Jr. said in a statement. Pratt said a new extended release version of Pfizer's Procardia prescription drug for angina and hypertension tallied $40 million in sales in just three months on the U.S. market. The company expects to win U.S. regulatory approval this year to sell another angina and hypertension drug, Norvasc, which it currently sells in Britain and Ireland, he said. The dollar's strength reduced sales by two percentage points and turned what would have been a modest growth in profits into a decline, the company said. A strong dollar makes U.S. products more expensive, and therefore less attractive, overseas. For the full year, net income fell to $727.3 million, or $4.31 a share, from $791.3 million, or $4.70 a share. Full-year sales rose to $5.67 billion from $5.39 billion. If the dollar hadn't risen in value last year, sales would have been three percentage points higher and the profit decline would have been cut in half, Pfizer said. The company's sales of pharmaceuticals increased 11 percent in the latest year while sales of hospital products rose 3 percent. Consumer products sales rose 12 percent, specialty chemicals sales gained 6 percent and sales of animal health care products were up 9 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Appellate Judge Throws Out Order Against Newsletter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with appellate ruling. Keegan Federal in 10th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A state appellate judge ruled Thursday that previously confidential material on the merger of two accounting firms could be published. Judge George Bundy Smith invalidated the action earlier in the day of state Supreme Court Justice Beatrice Shainswit who had refused to lift her temporary restraining order forbidding Bowman's Accounting Report from publishing how Ernst & Young partners will share profits and on other operations. Shainswit had said she would decide ``within a couple of days'' whether to allow Bowman's to publish. Lawyers for several media immediately went to Smith's court and successfully sought repeal of the order. The appellate judge's decision permits publication of the material and allows other news organizations access to sealed material, said Richard Winfield of Rogers & Wells, representing The Associated Press and other media. Ernst & Young was formed last year after Ernst & Whinney merged with Arthur Young to become one of the largest accounting agencies in the world. The merged company has sought to prevent the release of the profit information, contending it contained trade secrets. The New York Times published some of the confidential information Thursday. The Times said the material shows Ernst & Whinney partners take home roughly 65 percent of profits earned jointly with Arthur Young for the next three years, while Arthur Young's partners share the rest. Carl Liggio, lawyer for Ernst & Young, conceded ``the cat is out of the bag,'' but said the Times did not publish all of the material, so continuing the restraining order was not meaningless. But Winfield and other media lawyers cited the Pentagon Papers case as an example of a decision prohibiting prior restraint on publication of a news story. ``The Times yesterday got a copy and yet there was this anomaly of the Atlanta newsletter that was enjoined by an absolutely invalid order,'' Winfield said. Keegan Federal, a lawyer for Bowman's, argued earlier in Shainswit's court that such prior restraint is prohibited by the First Amendment. Liggio admitted that the merger was a newsworthy event that should be covered, but he said one could glean from the 30-odd pages of leaked information trade secrets about how the firm operates and makes decisions. The lawyer compared the accounting firm's material to Coca-Cola Co.'s closely guarded soft-drink formula and Shainswit's personal income tax returns. He argued that these were things that could be restrained prior to publication. Liggio complained that Bowman's had started a media ``feeding frenzy'' by passing word that it had been censored by Shainswit on Jan. 8. The judge issued the order without letting Bowman's know until after she had done it. Liggio asserted that Ernst & Young was entitled to ``recapture'' that material, which he said had been prepared for the eyes of partners only and which he suggested had been obtained illegally by news media. ``How are you going to recapture it from The Times,'' Shainswit asked. Liggio acknowledged there was nothing preventing the Times from publishing the rest of the material, which would make the court order moot. Federal, who also referred to the newsworthiness of the merger, noted that Ernst & Young, which has thousands of clients and operates worldwide, issued numerous press releases containing revenue information. ``The public has an interest in knowing whether those press releases were true or false,'' Federal said. Winfield of Rogers & Wells submitted briefs and asked Shainswit to unseal court records in the case. ``The news organizations represented before you this morning have more than a general interest that there be no order upholding prior restraint in New York state,'' Winfield said. Shainswit had said she would rule on unsealing the records when she rules on the temporary restraining order. The Times account said the confidential documents showed Ernst & Whinney was by far the stronger of the two firms and its partners historically out-earned their peers at Arthur Young. The Times did not explain how it got a copy of the documents, which also were leaked to Accounting Today, a twice-monthly newsletter based in New York. Bowman's Accounting Report is barred from talking about the case. Editor Robert Crane of Accounting Today said Wednesday he plans to publish the material in its Feb. 5 edition, which is to mailed to subscribers Jan. 30. The news organizations, who joined Bowman's in charging that Shainswit's order was an unconstitutional abridgement of press freedom, include: The Associated Press, New York Times, Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Wall Street Journal, the Newsletter Association, the New York Daily News, Newsday, American Lawyer, the Society of Professional Journalists. Also submitting a friend of the court brief on behalf of Bowman's was the New York Civil Liberties Union.

DOC.HEAD: New Real Estate Appraisals Guidelines Issued
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Thursday issued new guidelines designed to raise the quality of real estate appraisals, a factor often cited as one of the causes of the savings and loan crisis. Under the S&L law passed last summer, states must license and certify their appraisers by July 1, 1991. If the states do not come up with a satisfactory plan, their appraisers can be frozen out of working on many transactions financed by federally insured banks, savings institutions and credit unions. Faulty appraisals that overvalued commercial properties are viewed as one of the chief contributors to bad loans that caused billions of dollars of S&L losses. Appraisers are supposed to independently value a property being sold, but can be influenced by lenders and real estate agents, on whom they depend for business, critics say. A subcommittee of the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, which coordinates standards among five federal regulatory agencies, issued guidelines, effective in 60 days, which tell the states how to set up their certification process. The rules encourage states to establish an independent regulatory agency, answerable to the governor or a cabinet-level officer, to regulate appraisals. The agency should be insulated from the banking and real estate industries, which may have conflicting interests. If budget constraints force a state to put appraisal regulation in the same office that governs real estate brokers, different officials should make the decisions on whether to license, de-license or discipline an appraiser, the council said. Appraisers in states that have systems already meeting the new standards will not have to undergo recertification, but appraisers in other states will. ``What we're trying to do is gain some consistency and integrity in the system,'' said Kevin Blakely, a deputy director of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and chairman of the appraisal subcommittee. Norman Flynn, president of the National Association of Realtors, praised the guidelines but said they should have been issued four or five months ago. He said states will be hard-pressed to get their systems ready to certify appraisers in time to meet the deadline. ``We're afraid the consumer is going to be standing in long lines trying to get an appraisal done. That's not good business,'' he said. Blakely said the deadline provides ``quite a bit of leadtime'' and said the law gives regulators power to extend the deadline to the end of 1991 if a state is making progress.

DOC.HEAD: CIGNA Agrees to Pay $777 Million For EQUICOR
DOC.TEXT: Financial services giant CIGNA Corp. said Thursday it has agreed to pay $777 million in cash for EQUICOR-Equitable HCA Corp. in a deal that may make it the nation's largest group indemnity insurance company. EQUICOR, based in Nashville, Tenn., is a group insurance and managed health care joint venture owned by The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and Hospital Corporation of America. Wilson H. Taylor, chairman and chief executive of Philadelphia-based CIGNA, announced the agreement, which is subject to federal review. As a result of the review, Taylor said he does not expect the deal to be finalized for several months. He said the purchase price would come from ``within corporate resources.'' Taylor, speaking in a conference call with reporters, said EQUICOR has a ``strong group insurance presence'' and a client list which includes a ``number of large Fortune 500-type accounts.'' Based on 1988 figures, EQUICOR ranks sixth in the nation and CIGNA ranks fifth in terms of premiums and premium equivalents, or revenue, in life and health insurance, Taylor said. Together, he said, the companies would be the largest in the country with more than 12 million participants. Taylor said EQUICOR's strength in the Health Maintenance Organization market was also a significant factor in the deal. Its 450,000 enrollees in 19 cities combines with CIGNA's 1.5 million enrollees in 31 cities to bring the total to almost two million, he said. Ten of the 19 cities covered by EQUICOR are not currently served by CIGNA, according to Taylor. He said ``size and scale are critical'' for success in the insurance business. The merger of these two companies, according to Taylor, will benefit both customers and shareholders. There will be ``some reduction in the workforce,'' Taylor said, but he refused to speculate on locations or numbers. Michael J. Monroe, CIGNA vice president, said antitrust laws prevent those types of decisions until the deal is closed. In 1988, CIGNA's Employee Life and Health Benefits segment had premium and premium equivalents of $8 billion and after tax profits of $43 million, while EQUICOR had more than $5 billion of premium and premium equivalents and $16 million of after-tax profits, CIGNA said. For the first nine months of 1989, CIGNA's EL&HB segment reported $120 million of after-tax profits and EQUICOR had approximately $30 million, both representing significant improvement from the first nine months of 1988, according to CIGNA. The CIGNA companies, with 1988 net income of $458 million and assets of $56 billion, are worldwide providers of insurance and related financial services products, including health care, pension-retirement benefits, investment management, property-casualty and life insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. said Thursday its net income fell 11 percent in the quarter ended Dec. 29, 1989, largely because of expenses stemming from cost-reduction programs and damages from the Bay area earthquake. Net income fell 11 percent to $124.8 million in the company's fiscal first quarter from $140.5 million a year earlier. Earnings per share fell 13 percent to 96 cents from $1.10. The cost-reduction programs and earthquake expenses reduced net income by $20.5 million or 16 cents a share. Revenues rose 6 percent to $1.49 billion from $1.41 billion. ``The modest year-over-year growth in revenues reflects diverse growth rates of our various products,'' said John Sculley, chairman and chief executive officer. Sales to consumers of the Macintosh Plus and Apple II computers declined in the latest quarter, he said, but sales to the business market of new products, including the Macintosh IIcx and SE@30, ``increased significantly.'' Recent cost-cutting measures announced by the company, including some job reductions and the elimination of company cars, ``will bring expense growth in better line with revenue growth as we progress through this fiscal year,'' Scully said. International sales accounted for 36 percent of total revenues, compared to 32 percent in the first quarter of fiscal 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Record Motorola Sales, Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. reported Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 21 percent, while both sales and earnings posted records for all of last year. The electronics company said it earned $132 million, or $1.01 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1989, compared with $124 million, or 95 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Fourth-quarter sales totaled $2.65 billion, up 21 percent from $2.19 billion in the final quarter of 1988. For the year, earnings rose to $498 million, or $3.83 a share, from $445 million, or $3.43 a share, a year earlier, Motorola said. Sales for 1989 increased 17 percent to $9.6 billion from $8.3 billion in 1988. ``The cellular telephone market continues to expand rapidly,'' said George Fisher, chairman and chief excutive officer. ``Overall, the communications arena promises to be one of the major growth opportunities of the 1990s, as we develop new ways to serrve the needs of our customers on the move.'' In addition to mobile phones, Motorola makes computer chips, two-way radio systems and other computer-related products.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Court Filing Threatens Pensions
With AM-Campeau Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bankruptcy court filings by Campeau Corp.'s retailers threaten pensions worth as much as $10 million for retired executives, the company says. The 525 affected executives make up less than 2 percent of the 25,000 retirees from Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. Many of them worked for Federated before 1953, when current pension plans were established. Another 25 signed individual employment agreements, according to court filings. Retirees who signed such agreements typically earned $100,000 to $1 million annually. ``Those things are not protected in a trust because they were individually negotiated and payments stop in a Chapter 11,'' said Carol Sanger, a spokeswoman for Allied and Federated. Federated and Allied filed for Chapter 11 protection in U.S. Bankruptcy Court Monday, citing $7.7 billion in debts, much of it stemming from Robert Campeau's purchase of the chains. ``It seems somehow wrong that people who worked hard for many years are now victims of Mr. Campeau's takeover,'' said former Federated vice president James Selonick, who said he stands to lose tens of thousands of dollars. ``Our money, which is a good many million dollars, is being used to bail out Federated, and I think that's unreasonable,'' he said. Ms. Sanger said other pensions, life insurance and medical benefits paid by Federated are protected in the bankruptcy proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Stocks Fall in Tokyo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Nikkei morning close, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen Friday morning while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange continued to decline moderately. The dollar was quoted late in the morning at 146.42 yen, near the top of the morning's range and up from 145.66 at the Tokyo close Thursday. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which slipped 91.68 yen on Thursday, fell another 154.74 yen, or 0.42 percent, to finish the morning session at 36,574.72. A currency dealer with the Bank of Tokyo said market sentiment for the dollar remains bullish following its overnight rise in New York after two officials from the U.S. Federal Reserve were quoted as saying the central bank would not cut interest rates any time soon. Manuel Johnson, a Fed vice chairman, and Wayne Angell, a Fed governor, told The Wall Street Journal they would not support easier short-term U.S. interest rates unless economic conditions changed. Higher interest rates tend to support a country's currency. There were reports that the Bank of Japan sold dollars in the Sydney market earlier in the morning, but the central bank hadn't been spotted in Tokyo. ``The Bank of Japan will intervene, but they won't have much impact on the market. It'll be difficult to push the dollar down when market sentiment is so bullish,'' said one trader at a major Japanese trust bank. Securities dealers said the yen's decline depressed the Nikkei index. The sudden surge of selling had an exaggerated effect on the market indices because trading was thin, said a dealer at Nikko Securities Co, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: First Boston Reportedly Removes Chief Executive; Link to Campeau
DOC.TEXT: First Boston Corp. has removed William E. Mayer as its chief executive and named him head of a new subsidiary that will monitor the firm's investment in Campeau Corp.'s troubled retailing divisions, according to a newspaper report. The investment bank was listed as the largest unsecured creditor of Campeau's Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. in the companies' Chapter 11 filing for bankruptcy court protection Monday. First Boston's exposure to the store groups was listed at $526 million. But the firm says its actual investment is more than $100 million below that figure, and that because it has taken some losses on its books already, the maximum amount it has at risk is $293 million, The New York Times reported in Friday's editions. Mayer will head a new subsidiary called CS First Boston Merchant Bank, the Times reported. The unit will manage the firm's investments in 29 companies as well as the Federated and Allied exposure, which was largely the result of a temporary loan the firm made to Campeau to help fund its takeover of Federated, the newspaper said. John M. Hennessy, chief executive of First Boston's holding company, CS First Boston, will replace Mayer as head of the investment bank. ``There is no question that Campeau needs a lot of attention,'' the Times quoted an unidentified First Boston spokesman as saying. But the spokesman said Hennessy and Mayer had found no need to have a different chief executive for the holding company and the operating subsidiary. ``They were falling over each other,'' the spokesman was quoted as saying. The Times quoted unidentified former First Boston executives as saying Mayer was being made a scapegoat because the firm's problems with Campeau went beyond the Federated and Allied situation. Hennessy had been wanting to tighten his control over the firm for some time, the newspaper quoted the executives as saying. First Boston could not be reached for comment on the Times report. A call to its main number after business hours went unanswered.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Denies Plans to File For Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Rumors on Wall Street that heavily indebted publisher Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. would file for bankruptcy sent HBJ stock plummeting Thursday and prompted a rare company denial. HBJ ``is not a candidate for Chapter 11'' bankruptcy protection, William Jovanovich, the company's reclusive chairman, said in a statement released after the market closed. Jovanovich made his statement to the Dow Jones Professional Investor Report, a New York news service, after the Orlando-based company sought to calm market jitters with another statement early in the afternoon. The bankruptcy rumors, Jovanovich said, came in response to the publicized problems of other indebted companies, an apparent reference to bankruptcy filings Monday by Campeau Corp.'s Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. Huge sales of HBJ stock early in the day fueled speculation surrounding the publisher. HBJ stock, which traded at nearly $10 a share just three months ago, traded as low as $2 before finishing 12{ cents down at $2.875, a record low. Volume totalled 4.8 million shares, making it the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. After the stock hit its low point, the company issued its first statement saying that operating income and cash flow in 1990 would be ``significantly higher'' than what HBJ will post for 1989. HBJ is not due to release 1989 earnings until February or March. In 1988, the company posted a loss of $126.5 million because of high interest payments associated with its debt. On Monday, Allied and Federated filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, largely because of billions of dollars of debt stemming from the acquisition of the companies by Canada's Campeau Corp. in recent years. HBJ has about $1.6 billion of junk bonds outstanding. The company borrowed nearly $3 billion as part of a frantic recapitalization 2{ years ago to repell a hostile takeover bid by British publisher Robert Maxwell. Last year, HBJ sold its six theme parks to Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. for $1.1 billion in an effort to pare its debt. The attractions included the Sea World parks in Orlando; San Antonio, Texas; San Diego; and Aurora, Ohio; Boardwalk and Baseball near Haines City and Cypress Gardens in Winter Haven. Ivan Obolensky, an analyst who follows HBJ for the Josephthal & Co. brokerage, told the Sentinel he didn't believe the publisher was on the verge of filing for bankruptcy. Neither did Douglas Evan Schimmel, a New York money manager. ``Things would have to get a lot worse for the company to file bankruptcy,'' Schimmel said.

DOC.HEAD: PNC Earnings Drop 98 Percent In Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Profit at PNC Financial Corp., the country's 13th largest bank holding company, dropped 98 percent in the fourth quarter last year as the bank set aside more money to cover potentially bad loans to Third World countries, the company said Wednesday. Pittsburgh-based PNC Financial, which owns banks in Kentucky, New Jersey, Ohio and Pennsylvania, posted net income of $1.47 million in the final three months of 1989. For the same period in 1988, the bank earned $119.11 million, or $1.28 per share. Earnings per common share in the fourth quarter of 1989 were nearly zero because the dividend paid to holders of preferred stock totaled $1.1 million, or nearly all the bank's profit, said Walter Gregg, executive vice president for finance. The bank normally sets aside about $40 million each quarter to cover potentially bad loans, but it increased that amount to $217.67 million in the fourth quarter. About $100 million of the money will go toward protecting the bank from medium- and long-term loans to less-developed countries, the bank said. With the move, the bank has set aside enough money to cover $191.2 million in medium- and long-term loans and half the $56 million it has made in short-term loans to less developed countries, it said. The bank also set aside $80 million for potentially bad domestic loans. Gregg said the move was designed to bring PNC back in line with reserving more than 100 percent of outstanding loans. The bank has set aside about 126 percent of the total amount it is owed, he said. For the year, PNC's profits dropped 18 percent to $377.44 million, or $3.98 per share, from $460.43 million, or $4.98 per share, in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Wal-Mart Chairman Undergoing Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Sam Walton, founder of the Wal-Mart discount chain, has undergone chemotherapy and radiation treatment for a malignant bone marrow disease, Walton said in a memo distributed Wednesday to Wal-Mart employees. In the two-page memo, Walton, 71, said he had been undergoing treatment at M.D. Anderson Hospital in Houston for multiple myeloma, which he described as a bone disease. Myeloma is a malignant tumor of the bone marrow, consisting generally of abnormal plasma cells. Since Sunday, Walton said, he had undergone two chemotherapy treatments and radiation treatment. Don Shinkle, a Wal-Mart Stores spokesman, said Walton wrote in the memo that he feels much better after experiencing aches and pains the past several months. Shortly after noon Wednesday, Walton visited one of the company's stores, a Sam's Wholesale Club, in Houston, Shinkle said. According to Shinkle, Walton said in the memo that he may be slowed down for a few weeks, but that he expects to resume visiting other stores in a few weeks. ``Along with Mr. Sam's doctors, we are very encouraged that because of early detection and treatment a full recovery is expected,'' the company said in a statement released by Shinkle from corporate headquarters here. Walton's memo outlined Wal-Mart accomplishments during the 1980s, said the employees were responsible for those accomplishments and that he looked forward to more success. Shinkle declined to provide a copy of the memo, saying it was personal.

DOC.HEAD: Lufthasa To Order Up To 41 Boeing Jets
DOC.TEXT: Lufthansa German Airlines said Wednesday it will order as many as 41 747-400s from Boeing Co. Spokeswoman Lucille Hoshabjian in New York also said the airline may convert options for 15 planes it signed with Boeing earlier to firm orders, putting the potential total value of the deal at $7.3 billion. She declined to say when the order would be placed, but David Lane, spokesman for General Electric Aircraft Engines, said the order could be announced as soon as Thursday. Brian Rowe, senior vice president of GE Aircraft Engines, said Wednesday that Lufthansa was considering ordering enough GE engines to power as many as 56 planes. Boeing spokesman John Wheeler said Boeing is talking with Lufthansa about an order but provided no details. The airline already has ordered 15 747-400s, with five delivered.
